DOC.HEAD: Anti-Abortion Forces Rally as Businesses Begin to Feel Boycott Threat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 12th graf, `More than ...,' to UPDATE with candlelight vigil; picks up 13th graf, `Some legal ...'
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Cecil Andrus said Wednesday his decision about signing the most restrictive state abortion law won't be swayed by a threatened boycott of Idaho potatoes and other products by some abortion-rights activists. ``I'm going to do what I think is right,'' said Andrus, who promised to act on the bill by Saturday. ``The economic things, those I'm going to have to handle no matter how it plays out.'' Andrus said the boycott threat from National Organization for Women President Molly Yard has prompted calls from leaders of Idaho's food processing industry and its printing, travel and resort businesses. ``All are highly concerned about this,'' Andrus said. ``Each of them has experienced cancellations.'' While continuing his silence on his intentions for the bill, the governor said: ``There's concern on my part. ... But economics is not going to be the deciding issue on this.'' The bill would ban abortion except in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is under age 18, severe fetal deformity or pregnancies that threaten the health of the mother. It would take effect July 1 if signed. It would ban more than 90 percent of the 1,500 abortions performed in Idaho each year. The governor is a longtime opponent of abortion except in cases of rape, incest and to save the life of the woman. He said he has consulted legal scholars, church officials and others but wouldn't discuss their advice. State officials said the monetary effect of the cancellations was still being assessed. Andrus would not identify any of the businesses, describing one as a very large printing company doing business all over the nation. ``There's too much outside influence,'' Andrus said. ``There are too many out-of-state experts involved in this. If they just give us time, we Idahoans can resolve this.'' Commerce Director James Hawkins said several businesses have reported cancellations. Others have received cancellation threats if the bill becomes law, he said. More than 600 anti-abortion activists rallied Wednesday on the steps of the Capitol to press their case. In the evening, nearly 1,000 pro-choice activists gathered at the Capitol for their eighth straight candlelight vigil. Some legal experts maintain the bill is so restrictive it will not stand the scrutiny of the U.S. Supreme Court _ a test abortion-rights advocates have promised if the bill becomes law. Anti-abortion activists designed the bill to test the court's commitment to legalized abortion. Hawkins said anti-abortion forces have contacted the state with promises to buy more Idaho products, although those offers have been few compared to the boycott threats. In Charleston, W.Va., activists were adding bags of Idaho potatoes to their grocery lists. ``We're issuing a challenge to the God-fearing people of West Virginia,'' said Avis Hill, spokesman for the 200-member West Virginia Parents for Life and pastor of Touching Jesus Fellowship in Alum Creek. ``We're saying to them, if they choose not to buy Idaho potatoes, we'll buy an extra bag and give it to a food pantry.'' Idaho State Sen. Marti Calabretta, the leading opponent of the bill, said she had contacted pro-choice activists across the country, including Yard, in an unsuccessful attempt to head off boycott talk. ``I tried to make the persuasive case that it was not in the best interests of those of us who have been fighting this bill,'' she said. ``Evidently the people I talked to had no influence on what's happening.'' She said any successful boycott would jeopardize state support for education and social services and hit hardest at the employees in food processing plants and other industries _ many of whom also oppose the bill. ``It's sad that Idaho is the battleground for national interests to wage their pitched battles,'' Calabretta said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Greyhound Drivers' Suit
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Wednesday dismissed a lawsuit filed by striking bus drivers claiming that Greyhound bus operations in Cleveland are unsafe, saying he doesn't have jurisdiction in the case. ``I'd like to have jurisdiction, because I'd like to help ... settle the strike,'' U.S. District Judge Alvin I. Krenzler said in turning down a request by the bus drivers union for an injunction against Greyhound. Krenzler agreed with attorneys for the country's only nationwide bus line who said the complaint should be handled through the proper administrative agency such as the U.S. Department of Transportation or the U.S. attorney general. The Cleveland complaint appeared to be the first such strike-related lawsuit filed against the company, Greyhound spokeswoman Melanie Scofield said from the bus line's Dallas headquarters. Cleveland Greyhound workers filed the civil lawsuit March 12, alleging that operations in Cleveland are unsafe because replacement drivers weren't qualified and weren't trained according to federal guidelines. The lawsuit also charged that the company failed to maintain buses during the nationwide walkout that began March 2. Alan Belkin, attorney for the union, said he will file the complaint with the Transportation Department. ``Hopefully, the DOT will subpoena the records we asked for with this suit,'' Belkin said. ``The people monitoring the (Greyhound bus) garage here haven't seen any maintenance going on.'' The complaint against Greyhound Lines Inc. in Cleveland was filed by Amalgamated Transit Union Local 1043, its president, Charles F. Flanagan; and Guy Selinka, a striker injured in the picket line in Cleveland on March 2. The union had sought a preliminary and permanent injunction against operating buses that haven't been properly maintained and that are driven by replacement employees not adequately trained. The union local represents about 130 workers. The company has said the lawsuit was a ploy to stop the bus line's operations. More than 9,000 Greyhound drivers, maintenance workers and office employees walked off the job nationwide March 2 over wages, job security and grievance procedures. Since then, there have been reports of at least 21 shootings and other incidents.

DOC.HEAD: Mourners Flood Bronx Funeral Home in Tearful Farewell
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Three women ...,' to UPDATE with at least 15 other people requiring medical assistance. INSERTS 1 graf after 19th graf, `More than ...,' to UPDATE with Honduran government declaring three days of national mourning, identifying 78 of the victims as Honduran; picks up 20th graf, `The government ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY7,NY22,HSN1
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of mourners, many weeping, others calling for revenge, offered their prayers at a funeral home Wednesday for 17 victims of the city's deadliest fire in 79 years. Officials, meanwhile, began preparations for a grim airlift of the dead to their Honduran homeland. The Red Cross has asked the New York National Guard to help transport the bodies, an aide to Gov. Mario Cuomo said. A funeral Mass Wednesday evening at St. Joseph's Catholic Church drew 1,500 people, while 1,000 others who could not get in stood outside the church during the service. Earlier, outside the Bronx funeral home across the street from St. Joseph's, the street was crowded with people waiting to pay their respects to the victims. The dead were among 87 people killed early Sunday inside the Happy Land social club in the Bronx, just 10 blocks away. Three women fainted outside the funeral home, collapsing in front of the crowd waiting to enter. At least 15 others needed medical assistance. Jose Alvarez, mourning his brother Denny, 22, left the Rivera Funeral Home sobbing and clinging to his cousin and a friend. Across the street on the steps of the church, Denny's father tearfully vented his rage at Julio Gonzalez, 36, the man accused of setting the fatal fire in a quarrel with an ex-girlfriend. ``They ought to take him and give him a public hanging,'' Pedro Alvarez said. ``People like that don't deserve to live.'' Two women emerged from the home screaming the names of dead relatives. Others expressed disbelief their friends were gone. ``He doesn't look like him. He looks too old,'' said Katy Carval, 17, after seeing former classmate Israel Bulnes, 18, who died with his girlfriend. Earlier in the day, family members of the victims met with American Red Cross officials at a public school near the burned-out red brick building to receive the belongings each victim carried or wore when the fire struck. Outside the school, Carlos Pena clutched a manila envelope that held a watch, a set of keys, and some cash _ things his brother Eli, 26, had with him early Sunday at the doomed Happy Land club. The watch came with Eli from Honduras, and Carlos said the timepiece would now be his. ``It means a lot, a reminder,'' he said. Also Wednesday, a civil court hearing did not determine whether the club operator's widow should replace her husband, Elias Colon, in an eviction lawsuit brought by the landlord, One Peach Associates. Jay Weiss, husband of actress Kathleen Turner, is part owner of One Peach, which held a 49-year lease on the building from one of New York's biggest landlords, Alex DiLorenzo III. The court hearing did not address responsibility for the fire or whether the landlords were aware of a city effort to close the club because it was illegal and unsafe. While wakes were held Wednesday, funeral arrangements still were being made. The Honduran government said it expected the bodies of 75 fire victims to begin arriving late this week at San Pedro Sula in northwestern Honduras. More than one-third of the Hondurans were from Puerto Cortes, a Caribbean port 135 miles northwest of Tegucigalpa, said Information Minister Nahum Valladares. The Honduran government declared three days of national mourning Wednesday, and said 78 victims had been identified as Honduran. The government was negotiating with Eastern Airlines to take the bodies from New York to Miami, where they would be transferred to the Honduran airline Tan-Sahsa, said the minister. The airline was working with the Red Cross to provide special fares for relatives wishing to attend the funerals in Honduras, said spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak. Tan-Sahsa and the Costa Rican carrier Lacsa also offered to help, said Red Cross spokesman Larry Mackler. In Washington, Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., called on the Air Force to donate use of a transport plane to return fire victims for burial in their homelands of Honduras and the Dominican Republic. ``Providing an Air Force plane would be a humanitarian gesture to the families of the victims,'' she said in a letter to Air Force Secretary Donald Rice. ``Moreover, it would help express America's sorrow for the tragedy and our affection for our neighbors in the hemisphere.'' An Air Force spokesman, Lt. Col. Darrell Hayes, said Rice has the matter ``under consideration.''

DOC.BYLINE: Body Attacks Breast and Pancreas Cancers, Study Suggests ^Eds: For release at 6 a.m. EST ^By MALCOLM RITTER
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have found evidence that people with breast or pancreatic cancer naturally mount an attack on their tumors, raising hopes for a treatment that might make the reaction more powerful. Patients with those diseases produce tumor-killing white blood cells that healthy people lack, said researcher Olivera Finn. She and colleagues have identified a substance on cancer cells that appears to be the target of the attack, and they hope that a vaccine-like treatment might boost the anti-cancer response, she said Tuesday. Finn, an assistant professor in the department of microbiology and immunology at the Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C., spoke at a science writers seminar sponsored by the American Cancer Society. More than 150,000 cases of breast cancer and 28,000 cases of pancreatic cancer are expected to be diagnosed this year. Finn, with graduate students Donna Barnd and Keith Jerome, found that patients with either cancer produced immune system cells that could kill cancer cells while ignoring normal ones. That occurred in all 14 pancreatic cancer patients and all six breast cancer patients studied, Finn said. Since no such cells could be found in healthy patients, they seem to come from a natural response to the tumors, she said. The target of the killer cells was found to be epithelial cell mucin, which is found on the tumor cells, Finn said. Tumors probably survive the attack by growing faster than killer cells can destroy them, she said. Or perhaps killer cells go after mucin that tumor cells secrete in large amounts into the bloodstream, instead of concentrating their attack on the tumor cells themselves. A vaccine based on mucin might boost the immune system response and make it more effective against the cancer, she said. The next step is to do large studies of patients with breast or pancreatic cancer to see how strong the natural immune system reponse is, she said. A vaccine may be ready for testing within a few years, she said. Dr. Drew Pardoll of the Johns Hopkins University of Medicine cautioned in a telephone interview that mucin is also produced by some normal cells in the body. That could present a problem if one wants to encourage an immune system attack on the substance, he said. But Finn said the killer cells do not destroy normal cells in the test tube. In the body, she said, the anatomy of organs that contain mucin-bearing normal cells appears to shield those cells from contact with the immune system. In another presentation, Patricia Steeg of the National Cancer Institute reported the discovery of a gene that appears to suppress a cancer cell's ability to spread within the body. In several kinds of cancer, the more active the gene was, the less ability the cancer had to spread, she said. Upcoming studies will see if the level of activity of the gene, called nm23, can predict the spreading behavior of breast, lung, bladder and prostate cancer cells, she said. If the gene does suppress spreading, called metastasis, it may be useful as a tool to find drugs that can hinder that process, she said. Also at the meeting, Dr. Dennis Slamon of the University of California, Los Angeles, School of Medicine presented an update on studies of another gene, called HER-2@neu. Patients whose breast or ovarian cancers show abnormally high numbers of copies of this gene per cancer cell had faster relapses and shorter survival times, he said. The extra gene copies lead to extra copies of a protein called a receptor on the cell surface, which may give the cell a growth advantage, he said. The receptor probably snares some kind of growth-promoting substance for the cell's use, he said. In one experiment, the growth of human breast cancers implanted in mice declined 80 percent when the receptor's functioning was blocked by proteins called monoclonal antibodies, Slamon said. When the antibodies were removed, the suppression disappeared, he said. Such antibodies may prove useful someday in therapy, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Approves Nicaragua-Panama Aid Bill _ With Major Additions
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's request for $800 million to help new democracies in Panama and Nicaragua is over its first congressional hurdle, but inflated to $2.4 billion by the addition of an array of domestic spending. The House Appropriations Committee gave voice vote approval to the money bill late Tuesday after cutting $80 million from the White House's $500 million request for Panama and leaving the $300 million Nicaragua package intact. Battles still lie ahead for the bill, however, and prospects dimmed that it could win final passage by Bush's April 5 deadline. The measure is expected to go to the full House next week, then must win Senate approval. One of the most potentially divisive issues _ whether to add restrictions on U.S. aid to El Salvador _ was not addressed by the appropriations panel. That disagreement was being fought in the House Foreign Affairs Committee, which was working on a separate bill needed to implement the Panama and Nicaragua aid. Bush is seeking $800 million for the new governments of President Guillermo Endara in Panama and President-elect Violeta Chamorro in Nicaragua to help both countries' damaged economies and to offer a visible demonstration of the benefits of democracy. The administration argues that the need is particularly acute in Nicaragua, where the economy is in ruins after a decade of civil war and where supplies are needed for the planting season that begins in a few weeks. While the panel approved Bush's full $300 million Nicaragua request, it cut the Panama package to $420 million, freeing $80 million for other areas where the president had not sought money. Those included $25 million to help feed refugees, primarily in Africa; $5 million to help settle Soviet Jews emigrating to Israel; $15 million in economic aid to eastern Caribbean countries; $5 million to repair damage in the same region from Hurricane Hugo; $10 million for the newly independent African country of Namibia; $10 million to promote democracy in South Africa; $2.5 million for Zambia; $2.5 million for Mozambique, and $5 million in African development aid not earmarked for a specific country. The bill also contains $70 million Bush asked to bolster the fund for U.S. resettlement of refugees to handle an increase of 27,000 in the number coming to the United States this year. Most of those are Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union. And the measure would offer $400 million in housing loan guarantees to Israel to help settle Soviet Jews there. In separate action on Tuesday, the House Foreign Affairs Committee approved provisions giving Israel a cut rate on loan origination fees for the package, saving that country $3 million along with the lower interest rate it would enjoy on the 30-year loan. But as it approved those elements of Bush's request, the committee added $1.6 billion for a host of politically favored domestic programs. These included $111 million for storm and flood disaster relief in the Southeast, $50 million for additional low-income energy assistance for the Northeast, $190 million for veterans' pensions and $50 million for veterans' medical care. Also included in the bill were $29 million for judicial salaries, $510 million to make up an expected shortfall in the food stamp program and $96 million to be shifted to states from the unemployment trust fund to cover unexpected administrative costs due to higher jobless rates. The committee also adopted an amendment offered by Rep. Sidney Yates, D-Ill., to add $442 million for U.S. Forest Service firefighting costs. The package is to be financed through cuts totaling $1.8 billion in the Pentagon budget for this year, taken largely from operation and maintenance accounts, weapons procurement and research and development. That left the overall package still nearly $600 million in the red, which would require a waiver of Gramm-Rudman budget reduction strictures when the measure is brought before the full House. The Gramm-Rudman law requires that any new spending be fully offset by reductions in other areas of the budget, resulting in no net increase in the deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Abuses Alleged in Argentina
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International today urged Argentina to investigate allegations of torture, disappearances and killings of members of an opposition group that attacked an army barracks last year. The group's report made some of the broadest charges of human rights abuses since a civilian government replaced a military dictatorship that was responsible for the kidnappings and deaths of thousands of people. Amnesty detailed violations against members of the small leftist Movement for the Fatherland, which tried to take over an army base on the outskirts of Buenos Aires. Twenty-eight attackers and 11 soldiers and police officers died in the Jan. 23, 1989 attack on the La Tablada base. Sixty law officers were wounded and 13 attackers arrested. The human rights group urged Argentina's president, Carlos Menem, to order an inquiry. In its 21-page report, the group says there ``appears to be strong evidence'' that two attackers listed as being killed in combat were summarily executed after surrendering. The report also says hree others disappeared after being captured and that there was medical evidence to support prisoners' allegations they were tortured while in custody. Amnesty said Argentina's attorney general promised prompt inquiries into these complaints in April. By the end of the year, the investigating magistrate had reached a decision in only one case. The report also says some investigations were flawed. It cited autopsy procedures, which it said were not of a high enough standard to determine whether deaths had occurred in combat or were the result of executions. The report alleges that security forces raided private homes, often without warrants, following the attack on the base. It says they threatened and in some cases tortured suspected sympathizers. Armed plainclothes officers reportedly stormed one home without formally identifying themselves or producing a warrant, tortured the couple, raped the wife and threatened to kill their 11-month-old child, the document alleges. Four women and 16 men, including a Roman Catholic priest, were convicted in October of planning or carrying out the attack on the military base and given sentences ranging from 10 years to life in prison. The attackers said they believed a military coup was imminent and that it was being coordinated at the barracks by rebel officers. Argentina was frequently criticized for widespread human rights abuses during the 1976-83 military dictatorship, but the subsequent civilian government promised to return to the ``rule of law'' and prosecuted the military leaders for killings, torture and abductions under their ``dirty war'' against suspected leftists. A government commission found 10,000 people were ``disappeared'' by security and paramilitary forces in the ``dirty war,'' but human rights organizations contend up to 30,000 were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Says Farmers are Losers in Trade Pacts
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter says decades of trade negotiations have left farmers out in the cold. It's time to change that, he says, but it will take ``a hefty dose of political courage'' on the part of the United States and its trading partners. ``There's no question in my mind that agriculture is the most distortive sector of the world economy, when one evaluates existing trade patterns,'' Yeutter said Tuesday. In the case of industrial goods, there has been substantial progress in trade liberalization under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. And there has been a move now under GATT to deal with the international aspects of the financial and service sectors. ``Agriculture has been on the agenda for the past 40 years, and probably nothing has happened,'' Yeutter said. ``We've gone through 40 years of GATT history, through a whole series of multilateral trade rounds, and for all practical purposes we, the members of GATT, have accomplished nothing in the way of agricultural trade liberalization.'' The current Uruguay Round of GATT talks is scheduled to conclude at the end of this year. Yeutter told a meeting of the Food Executives International Congress that the Uruguay Round offers ``great potential for liberalization'' and that the United States has put its own quotas and trade-distorting policies on the negotiating table. But Yeutter, as he has many times, stressed that the United States will not ``disarm unilaterally'' and that ``if our trading partners won't march, we're not going to march, either.'' Yeutter said all sorts of ``schemes'' are used to avoid trade liberalization and that agricultural commodities are favorite targets. ``If it exists, it's applied to agriculture,'' he said. ``If there's anything that is distortive, you can bet your bottom dollar it's used by some country somewhere to impede agricultural trade.'' These devices, he said, include export subsidies, high internal price supports, quotas and licensing. Yeutter pointedly used Japan's restrictive import policy on rice as an example. Recently, he said, a U.S. rice industry group participated in a food show in Japan and included samples of American rice. But the Japanese government asked that the samples be withdrawn. ``I wonder about anyone's commitment to trade liberalization when we can't even show a sample of an American food product in Japan,'' Yeutter said. The European Economic Community, for years a favorite target of U.S. trade officials, also was cited by Yeutter for boosting internal soybean price supports to more than $18 a bushel. The U.S. price support was $4.53 for 1989 soybeans. ``I told some of them here recently that if you paid me $18 a bushel for soybeans, I'd grow them on the Alps, and I think maybe somebody's going to grow them on the Alps if that continues very much longer,'' he said. ``If you pay farmers enough money, they'll grow anything anywhere.''

Colder weather has slowed winter wheat development in the Great Plains and may have caused some damage in a few southern areas where top growth was heavier, according to a government report. The Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Tuesday that a winter storm brought ``some beneficial moisture'' to the northern plains during the week of March 19-25. Wheat growth in Kansas was reported excellent early in the week before the cold front moved through. ``Oklahoma's winter wheat was good to fair, but freezing temperatures damaged some fields with moderate top growth,'' the report said. ``Cold weather slowed growth in most areas of Texas at the end of the week.'' The weather facility is operated by the Agriculture and Commerce departments. Weekly reports cover crop conditions but do not include production forecasts. Looking at other crops, the report said fieldwork progressed well in the Mississippi Delta as fields dried. Corn planting was more than one-third complete in Alabama, but earlier flooding may force some replanting. Rice planting continued in Louisiana, and cotton farmers continued planting in Arizona and Southern California. Tobacco was reported in good-to-fair condition in Georgia and North Carolina, and in fair-to-good shape in South Carolina. The storm in the northern plains was a hardship for livestock and newborn calves, despite its moisture benefits for pastures and crops, the report said. Pastures were said to be in mostly good-to-fair condition in the Delta and the East.

Texas has the most stock sheep, but when it comes to lamb chops, count on Colorado as No. 1. Agriculture Department statisticians say the Texas inventory was about 1.9 million head as of Jan. 1, up 11 percent from a year earlier. But Colorado remained the largest lamb-feeding state with 385,000 head reported, up 1 percent from Jan. 1, 1989. Texas was second with 200,000 head, an 18 percent increase. Overall, the U.S. inventory of sheep and lambs was about 11.4 million head on Jan. 1, up 5 percent from a year earlier. ``This increase in sheep and lamb inventory implies a substantial corresponding rise in lamb and mutton production in 1990,'' the department's Economic Research Service said. ``Production for the year is expected to increase about 4 percent to 355 million pounds.'' Meanwhile, the American Sheep Industry Association, based in Denver, says National Lamb Month will be in September for the second consecutive year instead of April, as had been traditional. ``It is the time of year when lamb is available to consumers at the best value per pound,'' said the association's Robin Ganse. ``Promotional efforts can give consumers that extra push in deciding to serve lamb for holiday meals.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Navy Secretary Suggests Shifting Much of Navy to Reserve Status
DOC.TEXT: The Navy should respond to the diminishing Soviet threat by shifting much of its fleet to reserve status, according to a former Navy secretary. John Lehman, a proponent of the 600-ship Navy during his tenure in the Reagan administration, said the Pentagon no longer needs to operate as if the nation is in a wartime mode. ``Regardless of the size of the Soviet fleet they're not about to attack tomorrow, or the next day, or the next year,'' Lehman told the House Armed Services Committee's defense policy panel Tuesday. However, Lehman said the size of the Navy is not affected by the rapid push toward democracy in Eastern Europe. Determining the number of ships in the fleet are the five oceanic regions where the United States has vital concerns and the continued modernization of the Soviet fleet, including production of submarines. The former secretary said the Navy should alter its approach, shifting ships and aircraft to the reserves, with half active forces and half reserves manning the ships and squadrons. He suggested shifting half the 20,000 sailors associated with ships near Europe to reserve status, but did not provide additional specifics. Pressed by lawmakers about the future U.S. naval fleet if it shrinks to 400 ships, Lehman said the Pentagon should keep at least 14 carriers and four battleships. In the fiscal 1991 defense budget, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has proposed mothballing two of the four U.S. battleships _ the USS Iowa and the USS New Jersey. Retired Air Force Gen. Russell E. Dougherty, former commander of the Strategic Air Command, agreed with Lehman that the likelihood of confrontation was slim. ``The tinderbox character ... in Europe is changed, maybe even gone and the changed political situation in the Warsaw Pact and Eastern European has dramatically changed the confrontation,'' Dougherty told the committee. But both Lehman and Dougherty stressed the need for development of the B-2 stealth bomber. Its cost of more than $70 billion for 132 planes has drew criticism in Congress. ``Keeping the long-range bomber leg makes eminent sense,'' Lehman said. But he questioned continued spending on land-based nuclear missiles to make them survivable in the event of a Soviet attack. Bush administration plans calls for moving the multiple-warhead, MX missile from hardened silos to railroad cars and developing the smaller Midgetman missile. ``Throwing more money after the land-based leg of the ICBM is really on the wrong end of the ledger of business,'' said Lehman, managing director of Paine Webber Inc. ``The amount of money that you have to spend to make ICBM survivable in this kind of environment just doesn't make any sense to me.'' Questioned further about his position on land-based missiles, Lehman said he favored keeping the MX missile but that officials should ``accept the fact it's vulnerable to a first strike.''

DOC.HEAD: Pilot in USAir 5050 Loses License; Transcript Released in Avianca Crash
DOC.TEXT: The government is revoking the flying license of the pilot who skidded his USAir jetliner into New York's East River last year. Saying Capt. Michael Martin lacked the ``care, skill, judgment and responsibility'' to fly a commercial airliner, the Federal Aviation Administration announced the revocation Tuesday and gave Martin 20 days to appeal to the National Transportation Safety Board. In another New York crash, the NTSB on Tuesday released a cockpit voice recorder transcript that showed the copilot of Avianca Flight 52 told the pilot he had radioed a fuel emergency, but he used less precise language with ground controllers. The Avianca jet, which apparently ran out of fuel, crashed Jan. 25 at Cove Neck, Long Island, killing 73 of the 159 people aboard, including all three cockpit crew members. In the USAir case, Air Line Pilots Association spokesman John Mazor said his group considers the action against Martin ``totally unwarranted and it will be appealed.'' Two people died in the Sept. 20 aborted takeoff, and 61 others were rescued from the airliner, which broke into pieces at the end of a LaGuardia airport runway. The FAA cited Martin's failure to fully complete a pre-takeoff checklist and perform other required actions on the taxiway. The agency earlier ordered alteration of cockpit controls in all Boeing 737 airliners as a result of the crash. The pilots' union said the faulty design of controls led to the aborted takeoff, and the NTSB has been looking into that as one of several possible causes for the crash. The revocation order, dated March 19 but announced Tuesday, faulted the pilot for failing to check a rudder control or monitor engine thrust, which it said caused the airliner to drift to the left. An FAA news release did not mention either Martin or copilot Constantine Kleissas by name and said nothing about the copilot's status. The FAA earlier suspended the licenses of both Martin and Kleissas, who was at the controls of a commercial Boeing 737 takeoff for the first time. The Avianca cockpit transcript said the Colombian pilot said, ``Tell them we are in emergency'' in Spanish just after the plane failed its first landing attempt and 10 minutes before it crashed. ``We're running out of fuel,'' the copilot told controllers in English at 9:24 p.m., after the crew of the Boeing 707 was instructed to abort the attempted landing at John F. Kennedy airport and loop around for another try. A few seconds later, the pilot again asked the copilot to tell the controller there was an emergency. ``Digale que estamos en emergencia,'' the pilot said, also asking whether his order had been carried out. ``Si, Senor, ya le dije,'' said the copilot _ ``Yes, sir, I already advised him,'' according to the transcript and translation released by the NTSB. None of the cockpit crew members was identified by name in the transcript. The flight had come from Bogota and Medellin. A source close to the investigation told The Associated Press in New York on Monday that the transcript appeared to show a pilot who did not seem to be in full charge of the flight and who did not give specific direction to the copilot to declare an emergency. The 68-page transcript of the flight's final 40 minutes, however, contained two instances in which the pilot used the critical word ``emergency'' _ ``emergencia'' in Spanish _ in communicating with his copilot. After the crash, the Federal Aviation Administration ordered all airlines flying to U.S. airports to ensure that their crews use specifically worded language in communicating emergencies to controllers. If a ``fuel emergency'' had been declared, the plane would have been given a higher priority in landing, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Gets Major Weapons Review
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Should stand
DOC.TEXT: Top Pentagon officials are trying to persuade Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that the military still needs some of its most expensive aircraft programs, including the B-2 stealth bomber, despite revolutionary changes in the Soviet bloc. Defense sources said Cheney planned today to begin viewing a slide presentation of the results of a program review that the secretary had requested in December to help him formulate long-term budget plans. The review looked into the expensive B-2 program, the C-17 cargo plane and two fighter aircraft still under development, the Air Force's Advanced Tactical Fighter and the Navy's A-12. Overall, the programs account for some $200 billion in projected Pentagon spending. Cheney is preparing the Pentagon's five-year defense plan in the face of severe pressure on Capitol Hill for military spending cuts to cut the budget deficit and respond to the political change that has swept Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. But so far, Cheney has advised against severe cutbacks in the U.S. arsenal. He contends that despite some reforms, the Soviet Union retains enormous military might that could pose a threat to this country. While the review had initially been touted as one could entail calls for canceling some of the programs, no such stark recommendation is made, Pentagon sources said Tuesday. Although the review reaffirms the military requirements for the new aircraft, it also lays out various options for trimming the numbers of planes or drawing production schedules out in light of tight budgets, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. A particular target for cuts is the radar-evading B-2 bomber, said one Pentagon source familiar with the outlines of the review. ``The B-2 numbers are in trouble,'' the source said. The Air Force has requested some 132 Stealth bombers, costing more than $500 million each. The bomber program has been the focus of fierce opposition on Capitol Hill, where some lawmakers are pressing for the program's termination. The three other programs receive more favorable treatment in the review, the source said, and ``the A-12 and the C-17 are considered to be in pretty good shape.'' The review provides Cheney with ranges of options to choose from, the source said. ``It's more of a philosophical presentation,'' he said. Pentagon spokesman Bob Hall said Cheney is ``going to advise Congress of any decisions that stem from this review. ... Any important recommendations he will want to make, any conclusions he will draw from it, I'm sure he'll discuss with the president.'' Congress will get the results ``in the near future ... weeks, I think,'' Hall added. Last week, John Betti, the undersecretary of defense for acquisition, said the studies had involved dozens of Pentagon officials, and that they planned to present Cheney with ``a menu of options.'' Betti, who helped organize the review, said it had involved ``going back to ground zero'' on the need for the aircraft during a period of ``strained resources.'' Cheney ``will have to decide what will be done. He'll have to establish priorities and the way he intends to sell them to the president and the Congress,'' Betti said.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Try To Change Minds About Capital Punishment
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of capital punishment are trying to overcome the large majority opinion in favor of it as the state's first execution in 23 years approaches. At 3 a.m. on April 3, unless last-ditch appeals succeed, 37-year-old Robert Alton Harris will be strapped into San Quentin's 49-square-foot apple-green gas chamber, and an invisible cloud of cyanide gas will end his life. ``Should we as a society use the same language as the murderer _ the language of death _ and create new victims? Society must rise above the level of the murderer,'' said Jim Young, who has been on a protest vigil outside the prison for three weeks. Young, a member of Death Penalty Focus, sat on Monday by a black cardboard coffin and signs reading ``Don't Kill For Me'' and ``The Death Penalty Is Dead Wrong.'' Two other people, one the wife of another death row inmate, stood nearby. Also on hand were a man and a woman carrying signs applauding the scheduled execution and urging people to remember his victims. Harris was found guilty and sentenced to die for the July 5, 1978, murders of San Diego 16-year-olds John Mayeski and Michael Baker after abducting them to use their car in a bank robbery. ``We know we're up against a hard rock of public opinion,'' Young said, referring to some statewide public opinion surveys showing 80 percent of Californians in favor of capital punishment. ``But (people) say they're for the death penalty because it's been sold to them,'' said Young. ``That's why we're out here at the gate _ to give out information.'' Members of other groups opposed to capital punishment and fearful that Harris' death will lead to further executions also have been fasting, speaking out, or writing to Gov. George Deukmejian to ask for clemency. Although opponents argue capital punishment is immoral and fails to deter crime, the head of a Sacramento-based national victims' rights group sees things differently. ``We believe that ultimately the death penalty simply incapacitates murderers more effectively than any other form of punishment contemplated or legal in the United States,'' said Michael Rushford, president of the Criminal Justice Legal Foundation. ``Harris will never kill again.'' Death penalty foes argue California has no need for the death penalty to prevent murderers from being released to kill again. ``We can effectively deal with the problem with the current law _ life without possibility of parole,'' said Stephen Souza, the regional membership coordinator of Amnesty International. Still, proponents are skeptical that such a punishment can be counted on with any certainty. ``They don't have any idea what that is about,'' said Steve Baker, the father of one of Harris' young victims and a San Diego police detective. Baker will witness Harris' execution. The American Civil Liberties Union argues that the death penalty is inherently a form of cruel and unusual punishment, and therefore unconstitutional. ``Errors cannot be corrected after someone is dead. Once they're dead, there's no appeal,'' said Martha Kegel, the ACLU's associate director in northern California.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Bill to Ban Food-Garbage Hauls by Truckers
DOC.TEXT: Truckers would be banned from hauling loads of food and garbage back to back, under legislation the House passed overwhelmingly over Bush administration opposition. The bill, approved 410-15 on Tuesday, directs the Department of Transportation to issue regulations banning refrigerated trucks, tank trucks and rail cars from alternating loads of food with shipments of ``unacceptable non-food products'' such as solid waste or chemicals. ``Backhauling is dangerous, disgusting and legal,'' Rep. William Clinger, R-Pa., one of the measure's prime sponsors, said before the vote. ``We have not eliminated this practice by publicity, which makes it terribly important that we pass this bill.'' The administration opposed the ban largely because of a provision that the Transportation Department assume enforcement responsibility. Alan I. Roberts, a hazardous materials specialist with the department, told a Senate panel three weeks ago that existing law ``is adequate to regulate the handling and transportation of food.'' If a bill were approved, he said, lead responsibility would more properly rest with the agencies with food safety expertise _ the Agriculture Department and the Food and Drug Administration. ``The administration has yet to see fit to correct these practices,'' Rep. Tom Luken, D-Ohio, said during debate on the bill. ``Evidently the Department of Transportation thinks it is the problem of the Food and Drug Administration. The FDA thinks its a transportation problem. And the EPA, which has jurisdiction over solid waste, doesn't know what to think. ``The bottom line is that Congress is going to have to direct these agencies to work together to stop these life-threatening practices,'' Luken said. The legislation would also require that asbestos, infectious waste and other health-threatening items be shipped only in vehicles designated for that purpose. The bill now moves to the Senate, where several similar bills are pending. The practice is known as backhauling because it often occurs after trucks haul food loads to the East. Rather than return to the Midwest empty, they carry garbage. A trucker testified last August that he liked hauling garbage because it could not be harmed en route. Concern about food-garbage hauls arose after the Centre Daily Times of State College, Pa., reported a year ago that refrigerated food-hauling trucks were being loaded with municipal solid waste. The report led Congress to investigate a related practice last year: alternating hauls of chemicals with shipments of juice or edible oils. An Oregon trucker's shipment log released by a House panel included loads of cooking oil, wine, apple juice, fire retardant, marine lubricant and lime sulphur. Several trucking groups have said that concern by food companies has pressured truckers into avoiding the practice. The government says it has yet to uncover any instances of contamination due to backhauling. But Clinger and Rep. Chris Smith, R-N.J., said that checks by their staffs have confirmed that backhauling is continuing. Voting against the bill were Reps. Bill Archer, R-Texas; Dick Armey, R-Texas; Dan Burton, R-Ind.; Larry Combest, R-Texas; Philip Crane, R-Ill.; William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif.; Tom DeLay, R-Texas; Robert Dornan, R-Calif.; Jack Fields, R-Texas; Bill Frenzel, R-Minn.; James Hansen, R-Utah; Edward Madigan, R-Ill.; Ron Marlenee, R-Mont.; Howard Nielson, R-Utah, and Norman Shumway, R-Calif. Not voting were Reps. Doug Barnard, D-Ga.; Jim Bates, D-Calif.; Michael Bilirakis, R-Fla.; Harold E. Ford, D-Tenn.; Jim Leach, R-Iowa; Denny Smith, R-Ore., and Bob Stump, R-Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Watkins Gives up Responsibility for Nuclear Worker Health Studies
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department is giving up responsibility for studying long-term health risks for workers at nuclear weapons plants, but Secretary James D. Watkins says he'll increase daily monitoring of the employees. Watkins announced Tuesday he has begun negotiations for the Department of Health and Human Services to take over the long-term health studies, which seek to answer such questions as whether exposure to low-level radiation causes increased cancer risks. The move reflected growing complaints from Congress, labor unions and communities near weapons plants that the Energy Department, which owns the facilities, cannot be trusted to perform objective studies of possible health hazards. Last month, the author of a federal study that found a unusually high rate of cancers among workers at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant in Colorado charged that Energy Department officials had pressured him to water down his findings in 1986 and 1987. The allegation by Gregg Wilkinson, a former epidemiologist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, which designs nuclear weapons, is under investigation by the Energy Department's inspector general. Watkins' decision was prompted by a panel of health physics experts, which said in a report released Tuesday that the department should monitor workers' health but should cede responsibility to another federal agency for studying long-term health issues. The panel, headed by Kristine Gebbie, the secretary of health for the state of Washington, said the public does not trust the Energy Department to do its own studies. ``Because the department's role is to promote energy production, there is an inherent potential conflict between immediate production goals and health and safety goals,'' the report said. ``To restore public trust, to assure the highest scientific quality, and to assure the independence of investigators, the department needs an independent system,'' it added. The panel also recommended that the Energy Department spend more time studying health risks from worker exposure to non-nuclear hazards at the weapons plants, such as toxic chemicals and beryllium, which are used in weapons manufacturing. A recent study said 12 people who were exposed to beryllium while working at Rocky Flats have contracted an incurable lung disease. They were among 750 employees at the plant who have handled beryllium, a metal used in making plutonium triggers. Ms. Gebbie said her panel saw indications that beryllium exposure could be a problem at other weapons plants. It recommended immediate action to study the problem. Watkins said he talked Tuesday with HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan about switching the long-range epidemiological work to his department. ``He's ready to go,'' Watkins said, adding that he hoped the Energy Department could conclude a ``memorandum of understanding'' with Sullivan's department within one month on terms of the transfer. Watkins initially resisted efforts in Congress to take away his control over the health studies. But in his public meeting with Ms. Gebbie's panel, he said, ``Research of this nature is better suited for an agency that regularly addresses such issues.'' Watkins stressed that his department would retain responsibility for protecting plant workers' health and for minimizing exposure to hazardous materials. He said he already had taken steps to improve day-to-day health monitoring. The secretary also announced that President Bush was nominating a health physics expert to fill the vacant position of assistant energy secretary for environment, safety and health, which holds responsibility for nuclear worker health issues. The nominee, Harry Pettengill, said in a brief interview Tuesday that he has worked in the department's office of environment, safety and health for 1{ years.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,263.57, down 562.39 points, or 1.77 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Groups Favoring Abortion Split Over Proposed Idaho Boycott
DOC.TEXT: Two of the leading abortion rights groups are split over whether an economic boycott against Idaho will effectively persuade the governor to veto the country's most restrictive state abortion law. Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion Rights Action League, said Tuesday the threat of a boycott on Idaho potatoes and other products could be counterproductive in the campaign to block Gov. Cecil Andrus' signature on the bill. ``I understand the frustration that has led to the idea,'' Michelman said. ``But I think that threats like that aren't always the best method. ... It's just something that complicates things.'' Andrus, a Democrat who opposes abortion under most circumstances, was deliberating on the bill, which prohibits abortion as a means of birth control. The bill won final legislative approval last Thursday. Hundreds of telephone calls, letters and messages from both camps flooded the Democratic chief executive's office Tuesday. Andrus wants to consult outside experts before making his final decision. On Tuesday, Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women, said if the bill becomes law she would recommend a nationwide boycott of all Idaho goods at the organization's national conference in June. It would be similar to the boycott NOW conducted against states refusing to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment in the 1970s. Groups and individuals in states throughout the nation have made similar threats, prompting state Commerce Director James Hawkins to say: ``We're becoming concerned.'' But anti-abortion activists, led by the National Right to Life Committee, have countered with pledges to increase their purchases of Idaho products. The legislation bans abortion except in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is younger than 18, severe fetal deformity and a threat to the life or physical health of the mother. The governor has until next Monday morning to act unless the Legislature adjourns before then. If that happens, as is expected, Andrus has 10 days from the time lawmakers leave. If signed, the bill would take effect July 1, but abortion rights advocates have promised a court test that anti-abortion forces hope will convince the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn its 1973 decision legalizing abortion. Michelman said she's ``not interested in hurting the people of Idaho. I think most of the people of the state disagree with what the House and Senate did.'' The most powerful influence on the governor, Michelman maintained, will come from his constituents. ``I'm not sure an Idaho potato boycott is as effective as real well-organized political grassroots activity,'' she said. ``I think the governor will be held accountable by the people of Idaho for whatever he does and so will the legislators.''

DOC.HEAD: Staten Island Dynasty: Molinari Succeeds Molinari
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Susan Molinari, the newest, youngest member of Congress, says she'll follow much of the course her father set in the House before her, but she'll continue to differ with him on the abortion question: she's pro-choice. ``In the interest of family unity we don't discuss it anymore,'' Ms. Molinari, R-N.Y., told reporters after being sworn in Tuesday. Her tenure as the least senior member of the House was to end today with the swearing-in of Jose Serrano, a Bronx Democrat. Both Ms. Molinari and Serrano won special elections March 20. Ms. Molinari, a two-term New York City councilwoman, defeated Democrat Robert Gigante, a local attorney and political newcomer. Serrano, a state assemblyman, was elected to fill the House seat vacated when Robert Garcia resigned after being convicted in the Wedtech influence-peddling scandal. Serrano defeated Simeon Golar, a Queens Democrat who ran as a Republican. Ms. Molinari celebrated her 32nd birthday Tuesday by taking the oath of office. She succeeds her father, former five-term GOP Rep. Guy Molinari, who resigned the seat last year to run for Staten Island borough president. House Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash., administered the oath of office to Ms. Molinari as her father stood at her side, beaming.
DOC.HEAD: NTSB Calls For More Natural Gas Explosion Protections
DOC.TEXT: The Transportation Department says it will consider a recommendation by federal investigators for utilities to install a device to help prevent explosions from leaking residential natural gas pipes. The National Transportation Safety Board called Tuesday for ``urgent action'' by DOT to require the devices, known as excess flow valves. The board said recent fatal accidents in Kansas and Missouri demonstrated the need for the equipment, which automatically restricts the flow of gas when certain increases occur, possibly from a leak or rupture in a line. Four people were killed and a dozen injured in a series of five explosions between September 1988 and March 1989 on KPL Gas Service lines in the two states. In a report on the explosions, the board concluded that the excess flow valves could have prevented or at least reduced the seriousness of three of the accidents. NTSB issued a similar recommendation for the devices in 1981, but board members said the KPL accidents caused them to renew their suggestion and assign it the highest priority for regulatory consideration.
DOC.HEAD: Transportation Secretary Announces $90 million For Denver Airport
DOC.TEXT: The federal government says it will provide $90 million for construction of a new airport in Denver. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner said Tuesday that the Federal Aviation Administration grant signals the Bush administration's commitment to expanding aviation capacity throughout the country. In addition, the department has told Congress it will seek $351 million for the new Colorado airport between fiscal 1991 and fiscal 1999. He said this is the largest federal airport commitment of its kind. ``Today we are making good on our promise,'' Skinner said in a meeting with Denver Mayor Federico Pena and members of Colorado's congressional delegation. He said the airport project represents a ``giant step'' towards expanded airport capacity in the country. FAA Administrator James B. Busey said the government is convinced ``we will be getting a big return on our investment'' in the Denver airport. He said construction of the airport is expected to reduce flight delays by 4 percent to 5 percent across the country by 1995.

DOC.HEAD: Transition Agreement Reached, Sandinistas Say They'll Cede Control of Army
DOC.TEXT: The Sandinistas have agreed to cede control of the army and police in a preliminary agreement with advisers to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro on transferring power. The agreement, reached late Tuesday, stresses that the demobilization of the Contra rebels is crucial if a civilian government led by Mrs. Chamorro is to take over from the Sandinistas on April 25 as scheduled. Dismantling of the rebel force that once had strong U.S. backing ``constitutes an essential element for creating the climate of peace, stability and tranquility in which the transfer of government should take place,'' the agreement says. The heads of the transition teams signed the preliminary agreement after a month of negotiations. Mrs. Chamorro defeated President Daniel Ortega in free elections on Feb. 25. Control of the security forces is a key issue in the transition from a decade-old leftist revolutionary government to the conservative United National Opposition, or UNO. Under the agreement, the Sandinista army and police will become non-partisan organizations under the control of Mrs. Chamorro and only these institutions should have combat weapons. The accord also says that the size of Nicaragua's armed forces, which Soviet aid built into the largest in Central America, will be determined by the ``economic capacity and social necessity of the nation.'' Mrs. Chamorro campaigned on a promise to end the draft and drastically cut the size of the military, which consumes half the national budget in this impoverished country. The Sandinistas, openly reluctant to relinquish their armed forces and police while the Contras remain intact, have been handing out thousands of weapons since their stunning election loss and urging people to defend the ``conquests of the revolution.'' Those ``conquests'' include thousands of houses and farms confiscated by the Sandinistas. The accord says the new government will respect the rights of people who were given confiscated property before election day. The transition document was signed by Defense Minister Humberto Ortega, head of the Sandinista transition team and the president's brother, and Antonio Lacayo, head of the UNO team and a son-in-law of Mrs. Chamorro. Lacayo said the agreement forsees the demobilization of the Contras by April 25. Gen. Ortega said it was necessary to ``isolate, neutralize and put in their right place those who aren't on the path of peace and democracy that is opening in Nicaragua.'' He said he was confident that the Contras would be dismantled ``once and for all'' whether they want to be or not. The Contras and UNO signed an agreement Friday calling for the rebels in Honduran base camps to disband by April 20. The accord says fighters in Nicaragua are to move into security zones under the supervision of the U.N. force and Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo. Most of the 12,000-man rebel army is believed to have returned to Nicaragua in recent months and Contra leaders have been vague on when the fighters on Nicaraguan soil would disarm. Oscar Sovalbarro, the Contra negotiator in the accord with UNO, said Monday that 2,000 rebel fighters had returned to Nicaragua since Friday alone. International observers say the Contra camps in Yamales, Honduras, are like ``ghost towns.'' The Contras now confront a unified effort to get them dismantled. Even the United States, their longtime sponsor, says they must disband. A U.N. observer force began patroling Nicaraguan war zones by helicopter Tuesday and the U.N. Security Council authorized adding 800 troops to the 200-member demobilization force. The U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, James Wilkinson, told the Security Council in New York that it is time for the rebels ``to demobilize freely and return to their land to contribute to its development.'' Twelve white helicopters emblazoned with the U.N. symbol landed at Sandinista army installations Tuesday morning and two hours later took off to the east. Military sources said the aircraft were carrying members of the observer force to eastern jungle zones, where they would try to contact Contra chiefs. The U.N. forces plan to collect weapons, ammunition, military equipment and uniforms from the rebels. The U.N. plan calls for Contras in Honduran camps to hand over their weapons and await repatriation or resettlement. U.N. observers also plan to establish temporary assembly points inside Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Tumble, Dollar Still Rising
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index fell sharply Wednesday, while the dollar rose against the Japanese yen for the ninth consecutive day despite government efforts to support the yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 562.39 points, or 1.77 percent, closing at 31,263.57. The Nikkei fell 14.53 points on Tuesday. The dollar closed at 158.63 yen, up 1.67 yen from Tuesday's close of 156.96 yen. It opened at 158.30 yen and ranged between 158.15 yen and 158.85 yen. The dollar now has gained 6.43 yen in nine trading days. The dollar last traded at the 158-yen level in January 1987. ``The dollar has been so strong, and its rising pace is very fast,'' said Shinichi Kato, a trader with Mitsui Bank. The dollar's advance followed its overnight rise in New York. Kato said a large demand for the dollar prior to year-end account settlements is pushing the U.S. currency higher. Japan's fiscal year ends on Saturday. Importers, many of whom are afraid that the dollar will rise further, jump at the dollar whenever it moves downward, he said. Kato blamed the lack of coordinated market intervention among central banks for the dollar's swift ascent. ``The Bank of Japan alone can no longer control the situation,'' he said. ``The dollar's upward momentum has become too strong now.'' Japan's central bank was seen intervening in the market by selling some $300 million. The bank does not officially comment on its market intervention. Because the U.S. Federal Reserve did not sell dollars during the previous day, Japanese market players began to speculate that the United States approves of the current dollar-yen rate, he added. ``The dollar will soon hit the 160-yen level. It's just a matter of time,'' Kato said. The yen's decline knocked the Nikkei index more than 650 points lower in early trading, but the Nikkei made up some of its losses as market players picked up shipbuilding issues whose prices had fallen earlier, dealers said. Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said after a Cabinet meeting Wednesday that he is watching current exchange rate levels with great concern, Kyodo News Service reported. It quoted Hashimoto as saying he had received an invitation to attend the meeting of the Group of Seven finance ministers in Paris in April, but that he would decide whether to attend the meeting on the basis of the conditions at the time in the Japanese Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Check Printer Offers New Line of Checks with Social Messages
DOC.TEXT: The nation's second-largest check printing company is offering checks with personalized, political messages for consumers who care about abortion, AIDS and other issues. Any of 21 messages offered by the John H. Harland Co. can be printed on a banner in the middle of the check. On abortion, people may opt for ``Pro Choice'' or ``Pro Life.'' Those interested in the environment may proclaim ``Stop Nuclear Power'' or ``Alternative Energy.'' Other messages include ``Stop Child Abuse,'' ``Attack AIDS'' and ``Seniors Have Style.'' ``It's been proven that they will pay for rainbows and puppies (on checks). It's not that farfetched,'' said Harland spokesman Bruce Danielson. The checks first were offered March 1 and sales have not been reported, he said. Stu Alexander, spokesman for Deluxe Check Printers Inc., the nation's largest check printing company in St. Paul, Minn., said he believed consumers will not go for the concept. ``Affinity'' checks, which allow people to state their loyalty to a school or organization, have not been big sellers, he said. ``While they seem like a good idea at the time, people tend to support their organizations (in other ways),'' he said. ``Someone who is gung ho on that will open their checkbook and write a check for that organization.'' Harland also has a new line that supports the Windstar Foundation, an educational organization for environmental concerns founded by singer John Denver. A marketing analyst said that could be an asset because the environment is a popular cause. ``People are putting their views on bumpers stickers. Why not on their checks?'' said Charlie Elberson, vice president of Prce-McNabb, an Asheville, N.C. marketing and communications firm. But Elberson advised caution in selecting messages. ``They would be wise to stay away from some issues, but most of these issues are pretty safe.'' The other messages offered by Harland are ``Save Our Earth,'' ``World Freedom,'' ``Protect Wildlife,'' ``Adopt A Pet,'' ``Shelter The Homeless,'' ``Share A Hug,'' ``Farmers Feed America,'' ``Just Say No,'' ``A Proud Vet,'' ``Stop Crime,'' ``Black Pride,'' ``Shalom,'' ``Orgulloso de ser Latino (Proud to be Hispanic),'' and ``Scientia est potestas (Knowledge is Power).''

DOC.HEAD: Texas Grower Defends Use of Banned Pesticide
DOC.TEXT: One of the state's largest vegetable growers told a regulatory board he was opposed to banning the pesticide chlordane, saying: ``sure it's going to kill a lot of people, but they may be dying of something else anyway.'' McAllen Mayor Othal Brand made the statement Tuesday during at his first appearance at the Agriculture Resources Protection Authority meeting, to which he was appointed by Gov. Bill Clements. Brand, who is also a grower, later denied making the statement, which was tape-recorded by a Fort Worth Star-Telegram reporter and a state employee. The board was discussing whether to close a loophole in state regulations that allows the use of chlordane by homeowners who own some of the banned pesticide. The pesticide is effective in fighting termites. In the tape, Brand said: ``I'm 70 years old and in great shape, and I mean, sure it's going to kill a lot of people but they may be dying of something else anyway.'' Texas Agriculture Commissioner Jim Hightower called Brand's statement outrageous. Elvin Caraway III, a Fort Worth attorney also appointed to the board, said Brand's comment was just an ``old country expression.'' ``The gist of his comment is there are many things that cause illness and that ... some of the concern about pesticide generally is a little over-exaggerated,'' Caraway said. ``I'm not saying I agree with that or disagree with it.''

DOC.HEAD: Tranquilizer Snaps Man Out of Vegetative State After 8 Years
DOC.TEXT: Eight years after an auto accident left him in a vegetative state, a man given a tranquilizer in a dentist's office fell asleep, woke up and started to speak. Soon he could say his name, walk and feed himself, a doctor says. Dr. Andres Kanner, a neurologist with the University of Wisconsin Hospital, said Tuesday it's a mystery why tranquilizers awakened the man. ``I don't know what it is,'' Kanner said. ``It was just luck he had to have some dental work and it was just luck they administered the drugs.'' The patient, identified only as a Wisconsin man in his mid-40s, had been in a vegetative state, not a coma: His eyes were open and he occasionally uttered words, but he could do nothing else, the doctor said in an interview Tuesday. ``His interaction with the environment was very limited. He rarely spoke one or two words,'' Kanner said. The patient had been given Valium March 12 as a painkiller for routine dental work, Kanner said. After the tranquilizer was administered, the man fell asleep about five minutes, said Kanner, who was not present at the time. ``Then he woke up and started talking. He was able to answer questions, say his name, to feed himself and walk,'' Kanner said he was told. Hours later, the man lapsed back into the vegetative state. He was given a second dose that brought him out of it for about 90 minutes. At that point he was able to recall parts of his life. ``I have to tell you he was a different man. He knew his name, the name of his family, where he used to work. He could add, subtract and perform complicated calculations,'' said Kanner, who witnessed the second reaction. Since then, the man, who remains hospitalized, has received different, longer-lasting forms of benzodiazepines, a family of drugs that includes Valium, and barbiturates that allowed him to remain lucid 10 to 12 hours at a time, Kanner said. The drugs are administered intravenously. Doctors can't tell why the drugs helped the man or what combination of drugs they can give him to take orally outside the hospital, he said. One theory is that benzodiazepines, which inhibit certain functions of the nervous system, are blocking the effects of the vegetative state, Kanner said. But doctors for now are viewing the man's case as an isolated one, he said. Kanner said the man suffers no medical problems other than his mysterious vegetative state. It developed about two years after he came out of a four-month coma brought on by a car accident 10 years ago. The neurologist said that, as with most such patients, little was known about how to treat the man's condition and there was little hope for recovery before March 12.

DOC.HEAD: On the Lite Side
LaserPhoto BI1
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Sinner is auctioning off the state automobile, a snazzy dark blue 1988 Lincoln Town Car loaded with accesories, to do his part in cutting $550,000 from state travel expenses. The car, purchased last July for $19,800, is conspicuous on the streets of Bismarck because of its size, long rear telephone antenna and license plates bearing the number ``1.'' ``You stuck out like a sore thumb, and I'm no better driver than anybody else ... I sometimes make little errors. You feel unduly conspicuous,'' the Democratic governor said. ``I frankly didn't like driving it.'' In car salesman's parlance, the four-door sedan is loaded. The dash has a computer that figures the car's fuel mileage, average speed, and can estimate the time a trip will be finished. Windows and seats are electrically adjustable. ``It's got all this stuff on it,'' Sinner said. ``I never did figure out how to use it.'' The car is one of 75 state cars being auctioned today.

The only clue for workers answering hundreds of calls in Spanish at Columbia Auto Parts was the word ``census.'' The callers were trying to reach a special toll-free number for questions about the 1990 Census. ``Friday, it was amusing,'' said Bill Carter, who runs the business. ``Saturday, it was funny. It's not even humorous today.'' On Monday, the Census Bureau sent a Spanish-speaking employee to the shop to take down telephone numbers and tell callers that someone would get back to them. The employee took more than 100 calls dialed to 800-283-6826, Carter said. Joe McNamara of MCI Telecommunications Corp., the long-distance carrier for the Census, theorized that callers held one button down too long, repeating the 8 in 283. Columbia Auto Parts' toll-free number is 800-288-3862. McNamara said MCI checked the lines and found no problems, but Carter decided to change his number. ``I wanted to be able to talk to my receptionist,'' Carter said. ``I hope the number is ringing somewhere in never-never land. The new number is as far away from the old one as I could get it.'' In Tennessee, a medical supply company was experiencing the same problem with its number, 800-228-3862. By late Tuesday, TriCity Medical Equipment in Johnson City, Tenn. had recorded 245 calls in Spanish that day alone, said manager Kathy Meade. Meade said she doesn't want someone from the Census Bureau in her office. She said the bureau told her to expect the deluge of calls to continue for another three weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Call `Armed Strike,' Bomb Campaign Offices
DOC.TEXT: Maoist guerrillas trying to thwart national elections with a bombing and assassination campaign called a strike for today after briefly taking over three radio stations in Lima to spread their message. Over the past week, the Shining Path rebels have assassinated four congressional candidates and exploded a car bomb in front of the Finance Ministry, killing two people and badly wounding 12. On Tuesday, at least four people were injured in a car bomb attack at the site of a planned campaign rally in the Andean city of Huancayo, police said. Earlier in the day, they seized the three radio stations, forcing workers to broadcast taped messages urging people not to vote in the April 8 elections and to observe an ``armed strike'' today, police said. An ``armed strike'' means a general strike in rebel terminology and carries the threat of violence against people who don't obey. Police said rebels distributed strike leaflets and stopped buses on Lima's outskirts Tuesday and daubed them with strike slogans. Angry drivers drove their buses to City Hall to protest lack of protection. In Huancayo, about 120 miles east of the capital, when Shining Path guerrillas detonated a car bomb on the main square, where leftist presidential candidate Alfonso Barrantes was scheduled to hold a rally, police reported. Barrantes had switched the rally time to later in the afternoon after police warned that the rebels may have learned his itinerary. Police said four people were injured. The Shining Path also set off a car bomb in front of a hotel Monday night in downtown Huancayo, injuring one man and damaging the building. On Monday night, rebels bombed a bank and a telephone company office in Lima, and police deactivated two bombs at movie houses in suburbs, police said. Police detained more than 3,000 people in a roundup in Lima Monday night and Tuesday morning. Most were stopped for not carrying documents and were released after a few hours, police said. The government declared Lima under a 30-day state of emergency Friday, suspending some civil rights and giving police extra powers to curb rebel activities. A third of Peru is under emergency status, affecting half of the country's population of 22 million. Police said rebels tossed bombs Monday night at four Lima campaign offices of the Democratic Front, the center-right coalition of presidential candidate Mario Vargas Llosa. Vargas Llosa said Tuesday he had information that members of President Alan Garcia's governing center-left Aprista party were involved, but gave no details. He said neither terrorists nor ``irresponsible and violent elements of the Aprista party'' would intimidate his followers. Peruvians on April 8 will vote for president and both houses of congress. Vargas Llosa leads in the polls, but must get 50 percent of the vote to avoid a runoff. The Shining Path has been fighting to overthrow Peru's elected governments since 1980. A senate commission reported recently that 642 people died this year in political violence, and that more than 18,000 have died in the last 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Restricting Calories Cuts Cancer Risk in Mouse Study
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 a.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: A low-calorie diet can delay cancer development and cut cancer risk in mice, a researcher reports. Scientists found that the more calories were restricted, while avoiding malnutrition, the more lifespan was extended and the longer cancer was delayed, said Richard Weindruch. ``I expect the same might apply to the human situation,'' he said Tuesday at a science writers seminar sponsored by the American Cancer Society. Scientists have long known that mice and rats live longer under a long-term low-calorie diet. Previous work has also shown reductions in cancer rates and delays in the appearance of the disease. Caloric restriction has also been shown effective in spiders, silkworms, guppies, trout and other animals, so ``this is not simply a rodent phenomenon,'' said Weindruch of the National Institute on Aging. In one experiment he described, 57 female mice ate a diet of 85 calories a week from age three weeks, while 60 others were put on a 40-calorie diet. Mice eating the low-calorie diet showed a 35 percent longer average lifetime and less than half the risk of tumors. The cancers they did get appeared at later ages. A separate experiment found that mice who began a low-calorie diet in mid-adulthood, an age of about a year, showed a 10 percent to 20 percent gain in maximum and average lifespan, Weindruch said. Gerald Murphy, chief medical officer of the cancer society, said he believed that humans can help lower their cancer risk by reducing calories along with moderate reductions in fat. But too little is known to say whether they will live longer, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Attackers on U.S. Ambassador's Residence Sentenced
DOC.TEXT: Three radical students convicted of attacking the residence of U.S. Ambassador Donald Gregg with homemade bombs were sentenced today to two years in prison. Another three student defendants were given suspended sentences by the Seoul Criminal Court. The six students, armed with homemade bombs, tear gas grenades and clubs attacked Gregg's residence on Oct. 13 to demand an end to alleged U.S. influence on the South Korean government and the withdrawal of U.S. troops. The attackers bolted past security guards and entered the residence, breaking lamps and artwork before they surrendered. Gregg and his wife, Meg, were unharmed in the attack. South Korea's radical students have staged violent anti-U.S. protests in recent years, attacking U.S. government and military facilities. American flags have been burned frequently during campus protests. Gregg, a former CIA station chief in Seoul, has been the target of several protests since he was appointed ambassador last year.

DOC.HEAD: American Comedian Discharged From Hospital
DOC.TEXT: A hospital today discharged actor and comedian Richard Pryor, who it had treated for a mild heart heart attack, doctors said. They said he would be returning to his home in Los Angeles. Pryor, 49, was readmitted to the Wesley Hospital on Monday after being discharged a day earlier. He suffered a heart attack while on a fishing vacation in northeastern Australia last week. American heart specialist John Perry flew from Los Angeles earlier this week to treat him. Dr. Perry said he recommended a discharge after Pryor passed cardiac tests. Pryor was first admitted a week ago for tests after experiencing chest pains while staying at the Sanctuary Cove resort on Australia's Gold Coast. Pryor is best-known for several movies based on his stand-up comedy performances and the comedies ``Silver Streak,'' ``See No Evil, Hear No Evil,'' ``Critical Condition'' and ``Harlem Nights.'' In 1980, he was burned severely and nearly died while free-basing cocaine, which involves heating the drug over an open flame. He recounted that experience and other hardships in his life in the films ``Richard Pryor Live on the Sunset Strip'' and ``Jo Jo Dancer, Your Life is Calling.'' Pryor is due to start filming ``My Silent Partner'' with Gene Wilder in May.

DOC.HEAD: WHO Finds Migrants Vulnerable to Disease
DOC.TEXT: Poor people migrating in search of food or opportunity in the Third World are finding that the journey can lead to a fate as cruel as poverty itself: infection with malaria or other severe disease. ``The process of development in itself can provoke outbreaks of tropical disease,'' says a new World Health Organization report on diseases in tropical regions. ``When people move to seek work, land and food or to flee wars or natural disasters, they can become exposed to tropical diseases to which they have no resistance, and epidemics break out,'' declared the report issued this week. A major example is Brazil, where ``the attempt to develop the Amazon is creating new breeding sites for malaria-carrying mosquitos,'' it said. ``As a result, poor workers, farmers, gold-seekers and miners in Brazil are suffering a devastating increase in malaria as they migrate to the jungle in search of land and work.'' Dr. Jose Najera, Spanish-born director of WHO's tropical disease control program, told a reporter Tuesday more than half of the malaria cases in the Americas are now in Brazil's Amazon region.
