He said major increases also have also been recorded in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Indochina, the scene of civil wars, ethnic conflicts and refugee concentrations, as well as parts of Africa. In contrast, India and China have achieved some successes against malaria, he said. Thailand, which has developed an anti-mosquito net costing about $2 and improved diagnostic and treatment facilities, reduced annual malaria deaths from 4,000 to 1,000 in the past decade. ``Tropical diseases were once considered diseases of the rural poor,'' Najera said. ``They still are, but now they are also closely associated with people's need to earn income, for example, with the recent massive migration from rural to urban areas, and with new irrigation and mining projects.'' This has prompted WHO workers to describe sicknesses such as malaria ``diseases of the new frontier of development ... which rob people of their hope of overcoming poverty,'' Najera said. Although malaria has been eradicated from areas inhabited by 1.5 billion people since the 1950s, it remains the most serious tropical disease because of its widespread distribution, and the emergence of mosquitoes resistant to insecticides and of malaria parasites to antimalarial drugs, the WHO said. At a given time an estimated 270 million people are carrying the malaria parasite, and about 110 million active cases appear a year, with symptoms of fever, shaking, chills and drenching sweat, Najera said. The annual death toll is 1-2 million, mainly young children in tropical Africa. For the first time in history the number of leprosy cases is declining, the report said, with 2.6 million patients undergoing or having completed treatment. In contrast to older treatments lasting a lifetime, the disease can be cured in six months to two years through use of three drugs, said Norwegian Tore Godal, director of the joint Tropical Diseases Research and Training Program of WHO, the World Bank and the U.N. Development Program. Other developments: River blindness, or onchocerciasis, has declined in West Africa through control of the blackflies that carry the parasite, and effectiveness of a new drug. In Uganda, simple fly traps, costing about $6 each, are curbing the population of tsetse flies, carrier of sleeping sickness, or African Trypanosomiasis. Control of the insect carrier is also reducing Chagas disease in Brazil. A drug called praziquantel has helped reduce some of the most serious effects of schistosomiasis disease, found in much of the southern hemisphere, such as massive swelling of liver and spleen and kidney damage.

DOC.HEAD: Juvenile Justice Conferees Discuss Gangs, Klan-Sponsored Punk Rock
DOC.TEXT: White racists who use heavy metal music to lure youths into the foul fold. Gangs for every ethnic group _ including Samoans. These were among the perils being discussed at a conference on juvenile delinquency. Some of the issues raised at the 17th National Conference on Juvenile Justice, which closes today, give the impression that America is not a great place to raise your kids. ``Gangs are coming to a community near you,'' Ronald Stephens, director of the National School Safety Center in Encino, Calif., told the conference on Tuesday. His center is a project of the U.S. Justice Department and Pepperdine University. The number of gangs are growing, Stephens said, with total membership exceeding 100,000 in the nation's three largest cities: Los Angeles has 800 gangs, Chicago 120 and New York 50. The average age of a gang member is 23. There's a gang for everyone: both sexes, many ages and every ethnic group, including Samoans, Stephens said. The members are violent, enterprising and often free of remorse, he said. ``Kids are coming into gangs at an earlier age and staying in a longer time,'' he said. ``Female activities are growing. Many are mules, carrying drugs or weapons.'' At the ``Gangs in School: Breaking Up is Hard to Do'' seminar, a Los Angeles Police Department videotape showed five teen-age girls as they fussed with their hair, put on eye makeup and giggled in front of a bedroom mirror. Then they traveled to a grassy field _ where the girls began pummeling one of their gangster sisters in an initiation ceremony. A New Jersey prosecutor said that skinheads, white supremacists and neo-Nazis are recruiting young members at rock concerts by groups like The Klansmen, Skrewdriver, The New Storm Troopers and Indecent Exposure. The Klansmen have an album entitled ``Fetch the Rope.'' ``There is a huge group of children out there learning their messages from heavy metal musicians, not from teachers, not from parents,'' said prosecutor Alan A. Rockoff of Middlesex County, N.J. Bias crimes in New Jersey have been affected by such communal hate groups, he said. ``The perpetrators of hate crimes do not just attack a human being. They attack the fabric of society,'' he said. ``Unfortunately these kids are looking for a sense of belonging ... and the only place they may find it is in gangs or hate groups,'' said Ernestine Gray, a juvenile court judge in Orleans Parish, La. She said the U.S. Justice Department has documented 5,000 hate crimes directed at minorities in the past decade. Rockoff said as New Jersey investigators explore the range of hate crimes, the common denominator is music that riles the worst instincts. ``In incident after incident, we find the evolution of the pollution. It is the lyrics that are designed to shock and create a triviality out of death, destruction,'' he said. Alienated teen-agers attracted to the dark symbolism of heavy metal music are sucked into a culture of intolerance, satanic images and anger, he said. Some become ripe for indoctrination by groups preaching Aryan supremacy that produce a raunchy form of music called boot boy, Rockoff said. Rockoff does not advocate censorship. ``We advocate protest, boycotting by aware parents and professionals. Why allow these people to make a buck polluting the minds of our children?'' Rockoff said. ``And secondly, exposure. Through exposure you create stigmatization.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Camp Officer Axed to Death
DOC.TEXT: Masked Palestinians armed with axes and knives killed a 32-year-old Arab U.N. worker and wounded six of his relatives in a West Bank refugee camp, the army and Arab reports said today. Arab reports said the slain man, identified as Yasser Kazmous, had been accused of collaboration with Israel in slogans painted on walls in the Nur Shams refugee camp, where he lived. They said more than 50 masked men participated in the raid and that they used a blowtorch to break into the family home Tuesday night. It was one of the bloodiest attacks involving a suspected collaborator in the 27-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The army confirmed the death and said police were investigating. The victim's 70-year-old father and a brother were reported in critical condition and four other family members were also hospitalized with stabbing and beating wounds, Arab hospital officials said. Kazmous was the 200th Palestinian killed by fellow Arabs since the uprising against Israeli occupation began in December 1987. Most were suspected of collaboration with Israel or of dealing in drugs or prostitution. A total of 669 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis in the 27-month-old conflict, and 43 Israelis have died. Officials at the U.N. Relief and Works Agency, which oversees refugee aid programs, said Kazmous was the agency's service officer in the Nur Shams camp and was responsible for supervising camp activities and processing applications for U.N. aid. The army spokesman's office said a curfew had been clamped on the camp this morning. Nur Shams, near the West Bank town of Tulkarem, is home to about 5,000 Palestinians. The U.N. officials, who asked not to be identified by name, said the attack on the Kazmous family was the second incident involving a U.N. worker. Last fall, a U.N. teacher accused of collaborating escaped from an armed Palestinian gang in a refugee camp near Jericho by throwing a grenade at his attackers. Also today, Israeli security agents used explosives to blow down the doors of two houses in the Jerusalem village of Jebel Mukabar and make arrests. Relatives said that Ibrahim Shkirat, 28, and his brother Mahmoud, 30, were detained. They said a cousin was taken into custody in a similar raid in a nearby village. The Shkirats are brothers of the late Ahmad Mishal Shkirat. He died of burns last May 4, four days after the car he was driving exploded near Jerusalem's central police compound. The vehicle was loaded with kerosene cans, but it was unclear at the time if the car was rigged to explode or the fire was accidental.

DOC.HEAD: Oscar Show Draws Lowest TV Ratings in 3 Years
DOC.TEXT: Oscar who? Hollywood's annual award gala drew its glitzy band of movie stars, directors and producers, but failed to lure a boffo TV audience, registering its weakest ratings in three years. Preliminary ratings figures released Tuesday by ABC showed the 62nd Academy Awards scored a 27.9 rating, meaning it was viewed in less than 26 million U.S. homes. The figures indicate that 48 percent of all television sets in use were tuned to the show, according the A.C. Nielsen Co. estimates. Last year's Oscars show, which featured a chancy duet between Rob Lowe and Snow White, was seen in nearly 27 million homes. The 1988 telecast also was more popular than Monday's edition. The broadcast was marred by an annoying sound glitch during a satellite feed from Moscow and was characterized by several on-screen comments critical of nomination omissions. Television critics were mostly kind in their reviews of the show, although some said it was too long and too conventional. The broadcast ran 3 hours, 34 minutes. Overseas segments also were shown from England, Japan, Australia and Argentina, designed to show the film industry's global influence. It was the longest show since the 1984 program, which ran 3 hours, 42 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Free Speech Gets Precedence In Alleged Breach With News Source
By TONY KENNEDY
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ruled that confidentiality agreements between reporters and sources must be explicit for courts to side with sources when they allege such pacts are broken. U.S. District Judge Harry MacLaughlin on Tuesday dismissed a lawsuit by a Minneapolis woman who complained that Glamour magazine went too far in identifying her in a story about sexual exploitation by therapists. MacLaughlin said the woman's agreement with writer Claudia Dreifus was ``too ambiguous to be enforced.'' The woman agreed to provide the magazine details of the sexual abuse she suffered during psychiatric therapy in 1979 and 1980, but she had asked not to be identified _ or identifiable _ in the story. Even though the September 1988 article gave the woman a fictitious last name, it went on to describe her as a Minneapolis lawyer and gave specifics about her activism on issues involving sexual abuse of patients by therapists. The woman sued Dreifus and Conde Nast Publishing Inc. for breach of contract. ``The court has no doubt that in balancing the rights of the free press with common contractual rights, the free press rights under the First Amendment must be given preference,'' MacLaughlin said. Dreifus had testified that the woman ``wanted some kind of masking,'' but ``was very casual about it.'' The judge said Dreifus honored the woman's only specific ``masking'' request by not describing problems she had at one of her previous jobs. The woman knows only two people who identified her from the article and they had been therapists for her, the judge said. The article portrayed the woman as ``someone who successfully recovered from an exploitative situation,'' MacLaughlin wrote. ``The `chilling effect' resulting from the possibility of protracted litigation and large damage awards, recognized by the Supreme Court in defamation actions, is also present in an action for breach of a reporter-source agreement,'' MacLaughlin wrote. To enforce reporter-source agreements in litigation, plaintiffs ``at a minimum'' must prove ``specific, unambiguous terms and to provide clear and convincing proof that the agreement was breached,'' MacLaughlin wrote. Elliot Rothenberg, the woman's attorney, said he is discussing with his client the possibility of an appeal. ``Newspapers and media must abide by the agreements they willingly enter into and the First Amendment does not absolve those obligations,'' he said. Rothenberg said that if he filed an appeal he would invoke the case of Dan Cohen, a Twin Cities public relations agent who won a breach of contract lawsuit against the Star Tribune and the St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch, which has since changed its name to Saint Paul Pioneer Press. The newspapers named Cohen as the person who leaked court documents in 1982 showing that a candidate for lieutenant governor had been convicted of shoplifting. Reporters promised Cohen confidentiality, but newspaper editors decided to name him because they believed the public had a right to know he worked for a rival gubernatorial candidate.

DOC.HEAD: City Council Approves Ordinances To Limit Cruising
DOC.TEXT: The city that inspired the film ``American Grafitti'' moved to shed its reputation as the Cruising Capital with a pair of ordinances trying to put the brakes on the pastime. The City Council unanimously approved the two rules Tuesday night after listening to testimony that ran nearly 3-1 against the proposals. Teen-agers, most of whom were born after the release of the 1973 film directed by George Lucas, a Modesto native, said they cruise popular McHenry Avenue in this central California city for the same reasons as their parents: to show off their cars and meet dates. ``I'm 17 years old and I've waited all my life to cruise,'' said Billy Moorehead. ``You can't get rid of us. We're going to stay.'' Under the ordinances, motorists passing specific checkpoints more than once in a four-hour period would face fines ranging from $75 to $250. Pedestrians, who routinely gather on sidewalks and in parking lots along the strip, would risk equal fines for loitering between 6 p.m. and 6 a.m. The ordinances, which require a second reading before becoming law, would be enforced only when traffic moved at less than 5 mph. ``My personal opinion is that moderate cruising will still exist along McHenry,'' said Police Chief Gerald McKinsey. The police department, which drafted the proposals, claims patrol officers can't reach trouble spots when cars clog the avenue many weekend nights. More than half of all assaults along McHenry Avenue and 78 percent of all drug arrests are made during the peak cruising hours, McKinsey said. Supporters of the rules contend that the pastime popularized in the 1950s is no longer good-natured when influenced by 1990s' problems: such as vandalism and drugs. They would rather it join sock hops as an object of nostalgia. ``The vandalism, drinking, drugs and prostitutes filter into our street and yards every weekend night,'' said Terry McCloskey. ``Many of us feel like prisoners in our own homes on weekend nights because we're afraid of what will happen to our property.'' Business owners taking up the anti-cruising side say they lose customers when the daily commuter corridor transforms into a cruising strip. ``Cruising has affected the quality of life on McHenry and for residents in a negative way,'' said Kyle Barker, a music store owner who organized the McHenry Avenue Merchants Association. ``Modesto, I don't think, wants to be known as the cruising mecca of the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Early Morning Freezing in Mid-Atantic; Snow in Rockies
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures dipped to below freezing early today along the mid-Atlantic states, and snow was falling in Denver and Casper, Wyo. Snow also was forecast today for much of Kansas, as cold weather pushed by northerly winds of 10 to 20 mph moved into the state from the Southwest. Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, and Richmond, Va., reported temperatures of 30 or lower today. In Portland, Maine, it was 16. Cold rain was expected across Kansas during the day, posing hazardous conditions for young livestock, the National Weather Service said. Thunderstorms late Tuesday were scattered across northeast Nevada. Rain and thunderstorms spread over eastern New Mexico, southwest Texas, eastern Colorado and southeast Wyoming. Rain fell from central and north central Texas across eastern and central Oklahoma into southeast Kansas. Snow was scattered across west central Wyoming. A high of 65 degrees Tuesday at Astoria, Ore., tied its record set in 1957. The nation's high Tuesday was 88 degrees at Fort Myers and Lakeland in Florida, and Parker, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Reporters at Daily News Authorize Strike
DOC.TEXT: The union for Daily News reporters voted to authorize a strike after being offered a proposal that would cut benefits and extend the work week, while increasing wages. The members of Local 3 of the Newspaper Guild voted 267 to 19 Tuesday to authorize their leaders to call a strike. ``Hopefully, this will let them know that the people who work at the News weren't thrilled'' with the contract proposal, said Larry Sutton, a reporter and member of the Guild negotiating committee. The News has said it will advertise for replacement workers for any union that authorizes a strike and said Tuesday it would do so for the Guild workers. On Monday, 2,000 people responded to ads for mailers jobs. ``The union leaders' knee-jerk rejection of a 30 percent wage increase is a grave disservice to their members,'' said John T. Sloan, the News' vice president for human resources. The Guild and nine other unions at the News are negotiating for new contracts. The old ones expire at midnight Friday, but all sides expect to continue talking beyond then. Management and the unions consider these talks the most important in the history of the tabloid, which has antiquated printing equipment and which management says is losing money. The News offered the reporters raises of 10 percent for each of three years. At the proposed contract's end, journalists with six years' experience would be earning $1,343 a week, higher than those earned now by any unionized reporters in the country. But union leaders complain that other provisions in the proposed contract will eliminate severance pay and cut back the health and pension plan. Union leaders said the proposed contract extends the work week by three hours to 37.5 hours, an increase in hours of 8.7 percent. They also said the proposed contract fails to guarantee a daily or weekly wage. Barry Lipton, president of Local 3, attacked the company's proposal to eliminate what he said would be $22 million in severance pay and have unlimited use of part-time employees.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Issue Caution on Lasers to Unclog Arteries
DOC.TEXT: A ``Star Wars'' medical mentality has bolstered the use of lasers to unclog blocked arteries, but other methods appear to be more effective and less costly, radiologists said. Doctors meeting here Tuesday for the Society of Cardiovascular and Intervention Radiology conference also said studies show the laser method increases the chances of patient complications. The radiologists issued the caution after surveying the 1,300 members attending. Several papers were submitted comparing lasers to the more common balloon angioplasty, in which plastic balloons are pushed through an artery to clear obstruction. The papers showed ``lasers actually have results that are somewhat poorer'' than the balloons when used in partially clogged arteries, said Dr. Arina van Breda, an associate professor of radiology at George Washington University in Washington. ``Lasers should not be considered to have any proven efficacy,'' said van Breda, program director for the society. ``They should be considered experimental and patients should be forewarned.'' The doctors said there are some situations in which lasers should be used _ chiefly when the blood vessel is completely blocked, preventing the insertion of a balloon. But they said lasers should be used only for backup, not as a primary treatment. Van Breda said patients are attracted by the idea of lasers, which sound more advanced than balloon angioplasty. ``People think that since they are high-tech, very expensive and very sexy, they must work _ it's kind of a Star Wars medical mentality,'' she said. Dr. Daniel Choy, who heads the St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital Center laser laboratory at Columbia University in New York, said he did not totally disagree with the findings. ``Certainly, laser angioplasty is still experimental,'' Choy said. ``But I don't think lasers by any means are dead _ they are being constantly improved.'' He said lasers must improve their reclosure rate if they are to ever supplant or even complement balloon angioplasty, and said new techniques _ including the use of ``smart lasers'' which can make application more specific _ aimed to do just that. Dr. Robert Hewes of the Kettering Medical Center in Ohio said his studies showed laser-opened blood vessels could have been wiened by simpler, less costly balloon angioplasty _ and at only about a third of the cost. In addition, lasers require an operating room and general anesthesia, raising costs and the odds of complications, he said. Also, the hot-tipped laser itself can actually damage the vessel lining, which can cause it to close again, he said. Hewes and his associate, Dr. Ted Miller, compared 42 laser angioplasties by vascular surgeons with 32 balloon angioplasties by interventional radiologists during the same period. The laser cases had a 19 percent complication rate, compared to 3 percent for radiologists. And they showed a 50 percent success rate vs. 94 percent for the balloon procedure.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I don't know what it is ... It was just luck he had to have some dental work and it was just luck they administered the drugs.'' _ Dr. Andres Kanner, a neurologist with the University of Wisconsin Hospital, explaining how a man in a coma-like, vegetative state for eight years awoke after taking tranquilizers.

``We cannot police every aspect of the industry, cannot crawl through the belly of every aircraft, look over the shoulder of every pilot, or personally screen every passenger and every piece of luggage that flies in the system.'' Federal Aviation Administration chief James B. Busey announcing a new policy in which airlines will not be fined for safety violations if the carriers find a problem themselves and report it to the government.

``You never use up all your bullets in the first assault.'' _ Ariel Ricardo, spokesman at the Cuban diplomatic mission in Washington, leaving little doubt that additional measures are planned against the United States after Cuba jammed the first broadcast of TV Marti.

DOC.HEAD: Billy Crystal's Oscar Joke Draws Italian-American Ire
DOC.TEXT: Two Italian-American organizations found little humor in comic Billy Crystal's Italian joke during the Academy Awards ceremony, and complained to ABC about it. Crystal, host for the 62nd annual awards ceremony broadcast on ABC, quipped that the proposed purchase of MGM by an Italian businessman meant the famous lion would no longer roar at the start of the movie but instead plead the Fifth Amendment. ``It was a cheap-shot joke against Italian-Americans,'' said a release from the Coaltion of Italo-American Organizations. ``There is a fine line between ethnic humor and negative stereotyping. We feel (you) crossed that line.'' The National Italian American Organization joined in the complaint, according to the Daily News. Coalition chairman William Fugazy said he been ``inundated'' with calls from his membership outraged at the joke. In a cable to Capital Cities@ABC chairman Thomas Murphy, Fugazy called Crystal's comments ``insensitive and inane,'' and said the crowd at the ceremony ``clearly rebelled at Crystal's prejudicial remarks.'' Crystal could not be reached immedately for comment. He also joked that the Japanese owners of another film studio wanted to make a romantic script of his into a Godzilla movie.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Completed; Trial Recessed Until April 3
DOC.TEXT: A jury that includes three postal workers will consider charges that former Philippine first lady Imelda Marcos helped in the alleged plunder of her country's treasury. The 12-person panel was sworn in late Tuesday for Mrs. Marcos' trial in Manhattan's federal court, and Judge John F. Keenan recessed the trial until April 3 when lawyers will present opening arguments. Her co-defendant is Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi. The jury also includes two transit workers, two utility employees, a retired secretary, a teacher's aide, an engineer, a computer operator and an estate manager with a law firm. In a written decision released Tuesday, the judge ruled that bank records from Hong Kong, Singapore and the Philippines could be used as evidence against Mrs. Marcos. Her lawyers had sought to block the foreign bank documents, but Keenan decided they were admissible because prosecutors had filed the proper certification. Keenan said he would rule on the admissibility of documents from Italy, Switzerland and West Germany before the trial's opening arguments. Among the documents allowed as evidence were 2,000 pages of records from two trust accounts at the Standard Chartered Bank of Hong Kong, which prosecutors alleged were controlled by Mrs. Marcos and her late husband, Ferdinand. Keenan said the government will use the trust account records to try to establish that the Marcoses owned three Panamanian companies that, in turn, owned a building at 40 Wall St. The building is among four Manhattan properties which prosecutors claim the Marcoses bought with more than $160 million allegedly stolen from the Manila government. The Singapore bank records relate to the alleged transfer of millions of dollars for the purchase of 40 Wall St., the judge's decision said. The other records found admissible were from the Traders Royal Bank in Manila. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is charged with racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. If convicted, she faces up to 50 years in prison and $1 million in fines. Khashoggi is accused of helping the Marcoses conceal the New York real estate deals. He faces up to 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines if convicted of mail fraud and obstruction of justice. The trial is expected to last three to four months.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Names Envoy to Hungary
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II today named the papal envoy to Colombia as the Holy See's first ambassador to Hungary in 45 years. Relations between Hungary and the Vatican, broken when the government expelled the papal envoy in 1945, were re-established in February. John Paul appointed Archbishop Angelo Acerbi, 64, an Italian serving in Colombia, to the post. Hungary was the second Soviet bloc country to re-establish ties with the Holy See after the pope's native Poland did so in July. This month, the Vatican and the Soviet Union established official ties, but they fall short of formal diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEAD: Injured Singer Gloria Estefan Up, Walking
DOC.TEXT: Singer Gloria Estefan was up and walking without the aid of crutches or a cane, a week after undergoing surgery for spinal injuries suffered when her band bus collided with a truck on a snowy road. ``She's doing really well,'' said Evelyn Torres, spokeswoman for the Orthopedic Hospital for Joint Diseases. ``Her spirits are up, and there's no paralysis at all.'' Torres said Tuesday that the 32-year-old singer would spend another five days in the hospital. Miss Estefan, star of the Miami Sound Machine, handed out presents sent to her by fans and well wishers to other patients. She suffered two broken vertebrae in the March 21 crash in eastern Pennsylvania. Doctors implanted steel rods to support her back.

DOC.HEAD: Landlord Tried to Evict Happy Land Social Club
With PM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to add rent figures for Happy Land and La Salsa and to delete description of ex-girlfriend's job at club as selling tickets because duties apparently varied. Picks up 15th graf, `Neighborhood residents...'
DOC.TEXT: Authorities had warned the owners of the building that housed the Happy Land Social Club that it was riddled with violations, including no sprinkler system on the first floor, where the fire started. Notice of the fire code violations, which also included an illegally added-on second floor, no second exit and no fire alarms, were sent to Alex DiLorenzo III, the owner, building Commissioner Charles Smith Jr. told The New York Times in today's editions. DiLorenzo leased the building to Jay Weiss, husband of actress Kathleen Turner, who in turn leased the building to club manager Elias Colon. Colon was among the 87 people who died in the fire Sunday. Normally, the violations report would have been forwarded by the owner to the leaseholder, but Weiss' attorneys said they never received a formal notice of the violations. They would not comment on whether they knew of them. Prosecutors are looking into whether the building's landlords or owners might bear responsibility for the fire. Police alleged it was set by Julio Gonzalez, in a jealous rage against his ex-girlfriend, who worked at the club. The club was incorporated in 1988 as a not-for-profit corporation for ``the purpose of providing for members entertainment, sport, recreation and amusement of all kinds,'' the Times reported. The incorporation papers appeared to enable Colon to avoid filing state and city income tax forms, the Times said. Weiss had been trying to evict the Happy Land Social Club for non-payment of rent since September, according to Weiss' lawyer, Roger Boyle. A lease signed by Happy Land on Oct. 7, 1987, called for monthly rents of $1,500 for the first year, $1,650 for the second and $1,950 for the third. Court papers concerning the rent squabble show that on Feb. 15, 1989, a process server stuck a notice on the door of Happy Land demanding $3,074 within three days for rent payments allegedly due since Dec. 1, 1987. Weiss' company, One Peach Associates, asked a marshal to obtain an eviction notice on Sept. 6, 1989, according to the papers. A judge validated the eviction warrant the next week and then Colon filed to stop the proceedings, saying he had not seen the court papers. Colon maintained in an affidavit that all his rent had been paid. A judge granted a stay of the eviction warrant. Papers filed on March 12 assert that Colon ``made substantial improvements to the premises with the approval and consent of the petitioner.'' The case was to have been tried today. One Peach also leased space to La Salsa, another after-hours club around the corner from Happy Land, for $2,500 a month, the Daily News said in today's editions. Neighborhood residents said La Salsa has one door and no windows. Because of fire code violations, it had been ordered closed on Aug. 28, 1988, the News reported. La Salsa was packed with revelers on the night of the fire at Happy Land.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Seeks Court Ruling on Obscenity Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Nine of...', to ADD number of photographs in show.
DOC.TEXT: A museum planning to exhibit sexually explicit photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe has taken the unusual step of asking a court to decide whether they violate local obscenity laws. The private Contemporary Arts Center hopes to forestall the sheriff's threat to file obscenity charges against the museum when it opens the six-week exhibit April 6. Sheriff Simon Leis, a veteran anti-smut campaigner, has called some of the pictures ``criminally obscene'' and said he will take action against the exhibit if police do not. Nine of the 175 photographs in the show depict homosexual activity and sadomasochistic sex acts. The pictures led Congress last year to limit federal support for the arts after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., labeled them obscene. The museum Tuesday filed a petition for a jury trial in Municipal Court. A trial date was not immediately set. Museum officials said they expected a ruling before the exhibit opens. ``It may be unorthodox for the person displaying the material to initiate this action, but in this case it is the common-sense thing to do,'' said Marc Mezibov, a lawyer for the museum. The show is an attempt to broaden artistic horizons in a city that has closed every adult bookstore and prosecuted publisher Larry Flynt for distributing Hustler magazine, museum officials said. ``I think there are people in the community who are a little embarrassed about the community's tendency to cave in to censorship,'' said Jack Sawyer, curator at the center. Chad Wick resigned last week as the chairman of the board of the Contemporary Arts Center, saying opponents of the exhibit were exerting heavy pressure on his employer, the Central Trust Co. Last summer, the private Corcoran Gallery in Washington canceled an exhibit of the Mapplethorpe photos, but they were later shown at the Washington Project for the Arts and appeared without incident in Philadelphia; Chicago; Boston; Hartford, Conn., and Berkeley, Calif. ``The city of Cincinnati police department has jurisdiction if the pictures are exhibited downtown, but if they fail to do what should be done, I will do it myself,'' said Leis. Leis, then county prosecutor, prosecuted Flynt in 1977 on charges of pandering obscenity. Flynt was convicted, but an appeals court in 1979 ordered a new trial. A new prosecutor dropped the charges in 1985. The museum director, Dennis Barrie, arranged for the exhibit after seeing Mapplethorpe's photographs in New York City in 1988, before they sparked controversy in Congress. ``I thought it was absolutely the most stunning photographic show I'd seen in years,'' Barrie said. ``There was no doubt in my mind that for this community and even for any community some of the work would be controversial, especially the work that dealt with his homosexual lifestyle. But, on the whole, the show was so overwhelmingly beautiful.'' The exhibit of Mapplethorpe's works also include pictures of marble sculpture, dramatically lighted flowers and portraits of bodybuilder Lisa Lyons and artists Andy Warhol and Laurie Anderson. Mapplethorpe died of AIDS in March 1989. Because of the uproar over the Corcoran Gallery exhibit, Congress approved a 1990 appropriation to the National Endowment for the Arts that forbids support of homoerotic or sadomasochistic art or depictions of sex acts. The Contemporary Arts Center is using no government money on the $50,000 exhibition. It will rely on ticket sales and a $10,000 grant from a local video production company, Barrie said. Barrie said the museum will put sexually explicit photographs in a separate gallery with a prominently displayed warning. People under age 18 will not be admitted without an adult.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Try to Halt Widespread Black Faction Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs to UPDATE number of deaths, new quotes, details on fighting. Pickup 16th graf, `Efforts by...'
DOC.TEXT: Rival Zulu factions armed with guns and knives waged bloody battles and set homes ablaze in Natal province today, while hundreds of soldiers and police moved in to halt their ``full-scale war.'' Terrified residents in black townships near the southeastern city of Pietermaritzburg abandoned their homes and fled into the countryside, residents said. ``It almost looks as though the whole area is burning,'' police Maj. Piet Kitching said. Army units were deployed around Edendale near Pietermaritzburg after 2,000 Zulus supporting the Inkatha party attacked supporters of the rival United Democratic Front. Police said patrols used shotguns and tear gas to disperse mobs attacking and burning houses. Police reported widespread clashes in the area since Tuesday, with at least two people dead and about 25 wounded in the fighting. But local reporters, who did not want to be named, said up to 14 people had been killed and scores of houses set on fire in townships around Edendale, in Natal province. Tens of thousands of people were unable to go to work, when the bus service shut down because of attacks, and the milling crowds added to the tension. ``Things are completely out of control. It looks terrible. There were 2,000 people fighting it out with guns and other weapons,'' said a journalist reached by phone. ``It's a bloody war out there,'' a medical worker said. Peter Kerchhoff, of a Pietermaritzburg peace group, said dirt roads leading to townships were blockaded with tree tunks, boulders, and burning tires; people were fleeing with pieces of furniture, and houses were burning in several townships. As his group drove through the crowds taking four injured to the hospital Kerchhoff said: ``People were saying, `Please, we need guns.''' ``There are reports of a full-scale war. Thousands of people are moving up to defend an area and thousands are moving down to attack,'' said Radley Keys, a community worker. Zulus went on the rampage in the area after opponents stoned buses and other vehicles returning Sunday from a Zulu rally, police said. Police said Zulus hijacked buses to truck in hundreds of armed youths for the fighting. Hundreds of people have been killed in black factional fighting in recent weeks in Natal. The Zulu tribe's Inkatha movement is fighting the UDF for control of the region. Both groups are anti-apartheid, but Inkatha supports separate states for different tribes or ethnic groups. The UDF wants a black majority government ruling all of South Africa. Several local leaders charged police were aiding Inkatha fighters, giving them ammunition and helping them attack rival UDF fighters. The leaders were appealing to government officials to force police to act impartially. Pierre Cronje, a white member of Parliament of the opposition Democratic Party, said he was furious because police were merely ``scolding'' armed Inkatha men instead of trying to confiscate their weapons and disperse them. Police commanders had no immediate response to the charges. Residents said hundreds of troops were seen near Edendale. An army spokesman, Col. John Rolt, said troops had been sent to the area to aid police but gave no further details. Efforts by Nelson Mandela and other black leaders to end the fighting have failed despite extensive appeals for peace. In other developments, President F.W. de Klerk said in Parliament in Cape Town on Tuesday night that a date could not be set for ending apartheid laws. He said the government wanted to move as quickly as possible, but the issue was linked to pending talks on ending white-minority rule. The government is to meet with the African National Congress April 11 to try to clear the way for talks on sharing political power with blacks.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Newspaper Criticizes Hungarian Airline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev adviser saying Arabs exaggerating issue. Pickup 8th graf, `In Leningrad...' ADDS 2 grafs at end with Shamir quotes. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A prestigious Soviet newspaper today criticized Hungary's state airline for suspending flights of Soviet Jews to Israel last week, calling the decision capitulation to international terrorism. ``I see it as my duty to decisively condemn such an action,'' political commentator Igor Belyayev said in the weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta. It was the first known Soviet condemnation of the decision by the carrier, Malev, to suspend service to Tel Aviv after a threat from Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, an Arab extremist group. The article did not, however, mention the position taken by the Soviet national airline Aeroflot, which has stopped selling tickets for Soviet Jewish emigres traveling to Hungary. Belyayev said there appeared to be a genuine threat to Malev passengers' security but added ``reconciliation with the Islamic Jihad's provocation amounts to indecisiveness in the fight against international terrorism.'' Up to 750,000 Jews are expected to emigrate to Israel in the next few years as the result of relaxed rules in the Soviet Union and tighter entry quotas in the United States. The expected influx has angered Arab leaders, who fear Palestinians will be displaced by the new arrivals. A Kuwaiti newspaper today quoted a senior adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as saying that Arabs are exaggerating the issue of Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel. Georgy Arbatov, a member of the Central Committee and director of the United States and Canada Institute, also predicted in an interview with Al-Watan that the number of Soviet Jews going to Israel ``will be on the retreat.'' In Leningrad, 13 Jews held a demonstration and a hunger strike at the Hungarian Consulate, demanding immediate transportation or compensation for those who had Malev tickets, as well as a public apology, said Abraham Demin, an activist who participated in the protest Tuesday. Hungarian officials later pledged rapid transportation of the emigres who have bought Malev tickets and said they would be taken by trains, buses or Aeroflot planes, he said. Hungarian Minister of State Imre Pozsgay has said Malev is independent of the ``party-state'' and that the government hoped it would reconsider its decision and resume flights to Israel. On Tuesday, the Bush administration expressed disappointment at the Malev move and urged Hungary to reconsider and a group of U.S. Jewish leaders met with a senior Foreign Ministry official to express concern about the steps taken by Aeroflot and Malev, the mission's leader said. Marvin Lander, national chairman-elect of the United Jewish Appeal, said representatives of some 140 U.S. Jewish leaders visiting Moscow met with Yuri Reshetov, head of the Foreign Ministry's department of international humanitarian cooperation and human rights. ``We expressed to him our great concern over response of the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries to terrorist threats. We hope these governments would not cave in,'' Lander said. He said Reshetov ``could not answer'' questions about Aeroflot, and that Soviet officials ``continue to point the finger at the Hungarians.'' ``Obviously what took place last week is of great concern to us,'' Lander said. ``This is certainly a roadbock to the emigration of thousands and thousands of Soviet Jews to Israel. We hope it's only temporary.'' Jewish leaders worldwide, concerned about rising Russian nationalism and anti-Semitism, fear a pogrom of Soviet Jews and are urging all measures to expedite their emigration. Polish leaders have said their country is ready to provide assistance for the emigrants. Some Jews are flying to Israel via the Romanian capital of Bucharest and many others are traveling to Budapest by train to get on Israeli El Al planes. In Jerusalem, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today lashed out at Arab threats against Soviet Jews headed for Israel and derided Western leaders as ``gullible'' for accepting Arab claims of moderation toward the Jewish state. ``Let the world open its ears and its eyes to the Arab threats to blow up planes that carry Jewish immigrants,'' Shamir said.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister Warns U.S. Not to Impose Trade Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: The foreign minister said today that Chinese-U.S. relations will suffer if President Bush imposes trade sanctions on China to protest Beijing's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators last year. The minister, Qian Qichen, also demanded that Fang Lizhi, a dissident living in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, ``plead guilty'' to charges of counterrevolutionary activities. Fang, a leading astrophysicist and intellectual, was granted sanctuary at the embassy in June after the military crushed pro-democracy student demonstrations, killing at least 500 people. Members of Congress have called for economic sanctions against China because of the continued suppression of political dissent following the June crackdown. Qian said that an end to most-favored-nation status for China, ``will undoubtedly greatly impair the trade relations between our two countries, thus causing a major retrogression in our relations.'' He called on the United States to ``make a wise decision'' and avoid harming relations. President Bush must inform Congress by June 3 whether to renew the 1980 agreement granting most-favored-nation status to China. Congress has three months to override his decision. The United States is China's third biggest trading partner after Hong Kong and Japan. The loss of most-favored-nation status would result in substantially higher tariffs on Chinese imports to the United States. Qian said his government will not allow the pro-democracy movement sweeping through the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe to spread to China. He said China has ``every reason to guard'' against reformers who are trying to alter its socialist system.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Social Club Fire, 3rd Ld - Writethru, a0507,0815
DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Build Case Against Suspect, Investigate Building Ownership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-10, `It's unfortunate...', with three grafs to ADD attribution on quote and Turner's comment through publicist. Picks up 11th graf, `Among those...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors intend to use a pair of gasoline-soaked sneakers and a hunk of dance floor to help make their case against a man charged with setting the fire that killed 87 people in a social club. A grand jury Tuesday began hearing evidence against 36-year-old Julio Gonzalez, charged with 87 murders in the blaze at the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx. Police said he set the fire early Sunday after being snubbed by an ex-girlfriend who worked there. ``We'll have a made case even if he backs out of the confession,'' said Edward McCarthy, spokesman for the Bronx prosecutor's office. Gonzalez was transferred Tuesday to a prison unit within the psychiatric ward at Bellevue Hospital, where a fellow inmate said he raged for hours against his ex-girlfriend. ``He is so emotionally distraught that tears keep coming down,'' the inmate, Louis Cuascut, said in today's New York Post. ``He seems very, very depressed.'' The Happy Land club had been ordered closed for fire and safety code violations and the landlord was trying to evict the owner for non-payment of rent. The building that housed the illegal club was subleased to the club's operator by a company co-owned by actress Kathleen Turner's husband, Jay Weiss. He leased it from one of New York's biggest landlords, Alex DiLorenzo III. Turner said she was shocked by the fire but that her husband wasn't to blame. ``It's unfortunate that it was that building but the fact is that you can even throw a firebomb into McDonald's and it would have had the same result,'' Turner said outside her Manhattan apartment, the Post reported today. The actress, starring in a Broadway revival of ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' said she was afraid that people would come to her home seeking vengeance. Turner also said Tuesday through her publicist, ``This is an act of a violent madman. It's a tragedy. It doesn't reflect on me or my husband.'' Among those scheduled to testify against Gonzalez are his ex-girlfriend, Lydia Feliciano, a worker at the club; and the man who sold Gonzalez the $1 worth of gasoline he allegedly used to start the blaze. ``And then we have the container that held the gasoline, his sneakers, which were soaked with gasoline,'' McCarthy said. ``We even cut up a hunk of the floor and brought it in to prove the burn pattern was caused by gasoline.'' District Attorney Robert Johnson said Gonzalez gave police a videotaped statement in which he admitted that he torched the Happy Land in a pique against Ms. Feliciano. Besides Ms. Feliciano, four other people escaped the inferno. Authorities had warned DiLorenzo that Happy Land was riddled with violations, including an illegally added second floor, no sprinklers on the first floor, no second exit and no fire alarms, Building Commissioner Charles Smith Jr. said in today's New York Times. Normally the violations report would have been forwarded by the owner to the leaseholder, but Weiss' attorneys said they never received a formal notice of the violations. They would not comment on whether they knew of them. Weiss, through his lawyer Roger Boyle, said Tuesday that One Peach Associates, a company he owns with Morris Jaffe, leased the building in 1985 from DiLorenzo's Clarendon Place Corp. One Peach two years later leased the club to its operator, Elias Colon, for up to $1,950 a month. Boyle said that since last spring the company had been trying to evict Colon for not paying rent. The case was to have been heard in court today. Colon died in the fire. One Peach also leased space to a second after-hours club, called La Salsa, around the corner from Happy Land, for $2,500 a month, the Daily News reported today. Neighborhood residents said La Salsa, too, was packed with revelers Saturday night. The club has one door and no windows. Because of fire code violations, it had been ordered to close in August 1988. Because many of the fire victims were poor Honduran immigrants, 10 airlines have offered to ship the remains free from Miami to Honduras, said Larry Mackler, a spokesman for the American Red Cross. The Red Cross plans to fly next-of-kin back as well to make funeral arrangements.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Donations to provide burials for the victims and counseling for their families should be earmarked ``Bronx disaster'' and sent to: American Red Cross P.O. Box 9131, Church Street Station New York, N.Y., 10256

DOC.HEAD: Maryland Town Forgotten Again By Census
DOC.TEXT: In 1980, the Census Bureau's computers apparently balked at the name Secretary, and the town got no survey forms. This year, the town's population of about 550 is again waiting. ``It's a very unfortunate coincidence,'' said Marilyn Stant, manager of the census district office in Salisbury. Stant said Secretary eventually was counted after the last census and will be counted this year too. As for why the town's 295 post office boxes have yet to get the forms sent nationwide last week, the cause is not clear. ``There were one or two ZIP codes where the post office had its own little mix-up. No system is absolutely perfect,'' Stant said. Ron Kern, the Postal Service's Eastern Shore census coordinator in Wilmington, Del., said Secretary ``was one of the small towns we didn't receive any mailings for. If they don't provide us the forms, we can't deliver them.'' ``We still look for them in the mail every day,'' said Walter Collins, mayor of the Warwick River town. ``We've had quite a bit of population growth in the last two years. I'd like to get them all filled out and see what the town's doing.''

DOC.HEAD: Defense Consultant Pleads Guilty to Bribing Pentagon Officials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 3, Galvin, 59, and inserts graf 9, Neither Paisley, with further background.
DOC.TEXT: Defense consultant William M. Galvin pleaded guilty today to charges he bribed an assistant Navy secretary and another senior Pentagon official to influence the award of defense contracts. Galvin, a major figure in the Justice Department's investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud dubbed ``Operation Ill Wind,'' pleaded guilty to conspiracy, bribery and tax evasion. Galvin, 59, admitted that he, Assistant Navy Secretary Melvyn R. Paisley and two Israeli businessmen conspired to influence the award of a Navy contract to guide remote-controlled drone aircraft. Paisley resigned from the Pentagon in 1987 to become a defense consultant. As part of the deal, Galvin, Paisley and the two Israeli businessmen were to split $2 million that an Israeli company, Mazlat, would place in a Swiss bank account, according to court papers. Paisley ordered the Navy to purchase a ground station for the aircraft drones that was produced by Mazlat, according to the court documents. Paisley issued the order when the Navy was about to purchase electronic equipment for the pilotless remote-controlled aircraft from another company. Six days after Paisley signed the directive, the company placed $50,000 in the Swiss account, according to the court papers. In all, the company put $268,000 into the Swiss account to be split by Paisley, Galvin and the businessmen, Mazlat President Zvi Schiller and consultant Uri Simhoni, according to the documents. Galvin additionally admitted that he conspired to bribe Victor D. Cohen, a senior civilian Air Force procurement officer, to influence the award of radar electronics contracts to Loral Corp. Neither Paisley nor Cohen has been charged in the continuing investigation. Galvin agreed to cooperate with the probe, which has produced 35 convictions in the last two years. As part of the plea agreement, Galvin agreed to pay back taxes and interest that he failed to report on his income tax forms totaling $647,548. U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton scheduled sentencing for Aug. 3. Galvin could be sentenced to up to four years in prison and fined as much as $1 million on his guilty pleas to two counts of bribery, conspiracy and tax evasion.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Praises Apology By Clayton Williams
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush says an insensitive remark by Clayton Williams won't deter her and President Bush from campaigning on behalf of the Republican gubernatorial nominee. Mrs. Bush, who was inducted into the Texas Women's Hall of Fame on Tuesday, said she is proud Williams apologized for a remark he made over the weekend about rape. At a rain-delayed cattle roundup Saturday in west Texas, Williams compared the weather to rape, saying, ``If it's inevitable, just relax and enjoy it.'' Williams has apologized, saying the remark was ``insensitive and had no place at the campfire or in any setting.'' Mrs. Bush said Williams is ``quite a person to speak up immediately and apologize and say he made a mistake. I'm proud of him and that's the last I'm going to say about it.'' Mrs. Bush was inducted into the Texas Women's Hall of Fame at its sixth annual awards ceremony with seven others. The first lady also received a special achievement award for community service in Texas and throughout the nation. Henceforth, the annual award will be known as the ``Barbara Bush Award,'' it was announced.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Ministers Face Grilling by Legislature
DOC.TEXT: Government ministers today for the first time faced a public parliamentary grilling on topics ranging from chronic food shortages to a foiled scheme to sell tanks abroad. The appearance of the ministers before the Supreme Soviet marked another step toward making appointed officials subordinate to the elected legislature, as envisaged in the perestroika program of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Previously, ministers had faced organized questioning only once, at their confirmation hearings last summer. Most of the heat fell on economic ministers who were asked to explain why an economic revival plan adopted three months ago had failed to produce tangible results. Vladilen Nikitin, first deputy chairman of the Council of Ministers, said the growth in the rate of food production shrank by more than 50 percent between 1988 and 1989, and that the growth of processing capacities was running far behind demand. ``Moving up the introduction of regulated market relations is the only way out of a very difficult situation,'' Tass quoted him as saying. Deputy Premier Alexandra Biryukova, who is also a candidate member of the Politburo, was quizzed for 90 minutes about shortages of consumer goods. She said production of consumer goods had increased 6 percent in January and February compared with the same period last year. But, she said, targets for some types of goods were not reached. Mrs. Biryukova blamed the shortfalls on instability in the country, including strikes and work stoppages because of political demonstrations. Igor Byelousov, chief of the Soviet military-industrial complex, was then grilled about a foiled scheme to sell a dozen Soviet tanks to the West. The plan surfaced in January and involved the ANT cooperative, which acquired the tanks from a factory and was trying to transport the sophisticated T-72 tanks to an unidentified buyer in Europe. The scheme was uncovered and foiled by the military. ``Byelousov was asked many loaded questions about the recent deal of the ANT state-cooperative enterprise, which tried to export tanks illegally,'' Tass said. ``The case is being investigated, but the deputy prime minister's answers did not dispel the deputies' concern.'' The news agency said the deputies wanted to know the responsbility not only of low-level officials involved, ``but also of those in high places who authorized it.'' Among some 60 observers at the Supreme Soviet session was Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., who was on a visit to the Soviet Union. ``I thought the questions were informed, intelligent, good responses, a lively exchange, and I think the whole political institution is being re-examined,'' Kennedy said after the session. But Tass said the first quizzing of ministers fell short of expectations. ``Some questions were too general, while some answers were too vague,'' the news agency quoted critics in the legislature as saying. It said Cabinet officers had received about 140 written questions from deputies.

DOC.HEAD: 21 Officers Ordered Court-Martialed For Roles in Failed Coup
DOC.TEXT: The military today ordered two generals and 19 other officers to stand trial for participating in December's coup attempt against President Corazon Aquino. Gen. Renato de Villa, the military chief of staff, issued the order after military investigators ruled there was sufficient evidence to court-martial the 21 officers for mutiny, murder and conduct unbecoming of an officer, said army spokesman Col. Juanito Rimando. No date was set for the trials, but de Villa ordered a judge advocate, Gen. Manuel Casaclang, to expedite the proceedings, Rimando said. The December coup attempt was the bloodiest of the six armed attempts to topple Mrs. Aquino since she took office in the 1986 ``people power'' uprising against the late Ferdinand Marcos. At least 113 people were killed and more than 600 were wounded before the fighting ended. Those charged included Brig. Gen. Marcelo Blando and Brig. Gen. Jose Commendador. Commendador took over an air base near the central city of Cebu, 350 miles southeast of Manila. It was the last position surrendered by the mutineers. Blando led mutinous Scout Rangers from the central province of Nueva Ecija but surrendered to government forces one day after the coup attempt was launched on Dec. 1. The other officers ordered to stand trial include three colonels, seven lieutenant colonels, three majors, five captains and a first lieutenant.

DOC.HEAD: Jamming Likely to be the First of Several Retaliatory Measures by Cuba
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 3rd graf, Broadcasting resumed ... to UPDATE with today's broadcasts; picks up 3rd graf pvs, The emphasis ...
DOC.TEXT: Cuba is expected to take additional measures against the United States in retaliation for U.S.-sponsored television programming to the island, producing further setbacks to the already strained relationship. After Cuban authorities jammed the initial broadcasts of TV Marti on Tuesday, the State Department expressed regret but said transmissions will continue. Broadcasting resumed this morning at 3:45 a.m. EST, but Cuban authorities jammed the signal within three minutes, a Voice of America official said. The programming went off the air at 6:45 a.m. The emphasis was on entertainment as testing began Tuesday, but a primary goal of the station is to provide objective news to a country that the administration says has received none in 31 years. The station is a pet project of conservative elements of the Cuban exile community in Florida, and Cuban officials have told U.S. diplomats that exiles may be a target of Cuban retaliation. Possible measures include a suspension of air and telephone links between the United States and Cuba _ services that exiles heavily depend on. TV Marti is modeled after Radio Marti, which some employees fear will be the next target of Cuban jamming. The station has been broadcasting relatively free of interference since going on the air in 1985. There also is the possibility that Cuba may try to interfere with domestic U.S. stations. Last Friday, Cuba broadcast a radio speech by President Fidel Castro that disrupted stations along the Florida coast and as far away as Nashville, Tenn. Ariel Ricardo, spokesman at the Cuban diplomatic mission in Washington, left little doubt that additional measures are planned beyond jamming. ``You never use up all your bullets in the first assault,'' he said, charging that the station violates international law. Gillian Gunn, a Cuba specialist at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said, ``The administration should not be lulled into believing that Cuba won't retaliate more vigorously.'' U.S.-Cuban relations have generally deteriorated in recent months and the introduction of TV Marti leaves prospects for improvement even bleaker. Castro has been warning his countrymen that, with the U.S. military ouster of Panama's Gen. Manuel Noriega, Cuba may be next on President Bush's agenda. He has said that any invading force will spill ``rivers of blood.'' In Panama, the commander of U.S. military forces in Latin America, Gen. Marc Cisneros, said, ``We don't have the slightest intention of invading Castro right now. There is no need to. His own people are going to do to him what ... (Panamanians) did to Noriega.'' Defending the selection of programs for the testing debut, U.S. Information Agency and Voice of America officials said the goal was to determine technical feasibility and not to influence Cuban public opinion. After a test pattern, there was a tape from the 1971 Baltimore-Pittsburgh World Series, an old ``Kate and Allie'' sitcom, MTV videos and a travelogue about New Mexico. ``The programs stink,'' said Frank Calzon, a Cuban exile who is a TV Marti supporter and Washington director of a pro-democracy group called Freedom House. He said the premiere should have featured tape on the opening of the Berlin Wall and on the Chilean and Nicaraguan elections. Jorge Mas Canosa, the chairman of a Miami-based organization that oversees TV Marti, had a different reaction. He said several viewers in Cuba had phoned relatives in Miami to say they were ``very, very enthused, extremely satisfied and really excited.'' The Cuban government issued a statement through the official news agency Prensa Latina saying that TV Marti constitutes an aggressive action and violates Cuban sovereignty. The TV Marti signal was sent from an antenna aboard a balloon dangling 10,000 feet above Cudjoe Key off the South Florida coast. Technical problems have delayed testing for months. Now that testing has begun, the Bush administration has three months to make a legal and technical evaluation of the operation, according to the legislation that authorized the station. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said international agreements do not prevent a country from engaging in television broadcasting to another country. She also noted that the U.N. Universal Declaration of Human Rights entitles all people to the freedom to ``seek, receive and impart information and ideas through the media.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Working Out a Few Bugs. And We Do Mean Bugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with latest midge `body count,' preparations resuming; picks up 8th graf, ``It is ...
DOC.TEXT: A thimbleful of bugs temporarily delayed preparation of the mammoth, $1.5 billion telescope that will allow scientists to look deeper into the infinities of space than ever before, NASA says. The gnat-like insects, called midges, were found in a room where the Hubble Space Telescope was being readied for installation in space shuttle Discovery. They forced NASA to delay loading the telescope until at least Thursday. Engineers feared the insects could damage the fragile 25,000-pound instrument, the most expensive unmanned spacecraft ever built. ``It's kind of ironic, something so tiny affecting something so big,'' said Lisa Malone, a spokeswoman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. As of Tuesday evening, 37 midges had been sucked into seven traps set up in the preparation room. ``They're calling it the body count,'' Malone said. Three or so more midges were captured overnight in the 4-foot cylinders, which contain fans and lights that apparently lured the insects. Technicians removed the traps today and began taking a special protective bag off the telescope in preparation for Thursday's installation. Installation originally was planned for Tuesday. ``It is a super clean payload,'' explained NASA spokesman George Diller. ``Any little particle at all can significantly degrade the effectiveness of looking at a very faint object.'' The delay in loading the Hubble will not affect Discovery's scheduled April 12 liftoff, Diller said. Once it begins orbiting 370 miles above Earth, the Hubble will be capable of looking seven times more deeply into space and detecting objects 50 times fainter than the best ground-based observatory. Astronomers will be able to look back almost to the beginning of time by studying stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling toward Earth for 14 billion years. The shuttle launch may be moved up a day or two since technicians have needed little of the contingency time built into Discovery's prelaunch program, even after being bugged by bugs. Mother Nature has troubled Hubble since the telescope arrived at Kennedy Space Center in October. Crews cannot spray insect repellent because of the telescope's extreme sensitivity, Diller said. In October, moths invaded an anteroom used to prepare the 43-foot telescope for transfer into a special clean room. Then, in December, wasps snuck into the room through a cable conduit. Each time, crews kept the telescope from being contaminated, Diller said. The telescope is kept inside a special protective bag, or cocoon, that is opened only in order for work to be performed. The midges were found on the orbiter's payload bay doors Sunday when a servicing machine was retracted to receive the telescope. The door was vacuumed, but some of the insects got inside a payload preparation room on the launch tower. Until lately, NASA feared a baby great-horned owl in a nest atop Discovery's launch pad structure might interfere with liftoff. However, the bird has not been spotted in nearly a week. ``We're on a wildlife refuge and critters are something we have to deal with around here,'' Diller said. ``Like the owls and gators, sometimes they (insects) will affect launch operations. That's part of the business at the cape.''

DOC.HEAD: American Missionary Assassinated in Southern Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with victim's age, name of wife, gunmen also killed guard dogs. Pickup 8th graf, ``One of...' Inserts 3 grafs after 13th graf, `He said ...' to ADD sister's quote. Pickup 14, ``Earlier this...''
DOC.TEXT: Two Lebanese extremist groups today claimed responsibility for the assassination of an American missionary who was gunned down by masked men in his home while singing prayers with his children. Villagers had accused William Robinson, 59, of trying to establish an Israeli settlement in Rashaya Foukhar in southern Lebanon. Acquaintances had said Robinson, who was born and raised in Athol, Mass., only wanted to expand his 7-year-old orphanage for handicapped children, located in Israel's self-declared security zone. Israel denied that any such settlement was planned, and sent troops to scour the area in search of the killers. U.S. officials said Robinson had been repeatedly warned of danger. Three masked assailants broke into Robinson's house Tuesday night while he was singing bedtime prayers with his American wife, four sons and 26 other children from his orphanage, Lebanese security sources told U.N. investigators. The assailants then tied up Robinson's wife, Barbara, and sent the children into another room before shooting Robinson three times in the neck and chest, the sources said. The masked men also took $4,000 and some jewelry before fleeing. They also killed his guard dogs. In Beirut, the Communist Party and the pro-Syrian Lebanese National Resistance Front claimed responsibility for the killing. ``One of our units Tuesday night carried out the death sentence against William Robinson, who was seeking to establish an Israeli settlement on Lebanese territory,'' a statement from the front said. The front has carried out several guerrilla raids on Israeli targets in the area. The Communist Party said in its statement that the slaying ``brought an end to schemes to plant Jewish settlers in south Lebanon.'' The party and its militia have carried out numerous raids on Israeli targets, including an abortive suicide truck bombing in southern Lebanon on April 21, 1985. U.S. Embassy officials in Tel Aviv, Israel, said Robinson had been repeatedly advised of U.S. government policy barring Americans from visiting Lebanon. They gave no hometown, citing restrictions on privacy. Rashaya Foukhar is inside Israel's ``security zone'' in southern Lebanon, about eight miles northeast of Israel's border. The six-to-10-mile-deep zone was set up to serve as a buffer against raids by guerrillas and is policed by the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army. William F. Wolford, administrator of the International Christian Embassy in Jerusalem, said Robinson was a former U.S. Marine from just outside Chicago who ``had a love for the children of Lebanon and went there to help.'' He said Robinson was a missionary who ``stayed in Lebanon because there was no other place to take care of these 20 children. He was trying to get permission to adopt so he could bring them out. He was trying to expand the facilities there.'' Robinson's sister said her brother didn't have any political motive for settling in Israel's security zone. ``A lot of the children's parents had been killed,'' she said in a telephone interview from her home in Athol. ``He taught them right in the home so that there wouldn't be so many children killed. That was his purpose in going over there.'' She said Robinson had studied electronics in the Marines and worked on television cable systems in Athol and Pittsfield, Mass., before moving to California and Illinois. Earlier this month, 5,000 residents of Rashaya Foukhar petitioned the government of President Elias Hrawi to prevent Robinson from establishing what they called the first ``Israeli'' settlement on Lebanese soil. The petition said Robinson moved to settle in the town's school right after Israel's 1982 invasion and gradually brought in relatives and Israeli acquaintances. Beirut newspapers have said Robinson used trained dogs to keep villagers off his fenced compound, arousing their suspicion about his activities. But sources in Lebanon, who asked not to be identified further, said Robinson was engaged in a dispute with Shiite Moslems over land on which he wanted to expand his orphanage. Robinson first entered Lebanon from Israel in 1978 and worked as a technician at a Christian TV station in the southern Lebanese town of Marjayoun. In 1983, he founded his ``Christian Children's Home'' project in Rashaya Foukhar and was caring for 29 handicapped children when he was shot, security sources said. The compound includes a young adults' home, a children's home, a swimming pool, a vocational training school, a medical center, a physical therapy center, a school, a retirement home and an animal shelter, as well as administration offices and stables.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. March 24 Statesman Journal, Salem, Ore., on the Soviet Union: Democracy is breaking out in the heartland of the Soviet Union in a way that contradicts the view that voters stick with the safety of what they know _ or that Soviet voters are less ready than others to run their own lives. Soviet voters know the Communist Party, but large numbers are turning to the uncertainties of democratic reform instead. The speed with which this is progressing is no less a miracle than the transformations that have broken upon the nations of Eastern Europe that were once under Soviet domination. The most dramatic change is taking place in the Slavic republics of Russia, Byelorussia and the Ukraine, which represent two-thirds of the nation's population. Supporters of democratic reform movements in this key region began turning out Communist Party candidates in runoff elections days after the Soviet Congress legalized a multiple-party system. ... Although it is too early to determine the total implications of this voting, it would appear that the Soviet Union itself is firmly in the grip of a revolution. The peaceful revolution of the ballot box appears to be sweeping aside the heirs of the bloody 1917 Bolshevik Revolution. The implications of a pluralistic Soviet Union that runs from the bottom up, rather than as it has been, from the top down, is almost too much to grasp for minds honed on this century's decades of hot and cold wars.

March 21 The Wichita (Kan.) Eagle on the Soviet Union: As the Baltic states of Estonia and Latvia line up beside the Republic of Lithuania in acting to end their occupation by Soviet troops, Soviet leaders should consider where their nation's best interests lie. Is it in trying to force the Baltics to be a part of the Soviet Union that forcibly and illegally ``annexed'' them 50 years ago, thus leaving a perpetually hostile tier of constituent republics on its western border? Or is it in working with the Baltics to end the Soviet occupation as efficiently and quickly as possible, and having a neutral but potentially friendly tier of independent nations along the western border instead? Clearly, the Soviet Union's long-term interests are better served by the latter alternative. It's just as clear that only brute force could stop the Baltic independence movement now _ a move that would destroy utterly any Soviet claims of being a changed society.

March 23 Riverside (Calif.) Press-Enterprise on Lithuania: Mikhail Gorbachev has built up a pretty substantial surplus of good will with the West over the last few years. Now, finally, in Lithuania, he's having to spend some of those savings. ... Stepping up military exercises on the Lithuanian border will cost him some. Ordering all Lithuanians to turn in their guns to Soviet authorities will cost him. Parading armored personnel carriers through the streets of Vilnius will cost him. ... Events are moving right along on this front, and they're following old ruts. ... Back in January, after the Lithuanian Communist Party voted to break away from the Soviet national party, ... Gorbachev became the first Soviet leader to visit there since the Soviets took over in 1940. He spent three days, with political leaders, in the streets, in a factory. Everywhere he raised the most pragmatic reasons against Lithuania's secession from the U.S.S.R. But there were nationalist rallies in the squares: The process already was under way. At that point ... Gorbachev, looking reluctant as could be, left the impression he might ultimately tolerate it. Now no one is quite so sure that the old rules haven't been reinstated. Lithuania may yet rediscover that what it thought to be no leash was really just a long one.

March 21 The News and Courier, Charleston, S.C., on Lithuania: Much as (Mikhail) Gorbachev would hate to admit it, Lithuania's secession has been a boon to Moscow because it helps deflect growing unrest elsewhere in the USSR with the abject failure of perestroika to resuscitate the Soviet economy. There is nothing like an affront to national honor to take people's minds off empty store shelves. It is a tactic that has been used successfully throughout Soviet history to rally the disaffected populace round the Kremlin. As Moscow and Vilnius jockey for position at the bargaining table, the silence from Washington is deafening. Surely Lithuania's bid for independence did not catch the Bush administration by surprise. (Lithuania President Vytautas) Landbergis already has issued a respectful petition to the United States and the other democracies for recognition, yet President George Bush so far has failed to respond, at least publicly. No doubt the telephone lines between the White House, the Kremlin and Vilnius have seen some heavy traffic recently. What was said? Moreover, where does President Bush stand? Lithuania wants to know. We want to know.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Zimbabweans Vote in Elections That Could Lead to One-Party State
LaserPhotos HAR1 and HAR2
DOC.TEXT: Zimbabweans voted today in national elections that could give President Robert Mugabe's party control of every seat in Parliament and the opportunity to legislate one-party rule. Mugabe has vowed to change Zimbabwe's Constitution and institute one-party rule if his Zimbabwe African National Union (Patriotic Front) captures all of Parliament's 108 contested seats. Before the election, Mugabe's party held 106 seats, but a unanimous vote is required to change the constitution. Half of Zimbabwe's 9 million people are registered to vote in the two-day presidential and parliamentary elections, the second since Mugabe led the white-ruled British colony to independence a decade ago. ``I feel quite confident we will win all the seats,'' Mugabe said in a interview with The Associated Press today. Seven parties are contesting the elections, but only the Zimbabwe Unity Movement is viewed as having a chance to block Mugabe's often-stated plan of imposing one-party rule. The Zimbabwe Unity Movement is led by one of Parliament's two opposition legislators, Edgar Tekere, and has pledged to block the constitutional change and fight government corruption if elected. Tekere, 52, is also running as the first candidate to challenge Mugabe for the presidency since independence 10 years ago. Tekere was a co-founder of the ruling party in 1963, but he was dismissed from the party in 1988 after accusing top leaders of corruption. Parliament has 150 seats, but twelve have been granted to the governing party as there were no challengers, and 30 others are reserved for tribal chiefs, provincial governors and presidential nominees, all of whom are considered Mugabe supporters. In repeated interviews Tekere has said that his party can win several seats provided the elections are not rigged. Election results are not expected to be announced until Friday night, polling officials said.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: to know.
DOC.TEXT: March 21 The News-Leader, Springfield, Mo., on the census: The Census Bureau ... is mailing questionnaires to American households in its decennial head-counting chore. But when President Bush issues a proclamation asking us to TRUTHFULLY answer all census queries, the temptation is to ask: Where was George... When the Reagan-Bush administration coined the euphemism ``disinformation'' to explain lying in connection with foreign policy? When Bush and Congress conspired in their own version of Reagan's Voodoo Economics by using Social Security, airport and highway trust funds to mask the full scope of the federal deficit? And the list could go on.

March 22 The Hudson Dispatch, Union City, N.J., on Poindexter-Reagan: There is something truly painful about watching a former president act like a petulant teen-ager with a diary.
