And it's even worse when a federal judge condones and legitimizes such behavior. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene has ruled that former President Reagan does not have to produce diary entries he made while in office. The judge is presiding over the Iran-Contra trial of John M. Poindexter, Reagan's former national security adviser facing five felony counts. Greene said the three dozen diary entries ... Poindexter wanted to use in his defense were not ``essential.'' Regardless of the precedent, Reagan's testimony was long overdue given the convoluted history of the Iran-Contra inquiry. Central to Poindexter's defense are his statements that he did what he did on Reagan's behalf. Reagan and the Bush administration fought ... Poindexter's subpoena on the grounds of executive privilege and by arguing that personal presidential papers should remain shielded. Rather than fighting to keep his written records of the Iran-Contra affair secret, Reagan should do everything in his power to clear up the mystery once and for all.

March 22 Hobbs (N.M.) Daily News-Sun on voter registration: The United States has one of the lowest voter turnouts in its democratic elections of any Western nation; but that dismal situation may be about to change. Despite White House opposition, the House of Representatives has approved the so called ``motor voter'' bill that reduces barriers to voter registration. The bill allows voters to register by mail, at government offices or when they renew their driver's licenses. This measure also makes it easier to purge those who have died or moved and imposes stiffer penalties for threatening voters or for voter fraud. Similar legislation is pending in the Senate. The voter registration bill is in trouble because some Republicans in Congress see increased participation as a threat. While they complain publicly about potential fraud and cost, the real fear seems to be that more Democrats than GOP voters will sign up under the loosened rules. The proposed voter registration bill will do a lot more to strengthen citizenship and American democracy than it can possibly do to hurt them.

March 26 San Antonio Express-News on polluting the seas: If you missed the reports that the Gulf of Mexico is becoming an international sewer, or doubt the extent of the pollution of the world's open seas, two recent studies may persuade you. A graphic U.N. report ... says sewage dumped at sea or into the seas poses a significant health risk to seafood lovers and swimmers who can pick up bacteria and viruses. And the Environmental Protection Agency, or EPA, issued a report ... that supports a Texas-sought special designation from the International Maritime Organization to strictly limit dumping from ships into the Gulf of Mexico. ... The reports make common sense. From the first ships that plied the seas to the supertankers of today, mariners have used the seas as their private sewers. The Gulf and coastal areas are worst-case examples of what might eventually happen everywhere if international laws aren't toughened and if polluters aren't clobbered for their idiotic and dangerous bad habits.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Black Youth Shot by Whites During School Argument
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Tuesday's confrontation ..., to include name of school, remove reference to confrontation; note language.
DOC.TEXT: Three white teen-agers taunted a black youth with a racial slur in the stairwell of a public high school, then shot and slightly wounded him, police said. The shooting Tuesday took place in the Bensonhurst area of Brooklyn, where another black teen-ager, 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins, was fatally shot during a confrontation with a group of young white men last summer. Eight white youths are charged with murder in that case. The 14-year-old victim Tuesday was taken to Coney Island Hospital for treatment of a gunshot wound to the right wrist, said a police spokesman, Detective Joseph McConville. The boy's name was not released. By this morning, no arrest had been made, said a police spokeswoman, Sgt. Mary Wrensen. The youths involved in the shooting had clashed with another black teen-ager last month and the 14-year-old had tried to act as a peacemaker in that dispute, McConville said. The violence Tuesday in New Utrecht High School occurred as the 14-year-old passed the three whites in a basement stairwell, and one of them said, ``What are you looking at, nigger?'' The black teen-ager told police he replied, ``If I were looking at you, I'd tell you,'' McConville said. One of the white youths then shot the boy. Police found a shell at the shooting scene, but did not say what kind of gun was used.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians Defy Kremlin Orders to Surrender Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with complaints that soldiers harassed, Gorbachev speaking with Thatcher, estimate of number of weapons in Lithuania; Picks up 11th graf, `In Moscow...'; Subs 26th graf pvs, `The official ...' to INSERT that diplomat says 38 deserters seized.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian police today defied Kremlin orders to surrender shotguns and rifles turned in by citizens, but Soviet authorities warned that they will restore ``law and order'' in the Baltic republic. In Moscow, the commander of Soviet paratroopers complained of increasing attacks on soldiers in Lithuania, which declared its independence from Moscow on March 11. Soviet paratroopers guarded the republic's Communist Party headquarters for a second day, but removed their riot gear and no longer carried automatic rifles. On Tuesday, Soviet troops seized the headquarters and apprehended deserters in raids on two hospitals in the first Soviet use of force of the confrontation that began when Lithuania declared itself independent. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis condemned the actions and again urged Western nations to speak out against Moscow. ``Is the West willing to sell Lithuania to the Soviet Union again?'' he said Tuesday. In Washington, Bush administration officials refused to criticize the Soviet military's use of force on Tuesday. ``We simply don't feel inflammatory language is helpful,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev discussed Lithuania in a telephone conversation today with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, the official Soviet news agency Tass said. ``Replying to Mrs. Thatcher's question, Gorbachev described developments in Lithuania, which have emerged as a result of the violation of the Soviet Constitution,'' the news agency said. Vilnius was calm overnight, with no reports of violence or of Soviet soldiers taking over any more buildings. Lithuanians defied Soviet orders to turn over hunting rifles and shotguns. Lithuanian Interior Ministry spokesman Yaroslav Prokopovich said only about 1,000 weapons have been given to police, but the police were not turning them over to the Red Army. Authorities estimate there are 30,000 weapons in private hands. Police Capt. Jonas Dervinis said: ``Lithuania has its own constitution, and we are working to enforce the law of Lithuania.'' He said he did not know if Interior Ministry officials from Moscow would attempt to enforce Gorbachev's order a week ago that authorities confiscate any weapons not turned in voluntarily in seven days. In Moscow, the Defense Ministry issued a statement saying the orders issued by Gorbachev and the Soviet Parliament remain in effect. ``No one should have any doubt have any doubt that law and order will be restored on Lithuanian territory.'' The statement accused Lithuania's government of giving Lithuanian deserters from the Red Army separate passports and sheltering them from Soviet authorities as part of an anti-army propaganda campaign. The nationalists ``support illegal, anti-constitutional activities of the Lithuanian government focused on the republic's secession from the U.S.S.R.,'' said the military statement from Moscow, reported by newspapers today. ``The republic's Interior Ministry organs refuse to take steps to detain them and bring them back to their army units,'' it said. ``The deserters find shelter in Catholic churches, hospitals and within the grounds of state institutions,'' the statement said. ``All attempts by army representatives to resolve the problem through a dialogue with the Lithuanian government have been fruitless.'' Landsbergis on Tuesday condemned the capture of the deserters, but said the republic will respond with ``moral strength'' rather than violence. ``The government of Lithuania demands the return of its kidnapped citizens,'' Landsbergis said in a letter sent to Gorbachev. In a letter to Gorbachev, Landsbergis said the army actions likely presaged further violence. ``You can see for yourself there is no violence, except for incidents created by the army,'' he said. ``We can see how they are going to great lengths to create the image that in the Baltics, and in Lithuania in particular, there is instability.'' At a news conference Tuesday in Warsaw, Poland, senior Soviet diplomats said Lithuania's independence drive could lead to destabilization of Europe and the rest of the world, but did not elaborate. A declaration read at the briefing said ``the aspirations of the Lithuanian leadership to speedily separate from the other nations appear unjustified and let's say frankly dangerous.'' In his letter to Gorbachev, Landsbergis said: ``Lithuania is an unarmed, peaceful state and the only way it can resist the aggressor is by moral strength and by not using armed resistance to violence.'' ``The government of Lithuania demands the return of its kidnapped citizens,'' he told the Soviet president, and demanded that ``negotiations with the government of the U.S.S.R. be held in neutral territory.'' Washington and other foreign governments urged restraint from Moscow but avoided attacking Gorbachev, who by fostering greater democracy has allowed independence movements to take hold in several republics. Gorbachev is also trying to implement market-oriented reforms that would nurse a badly crippled economy to health. Tass said Soviet soldiers seized 23 Lithuanian deserters in the pre-dawn raids. A Lithuanian diplomat in Rome today said at least 38 deserters were seized. Witnesses said some deserters were beaten as they were taken from a psychiatric hospital in Vilnius. A trail of blood led down the steps and out the front door of the hospital. Gorbachev has called Lithuania's independence declaration invalid and last week ordered Lithuanians to turn in their weapons and stop signing up with a volunteer militia. But the Lithuanians have not backed down. The Soviet leader had promised not to use force unless lives were endangered in the Baltic republic, which the Soviet Union forcibly annexed along with Latvia and Estonia in 1940. But military authorities had warned they would seize deserters who did not return voluntarily by last Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Criticizes U.S. Immigration Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs graf 8, Public affairs officers, with three new grafs of reaction.
DOC.TEXT: The United States illegally discriminates against refugees from Guatemala, Haiti and El Salvador who have ``reasonable fears for their lives,'' Amnesty International charged today. The organization, which monitors human rights violations, said government bias against asylum-seekers from particular countries ``appears to be a worldwide pattern.'' It said Congress, however, passed a refugee act in 1980 requiring U.S. officials to use a single standard regardless of the applicant's nationality, ideology or immigration status. Despite this, Amnesty International said, only 2.5 percent of Salvadorans and 2 percent of Guatemalans and Haitians seeking asylum between 1983 and 1989 were successful. The organization said government records show that people of other nationalities were granted asylum at a rate of more than 36 percent. In a 29-page report, Amnesty International said it had ``communicated its concerns for many years'' to the State Department, the Immigration and Naturalization Service and other officials of the Justice Department. ``No substantiative response has been received to date, and people with reasonable fears for their lives continue to be denied protection,'' the organization said. A Justice Department spokesman, Duke Austin, commented, ``Can it be established that the United States is in fact returning people to their native homelands and they are subsequently being persecuted?. If that is the case, then we are violating the intent of the law. I don't know of a single case that that has ever been established in El Salvador or in Haiti. Not one.'' Randy L. Levine, a New York attorney who was ranking associate deputy attorney general from 1986 to 1988, said, ``In my experience, most of the refugees from Guatemala and El Salvador would not qualify for asylum because they do not have a well-founded fear of persecution. Most of them are economic refugees.'' Nathan Kingsley, public affairs officer for the State Department's Bureau of Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, which advises the Immigration and Natural Service on asylum matters, said he had not seen the report. Amnesty International said U.S. authorities have justified denial of asylum applications from Guatemala on the basis of changes in the Guatemalan government. But it said rights abuses in the Central American country have continued despite the government changes and the number of reported cases has increased since 1988. In fiscal year 1989, only 67 of 3,325 Guatemalans whose cases were decided by district directors of the immigration service were granted asylum, an approval rate of 1.9 percent. It said the overall rate of approval was 14 percent. The human rights organization said the U.S. policy of using the Coast Guard to interdict Haitian refugees ``frustrates the intent of the 1980 Refugee Act by subjecting this group of people to an asylum process, conducted at sea, which appears to be thoroughly inadequate.'' It said fewer than 10 of more than 20,000 Haitians interviewed at sea since 1981 have been permitted into the United States to claim asylum. Amnesty said the INS denied 13,861 applications for asylum from Salvadorans in 1989, while granting 337.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Hangs Two For Spying, Other Crimes
DOC.TEXT: Two men convicted of spying, theft and ``counterrevolutionary activities'' were hanged Wednesday in Iran's southeastern Sistan-Baluchestan province, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, identified the two as Abbas Raisi and Ahmad Janghi Razhi. It said they were charged with spying for Iraq and ``collaborating with bandits and counterrevolutionaries.''

DOC.HEAD: Indian Border Guards Kill 2 Pakistanis
DOC.TEXT: Indian border guards shot and killed two Pakistani ``intruders'' Wednesday after about 100 people crossed into India's Jammu-Kashmir state from Pakistan, government officials said. In New Delhi, a government spokesman told Pakistan the crossing ``can have tragic consequences.'' The spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing regulations, did not elaborate. Officials in Srinagar, Kashmir's main city and the center of a Moslem separatist campaign, said 100 Pakistani civilians shouting anti-Indian slogans headed into India from Pakistan. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the people were warned to turn back. When they ignored the warning and came about 200 yards inside Indian territory, border guards opened fire and killed two people, the officials said. The border incident was the fourth since Moslem militants intensified their secessionist campaign in Indian-governed Kashmir in January. The most serious incident occurred Feb. 5 when about 4,000 Pakistani civilians attempted to cross the border to support their Moslem brethren in Kashmir. Indian troops opened fire and killed at least four people. At least 201 people have died in Moslem separatist violence in Kashmir since the secessionist campaign flared Jan. 20. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Moslem-dominated state in India, which is mostly Hindu. Pakistan also claims the state because of its predominantly Moslem population and has twice gone to war with India over the region. Pakistan now controls the western part of the state, while the larger portion is governed by India.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Approves Draft Measure to Ban Tobacco, Alcohol Ads
DOC.TEXT: The government declared war on tobacco Wednesday, approving a draft law banning all cigarette advertising and announcing a 15 percent increase in the price of tobacco products beginning next year. In addition, advertisements of nearly all alcoholic beverages will be banned except in the print media. The measure will be submitted to Parliament during its spring session, said government spokesman Louis Le Pensec. If approved, the bans will be implemented progressively over a three-year period. Most cigarettes now cost between 95 cents and $1.75. The government receives about 75 percent of the revenue from tobacco sales. Le Pensec said tobacco and alcohol are responsible for 20 percent of the deaths in France. ``You can never be too tough in preventing the self-destruction of our citizens,'' he quoted President Francois Mitterrand as telling the Cabinet.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Exhibits The Smells of Europe
DOC.TEXT: A museum in this eastern town is leading visitors on an aromatic journey through the 12 nations of the European Economic Community. ``By their power to evoke, odors are the vector of communication,'' said the aromatician Michael Motsseeff, who helped organize the exhibit. ``Each person recognizes a country by his experiences, which are recalled by the scents he imbibes.'' In the show at the Musee des PTT d'Alsace, people may jog their memories of Britain with smells of freshly cut grass offered in a picnic setting. Ireland smells of old whiskey; the Netherlands fresh cream; and Denmark features smoked fish. West Germany offers cinnamon, Belgium burned fat. Greece is evoked with olive oil and oregeno, Italy with capuccino. Spain features musty bull smells, and Portugal cod fish. France is evoked by a perfume created especially for the exhibit. Only Luxembourg has not been assigned a national smell. It is represented by a safe. The show opened Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Two Schoolgirls Killed, 13 Injured When Rock Falls
DOC.TEXT: Two 13-year-old schoolgirls were killed and 13 of their friends were injured Wednesday when a large rock fell on them as they were climbing at a popular waterfall in southern Australia, police said. They said the two girls were standing on a cliff ledge at Lal Lal Falls, in the state of Victoria, when the rock dislodged. Both suffered serious head injuries and died at Ballarat Base Hospital on the ouskirts of Melbourne. Two teachers and two instructors were accompanying the children at the time. The other children suffered minor cuts and bruising.

DOC.HEAD: Greece Says Turkey Agrees to Dismantle Controversial Mini-Dam
DOC.TEXT: Turkey on Wednesday ordered the dismantling of a small dam following Greek protests that the structure was changing the flow of a river dividing the countries, the Greek government said. Greece issued the protest Monday, saying the sandbag structure on the Evros river made it appear that a small island was actually an extension of the Turkish mainland. The two countries share sovereignty of the 25-acre island. Greek government spokesman Prokopis Pavlopoulos said Turkey's assistant foreign undersecretary, Hussein Celem, assured the Greek ambassador the sandbags would be removed immediately. Celem said Turkish villagers, and not officials, were responsible for building the dam, Pavlopoulos added. Turkey also denied that soldiers had been stationed on the island, he said. The two countries agreed Wednesday to hold technical level talks to prevent any similar border problems in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Letter To Pastor Admissible in List's Murder Trial
DOC.TEXT: A 1971 letter in which John E. List admitted killing five members of his family, saying he couldn't support them and didn't want to see them on welfare, was released today by the judge in List's murder trial. ``I know that what has been done is wrong from all that I have been taught and that my reasons that I might give will not make it right,'' List wrote in a five-page letter left for his Lutheran pastor, the Rev. Eugene A. Rehwinkel. List also said that he was concerned about his 16-year-old daughter Patricia, who he said was ``so determined to get into acting I was also fearful as to what this might do to her continuing to be a Christian.'' Judge William L'E. Wertheimer released the letter, rejecting defense arguments that it should be considered confidential because of the ``priest-penitent'' privilege. List is accused of killing his wife, Helen, their three children and his mother on Nov. 9, 1971 in their Westfield home. After the slayings, List lived nearly 18 years under an assumed name in Colorado and Virginia, prosecutors said. He was arrested in Richmond, Va., in June after a tipster phoned a nationally broadcast anti-crime TV show. The letter gave a methodical explanation of why List felt compelled to kill his family. Authorities said List shot dead his wife and mother and then killed Patricia and his sons John Jr. and Frederick. ``It may seem cowardly to have only shot from behind but I didn't want any of them to know even at the last second that I had to do this to them,'' he wrote. ``P.S. mother is in the hallway in the attic _ 3rd floor. She was too heavy to move. ``John got hurt more because he seemed to struggle longer. The rest were immediately out of pain,'' he wrote. Wertheimer allowed the letter to be used because of its contents, the way it was left for the pastor, and because List never sought confidentiality. Police found the letter in an unsealed envelope with the name of List's pastor, the Rev. Eugene A. Rehwinkel, written on it. The envelope was in a locked filing cabinet.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Lecturers' Wives, Protesters Demand President's Ouster
DOC.TEXT: Riot police arrested 27 women Wednesday who were protesting the jailing of university professors and fired a stun grenade and tear gas to disperse bystanders who were supporting the protesters. ``Houphouet, thief! Houphouet, resign! Houphouet, go!'' the nearly 300 bystanders chanted. They were referring to President Felix Houphouet-Boigny. For an hour after the arrests, riot police waving batons charged the bystanders, who repeatedly regrouped and resumed chanting at different street corners. The women marched down the central Boulevard de la Republique shouting, ``Free our husbands! Free our parents! Let them go!'' Most of them were wives or daughters of 127 university professors, who were jailed Monday after defying a ban on protests and meetings. Meanwhile, the government threatened to fire hundreds of striking government medical workers if they did not return to work. ``All those who are not at their work posts this Wednesday, March 28, 1990, will be dismissed and replaced,'' a government statement said. ``We refuse to respond to the government order,'' said an official of the National Union of Senior Health Officers, who asked that he not be named. The medical workers and the university professors were protesting austerity measures that include salary cuts of up to 17 percent to save this once-prosperous West African nation from bankruptcy. Houphouet-Boigny blames the crisis on the slumping prices of cocoa, Ivory Coast's main export. But his critics allege government officials have stolen millions of dollars from state coffers. Houphouet-Boigny has ruled Ivory Coast as a one-party state since its independence from France in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: bad habits.
DOC.TEXT: March 24 The Keene (N.H.) Sentinel on the cost of sugar: Why, one might wonder, would anyone spend good money to put an ad on TV _ week after week, year after year _ telling us how cheap sugar is? The answer ... is that it isn't true. Political action committees affiliated with sugar producers hand out about $1 million each election year to sweet-toothed congressmen on key committees. No connection, of course, but Congress has imposed very strict quotas on sugar imports, the kinds of quotas American trade representatives complain loudly about when the Japanese put them on beef, citrus fruit and rice. ... According to Citizens for a Sound Economy, a free-trade lobby, Americans pay the highest price for sugar of any western nation _ three times the average of what the rest of the world pays. A Department of Commerce study shows that sugar quotas cost American consumers ... $3 billion a year. The quotas also keep the prices of artificial sweeteners and other sweeteners such as corn syrup about $2 billion a year higher than would otherwise be the case, according to a Congressional Research Service report. And the quotas hurt Third-World sugar producing countries, many of which receive U.S. economic aid that wouldn't be necessary if they could sell us their sugar.

March 26 Portland (Maine) Press Herald on censorship of art: The Bush administration did credit to itself last week by striking a blow against government censorship. Ignoring the demands of Sen. Jesse Helms and other right-wing activists, the administration told Congress it opposed legislation to control the content of art supported with federal funds. Fine. Whether or not the federal government should be subsidizing art projects in the first place is open to argument. But once subsidies are authorized, the government ought not to get into the business of dictating the specifics of artistic output. To place restrictions on the content and form of art to be supported amounts to government censorship.

March 25 The Providence (R.I.) Sunday Journal on art thievery: (The) ... theft from Boston's Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum is sad indeed. ... We hope the museum will bolster its security to protect the master pieces that remain. ... Art thievery will grow more brazen as long as the market value of art escalates. But if people could purchase a copy of a painting as easily as they can buy a book or a musical recording, this crime might decline. ... (W)e recently viewed copies of paintings by Claude Monet. ... They were ``painted'' by computer. Such copies, reproducing even the texture of brush strokes, are quite expensive, but prices could decline if consumer demand creates a lucrative market. This could revolutionize the art world: Aside from making virtual duplicates of art available to hang in the average aesthete's living room, this process could moderate the value of original works.

March 26 The Greenwood (Miss.) Commonwealth on the broccoli brouhaha: A reporter in our newsroom the other day asked: Why all this fuss over something as insignificant as broccoli? The reason, we suspect, is this: Broccoli is something every American can understand. We either like it or we don't like it. It's, ugh, something we can get our teeth into. Therefore, every one of us has an opinion about broccoli. We understand it. We can talk it over and argue about it at the family dinner table. But consider really weighty problems of the nation, like the multi-billion-dollar federal savings and loan bailout. That financial mess probably is the worst misuse, abuse and waste of taxpayer money in U.S. history. It will cost $200 billion, maybe $300 billion to fix it. In other countries, governments would fall over such a scandal. Congressmen and senators should be voted out of office because of it. Here's a subject taxpayers really ought to be upset about, not broccoli. But the fact is, the savings and loan controversy is so complex, it came about because of so many complicated reasons _ including bad judgment by Congress _ the American people don't really understand the high cost or know where to place the blame. It's a lot easier, and more comforting to argue about broccoli.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Caterpillar Pull Toys Recalled
DOC.TEXT: A Chicago-based manufacturer voluntarily recalled 1,500 pull toys Wednesday because they may break apart, leaving sharp edges or small parts that could injure or choke young children, the government said. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Sandberg Manufacturing Co. is recalling 1,500 Caterpillar Pull Toys that sold nationwide for children ages 1 to 3 from October 1988 to May 1989. The toys are made of green, orange, yellow, blue and red plastic with two small balls on the end of two springs and a red pull string attached to the head of the caterpillar. The toys ``may break apart during use producing small pieces of plastic, some with sharp points,'' the commission said. ``The balls on the ends of the antenna may also detach presenting a choking hazard to young children.'' Agency officials advise adults to take the toys away from young children and return them to the store where purchased for a refund.

DOC.HEAD: Designer Halston, Known For Classic Fashions, Dead at 57
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and last graf to CORRECT that Halston had not previously lived in California but moved there from New York to be with relatives. SUBS 12th graf, `He began...', to CLARIFY that he moved to New York before joining Bergdorf. ADDS survivors.
DOC.TEXT: After learning that he had AIDS, fashion designer Halston moved to California, where he spent some of his final days touring the majestic coast around Big Sur in his new, jet-black Rolls-Royce. The designer, who transformed fashion in the 1970s, died Monday night. His brother said Tuesday that Halston had asked that the $300,000 Rolls be auctioned off, with the funds going to AIDS research. Robert Frowick described his brother as intensely private, but said the family wanted to hold a memorial service that would accommodate Halston's many fans and friends. It will be held Friday at San Francisco's Calvary Presbyterian Church. The 57-year-old designer died at Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center, where he had been hospitalized with Kaposi's sarcoma since December. ``We are all deeply saddened by Halston's death,'' said Ronald Perelman, board chairman of Revlon Group Inc. in New York. ``He was an American leader of design and style who helped to define his entire era. He will be sorely missed.'' Mr. Blackwell, the acerbic fashion designer known for his annual worst-dressed celebrity list, lamented Halston's loss. ``Halston in the last several years has been conspicuously absent from the scene. His death is a tragedy,'' Blackwell said from his home in Los Angeles. Halston's first client was Fran Allison of ``Kukla, Fran and Ollie.'' Within months he was creating hats for Kim Novak, Hedda Hopper, Deborah Kerr and Shirley Booth. Known for his signature black and red attire, the Ultrasuede shirtdress and the pillbox-style hat worn by Jacqueline Kennedy at the 1961 presidential inauguration, Halston also designed clothes for Lauren Bacall, Liza Minnelli, Carol Channing and Bianca Jagger. He opened his own couture house in 1968. Through his work he collected a star-studded circle of friends, including artist Andy Warhol. Born Roy Halston Frowick, the son of an accountant and a housewife, he took to fashion early on. At age 13, he made a red hat and veil for his mother to wear on Easter. His brother, Robert, said Halston always had an innate taste for clothes. He began working in Chicago, where he sold hats at the Ambassador Hotel before moving to New York where he joined Bergdorf Goodman in 1957. Halston quickly rose to fashion fame and fortune in the Big Apple, earning two prestigious Coty awards for fashion. ``He was temperamental, spoiled, always threatening to quit,'' Andrew Goodman, Bergdorf's president, said in 1973. ``But we indulged him because he was so talented.'' His hallmark cardigan draped over the shoulders, slinky jerseys, caftans and other designs swept the country, and he opened a Madison Avenue boutique. But Halston's position at the pinnacle of the fashion industry began to slip in 1973, when he signed a $16 million deal with Norton Simon Inc. for his ready-to-wear line, his couture operation and the Halston trademark. The agreement let Norton Simon use the Halston name for products he didn't design. J.C. Penney Co. Inc. approached Norton Simon with the idea of a line of inexpensive Halston clothes to be sold exclusively in the low-price department stores, and Halston agreed. That deal was signed in 1982. Shortly after that, Bergdorf Goodman announced it would no longer sell Halston clothes because of the association with Penney. Adding to the designer's woes, Norton Simon was acquired in a takeover of the Esmark Inc. conglomerate by Beatrice Cos. Beatrice canceled Halston's limousines, dismissed staff and dismantled his company. Revlon bought use of the Halston name in December 1986, although the designer retained the right to also use it. Revlon used it on a popular fragrance line. Diagnosed about a year ago as infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, Halston moved to northern California to join family members living in Santa Rosa. He is survived by two brothers and a sister.

DOC.HEAD: High School Mourns Five Killed in Fire
With AM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Once it was a wall; by Wednesday, it was a memorial. Students at Roosevelt High School, who lost five classmates in the Happy Land social club fire, covered a second-floor hallway with flowers and scrawled goodbyes in a tribute to the dead youths. ``I wish you are all in HEAVEN. I'll meet you there, my friends! I miss you,'' wrote one student at the school, which is attended by about 140 youths of Honduran descent. ``Our family, our friends. We will never forget. May your souls rest in peace,'' said another message. The remembrances came in English and Spanish; flowers, now wilted, were stapled along the length of the 28-foot tribute. Teachers joined students in sharing their grief over the loss of people who two weeks earlier had partied with them at a high school dance. ``Norman _ you were a wonderful student, a joy to have in class,'' wrote one teacher. ``Always smiling, bright-eyed, sensitive, respectful, kind, humorous, a wonderful son. I will always keep you in my heart and pray for you.'' Above the scores of names and messages was a computer-printed sign flanked by bouquets of paper roses. ``In memory of Wendy, Alba, Isabel, Norman, Ernesto,'' it simply said. All five died early Sunday; the messages first appeared Monday morning. Norman Clark was the youngest of the five Roosevelt students killed. He and three others attended the school this year. The fifth, Ernesto Gamoneda, was in the class of '89. Wendy Manaiza, 18, planned to attend college following her graduation this June. Alba Escuto went to the club with her boyfriend, Juan Carlos Colon; her cousin, 17-year-old Isabel Lopez, also was there. Funeral services for the five teen-agers were expected to begin Thursday. ``They were beautiful kids,'' recalled the principal, Paul Shapiro. ``The school is suffering together on this. This is not business as usual. Business is not as usual.'' Friends of the dead youths arrived at school Monday morning badly shaken, some sobbing and screaming uncontrollably as they met with counselors assigned to the school to help students through the tragedy. More than 400 students came in to talk about the tragedy and its effects on them. Part of the healing process was creation of the memorial, counselors said. ``It was an ice-breaker in trying to get something positive out of this,'' said Cecilio Rodriguez, a former Roosevelt teacher and now a member of the Bronx high school crisis response team. ``Some of the Honduran kids, who spoke no English, asked how to write `God bless you' or `We miss you' in English,'' he said. ``They wanted everybody to understand their message.'' Students told the counselors their friends went to the Happy Land after a party attended by many Roosevelt students; several who stayed at the party felt guilty about surviving. ``They had to confront that: `I was with so and so two hours before at the party.' It's mortality _ here today, gone tomorrow. Kids that age think they're invincible,'' said Milta Vega, a drug counselor at the school. The deaths were keenly felt at the school of 3,300 students, 60 percent of whom are Hispanic. Counselors said students of varying ethnic backgrounds were brought together in mourning. ``It was almost beautiful to see the way they came together,'' Rodriguez said Tuesday afternoon. ``There was a good spiritual energy generated by the end of the day.'' The counselors, while pleased with the progress made so far, say there's more work to be done at Roosevelt. ``These kids live in an area where there are 6,000 Hondurans within 10 blocks,'' said Ms. Vega. ``They will pass by the club every day on the way to school. It's really important to have a crisis team here for them.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
5 Arrested in Attempt to Smuggle Nuclear Detonating Devices to Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 4th pvs, `In Washington...' to UPDATE with White House comment. Pickup 5th pvs, `The incident...'
DOC.TEXT:
Customs officials said they foiled an attempt today to smuggle 40 U.S.-made nuclear trigger components to Iraq via London. They said five people were arrested, including an Iraqi who was picked up at Heathrow Airport and is being expelled from Britain. Earlier reports had said two Iraqis and up to five other people had been taken into custody. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the devices arrived from the United States two days earlier and were kept under surveillance until the alleged smugglers attempted to put them on a scheduled Iraqi Airways flight to Baghdad. In Washington, a U.S. Customs Service spokesman, Ed Kittredge, said the arrests resulted from an 18-month investigation by U.S. and British customs officials. A sealed indictment has been returned in the case in U.S. District Court in San Diego, he said. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``This issue raises once again our concern for the nuclear proliferation in the Middle East. It continues to pose a serious risk to U.S. interests and it continues to exacerbate regional problems.'' He called on nuclear suppliers ``to exercise special restraint in providing materials to this region of the world, and we continue to urge that all states adhere to the Non-Proliferation Treaty,'' including Iraq. The incident could further strain relations between Britain and Iraq. Earlier this month, Britain recalled its ambassador from Baghdad after the Iraqis hanged an Iranian-born journalist working for a British newspaper. Iraq accused the journalist, Farzad Bazoft, of spying. BBC-TV said customs officials, tipped off by their American counterparts, removed the nuclear devices and substituted harmless replacements, then waited for the packages to be collected from their freight shed. It showed footage of the operation which it said was shot by an NBC crew which had been following the investigation. The customs officials said the items were capacitors, electrical devices that form part of the detonation chain of a nuclear bomb. They said the detainees included three Britons and a Lebanese. The Home Office said the Iraqi was being deported because of attempted breaches of British laws restricting the export of high technology. A second detainee who was to have been expelled turned out to have British citizenship, it said. Kittredge said Washington was limiting its comment on the incident out of deference to the British government. ``They're sensitive about Iraq and the number of British citizens there,'' he said.
Professor Paul Wilkinson, a Bradford University terrorism expert, said: ``If they're trying to smuggle in these highly sophisticated trigger devices, that means they're very serious about making nuclear weapons and soon.'' Tony Banks, a Middle East expert at the respected Jane's Defense Weekly, said nuclear triggers are devices for initiating an explosion in a nuclear weapon. ``This is a very, very high technology. There are only a very few countries in the world capable of manufacturing this type of technology and there is no other use for a nuclear triggering device than to trigger a nuclear weapon,'' he said. The Foreign Office would not link the deportation to the disclosure of the smuggling operation, and no government agency would officially confirm that such an operation had been attempted. A Foreign Office spokesman said Iraqi Ambassador Azmi Shafiq Al-Salihi was informed of the deportation by senior Foreign Office official Roger Tomkys, who is responsible for Middle East affairs. It was not known whether Iraq has nuclear weapons capability, but it has been developing a long-range missile judged by some military analysts to be capable of delivering a nuclear warhead. In 1981 the Israeli air force bombed and destroyed a nuclear reactor in Iraq which was nearing completion. Israel claimed the reactor would give Iraq nuclear weapons capability. Iraq insisted the installation was for peaceful use.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen to Retire, Aide Says
DOC.TEXT: Rep. George Crockett, D-Mich., has decided to retire after five terms in Congress, ending a career of public service spanning more than 40 years, an aide says. Crockett, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs, planned to announce his decision in a floor speech later today, administrative assistant Joan Willoughby said. ``It's a decision he's come to over the last couple of months,'' Ms. Willoughby said. ``He's 80 years old and he's worked for 68 years.'' She said Crockett was not concerned about his chances for winning a sixth term. A native of Jacksonville, Fla., Crockett earned his law degree at the University of Michigan. He gained national attention in 1949 for his defense of 11 avowed New York communists charged with subversion. He was elected to the Detroit Recorder's Court, which handles the city's criminal cases, in 1966. His 12-year term on the bench was steeped in controversy, capped by his release of more than 100 people arrested at a meeting of a black militant group in 1969. He was elected to Congress in 1980, replacing Rep. Charles Diggs, who had been convicted in a kickback scandal.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Charge Pressler Violated Senate Rules, Federal Law
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Larry Pressler, R-S.D., violated Senate rules and federal law by using his staff to help an elderly woman write a campaign-related letter to newspaper editors, Democrats said Wednesday. The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee asked the Senate Rules Committee in a letter Wednesday to tell Pressler ``that this practice must be discontinued.'' Pressler violated restrictions against members of Congress using their official staff and mailing privileges for campaign business, DSCC attorney Robert Bauer said at a news conference. ``He should not be mixing campaign and Senate business'' in his Senate offices, Bauer said. The letter published earlier this month in the Sioux Falls Argus-Leader and two other South Dakota newspapers complained that the National Committee to Preserve Social Security and Medicare had endorsed Democratic Senate candidate Ted Muenster without polling its members. The letter writer, Irene McLaughlin, 69, of Sioux Falls, said she had arthritis and asked Pressler's Sioux Falls office to type the letter for her. ``If it is a mistake to respond to a constituent's request to assist someone with arthritis in typing a letter, that is exactly what we did,'' said Kevin Schieffer, the senator's chief of staff. ``If it is wrong we will correct it, as we always do.'' Schieffer wrote the Senate Ethics Committee on Monday seeking advice on whether it was proper for Pressler's staff to have prepared the letter. However, Schieffer's request does not mention the nature of the letter -- only that the writer was ``supportive of Senator Pressler'' and angry about a newspaper article. Schieffer said McLaughlin dictated the letter to a Pressler aide, who typed up the letter on his own time. Schieffer said he did not know who paid for the stamps that were used to mail the letter or when and where the aide typed it. ``They were all her words. She dictated. It was her idea. It was her initiative,'' Schieffer said. The Democrats' complaint was based on an article in the Sioux Falls newspaper that disclosed that Pressler's staff helped prepare the letter. McLaughlin had complained to the Argus-Leader that her last name was listed incorrectly, the newspaper said. Bauer said Wednesday that Pressler had probably used his staff to prepare similar letters to the editor through other people. However, Bauer acknowledged his evidence consisted of copies of letters about the Senate race, written by the same people, that appeared in multiple South Dakota newspapers. ``In my experience this is not likely to be an undirected activity,'' Bauer said. Spokesmen for both Pressler and Muenster have acknowledged that they advise supporters on what to write to newspapers. Pressler has used his campaign staff to solicit supporters to write letters to the editor, Schieffer said.

DOC.HEAD: Factional Fighting Burns Scores of Homes, Villagers Flee
LaserPhoto CPN1
DOC.TEXT: Rival Zulu factions battled with guns, clubs and knives Wednesday in Natal province, setting scores of homes on fire and forcing hundreds of villagers to flee into the countryside. Soldiers and police patrolled Natal in an effort to quell the violence, which broke out Tuesday and has killed at least two people. ``The whole so-called `Valley of Death' is covered with blue smoke. I saw 120 homes burning at the same time in a radius of (15 miles),'' said journalist Khaba Mkhize after flying over the Edendale Valley near the provincial capital of Pietermaritzburg. From 1,000 feet up, Mkhize saw crowds of more than 1,000 gathering in streets and bodies lying in fields. Police reported two deaths and 25 injuries since Tuesday but expected the figures would rise. Local reporters, who did not want to be named, said up to 14 people had been killed. As night fell, officials and monitors reported 1,500 people fleeing the townships with their belongings loaded onto trucks. Army units and extra police were deployed after some 2,000 Zulus supporting the Inkatha party went on rampage with guns and knives against supporters of the rival United Democratic Front. Observers and police say the violence was sparked by the stoning of Inkatha buses that drove through UDF areas after a rally Sunday. Inkatha is fighting the UDF for control of the region. Both groups oppose apartheid, South Africa's system of racial segregation. However, Inkatha supports separate states for different tribes or ethnic groups, while the UDF wants a black majority government ruling all of South Africa. Police said officers used shotguns and tear gas to disperse mobs attacking and burning houses. Maj. Piet Kitching said the army would patrol all night along major routes in the 120-square-mile area where fighting was reported. ``It almost looks as though the whole area is burning,'' said Kitching. ``In a field, on one side of a hill a battle was raging, we could hear the guns,'' said Peter Kerchhoff, of a Pietermaritzburg peace group. ``On the other side, we just heard the weapons being fired amongst the trees. Masses of people were watching the confrontations and masses of people were ... trying to go to the rescue of other people in conflict on the hill.'' Kerchhoff said dirt roads leading to townships were blockaded with tree trunks, boulders, rubbish and burning tires. He said people were fleeing Caluza township, where much of the fighting was centered. Houses were burning in several townships, and many of those fleeing carried with them pieces of furniture, he said. As his group drove through the crowds taking four injured to the hospital, Kerchhoff said, ``People were saying, `Please, we need guns.''' Several residents and local journalists said they saw some police giving Inkatha fighters ammunition, supporting them in the battles, and refusing to confiscate their weapons. Township residents welcomed the army's arrival, said Mkhize, the journalist. A 13-year-old boy in a house in Caluza said over the telephone: ``The police is coming and shoot the people. A helicopter is up there.'' The boy, who could not be identified because of safety concerns, said his father had left the house ``because of the war'' and ``I am running away now.'' Kerchhoff said he saw young and old men fighting on a distant hilltop with sticks, clubs and machete-like knives called pangas. Among the Inkatha fighters, Kerchhoff said he saw men in blue uniforms, but he could not be sure they were police. One of the injured he transported to a hospital claimed to have been shot in the shoulder by police officer, Kerchhoff said. Police did not respond to the charges, but photographers took pictures of white security policemen, riot squad officers and local black police in the company of armed Inkatha men near Caluza. Hundreds of people have been killed in black factional fighting in recent weeks in Natal. Nearly 4,000 have died since 1987 as the Inkatha movement and UDF fight for control of the region. The groups have ignored repeated appeals from Nelson Mandela and other black leaders to end the fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Letting Moscow Know of Opposition to Use of Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, editing throughout to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, while avoiding inflammatory public statements, is making its opposition to the use of force in Lithuania known to Moscow ``in the strongest fashion,'' the White House said today. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said U.S. communications with Moscow over the tense situation in the rebellious Baltic republic have included private diplomatic cable messages. ``The fact that we have made that position known to them by almost every recognized channel _ which is to say diplomatic and direct conversations between (Secretary of State James A.) Baker and (Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A.) Shevardnadze as well as cable messages to the Soviet Union _ indicates that we have registered our position in the strongest fashion,'' Fitzwater said. Bush found himself confronted in the White House today by criticism from some Republican lawmakers that his policy on Lithuania wasn't aggressive enough. But he argued forcefully for his go-slow approach, participants at a White House GOP leadership meeting said. ``We had a very spirited exchange and he won,'' said Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., assistant House Republican leader. Gingrich said he was one of several GOP leaders who voiced concern to the president over his cautious policy in reacting to Soviet moves to block Lithuania's seccession. The lawmaker, speaking to reporters on the White House driveway, said he began the meeting ``more aggressive, more positive than I came out.'' But Gingrich said he was persuaded that any overt U.S. action _ such as formal recognition of Lithuania _ would trigger the immediate use of force against Lithuania by the Soviet army. Gingrich said Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was under enormous pressure, including from the Soviet military, to use force in Lithuania. ``We don't gain anything by forcing a confrontation,'' Gingrich said. The lawmaker said he ``was educated'' by today's White House session. ``I think it is clear there are extraordinary pressures on both sides, certainly on Lithuanians and on the Soviet Union. And it's in our interest to promote a peaceful dialogue,'' Fitzwater said. Fitzwater and other officials are avoiding ``inflammatory language'' in public comments on the Soviet use of force in Lithuania but say they are keeping diplomatic channels open with the Soviets. Some officials have said private messages to Moscow are much stronger than the public statements. ``We are letting them know that if they really crack down, we will react, and not just the administration. Congress could take steps, and we might not be able to control the reaction,'' said one administration source who requested anonymity. One senior administration official suggested Baker had sent a cable Tuesday to Shevardnadze that dealt with U.S. concerns over Lithuania in much sharper language than contained in the White House statement. Later, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler denied that Baker had sent a message. She called that report erroneous. And Fitzwater said he did not think such a cable had been sent on Tuesday, that there may have been confusion with ``an earlier cable over the weekend.'' Still, the spokesman said, ``I think that the Soviet Union is certainly aware of our position.'' Soviet officials said they expected the Lithuanian controversy to be high on the agenda when Shevardnadze visits Washington early next month. The U.S. government has never acknowledged the Soviet annexation of Lithuania and its sister republics of Latvia and Estonia during World War II. Latvia and Estonia are moving more slowly toward independence. Lithuania declared independence on March 11, and since then the Soviet military has increased pressure on the republic. Soviet soldiers jeopardized the improvement of U.S.-Soviet relations by breaking into two hospitals in Lithuania to detain Lithuanian deserters from the Soviet Army. Possible U.S. responses include postponing a summit scheduled for June or delaying treaties on nuclear, chemical and conventional arms, said two well-placed sources, who also requested anonymity. ``We don't want to do something that would punish us as much as the Russians,'' said one source. A likely first step would be suspension of trade talks designed to give the Soviet Union most favored nation status in commerce with the United States. Gorbachev has shunned direct public comment on Lithuania, letting Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov and other generals issue warnings, said a senior American intelligence analyst. The Soviet constitution gives the 15 republics the right to secede, but none has tried it before. Gorbachev may be avoiding public comment on Lithuania, allowing his generals to make threats and use limited force, so that he can later disown the policy, sources suggested. Gorbachev met Monday with Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and Kennedy later quoted him as saying the Kremlin would not use force in Lithuania ``unless lives were threatened.'' A senior Soviet diplomat in Washington told a news conference Tuesday that Lithuania likely would be allowed to secede, but not immediately. The central government wants the Lithuanians to hold a referendum on secession and open negotiations with Moscow on issues including the rights of non-Lithuanians in the republic, Soviet military bases there, and compensation for major enterprises built there by the central government, said Sergei Chetverikov, the No. 3 man at the Soviet embassy.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Apartheid Art Exhibit Opens at Parliament
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An international anti-apartheid art exhibition opened in a Parliament building Wednesday to build awareness among Japanese lawmakers of South Africa's policy of racial segregation. The event, ``Apartheid Non,'' features 154 paintings, sculptures and posters by 81 artists from 34 countries. Many works have political and anti-apartheid themes. Some depict scenes of life in South Africa. The three-day display was organized by the Parliamentarians' Anti-Apartheid League, a 50-member group led by Socialist lawmaker Kanji Kawasaki. The exhibition, which arrived in Japan in June 1988, has visited more than 180 places throughout the nation, according to Atsuko Hironaka, a spokeswoman for a group of citizens who organized the tour. The exhibit has also gone to 10 other countries. It originated in Paris in 1983. ``Japan will continue to urge the South African authorities to make further efforts for a peaceful solution to apartheid,'' Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said at the opening ceremony for the exhibit. ``We strongly look forward to the establishment of a democratic South Africa where there is no racial discrimination.'' Socialist Party Chairwoman Takako Doi, also speaking at the ceremony, called for more efforts by Japan to end apartheid, under which South Africa's black majority has no voice in national affairs. ``Our anti-apartheid measures have never been enough. We have to work harder so that we won't be ashamed of not observing our constitution, which urges us to gain an honorable place in the world by fighting against dictatorship and oppression,'' she said. Japan came under international criticism in 1987 when it became South Africa's largest trading partner. But in 1988 it fell behind West Germany in total trade with South Africa. Figures for 1989 have not been released. Japanese sanctions against South Africa include a ban on direct investment, limits on cultural, sports and tourism exchanges, and a ban on sales of computers for police use.

DOC.HEAD: Experts: Taking the Byte Outta Crime Isn't Easy
DOC.TEXT: This was going to be a simple a story about computer viruses until the hackers intruded, until the hackers intruded, until the hackers intruded.... You get the idea. There are a lot of problems facing the nation's computers _ within and without. From big mainframes at universities and government installations to the personal computer that keeps track of your household finances, the equipment is vulnerable to a variety of intrusions by pranksters, vandals and just plain thieves, say computer experts. But the industry is split over how to deal with the threat or even what the threat is. Nearly all agree, however, with the assessment of Bill Murray, an information system security expert with the accounting firm of Ernst & Young: ``if people become sufficiently fearful, they'll stop using computers.'' In 1989, computer software and related services were a $60 billion industry in the United States. Software are the sets of instructions that tell computers what to do. Some experts believe the biggest threat comes from rogue programs _ viruses, bombs and worms _ called ``malicious software.'' They can cripple a personal computer or a network by scrambling or deleting data or simply duplicating itself, like the first paragraph of this story, eating up valuable storage space. News reports about these programs, like the Friday the 13th virus that failed to materialize in large numbers last October, have panicked many computer users. Other experts focus on the self-styled `catch-me-if-you-can' hackers who make a game of out of invading the computer systems of industry and government. Less than three months ago, a federal court jury in Syracuse, N.Y. convicted a former graduate student of unleashing a computer ``worm'' program that disrupted a nationwide computer system, Internet. Earlier this month, reports surfaced of a new intruder in the same system, indicating that not every worm may have turned. ``What we have seen and can confirm is an intruder was making persistent attempts to get into the Internet systems,'' said Terry McGillen, a spokesman for the Software Engineering Institute, a Defense Department-funded operation that oversees the Computer Emergency Response Team, or CERT. ``We know of several systems that have been broken into and several more attempts'' on March 15 and 16, said McGillen. However, he declined to say where the intrusions occurred in the massive Internet system which is linked to 200,000 computer terminals including ones at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. McGillen said it was CERT policy, not to protect the innocent _ or even the guilty _ but to encourage victims to share their experiences with intruders. Such information is often difficult, if not impossible, to come by said several computer experts. ``As far as computer crime is concerned, I can assure you there are no valid numbers,'' said Donn B. Parker, a computer security expert at SRI International, a research center in Menlo Park, Calif. The reason, he added ``is because the victims do all they can to avoid reporting it.'' Large corporations, universities and government agencies, out of embarassment or fear of encouraging further tampering, don't like to admit publicly they've been hit by a virus or hacker, agreed Stuart Katzke, of the National Institute of Standards and Technology, a federal agency in Gaithersburg, Md. ``That's been a problem with the computer security area for a long time, people choose to cover up incidents and not report them,'' added Katzke, chief of NIST's division of computer security. NIST doesn't compile listings of computer security problems, neither does CERT. Last month Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said ``increasingly, computers are being found in illegal activities of drug networks.'' But the FBI lacks hard data on software crime because computers are often perceived as a tool in committing other crimes such as fraud and theft, said an FBI spokeswoman in Washington. ``In relation to other crimes, it's more a medium than the actual culprit,'' explained Kelley Cibalus, the spokeswoman. The lack of centralized information about computer security was ``something we heard at the hearings'' conducted last fall by a subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee, said Eric Hauser, an aide to Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., the subcommittee's chairman. Legislation to restrict computer viruses is pending in various forms before the criminal justice subcommittee in the House and is being explored on the Senate side. While the debate rages over whether hackers or viruses are the main threat to computer security, experts agree that attitudes have to change about interfering with someone else's equipment _ for whatever reason. ``One thing being discussed in the industry,'' said NIST's Dennis Steinauer, ``is what should we do to instill an updated sense of ethics. Computer and network technology is of value to us all, but tampering undermines the technology for all of us because it usually means restrictions are placed on it.''

DOC.HEAD: The Latest New Nixon: Mellower, Regrets Swearing on Tape
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 6th graf, Later when
DOC.TEXT: Richard Nixon says that a most unfortunate disclosure during Watergate was that he used foul language in the Oval Office. Other presidents also swore, he says, ``but none of them had the bad judgment to have it on tape.'' Most people swear at one time or another, he says, ``but since neither I nor most other presidents had ever used profanity in public, millions were shocked. I have heard other presidents use very earthy language in the Oval Office.'' Nixon says this in ``In the Arena,'' a book summing up his life. The seventh book he has published since resigning the presidency in 1974 is the most personal statement of how he has come to feel at peace with himself. ``Only when you have been in the depths can you truly appreciate the heights,'' he says. ``In the end what matters is that you have always lived life to the hilt,'' he writes. ``I have won some great victories and suffered some devastating defeats. But win or lose, I feel fortunate to have come to that time in life when I can finally enjoy what my Quaker grandmother would have called `peace at the center.''' At the height of the Watergate scandal, in April 1974, Nixon released a 1,300-page volume of transcripts of secretly taped conversation. They were heavily edited to put private comments in the most favorable light and are especially remembered for hundreds of designations, ``expletive deleted.'' Later when the blanks were filled in, Nixon's heavy use of barnyard language was laid bare. For example, instructing aide John Dean, he said ``I don't give a shit what happens. I want you all to stonewall it.'' At another meeting he told Dean and former attorney general John Mitchell, ``The point is, get the goddamn thing over with.'' The 369-page book is to be published by Simon & Schuster on May 2. Excerpts appearing in the current issue of Time magazine focus on his attempts to debunk ``myths'' about his role in Watergate. He characterizes as ``the most blatantly false myth'' the assertion that he knew in advance about the 1972 break-in at Democratic headquarters in the Watergate. However, no one knowledgeable has made that claim. Nixon said ``the most serious myth'' was that ``on my specific orders, the CIA obstructed the FBI'' investigation of Watergate. In fact, the disclosure that cost him the presidency was that he tried to bring that about, even though his instruction was rebuffed by the CIA. The Nixon in the book, at 77, is a mellower Nixon than he previously showed himself to be. For instance, he says kind things about journalists: ``I could not possibly have gone as far as I did in the political arena without having the benefit of some balanced as well as negative coverage.'' And, he takes a surprisingly relaxed view of flag burning. ``If the day comes when they refrain from desecrating it only because of the law or some dimly remembered custom, it will have truly become an empty symbol,'' he says. Nixon says his wife, Pat, had better political instincts than he did. ``She urged me not to run for governor of California,'' he says. ``She was right.'' Nixon lost that race in 1962, two years after he lost the presidency to John F. Kennedy, and snarled at reporters ``you won't have Nixon to kick around any more because, gentlemen, this is my last press conference.'' Nixon says the question he is asked most frequently is ``How's Pat?'' His reply: ``Considering what she has been through, she is remarkably well. You would never know that she had suffered a stroke. She no longer participates in public events, but devotes all of her time and energy to her children and (four) grandchildren. Nixon observes how television has changed politics, saying there's little correlation between what makes a good leader and what is a good TV performance. ``In the age of soundbites, the three-minute Gettysburg Address would have been 2 1@2 minutes too long,' he writes. ``One of today's ambitious young correspondents would probably have summed it up this way: `The president himself admitted to this subdued Pennsylvania crowd what his men have been saying privately: that no one will long remember what he said here.'''

DOC.HEAD: Nixon's Helpful Hints for Handling Reporters
With AM-Nixon's Book
DOC.TEXT: Richard Nixon thinks some reporters are ``con artists'' who don't always tell the truth when they're interviewing public figures. Here, from his book ``In the Arena'' is what he thinks reporters mean by some of their lines: _``I really want to write a positive story.'' Nixon: ``This is usually a signal that subject should watch his back, because someone is about to stick a knife into it.'' _``If you don't talk to me, your side of the story won't be represented.'' Nixon: ``... When you get this line from a reporter, trust your instincts. Does he want your views or just the legitimacy that your participation in the story will give him? In a way, this con is a form of blackmail: Talk to me, or else...'' _``You should hear what this other guy said about you.'' Nixon: ``This is journalistic entrapment, a favorite tactic of reporters who want to provoke you into saying something critical about the other guy. Don't be suprised if your angry jibe appears in print and his doesn't.'' _``I'm going to write the story, whether you talk to me or not.'' Nixon: When you hear this, you should consider whether the reporter might be worried he doesn't have a story at all unless you talk to him.'' _``Oh, and just one more question.'' Nixon: Forget the other 10 he asked; this is what he really came for.''

DOC.HEAD: P&G to Expand Use of Recycled Containers
DOC.TEXT: Procter & Gamble said Wednesday that it will expand the use of recycled plastic in containers for Tide, Cheer and other products to create a new demand for the material and keep it out of landfills. The bottles will be specially marked and will start to appear on supermarket shelves this fall, the company said. Procter & Gamble estimates its expanded recycling effort will keep 80 million milk, water and soft drink plastic bottles out of U.S. landfills in its first year. It said the project will create a new demand for recycled plastic and legitimate expansion incentives for facilities that collect and reprocess plastic bottles. Frank Bossu, associate director of product development for the company, said the announcement marked ``another step toward expanding the use of recycled plastic to all of our brands.'' In the future, he said, Procter & Gamble wants all of its own bottles to be collected and reprocessed. Under the project announced Wednesday, recycled plastic will be used for select sizes of Tide, Cheer, Era, Dash, Downy and Spic 'n Span, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Major Member PACs Raised $15 million in 1989
EMBARGOED for release at 12:01 a.m. Thursday
DOC.TEXT: Political action committees controlled by members of Congress raised more than $15 million in the past three years and donated more than $3 million of that to other candidates for office, according to an analysis released Thursday. Common Cause, which wants Congress to outlaw the so-called ``member PACs,'' said five members of Congress had PACs which raised more than $1 million in the past two years. The analysis, based on year-end financial reports filed with the Federal Election Committee, covered 32 PACs associated with current members of Congress that raised at least $25,000 from Jan. 1, 1987 through Dec. 31, 1989. Those 32 PACs raised $14.96 million in the three-year period, Common Cause said. The total raised by the member PACs in that period surpasses $15 million if 15 additional member PACs which raised less than $25,000 each in the period are also counted. Common Cause, the self-styled public interest group, has been heavily lobbying Congress to make several major changes to campaign finance laws. The group has long been critical of allowing members of Congress to establish PACs, saying such committeess allow special interests to curry favor with lawmakers by donating to their campaigns and the member-controlled PACs. Members of Congress can put the money to a variety of uses provided they are related to the member's political activities. That provision has been loosely interpreted to allow member PACs to make contributions to other candidates and to pay for political travels and expenses. Common Cause said five members have PACs that raised more than $1 million each during the three-year period. The lamwakers and amounts raised by their PACs in the last three years are: Senate Republican Leader Robert Dole of Kansas, $5 million; Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., $1.5 million; Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., $1.4 million; Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., $1.1 million; and Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., $1 million. The top three Democratic House leaders also have member PACs. Speaker Thomas Foley's House Leadership Fund raised $353,509 in the three-year period, according to its report to the FEC. Majority Leader Richard Gephardt's PAC raised $495,000 in the period and Majority Whip William Gray's PAC raised $346,000. The PAC controlled by House Republican Leader Robert Michel of Illinois raised $72,000 in the same period and distributed more than half of its receipts to GOP candidates.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Kill 59 in Army Raid on Communist Base
DOC.TEXT: Government troops destroyed a heavily fortified Communist rebel training camp after two days of fierce fighting that left 59 insurgents and one soldier dead, the military reported Wednesday. Armed forces spokesman Col. Juanito Rimando said 23 troops were wounded as 1,200 soldiers stormed the camp. ``The report we received was sketchy, but judging by the size of the government casualties, I would say that it must have been a really big gunbattle,'' Rimando said. He said a platoon of Army Scout Rangers discovered the heavily fortified camp used by the Communist New People's Army on Sunday. It was in the remote mountain town of Lianga in Surigao del Sur province, about 540 miles southeast of Manila. Rimando said the troops called for reinforcements, and a two-day firefight ensued after rebel sentries spotted the soldiers around the camp. He said the rebels were armed with U.S.-made M-60 machineguns, grenade launchers and automatic rifles. Rimando said many of the rebels fled during the battle. Also Wednesday, Communist rebels ambushed a police patrol in central Manila almost one mile from the presidential palace. One police officer was killed, police spokesman Sgt. Florentino Bagallon said. He said police reinforcements killed one rebel and arrested another as they pursued the gunmen through a residential district. On Saturday, 12 Marxist rebels and three soldiers were killed in a shootout in Davao del Sur province, 620 miles southeast of Manila, the military said. Three soldiers were wounded and 11 reported missing. The clashes occurred on the eve of the New Peoples Army's 21st anniversary. The paramilitary rebel group is the military wing of the banned Communist Party of the Philippines. The National Democratic Front, an alliance of 12 underground Marxist groups including the Communist Party, renewed its offer for a cease-fire if President Corazon Aquino closes the six U.S. military bases here. In a statement marking the anniversary, the alliance urged Mrs. Aquino to close the U.S. bases so the two sides ``could in earnest sit down to arrive at a comprehensive political settlement.'' Mrs. Aquino has repeatedly rejected such offers. The commander of the U.S.-run Subic Bay Naval Base, Rear Adm. Roger Rich, banned non-essential travel to the capital this week by the more than 6,000 U.S. sailors at the base. He cited ``threats against U.S. military and military-associated personnel.'' Navy spokesman Lt. Cmdr. Kevin Mukri said the order bans visits to Manila for all personnel with the exception of servicemen with immediate family members in the city. That order does not apply to the 9,000 U.S. servicemen at Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila. But Air Force officials said personnel at the base were told to refrain from traveling to Manila at night.

DOC.HEAD: Educators Criticize Public Funds for Private School Tuitition
DOC.TEXT: A plan to give state money to poor parents so that their children can attend private schools could be a national model, supporters say. But critics say the idea suggests that people have ``given up'' on city schools. The Legislature last week passed a bill that would give as much as $2,500 to each of nearly 1,000 low-income Milwaukee students to help them leave the public schools and enroll in non-sectarian private schools. The average yearly tuition at the academies is $3,200. The experiment would affect about 1 percent of the city's estimated 97,000 students. The state funds used would be deducted from the city's school budget. Gov. Tommy G. Thompson said he will sign the bill into law by April 27 but will wait to see the results of the Milwaukee program before deciding whether the school choice plan should be expanded statewide. U.S. Education Undersecretary Ted Sanders, who praised the experiment, said the plan could provide a form for restructuring U.S. schools and give options to parents whose choices have been curtailed by their income. But a spokesman for the nation's largest teachers' union denounced the plan. ``It could lead to racial, educational and economic isolation of students. Those children left behind will feel the impact,'' said Howard Carroll of the National Education Association. Milwaukee's school superintendent, Robert Peterkin, also opposes the plan, saying it would drain resources from depleted inner-city schools and reverse two decades of city and surburban school desegregation achieved through voluntary busing. ``The concept that the competitive market place will magically make the public school system improve is simplistic,'' said Peterkin, who gained national attention in integrating Cambridge, Mass., schools. Peterkin nevertheless has said he won't challenge the program in court. Plans that allow parents more choice on where to send their children to school have gained momentum in the last five years. Minnesota and Iowa were among the first to offer tax credits to parents sending their children to private schools. Wisconsin's voucher plan would be first in the nation to directly provide government funds for the purpose. Parents not more than 75 percent above the federal poverty level _ an income of $12,000 for a family of four _ will be eligible. Those who already send their children to private schools are not. The bill would take effect for the next school year. Eight Milwaukee-area private schools have agreed to accept students. State Rep. Annette Williams, a Democrat who represents an inner-city Milwaukee district, sponsored the plan. At the invitation of the Bush administration, she has traveled around the nation in recent months touting the idea as a model for future school-choice plans. ``For the first time, poor people will get respect because they can take their $2,500 to a school of their choice and say, `I want my children educated,''' Ms. Williams said. A spokesman for the state's largest teachers union disagreed, saying the program only ships inner-city school problems to the suburbs. ``What it's really saying is Milwaukee has some major problems. We think the problems should be addressed, not sent to the suburbs,'' said Michael Brennan, legislative director for the Wisconsin Education Association Council. ``We think they've given up on the public schools in Milwaukee. We think that's a mistake. We don't think the answer is to shove those kids out of the system and hope the problem goes away.'' The Wisconsin chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union said it will watch the program to assure children are chosen fairly. ``Not all children, black children, will be candidates for those schools,'' said ACLU director Eunice Edgar. ``Those private schools will choose which students they accept. If it's publically funded, all children should have the option.''

DOC.HEAD: Letter from President Bush Cheers Hostage's Child
DOC.TEXT: The 9-year-old son of hostage Frank Reed is lonely and confused not to have his dad, but has spent the last few days cheered by a letter from President Bush advising him to ``stay strong.'' The president said ``he knows I miss my father a lot so he's doing all he can do to free the hostages,'' said Tarek Reed, whose third-grade class all wrote letters to the Oval Office asking Bush for help. The president wrote back to all 18 pupils. Reed, the director of the Lebanese International School in Beirut, was abducted on Sept. 9, 1986. Peggy Say, whose brother Terry Anderson is the longest-held Western hostage, delivered the letters when she and other relatives of the eight Americans missing in Lebanon met March 16 with Bush and his wife, Barbara. The meeting was on the fifth anniversary of Anderson's abduction. An Iranian-backed fundamentalist group, Islamic Jihad, claimed it kidnapped Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. ``I was amazed at the quick time with which (Bush) answered,'' said Reed's Syrian-born wife, Fifi. ``How can you not like a president like this? So down to earth.'' The president's secretary called Glenwood School soon after the hostage families' reunion to get the pupils home addresses, Mrs. Reed said.
