His replies started showing up at homes around this Boston suburb on Monday. ``The school has been enraptured,'' said Reed's 91-year-old mother, Leota Sprague. ``And little Tarek has read it and read it.'' The boy said Wednesday his schoolmates realize he is lonely without his father. ``They feel bad that my father was kidnapped,'' he said. ``They really care about my father.'' The president's letter said, ``We're trying hard to help bring your dad back home. Everyone tells me he's a wonderful man and I know you miss him a lot. I hope that all the hard work and all the prayers will result in the release of the hostages.'' ``Stay strong, pray for your dad's safe return,'' it said. Mrs. Reed said she was ``not that optimistic'' that her husband will be freed soon. ``But I'm not an optimist by nature,'' she added. Reed's mother said the president's gesture helped keep the family strong. ``This was just a lovely thing for him to do because our little boy is torn between knowing what we can't do and wishing we could,'' she said. ``We can't answer his questions because we're asking the same thing: Why? Why must this go on?''

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Rates Maryland as Best-Managed, West Virginia as Worst
DOC.TEXT: Maryland's leadership heads a magazine's rankings of the states' financial management, while West Virginia'a ``Ouija board guesswork'' drags that state down to last. Financial World magazine, in its April 17 issue, said it evaluated each state as if it were an independent business, with emphasis on balancing the budget, accurately predicting revenue and using generally accepted accounting principles. Maryland has an excellent accounting system, conducts regular performance evaluations and uses a solid development department to attract big-name companies to the state, the New York-based magazine said. Maryland also keeps spending in line with increases in personal income, the magazine said. Utah was ranked second, followed by Minnesota, Pennsylvania and South Carolina. At the bottom of the list were Massachusetts in 48th, followed by Louisiana and West Virginia, which raised taxes a record $392 million last year while trying to straighten out its finances. ``At least Louisiana has oil,'' the magazine said. ``West Virginia has had almost nothing except cheap coal, corrupt government and poverty. Expenditure estimates (are) little better than Ouiji board guesswork.'' The magazine said West Virginia's employee pension funds are grossly underfunded, its infrastructure is ``awful,'' and its computer system is behind the times. Chuck Polan, secretary of the West Virginia Department of Administration, said the article had raised some valid issues the state is working on, but, ``I thought the analysis was pretty shallow on West Virginia and all states.'' The magazine hailed Utah for keeping its debt low and short-term, Minnesota for its performance evaluations and huge ``rainy day'' fund, Pennsylvania for its accurate forecasting of revenues, and South Carolina for its focus on attracting investment and business. The rankings do not reflect the best places to live, the magazine said. ``It's entirely possible that the average citizen of West Virginia is far more comfortable in his state than the typical Marylander,'' the article said. The magazine said it interviewed state treasurers, chief budget officers and legislative leaders in each state.

DOC.HEAD: Frank Nears Decision on Re-election Bid
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Barney Frank, whose personal and professional relationship with a male prostitute is being investigated by the House ethics committee, said Wednesday that he will decide soon whether to seek a sixth term. The Massachusetts Democrat had said he would make no political announcement until the committee discloses its findings into his relationship with Stephen Gobie. However, Frank said he would begin raising campaign funds. ``You reach the point where if you don't do anything, you've decided by default,'' Frank said. Congressional candidates must formally submit nomination papers by May 8. A closed-door session of the ethics committee was set for Wednesday afternoon and there was speculation that an announcement would be made on the Frank case. Rep. Chester Atkins, D-Mass., a member of the panel, planned to attend the meeting. His attendance has been taken as a sign that Frank was not on the agenda because Atkins said last fall he would not attend meetings in which the Frank case was discussed. Atkins said his friendship with Frank and his role as the Democratic State Committee chairman in Massachusetts made him unable to remain impartial. Frank plans weekend fund-raisers in Boston and other towns to mark his 50th birthday Saturday. No Democrats have announced plans to run for Frank's seat. Two relatively unknown Republicans, lawyer John Soto and physician Jim Nuzzo, are running. The committee is investigating whether Frank violated House ethics regulations in his relationship with Gobie. Gobie alleges that Frank was aware he was running a sex-for-hire ring out of the congressman's Capitol Hill apartment. Frank said he fired Gobie from his job of personal assistant in 1986 after he learned of the prostitution ring. Frank has said he initially paid Gobie for sex, but later befriended him and gave him the job in an effort to change Gobie's life. Frank said he has testified before the ethics committee and has supplied it with all the documents and other information requested.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Searches Globe To Recover Looted Treasury
DOC.TEXT: Three lawyers in a cramped office in Panama City have been quietly trying to unravel a global web of transactions in hopes of recovering up to $800 million in assets they say Manuel Noriega looted from Panama. The money has been stored in at least 10 countries during the last 21 years, masked through shell corporations, bank accounts, homes, yachts and other property, prosecutors said. ``The corrupt arm of Noriega did not respect borders. It violated sovereignties; it exported its crimes,'' Eusebio Marchosky, head of the Panamanian task force, said in a speech Tuesday night before an international conference of government and corporate auditors. U.S. prosecutors of the Miami drug-trafficking charges against Noriega said in January that they had identified about $20 million of assets the deposed dictator squirreled away in bank accounts in the United States, Britain and Belgium. After the speech, the Panamanian prosecutors said Noriega still has property including a castle in France, a ranch in the Dominican Republic and apartments in Caracas, Venezuela, and Madrid and on the island of Majorca, Spain. The loot also includes sizable bank accounts, possibly including profits from drug trafficking, managed by associates of Noriega in West Berlin, Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan, said Eduardo Lombana, who along with Marchosky and Gonzalo Menendez-Franco faces the daunting task of recovering the assets. ``It's our duty to go for all the money you can find from this man. We don't know exactly how much, and we don't know exactly where it all is, but we know he has more or less $700-800 million, and we want that money,'' said Menendez-Franco. While Noriega is the primary focus of the search, the prosecutors say up to 400 people, ranging from Noriega's military associates and family members to former bank managers and local officials, have taken assets belonging to Panama. ``It's not only Noriega. It's the whole crew,'' said Menendez-Franco. ``At the vault of the national bank, the military arrived with guns and took out $140 million. My colleague has a voucher for a yacht worth hundreds of thousands of dollars that Noriega sold to one of his officers for $12,000. ... The situation in Panama is really diabolic.'' A Miami-based magazine called Money Laundering Alert reported last month that almost $1 billion was transferred from a Swiss bank in Panama to a Grand Cayman bank in the four months after Noriega was indicted in Florida in February 1988. The magazine quoted classified State Department documents. The special prosecutors, who have no computers, only four aides and not enough money from the bankrupt Panamanian government to pay the phone bill, say U.S. agents have been helpful in sharing information. And other clues are rolling in daily. ``The office has just received a letter from a Swedish businessman offering to buy property Noriega had in Sweden,'' said Menendez-Franco, adding that they were previously unaware of the property. The 2-month-old group is swamped just trying to sort out the assets inside Panama and has not yet pursued leads in other countries. Also, many documents that might have helped track the money were destroyed during the U.S. invasion, prosecutors said. Much investigation is needed before Panama can indict Noriega and his associates, and for now, the small mountain of papers and computer files seized during the December U.S. invasion should remain in the United States for safekeeping, Marchosky said.

DOC.HEAD: Cruising Limits Put Brakes on National Pastime
DOC.TEXT: Teen-agers who want to keep cruising alive in the city that inspired the film ``American Graffiti'' may find themselves in violation of laws designed to limit the weekend rite of passage. The City Council approved the rules Tuesday night despite testimony from residents who mostly spoke against them. Many said there are few alternatives for youngsters in the central California city. ``It's a niche. It's a true niche. It's the way they are accepted,'' said Ron Bower Sr., president of the Cen-Cal Street Rods, a car club. Officials said the ordinances were not designed to outlaw cruising, concentrated on McHenry Avenue, but to give officers ways to control vandalism, drugs and gangs. ``My personal opinion is that moderate cruising will still exist along McHenry,'' said Police Chief Gerald McKinsey. Under the limits, motorists who pass checkpoints more than once in four hours would face fines ranging from $75 to $250. Pedestrians who routinely gather on the sidewalk and in parking lots along the strip would risk equal fines for loitering between 6 p.m. and 6 a.m. The ordinance, which requires a second reading before becoming law, will not affect the annual Graffiti Night. The June celebration of cruising, started two years after Modesto native George Lucas' film was released in 1973, draws up to 100,000 people in 30,000 cars. At other times, officers would enforce the ordinance within a marked no-cruising zone on McHenry Avenue when traffic moves less than 5 mph or intersections are blocked. The police department drafted the proposals out of concern that officers could not reach trouble spots when as many as 5,000 cars clogged the two-mile strip. Much of the problem, McKinsey says, is that Modesto attracts teens from other cities where cruising already has been banned. Nearly half of all citations issued along McHenry were to non-Modesto residents, he said. Peak cruising hours also account for more than half of all assaults on McHenry Avenue and 78 percent of all drug arrests, McKinsey said. Backers of restrictions agree that a pastime that grew out of the good-natured 1950s has grown unmanageable in this city of 130,000. ``The vandalism, drinking, drugs and prostitutes filter into our street and yards every weekend night,'' said Terry McCloskey, a resident who attended the council meeting. ``Many of us feel like prisoners in our own homes on weekend nights because we're afraid of what will happen to our property.'' But teen-agers say they cruise for the same reason as their parents: to meet dates and show off their cars. Cruising has become a ritual for teen-agers who grew up with the legacy of the film ``American Graffiti.'' ``I'm 17 years old, and I've waited all my life to cruise,'' said Billy Moorehead. ``You can't get rid of us. We're going to stay.''

DOC.HEAD: Growth, Though Better Than First Thought, Still Small
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy grew a modest 1.1 percent in the last quarter, better than previously believed, the government said Wednesday. Analysts predicted the rebound will continue this year, but at its slowest pace since the last recession. ``The economy is still quite sluggish,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic adviser for the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``We're not in recession and probably won't go into recession, but economic growth will be very, very slow.' The Commerce Department first reported in January that fourth-quarter growth had edged up a barely perceptible 0.5 percent, then revised the rate upward in February to 0.9 percent before issuing its final 1.1 percent estimate Wednesday. ``The revision showed an economy on sounder footing than earlier reported,'' observed allen Sinai, chief economist with the Boston Co. But while the final estimate was an improvement and provided fresh reason to believe the economy will avoid a recession, it also demonstrated softness in some sectors, particularly construction and manufacturing. In another report Wednesday that pointed to weakness in construction, the department said that while new home sales in February bounced back 3.1 percent from steep declines in December and January, the 607,000 units sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate last month were well below the 647,000 units sold in 1989. But in a third report, the department said fourth-quarter after-tax corporate profits rose 2.8 percent. It was the first advance of the year after declines of 1.1 percent in the first quarter, 7.2 percent in the second and 5.4 percent in the third. Economic growth in the final three months of 1989 followed increases of 3.7 percent in the first quarter, 2.5 percent in the second and 3 percent in the third. The 3 percent gain for all of 1989 was the smallest since a 2.7 percent advance in 1986 and followed increases of 4.4 percent in 1988 and 3.7 percent in 1987. ``Nothing in the report hints at a recession,'' Sinai said, ``so the focus has to be, does slow growth continue or does it accelerate? The first half (of 1990) probably will be more of the same, between flat growth and 2 percent.'' The latest survey of top economists by Blue Chip Economic Indicators projects growth of 1.7 percent this year. That would be the poorest performance since economic activity declined 2.5 percent in 1982 during the last recession. The Commerce Department attributed its final GNP revision to an increase in final sales and a decrease in inventories. John Silvia, financial economist with Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago, said sales rose because consumer spending was ``up just a touch,'' which in turn helped reduce stockpiles and possible job losses. ``High inventories tend to lead to cutbacks in future production,'' he noted. ``It doesn't seem to be the case that inventories are going to lead to a slowdown in the economy.'' Another plus was a 9.6 percent increase in exports compared to a 2.2 percent gain in imports. Services were up 5.9 percent. While overall personal consumption expenditures rose 0.5 percent, durable goods were down 14 percent and capital investment was off 5.4 percent _ both signs of sluggishness in the manufacturing sector. An inflation index tied to the GNP rose at an annual rate of 4.5 percent last year, reinforcing Sinai's belief that the economy will grow sluggishly, ``occasionally flirting with recession, until inflation gets down low enough to permit the Fed to lower interest rates.'' The Federal Reserve forced up interest rates last year in its fight against inflation. While inflation has not declined significantly, however, the Bush administration and many economists have urged the Fed to ease its credit policies to stimulate the economy. The various changes left the GNP expanding in the fourth quarter at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.17 trillion.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Hears Clash Over Preferential Awards of Broadcast Licenses
DOC.TEXT: Opposing sides in the Supreme Court's latest affirmative action cases clashed Wednesday over the value and constitutionality of preferential treatment for women and minorities seeking broadcast licenses. Opponents said the preferences aren't achieving their goals and violate the rights of white men. But the policy was defended by the Federal Communications Commission and others as a way to let ``missing voices'' be heard on radio and television. The court, which dealt affirmative action a major setback last year, heard arguments in cases from Florida and Connecticut that could affect other programs designed to counter the effects of alleged past discrimination. The court is expected to announce decisions in both cases by July. Justice Antonin Scalia took a leading role during the two-hour session in challenging the FCC's policy, questioning whether it promotes diverse viewpoints. ``It has to do with nothing but blood, not background and environment,'' he said. At one point, Scalia suggested that a black person from the wealthy, predominantly white community of Scarsdale, N.Y., could benefit from such preferential treatment. ``Whether you were born in Scarsdale or Harlem contributes to what you believe,'' replied Margaret Polivy, a lawyer for a Hispanic-owned company in Florida. ``What we have identified here are groups that have been excluded from the mass media.'' She said Congress regards women and racial minorities as ``missing voices'' which should be given special consideration in the awarding of broadcast station licenses. Achieving equality is ``a concept that underlies our democracy,'' Ms. Polivy added. But Scalia said promoting a colorblind society is just as important. The idea that government benefit should be awarded regardless of ``the color our skin ... also underlies our democracy,'' he said. Ms. Polivy represents Rainbow Broadcasting Co., which was awarded a TV license in Orlando, Fla. A rival, Metro Broadcasting Inc., argued unsuccessfully before a federal appeals court that it was denied the license unfairly. Gregory Guillot, Metro's lawyer, said the FCC's affirmative action program has increased minority ownership of television and radio stations by only 1 percent in 18 years. ``I'm no mathematician. But that means there will be 600 years left'' before equal racial representation in broadcast company ownership is achieved, Guillot said. Daniel M. Armstrong, representing the commission, said ``some race-conscious steps are necessary'' to make sure women and minorities have access to the media. In the Connecticut case, a federal appeals court struck down the commission's so-called distress-sale policy, which allows a broadcaster faced with the loss of a license to sell to a minority-owned buinsess at 75 percent of market value. The appeals court overturned the award of a license in Hartford to Hispanic-led Astroline Communications Co. The appeals court gave Alan Shurberg, who is white, a chance to compete for it. J. Roger Wollenberg, Astroline's lawyer, said the minority groups Congress has singled out for preferential treatment ``really and truly have not had a break in our society... While the Constitution may be colorblind, the truth is race is with us.'' Shurberg's attorney, Harry Cole, said Astroline won the license only because its general partner, Richard P. Ramirez, has a Hispanic surname. ``Why is Alan Shurberg any less capable of increasing diversity just because he is white?'' he asked. The justices last year struck down an affirmative action program in Richmond, Va., that set aside a percentage of local public works contracts for minority-owned business. The ruling cast doubt on the validity of numerous preferential plans of states and cities but had no direct effect on federal programs. A less conservative high court in 1980 upheld a federal public works program that set aside 10 percent of the funds for minority contracts. The high court said then that Congress has special constitutional authority to approve affirmative action. One reason the commission's affirmative action policies have remained in place since the early 1970s is because Congress has barred it from spending money to restudy or repeal the policies.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus-Affirmative Action
Court Settles Adverse Evidence Issue in Mississippi Death Sentence Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Wednesday gave state appeals courts the power to uphold murderers' death sentences even if their sentencing juries wrongly considered some adverse evidence. By a 5-4 vote, the justices said appeals courts are empowered to reweigh the sentencing evidence in capital punishment cases without sending them back for new jury determinations. The dissenters said the decision may streamline the carrying out of capital punishment ``but at a cost that seems ... to be intolerable.'' The court stopped short of upholding the death sentence of Chandler Clemons, who had challenged a state court's reweighing of the sentencing evidence in his case. Clemons was convicted of killing a delivery man after robbing him of $5 in cash and a few pizzas in Vicksburg, Miss., three years ago. One of the aggravating factors Clemons' sentencing jury considered was the ``especially heinous, atrocious or cruel'' nature of the crime. The Mississippi Supreme Court later acknowledged that, under past rulings by the nation's highest court, such an aggravating factor is unconstitutionally too vague. But rather than throw out Clemons' sentence, the state Supreme Court ruled that he would have been sentenced to death even if the impermissible factor had not been considered. Clemons had contended that such a reweighing by an appellate court violated his rights. Rejecting that contention, Justice Byron R. White wrote for the court, ``The Constitution does not prevent a state appellate court from upholding a death sentence ... by reweighing of the aggravating and mitigating evidence.'' White said state appeals courts also may determine that such an error amounted to ``harmless error.'' White was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justices Harry A. Blackmun, William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and John Paul Stevens dissented. Writing for the four dissenters, Blackmun said, ``If a death sentence is to be imposed, it should be pronounced by a decision-maker who will look upon the face of the defendant as he renders judgment.'' ``The bloodless alternative approved by the majority conveniently may streamline the process of capital sentencing,'' Blackmun said, ``but at a cost that seems to me to be intolerable.'' The decision did not uphold Clemons' death sentence, but instead sent his case back to the state Supreme Court for further study. White said it was unclear whether the state court actually engaged in a reweighing of the sentencing trial evidence or in a harmless-error analysis. Clemons used a shotgun to kill Arthur Shorter, prosecutors said, because he thought the delivery man might be able to identify him as the robber.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Appoint Don Newman to Aviation Organization
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he will appoint Don M. Newman as the U.S. representative on the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization. Newman, 66, is a former undersecretary of the Department of Health and Human Services and a longtime associate of former HHS Secretary and Indiana Gov. Otis Bowen. Newman was a pharmacist before entering government work. Newman, who lives in Washington, would succeed Edmund Stohr.

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Says Pollution Hits Minorities Worst
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Denis in 9th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Minorities and the poor should take the lead in fighting for clean air and water because they suffer most from pollution, Jesse Jackson said Wednesday. ``The common people who marched for the right to vote must now march for the right to breathe,'' Jackson said as he launched a six-stop ``Rainbow Environmental Tour.'' He praised community leaders in the River Terrace neighborhood of Northeast Washington who have been fighting plans to expand an electricity generating plant they blame for fouling the air. His tour is part of the buildup for Earth Day on April 22, when worldwide rallies, demonstrations and other events are scheduled to support the environmental movement. ``Throughout this country, poor communities are stained by the worst pollution,'' Jackson said. The veteran civil rights leader and two-time Democratic presidential contender said his stops in Georgia, New Mexico, California and Los Angeles would focus attention on efforts by blacks, Hispanics and Indians to battle environmental hazards where they live. ``These struggles are examples of a growing people's movement for environmental justice across the land,'' he said at a news conference. ``They explode the widespread myth that the poor and minorities do not care about the environment.'' Protests in River Terrace have stalled plans by the Potomac Electric Power Co. to build two more combustion turbine generators at its Benning Road station, burning oil or coal to generate electricity. Denis Hayes, chairman of Earth Day 1990, said at the news conference that most members and leaders of major national environmental groups have been white, but that they have worked with minority groups to fight pollution hazards. ``We're calling attention to something that already exists _ a broad-based coalition,'' said Hayes, who is accompanying Jackson on the tour. Jackson will be in Atlanta on Friday, Albuquerque, N.M., on Saturday, Richmond, Calif., on Sunday and Los Angeles on Monday. The tour ends Tuesday in Baton Rouge, La.

DOC.HEAD: Upjohn Authorized to Field Test Squash, Cantaloupe
DOC.TEXT: The Upjohn Co. of Kalamazoo, Mich., has been authorized to field test squash and cantaloupe that have been genetically altered to resist two major crop diseases, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. James W. Glosser, head of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said the squash and cantaloupe have been altered to resist cucumber mosaic virus, or CMV, and papaya ringspot virus, PRV. Glosser said the agency has reviewed the field-test procedures and determined ``Upjohn is following the necessary steps to assure the safety of the field tests'' in California, Georgia and Michigan. The tests will be conducted in May in Kern and San Benito counties, California; Worth County, Ga.; and Kalamazoo County, Mich. Upjohn will infect the genetically altered squash and cantaloupe with CMV and PRV under controlled conditions and then monitor the plants for disease symptoms, Glosser said. Current practices for controlling the diseases in the crops include chemical treatments, buring infected plants and spraying fields with low levels of the viruses to stimulate immunity. Glosser said the Upjohn field tests are the first permitted by the USDA agency for genetically altered squash or cantaloupe. However, last August, the agency issued a permit to a Cornell University researcher for a similar study on CMV-tolerant cucumbers. Cucumber, cantaloupe and squash belong to the same plant family and are similarly affected by CMV, which results in yellowing and in distortion of leaves and fruit. Like all plant viruses, CMV and PRV do not harm humans, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Capital Gains Tax Fight Erupts into Word War
DOC.TEXT: The economists and tax lawyers took over Wednesday and turned the battle over President Bush's No. 1 legislative goal _ a cut in the tax on capital gains _ into a mind-boggling word fight over elasticity, static revenue and induced realizations. Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., had billed it as ``the Finance Committee equivalent of a one-on-one game between Michael Jordan and Magic Johnson.'' Nobody won and there was no evidence any member of the Senate panel had changed his mind. The chief combatants: Kenneth W. Gideon, assistant secretary of the treasury for tax policy, and Ronald A. Pearlman, who used to hold that job but now is chief of staff for Congress's Joint Committee on Taxation. The issue: How would Bush's proposal to cut the tax on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of investments, affect federal tax collections over the next six years? The cut would increase revenues by $12.5 billion, Gideon said. The cut would reduce tax revenues by $11.4 billion, Pearlman said. That's a difference of $23.9 billion _ sizable even by Washington standards. Pearlman and his staff wrote a 69-page pamphlet to justify their estimate; Gideon responded with a 14-pager and 29 pages of backup explanation, charts and tables. Pearlman said almost all the difference was caused by Treasury and congressional experts who could not agree on how many billion dollars worth of capital gains would be pocketed _ or realized, as the experts say _ if there were no change in tax law. Pearlman relied on a Congressional Budget Office projection of $254 billion worth of capital gains this year, up 50 percent from 1988. He said gains generally rise with the stock market and that four times between 1977 and 1988, gains had increased by 50 percent over a two-year period. Gideon cited a White House Office of Management and Budget forecast of $214 billion of gains and said ``the year-to-year relation of realizations to stock prices is weak at best.'' Gideon emphasized differences with Pearlman over ``elasticity'' _ that is, how much would taxpayers increase or reduce their investments in response to a change in tax law. Gideon and the administration are far more optimistic than Pearlman and Democratic leaders of Congress that, for years to come, cutting the capital-gains tax will induce people to sell old investments and put the money into new ones. Pearlman acknowledged there would be a considerable amount of new buying and selling for a year or two as a result of the rate cut. Nevertheless, he says, the law still would leave many people with a strong incentive to hold their investments until death and pay a far lower tax. After a quick review of Pearlman's pamphlet, Gideon said, ``our preliminary conclusion is that we find no basis in the arguments presented ... for changing the elasticities utilized in our estimates.'' ``The Joint Committee staff relies on 30 years of historical economic data,'' countered Pearlman. Michael J. Boskin, Bush's chief economics adviser, weighed in with word that Gideon's estimates ``are more representative (than Pearlman's) of the extensive research on the effect of changes in capital-gains tax rates on realization.'' Jane Gravelle, a senior specialist with the Library of Congress, presented a brand new study of her own _ and concluded that a capital-gains cut might cost the government even more revenue than the Joint Committee staff predicted. In the end, the experts were conciliatory. ``We respect the right of ... (Pearlman's) staff to hold a different professional opinion,'' said Gideon. And Ms. Gravelle reminded the lawmakers of what they have always suspected: ``In the final analysis, there is always some uncertainty associated with statistical studies.''

DOC.HEAD: Independent Television Station Banned After an Hour on the Air
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's first independent television station was banned Wednesday after being on the air barely one hour. Federal inspectors interrupted the broadcasting, saying the station, Studio B Television, failed to get permission from the official state-run Belgrade television. ``The real reason is ... political struggle,'' said a source at Studio B, who refused to be identified. He alleged that the state was trying to preserve its monopoly on information. The spokesman said the station had received permission from the Federal Board for Communications to start broadcasting 10 years ago. ``But the climate at the time was not auspicious. Things have changed now,'' he said, referring to political and economic reform sweeping Eastern Europe. The independent station plans to provide general information, music and entertainment. The state Tanjug news agency said the independent station was swarmed with calls from disappointed viewers after it went off the air, demanding that the program be continued. It was not known when the station would be back on the air.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor's to Test Honecker's Competency to Stand Trial
DOC.TEXT: Doctors will examine ousted Communist leader Erich Honecker to determine if he is physically and mentally able to face charges of corruption and abuse of power, a prosecutor said Wednesday. A team of medical specialists, including psychiatrists, will also examine other officials from Honecker's regime to determine their competency to stand trial, said deputy chief prosecutor Lothar Reuter. The examination further increases the chances that the 77-year-old man who ruled East Germany under strict socialism for 17 years will avoid a criminal trial. Much of the fervor to prosecute the former authorities has eased as some of East Germany's freely elected leaders struggle with allegations they had ties to the Communist government and its network of functionaries and informants. Reuter's announcement, described by the state news agency ADN as his ``personal recommendation,'' came two days after the chief prosecutor's office said there were no grounds to charge Honecker, former economics minister Guenther Mittag and former state security chief Erich Mielke with high treason. Chief Prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph also said that Honecker and the other two had been cleared of conspiracy charges. But Honecker, now in poor health, and other officials are still under investigation for charges of corruption and abuse of power. Reuter said the independent medical team plans to complete its examinations by the end of April. Honecker and the 64-year-old Mittag are accused of embezzling state funds to build vacation homes and buy luxuries. Mielke, 84, is charged with abusing his control of the state security system. The prosecutor's office said indictments against members of Honecker's regime were not expected before May or June. It said trials of the three probably would not begin before summer because of the poor health of all three men. Honecker's government was deposed in October by a massive peaceful revolt. He was arrested in January after undergoing surgery for kidney cancer and was freed the next day.

DOC.HEAD: Space Telescope No Longer Bugged By Bugs
LaserPhoto NY19
DOC.TEXT: NASA began preparations Wednesday to load the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope into the shuttle Discovery after working out a few bugs, namely gnat-like midges. Technicians snared about 40 of the insects before removing the traps and preparing for Thursday's installation. ``We're up and running,'' said George Diller, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The agency had planned to install the telescope in the orbiter Tuesday. But it was forced to delay the procedure after midges were found in a payload preparation room on the launch tower. Engineers feared the insects might damage the fragile 25,000-pound telescope, the most expensive unmanned spacecraft ever built. NASA decided to proceed with preparations to install the telescope after only three or so midges were captured late Tuesday and early Wednesday. During the previous 24 hours, 37 midges had been sucked into 4-foot cylinders containing lights and fans that apparently lured the insects. Technicians spent Wednesday removing the special protective bag from the telescope and opening Discovery's payload bay door. The delay in loading the telescope will not affect Discovery's scheduled April 12 liftoff, Diller said. The launch may be moved up a day or two, in fact, since technicians needed little of the contingency time built into Discovery's prelaunch program. Discovery's five astronauts are to deploy the Hubble on the second day of the five-day mission. Once it begins orbiting 370 miles above Earth, the telescope will be capable of looking seven times more deeply into space and detecting objects 50 times fainter than the best ground-based observatory. Astronomers will be able to look back almost to the beginning of time by studying stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling toward Earth for 14 billion years.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: The usual club crawlers, hacks and nighttime entrepreneurs of the city's urban jungle had some beastly company in Wednesday's pre-dawn hours when the circus came to town. The Ringling Bros. Barnum & Bailey Circus sent 17 elephants, 42 horses, three camels, four llamas and a streetsweeper through an East River tunnel for their annual trek from a railroad yard in Queens to Madison Square Garden. About 80 people, tossing peanuts and apples, were waiting to greet them. Walter Clark, who had a plastic elephant trunk strapped over his nose to welcome the circus, said he just came from an annual elephant party. ``We watched Dumbo videos and ate animal crackers,'' he said, sipping on Elephant malt liquor. ``The focus is pretty much on elephants, but if a llama showed up we wouldn't kick them out.'' The real elephants, wearing silvery head masks with small lights, lumbered trunk-to-tail at the head of the procession down 34th Street, pausing for a 1:45 a.m. buffet of 250 pounds of carrots, lettuce and apples. Yolanda Jardine, 22, petted one of the elephants, a well mannered male named Beecher. ``When I have a baby, I'll name it Beecher,'' she said.

Four generations of one family crowded into the waiting room at Florida Hospital to greet the arrival of the fifth generation and an addition for the fourth. Annie Marie West, 17, gave birth to Kenneth Michael, making Carroll and Laura Kinney great-great-grandparents. On the same day, the Kinneys became great-grandparents again when granddaughter Melonie Ridout, 26, gave birth to Allysa Carole. The babies are the 40th and 41st members of the family. ``I didn't think I'd live to have five generations,'' said Mrs. Kinney, 79. ``But I'm glad to have kids.'' Her husband said the near-simultaneous births were ``a pretty nice thing to have happen when you're 79 years old.'' The mothers are first cousins once removed. They had the same due date _April 22. The Kinneys already had 14 great-grandchildren. Almost all of the family lives in Orlando. ``When the lord said be fruitful and multiply, he should have had his head examined,'' jested Lorraine Byington, great-grandmother of Kenneth Michael.

DOC.HEAD: Critics Denounce Amnesty Plan for Former Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: Critics on both sides of the border Wednesday denounced a West German government proposal to grant amnesty to former members of East Germany's hated secret police. In Bonn, members of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's junior coalition partners, the Free Democrats, joined with the left-leaning opposition Social Democrats in rejecting a government proposal to grant amnesty to former members of the secret police force known as the Stasi. The 85,000-member Stasi and its 109,000 informers were used by East Germany's hard-line Stalinist government for decades to control the country. Under pressure from pro-democracy groups, outgoing Premier Hans Modrow ordered the secret police disbanded after the overthrow of hard-liner Erich Honecker last fall. Since East Germany's first free elections on March 18, which were won by a coalition headed by Lothar de Maiziere, there have been allegations some of the new 400-member parliament may have secret police links. The allegations have targeted de Maiziere and the leader of another party, Ibrahim Boehme of the Social Democrats. Both have denied any links to the secret police but Boehme has temporarily resigned his party post until his name is cleared. West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said Tuesday ``a generous amnesty,'' for the Stasi may be needed to quell further instability in East Germany. ``Not everyone who was forced to report to the Stasi was a criminal,'' Schaeuble said. Kohl later told reporters he agreed ``in principle'' with the proposal. Gerhard Baum, deputy chairman of the Free Democrats, strongly rejected the amnesty proposal Wednesday. ``The new democracy in the GDR (East Germany) must start with a thorough study of the past, not by drawing a line under it,'' as if it never existed, Baum said. ``The moral side of the changes in the GDR should not be forgotten,'' Baum said. He acknowledged that many Stasi members were innocent of wrongdoing, but added: ``Purposely committed illegal wrongs cannot be allowed to be swept under the table.'' Horst Ehmke of the main opposition Social Democrats also blasted the suggested amnesty. ``The freely elected parliament cannot sweep the `Stasi affairs' under the rug without seriously damaging the young democracy,'' Ehmke said. Former Stasi members should be allowed to begin new careers, Baum said, but it is ``out of the question'' to allow them to hold important political posts. East German leftist groups have demanded an immediate investigation into the allegations against newly elected parliament members. They called for demonstrations Thursday to press their demands to determine which deputies may be linked to the Stasi.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Baker Has Malignant Growth Removed
DOC.TEXT: Joy Baker, the wife of former Senate Republican Leader Howard H. Baker Jr., had a small malignant growth removed from her right lung Wednesday, a family spokesman said. The tumor was removed during a 90-minute operation by Mayo Clinic doctors at St. Marys Hospital in Rochester, Minn., said spokesman Tom Griscom. The growth, he said, was removed from the right lobe of her right lung. A source familiar with her case, who did not wish to be identified by name, said the growth was ``a low grade tumor'' not a recurrence of the cancer that was removed from the same lung in 1982. Mrs. Baker was to remain in the intensive care unit for two or three days, and in the hospital for another 10 days to two weeks. She is not expected to require additional treatment, the source said. Mrs. Baker is the daughter of the late Senate Republican leader Everett Dirksen of Illinois. Howard Baker served in the Senate from 1966 until 1984 and was President Reagan's White House chief of staff from February 1987 until July 1988. The Bakers' primary residence is in Huntsville, Tenn., but they also maintain a home in Washington, where Baker practices law.

DOC.HEAD: High Interest Rates, Low Confidence Depress Sales
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: High interest rates and declining consumer confidence somewhat depressed new home sales in February although they bounced back slightly from steep declines the previous two months, according to Commerce Department figures released Wednesday. The department said new single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 607,000 units in February after plummeting 6.8 percent in January and a revised 8.0 percent in December. But the February rate still was below the 649,000 homes sold in 1989 and, except for January, the lowest since 556,000 homes were sold on an annual basis last March. Sales totaled 589,000 in January. ``The housing industry has been adversely affected by the increase in mortgage rates in January and February,'' said economist Richard Peach of the Mortgage Bankers Association. ``I don't see much of a decline in rates in the months ahead and there's substantial risk that they will go higher in the second half of the year.'' David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, also pointed to weakness in the economy, including slower job growth, as contributing to a decline in consumer confidence and thus softer sales. The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. said interest on fixed-rate mortgages rose from 10.17 percent at the beginning of February to 10.31 percent before falling to 10.23 percent at month's end. Mark Obrinsky, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, described the 10 percent level a ``psychological barrier'' that was keeping the housing market a little weaker than at the end of 1989 when rates dropped into single digits. John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, also blamed high mortgage rates for a 2.3 percent decline in existing home sales last month. The Realtors said the February pace was the slowest in seven months. Many analysts had expected sales to surge with the unusually warm weather in January and February following the fourth coldest December on record. But Obrinsky said the median time to find a house is about seven weeks ``so that some that sat on the sidelines in December may still be looking but haven't found their house yet. ``It's possible we could see some further increases in March and April,'' he said. Sales were up 21.3 percent to 256,000 units at an annual rate in the South, more than rebounding from a 16.3 percent decline in January. But sales fell elsewhere in the nation. They were down 18 percent to 82,000 units in the Northeast, 6.4 percent to 88,000 units in the Midwest and 1.6 percent to 181,000 units in the West.

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lankan President Dissolves Cabinet
DOC.TEXT: Sri Lanka's president dissolved the Cabinet on Wednesday and prepared to appoint a new council of ministers, a senior government official said. Cabinet spokesman and Foreign Minister Ranjan Wijeratne said Prime Minister Dingiri Wijetunga resigned early Wednesday, clearing the way for the president's order to dissolve the Cabinet. ``The prime minister has ceased to hold office by resignation, the Cabinet of ministers stands dissolved by operation of law,'' said Wijeratne, reading a statement by President Ranasinghe Premadasa. Wijeratne said a new prime minister and Cabinet would be named Thursday. Wijetunga, who took office in March 1988, gave no explaination for the resignations, but Wijeratne said it marked the end of the Cabinet's one-year term. ``When he was appointed, the president said the term would be a one-year period,'' he said. The former Cabinet, which was appointed after Premadasa's United National Party won the parliamentary election, had 21 ministers and 50 deputy ministers. The Sri Lankan Constitution provides for a weak prime minister and gives all executive powers to the president. The president is also the head of state and the commander in chief of the armed forces.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Ally Predicts Economic Union By Summer
DOC.TEXT: A close adviser to West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl predicted Wednesday that economic union with East Germany could come as soon as July. Bernhard Vogel, chairman of the Konrad Adenauer Foundation, which is allied with Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, said East Germany would adopt the West German deutschmark as its currency as part of the union. Vogel called it ``a first courageous step to provide East Germans with the living conditions of their West German neighbors.'' East Germans, in an election 10 days ago, endorsed German unification and a market economy by choosing a coalition of conservative parties allied with the West German Christian Democrats. Since then, Vogel said, the stream of East Germans emigrating to West Germany has slowed. He said that showed East Germans expect a fundamental improvement in their economic, social and political situation. Vogel said the drafting of a Constitution for all of Germany would be the next step after economic and monetary consolidation. He said the fastest approach would be East Germany acceding to the West German constitution. Vogel offered assurances that ``a united Germany will continue to remain a democratic and stable nation.'' He said Germans wanted to achieve the kind of friendship with Poland to the East that has existed for years with France to the West. After Germany's defeat in World War II some of its eastern territories were turned over to Poland, which had lost land of its own to the Soviet Union. ``We don't want to respond to injustice with injustice,'' Vogel said. ``For us the Polish border is final and definitive. But it is not enough for us to say that. A united Germany will have to put its seal on this guarantee.''

DOC.HEAD: First Probe Fails to Find Ceausescu Millions in Switzerland
DOC.TEXT: Swiss authorities said Wednesday they found no evidence that ousted Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu stashed vast sums of cash in a Basel bank account. A similar investigation in Geneva is pending. The suspicion of money being stashed in secret Swiss accounts was raised by the new Romanian government that came to power after last December's revolution in which Ceausescu and his wife Elena were executed by a firing squad. Attorney Moritz Leuenberger, a Swiss member of parliament, said he was tipped by unidentified Romanian exiles that Ceausescu had transferred about $400 million, mostly in gold bullion, to Zurich shortly before his downfall. Swiss authorities lifted strict banking secrecy rules after the new Bucharest leadership asked them for help in its search for assets the Ceausescus allegedly spirited out of the country during their 24-year reign. The Swiss government put a precautionary freeze Dec. 24 on any assets linked to Ceausescu and his clan that may be in Swiss banks. District attorney Walter Rothenfluh said an investigation of bank files ``made it seem credible'' that the Basel account, opened in 1980, was used solely for regular transactions by the Romanian foreign trade ministry. Rothenfluh declined to name the bank.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Will Nominate Treasury Official to Education Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he will nominate Michael L. Williams, a Treasury Department official, to be assistant secretary for civil rights in the Education Department. If confirmed by the Senate, Williams would succeed LeGree S. Daniels. Since 1989, Williams has been deputy assistant secretary for law enforcement at the Treasury Department. He was a policy analyst for Bush during the 1988 presidential campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth-Quarter Profits Post 1989's First Gain
DOC.TEXT: Corporate after-tax profits rose 2.8 percent in the final quarter of 1989, their first gain of the year, the government said Wednesday. The Commerce Department said the $156.7 billion increase at a seasonally adjusted annual rate followed declines of 5.4 percent in the third quarter, 7.2 percent in the second and 1.1 percent in the first. John Silvia, financial economist with Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago, described profits as ``a leading indicator'' useful in forecasting future business developments. As an example, he said, ``when corporations are faced with profit cuts, profit squeezes, they tend to cut employment, capital spending.'' A broader measure _ before-tax profits adjusted for depreciation and inventories _ declined 3.2 percent to an annual rate of $285.7 billion. This measure fell during each of the quarters of 1989 and ended the year down 8.3 percent. It was the first annual decrease since a 0.1 percent drop in 1986 and the largest since a 20.2 percent loss in 1982, during the last recession. Corporate cash flows _ a measure intended to show the amount of funds that corporations have available for investment _ dipped 0.3 percent to $398.2 billion at an annual rate in the fourth quarter. They had risen 1.9 percent in the third quarter and 0.8 percent in the second after falling 5.6 percent in the first. Dividend payments to stockholders increased 1.9 percent to an annual rate of $125.6 billion after gains of 1.9 percent in the third quarter, 2.0 percent in the second and 2.9 percent in the first.

DOC.HEAD: Aquaculture a Young but Growing Industry
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. aquaculture industry is young but growing rapidly into a major provider of food for an expanding world population, an Agriculture Department report said Wednesday. ``The 1990s should be an important decade for growth,'' the report said. ``World population gains and limits on wild catch from the oceans should increase the demand for aquaculture products.'' Acquaculture refers to commercial production of a wide variety of fish, shellfish and seafood products. It includes baitfish, hatchery operations and the stocking of fish farms. ``If U.S. seafood consumption continues to grow, the rise in demand will likely be met through increased imports and higher domestic aquacultural production,'' the report said. Fish farmers and other aquacultural producers ``have an advantage over capture fisheries in that production can rise without endangering future supplies. Catfish are the leading species grown commercially in the United States. Production in 1989 rose 16 percent in volume to 342 million pounds delivered by farmers, the report said. Overall, including the wild catch, catfish ranked fourth in 1988 behind pollock, salmon and cod, and may have moved into third place ahead of cod in 1989, the report said. Prices paid to catfish farmers last year averaged 72 cents a pound, down 6 percent from 1988 because of the larger supply and lower prices paid by processors for large fish. But catfish prices have risen since October and by February had reached 75 cents a pound, the report said. Also, growers have formed a bargaining association that has negotiated prices with many processors for the first half of 1990. The most recent survey of trout growers showed a decrease in the number of producers to 478 in 1989 from 518 in 1988. However, sales of trout and trout eggs rose to $72.6 million from $66.4 million in 1988. Domestically grown farm salmon output was estimated at nine million to 10 million pounds in 1989, a sharp increase from six million pounds in 1988. The gain was attributed to larger output on both the East and West coasts. Oyster production has increased in the Northwest while disease problems reduced oyster harvesting in the Chesapeake Bay, formerly the largest producing area, the report said. Pacific Coast oyster production grew from 6.7 million pounds of meat with a value of $5.6 million in 1980 to eight million pounds valued at $14.5 million in 1988, the most recent figures available.

DOC.HEAD: Governments Seen Near Accord on More Money for International Monetary Fund
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the International Monetary Fund are nearing accord on providing billions of dollars it can lend to countries in financial trouble, a U.S. official said Wednesday. ``We've been talking about an increase of 33 to 50 percent, and it's narrowing to the upper end of that range,'' said Assistant Treasury Secretary Charles H. Dallara. The fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, has sought a doubling of its resources. Those ``quotas'' are equivalent to $117 billion but much of the money is in the currencies of Third World countries, which borrowers don't want. The United States, Britain and Saudi Arabia were the major holdouts against a 100 percent increase. The United States supplies about one dollar of every five available to the fund. A 50 percent increase would require about $12 billion from the United States, but the contribution would not be counted as increasing the federal deficit. There is hope for an agreement next week when Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady meets in Paris with financial leaders from the governments of Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy. The ``G-7'' group tries to coordinate the policies of the world's leading economic powers. The fund has 152 member governments. In recent years its main job has been lending to Third World countries in return for promises of policy changes designed to bring them additional loans and put them in better shape to repay. Recent moves in eastern Europe away from Communism and toward market economies have opened new needs for the fund's help. It recently made new loan agreements with Poland and Hungary. Extensive calls on its resources are expected from Argentina, Brazil and other heavily indebted governments. The accord on new money for the fund has been held up by disagreement over the total, the position of France and Britain as Japan becomes the second biggest contributor, and increases in overdue debt to the fund that amount to more than $4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Mental Health Services For Indian Teens Woefully Inadequate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed until midnight EST Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: Indian teen-agers suffer higher rates of suicide, substance abuse and other mental health problems than white youth, but the government provides just a tenth of the necesssary mental health workers, congressional researchers say. Despite acute psychological problems among Plains tribes, the Indian Health Service has no mental health professionals in Minnesota and just two to serve tribes in North Dakota, South Dakota, Nebraska and Iowa, according to the report by the Office of Technology Assessment. The IHS declined to comment on the report or the agency's mental health services. The congressional researchers refused to give the agency a copy of the report until it was released to the public Thursday, said IHS spokeswoman Patricia DeAsis. The IHS has 17 mental health professionals nationwide to serve 397,000 Native American children and adolescents. Nine of them are in Montana and Wyoming. ``The resources to cope with these serious problems are clearly inadequate,'' said the report, which was prepared for the Senate's Select Committee on Indian Affairs. The researchers said scientifically accepted data on the extent of mental health problems among Indian teen-agers is scarce but available information suggests Indian youth are more prone than white teen-agers to a laundry list of ills including suicide and alcohol and drug abuse. Indians in their early teens are four times more likely to kill themselves than youth of other races, and suicide rates among northern Plains tribes have climbed rapidly during the 1980s, the report said. In the IHS' Aberdeen, S.D., region _ South Dakota, North Dakota, Nebraska and Iowa _ 6.5 percent of the Indian youth who were hospitalized in 1988 were treated for attempted suicides, up from 3.5 percent in 1980. In Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan, the percentage of hospitalized Indian youth treated for suicide rose from 3.7 percent in 1980 to 15.5 percent in 1988. The mental health problems among Indian children are brought on by a wide range of other health and family problems, including divorce and parental substance abuse, the congressional researchers said. More than 22 percent of Indian adolescents have parents with drinking problems, compared to 14 percent for other Minnesota teens, a University of Minnesota study said. Indian youth are more than twice as likely as other adolescents to be living with just one parent and 10 times more likely to be living without a parent, the study found. ``Given the hunger and social deprivation which results from high unemployment in Indian country, it should come as no surprise to others that the lives of these children are filled with stress,'' said Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, chairman of the Indian affairs committee. The report said at least 170 mental-health workers were needed for Indian adolescents. To recruit the additional workers, scholarships could be provided to students in mental health fields who promise to work with Indian children, the report recommended.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Sworn In
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Jose Serrano was sworn in Wednesday as a member of the House of Representatives from New York City's South Bronx district, the nation's poorest. ``Let the message go from here today to those children who are still in the projects and who are on the street corner that there is a better tomorrow,'' Serrano told the House of Representatives moments after taking the oath of office. Serrano's swearing-in came on the 38th anniversary of his mother's arrival in New York from Puerto Rico to join her husband. Serrano, 46, is the only member of Congress who was born in Puerto Rico. ``While her youngest son is in the gallery, her oldest son is sworn in as U.S. congressman,'' Serrano said proudly. His parents are deceased. Serrano was joined on the floor with three of his five children. His wife, Mary, brother, other children and about 200 campaign workers stood in the gallery and cheered. Serrano, a 16-year veteran of the state Assembly, won 92 percent of the vote in a special election March 20 to fill the seat vacated in January when Rep. Robert Garcia, D-N.Y., resigned. Garcia was convicted of accepting bribes in the Wedtech influence-peddling scandal.

DOC.HEAD: Five Disabled Protesters Suing D.C. Government
DOC.TEXT: Five people who were arrested for protesting the lack of access for the handicapped to public buildings sued the District of Columbia Wednesday because their wheelchairs couldn't get into the probation office. The U.S. District Court lawsuit asks that ramps or other modifications be made to the building to allow wheelchair access. U.S. Capitol police arrested 104 demonstrators who were protesting the lack of access to public buildings nationwide during a March 13 demonstration in the Capitol. All the demonstrators were sentenced in D.C. Superior Court to unsupervised probation or time served with no probation, with the exception of five defendants who were sentenced to supervised probation, according to the lawsuit. When those defendants arrived at the probation offices, there was no wheelchair access, the lawsuit said. ``It made my angry to come all that way to our nation's capital to protest the lack of access across the nation, and face the cruel irony that essential government services are not accessible to those of us who use wheelchairs for mobility,'' said Stephanie Thomas of Austin, Texas. Ulysses Hammond, administrator of D.C. Superior Court, was not immediately available for comment. Timothy Cook, director of the National Disability Action Center, said the five wheelchair users never got into the probation offices and have written the court asking what they should do. No responses had been received as of Wednesday, Cook said.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Authorizes Collider Plan; Caps Federal Spending
DOC.TEXT: A House committee voted Wednesday to cap federal spending on the super collider at $5 billion and to hinge construction decisions on proof a key component will work. The House Science, Space and Technology Committee gave the $8 billion superconducting super collider its first congressional authorization by a 32-9 vote after an emotionally charged debate on the rising cost and questions about technology. The committee defeated attempts by Rep. Sherwood Boehlert, R-N.Y., to bar all construction on the collider, to be built south of Dallas, until the energy secretary certifies the superconducting magnets _ a key component _ could be mass produced by industry. Chairman Robert A. Roe, D-N.J., said Boehlert's amendment could result in an 18-month delay costing $1.5 billion to $2 billion. The Energy Department originally estimated the total cost at $4.4 billion, then increased the price to $5.9 billion last year. DOE officials are suggesting the cost could be closer to $8 billion. The super collider involves a 54-mile underground ring in which streams of protons, guided by the powerful magnets, would be hurled at almost the speed of light until they smash together and break into even smaller particles. Scientists say it would recreate the physical state of the universe after the ``Big Bang,'' a theory that the expansion of the universe began with a gigantic explosion. The bill now goes to the House floor.

DOC.HEAD: Election Begins That Could Make Zimbabwe One-Party State
DOC.TEXT: Zimbabweans began voting in elections Wednesday that will decide whether Robert Mugabe's government, the sure winner, will transform one of Africa's few Western-style democracies into a one-party state. Half of Zimbabwe's 9 million people are registered to ballot in the two-day presidential and parliamentary polls, the second since Mugabe led Zimbabwe _ formerly the white-ruled British colony of Rhodesia _ to independence in 1980. Mugabe, 66, cast his vote at Mpofu School in the Highfield West constituency of Harare, the capital of Zimbabwe, just before noon. Seven parties are running in the election, but only Edgar Tekere's year-old Zimbabwe Unity Movement is viewed as a serious challenger to Mugabe's governing Zimbabwe African National Union (Patriotic Front). Mugabe's party is expected to capture most, if not all, of the 108 seats at stake in the 150-seat Parliament. His dream is to amend the constitution to establish a one-party state after winning every seat up for election. Tekere insists he can win several seats provided the elections are not rigged, thus thwarting Mugabe's goal of a single-party state. But Mugabe told The Associated Press on Wednesday, ``I feel quite confident we will win all the seats.'' Of the 150 seats in Parliament, 12 have already been granted to the governing party because there were no challengers, and 30 are reserved for tribal chiefs, provincial governors and presidential nominees, all of whom are considered Mugabe supporters. Tekere, 52, once a close friend of Mugabe and co-founder of the governing party in 1963, is the first candidate to challenge the president. He had been No. 3 in the ZANU (PF) hierarchy as secretary-general, but was dismissed from the governing party after accusing senior leaders of corruption. He wants to block Mugabe's plan to impose one-party rule and pledges to weed out corruption, improve the lot of Zimbabweans and liberalize the socialist state. In asking for voter support, Mugabe points to the thousands of landless families granted farms during his administration and to the inexpensive schooling and health care to which all Zimbabweans are entitled. Mugabe, who led a seven-year guerrilla war to end almost a century of white minority rule in Rhodesia, is certain to be returned to power. In the old Parliament, Tekere and an independent sat as the only opponents of the government. While Tekere enjoys some support in his tribal stronghold of Manicaland, he still must counter recollections in Zimbabwe of how after independence he was tried for the murder of an elderly white farmer and acquitted on a legal technicality. Tekere said he led gunmen on an attack on the man's small tract on Mugabe's orders after learning about an arms cache there. Campaigning has been the most violent since independence. Tekere has accused Mugabe of seeking to impose a Marxist dictatorship on Zimbabwe. Mugabe has claimed Tekere is plotting a coup if he loses the elections. Bloody clashes have taken place between rival party supporters. One of Tekere's candidates was shot and wounded. But police reported no incidents Wednesday. Reports from most parts of Zimbabwe said voting got off to a slow start, reflecting the apathy shown by many of the people. ``Why bother going to vote when we know ZANU (PF) will win,'' Robson Charuma, a 33-year-old busdriver, said in Zimbabwe's second city of Bulawayo. Results from the polls are expected to be announced Friday night, according to polling officials.
