DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd item to include calls for comment were referred to attorney
DOC.TEXT: Lucasfilm Inc. is suing rapper Luke Skyywalker of the group 2 Live Crew, alleging the singer has tarnished the clean-cut image of the similarly named ``Star Wars'' movie hero. 2 Live Crew's latest album, ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be,'' has been banned in two Florida counties because of its sexually explicit lyrics. The $300 million federal lawsuit filed Tuesday charges Skyywalker, 29, whose real name is Luther Campbell, and Luke Skyywalker Records Inc. with trademark infringement, dilution, unfair competition and unjust enrichment. The film company owned by director George Lucas believes the public may associate Lucas, Lucasfilm and the ``Star Wars'' trilogy hero Luke Skywalker with the rap group's music, said attorney Bertram Fields. Luke Skyywalker Studios referred calls for comment to its business attorney, Allen Jacobi of Miami. A message left at Jacobi's office on Wednesday was not immediately returned. The space-age character played by actor Mark Hamill is associated with ``wholesomeness and bravery and honesty and a clean-cut character that we would want our kids to be like,'' Fields said. Fields said Lucasfilm had received complaints from people who believed the company approved of the band's music. One parent complained that his young son purchased the album thinking it was connected to the movies, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Everest Peace Expedition Reaches 23,150 Feet
DOC.TEXT: Members of the first group of U.S., Soviet and Chinese climbers to try to scale Mount Everest have reached Camp IV at 23,500 feet, less than 6,000 feet from the top, it was reported Wednesday. All 45 people on the climb were in good health, except for a couple with colds, deputy leader Warren Thompson said in a statement issued by the Mount Everest International Peace Climb Team through a public relations company. ``The climb is progressing slightly ahead of schedule,'' Thompson said. The camp was established earlier this week, the climb's publicists said. The expedition is led by Jim Whittaker of Port Townsend, Wash., the first U.S. climber to scale the 29,028-foot peak, and consists of three 15-member teams, each with five climbers and 10 support personnel. The goal is for one climber from each nation to reach the summit of the world's highest mountain together and to collect trash and debris from previous expeditions. Plans call for the group to establish seven camps on the way to the top. The statement said Camp IV was reached after a blizzard destroyed two tents Friday and forced the entire expedition to retreat to the base camp at the terminus of Main Rongbuk Glacier in Tibet, about 17,000 feet up the mountain.

DOC.HEAD: Acne Drug Suppresses Pre-Cancerous Mouth Growths, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: An acne drug can suppress pre-cancerous growths in the mouth for up to a year, a researcher said Wednesday. The work is aimed at suppressing white patches in the mouth called leukoplakia, which can be a precursor of cancers in the mouth, pharynx, larynx and esophagus. Altogether, those cancers afflict 50,000 people a year. The drug, called isotretinoin or Accutane, shrank growths significantly for three months and largely prevented progression during the following nine months, said Dr. Scott Lippman. Lippman, of the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, presented his results at a science writers seminar sponsored by the American Cancer Society. He stressed that his work does not involve women of childbearing age, because of isotretinoin's risk of causing birth defects. The study, still in progress, has included 58 patients. About 60 percent of patients showed shrinkage of at least half their growths after three months of taking isotretinoin orally every day, Lippman said. After three months, they and the non-responders were randomly assigned to a follow-up therapy of either a lower dose of isotretinoin or doses of another substance called beta carotene. The two follow-up groups contained equal shares of non-responders, Lippman said. In the beta carotene group, 56 percent relapsed over the following nine months. A relapse was defined as growth of the mouth lesions or appearance of new ones. That relapse rate is essentially equal to what another study found with no follow-up treatment at all, Lippman said. In contrast, only one relapse has been seen so far among participants in the low-dose isotretinoin group, he said. Sixty percent of these participants improved after going on the low dose, he said. Side effects from the initial high-dose treatment included dry skin and lips and an eye condition called conjunctivitis, he said. They were less severe and less frequent on low doses, he said. The work was financed by the National Cancer Institute. Dr. John Laszlo, the cancer society's senior vice president for research, said the results look promising. Further work might produce drugs that work as well without isotretinoin's side effects, which can include harm to the liver, he said. Because of side effects, he said he would be worried about people using isotretinoin on their own for fighting cancer. Dr. Arthur Mashburg of the Veterans Administration Medical Center in East Orange, N.J., said he believed the focus of the study was incorrect. Leukoplakias usually do not progress to cancer, he said, so the leukoplakias that shrink under therapy may not have actually been pre-malignant. In a second presentation, a researcher said his work suggests a way to identify breast cancer patients who would not need follow-up treatment after surgery. Perhaps 20 percent of breast cancer patients would fit the category, and so not require chemotherapy, hormonal therapy or radiation after surgery, said Dr. Thomas Nealon Jr., of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in New York. Those women have a tumor of 2 centimeters or less, no spread of cancer to the lymph nodes or elsewhere, a favorable appearance of cancer cells under a microscope, a well-limited tumor, no cancer in vessels leading to the lymph nodes, and no tumor cells in the blood vessels. But Marc Lippman, director of the Vincent Lombardi Cancer Research Center at Georgetown University in Washington, said Nealon's results included too few women to convince him. Furthermore, only about 7 percent of breast cancer cases might meet the criteria, he said. And most breast cancers occur in post-menopausal women, for whom treatment with an anti-estrogen drug called tamoxifen is safe and beneficial, he said. He also said the criteria would be difficult to apply uniformly because of judgment calls on appearance of cancer cells.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker: Wrong Men in Jail in `Birmingham Six' Bombings
DOC.TEXT: An IRA informer identified one of the bombers who killed 21 people at two Birmingham pubs, but six innocent men had already been convicted and police failed to follow up the lead, a British lawmaker said Wednesday. The allegation comes as campaigners are pressuring authorities anew over the cases of the ``Birmingham Six,'' who were convicted of bombing the pubs in 1974, saying they were victims of a miscarriage of British justice. The bombings in that northern city, which also left 162 injured, were the deadliest ever by the Irish Republican Army in its campaign to end British rule in Northern Ireland. Chris Mullin, a member of the opposition Labor Party, said he based his charge on a police document _ a summary of an interview with an IRA informer _ and said it ``ought to bring the end of this scandal.'' Mullin spoke hours before four alleged bombers were identified in Granada Television's dramatized documentary, ``Who Bombed Birmingham?'' The program identified the suspects as a man who served 12 years for other offenses, a man serving a life sentence in Ireland for murder and two men now living in Ireland. One of those two men, the program alleged, was involved in other IRA attacks including the murder of 11 people in London in 1982 and the bombing in Brighton in 1984 that nearly killed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Granada said a fifth suspect could not be named for ``security reasons.'' None of those identified on the program is among the six convicted of bombing two pubs in Birmingham on Nov. 21, 1974. West Midlands Chief Constable Geoffrey Dear said he would investigate any new evidence disclosed by the TV broadcast. He also said police had never claimed the convicted six were the only ones involved. In Dublin, a High Court judge rejected an application by attorney Frank Clarke for an order blocking the television broadcast on Ireland's RTE network. Clarke appeared on behalf of a man who claimed he was identified as one of the bombers. He was not identified in court. Ireland's Supreme Court later declined to hear the case. The IRA's legal political wing, Sinn Fein, denounced the television program. ``The quality and strength of the evidence which proves the innocence of the six is not, not should be, dependent upon pointing the finger of suspicion at others,'' it said. Mullin, who claims to have interviewed four men who carried out the bombings, would not comment on the identifications made in the broadcast. However, he said, ``I advise you to take very seriously'' the Granada broadcast. Last week, Home Secretary David Waddington ordered a new investigation of several matters raised by attorneys for the convicts, known as the ``Birmingham Six.'' Waddington has refused to say what specific points are under review. ``The lie cannot be sustained much longer,'' Mullin said at a news conference to publicize the third edition of his book on the case, ``Error of Judgment.'' Mullin said the most important information in the new edition of his book concerns a file from the archives of the anti-terrorist Special Branch, which he received from Granada television. That file was described as a summary of an interview with an IRA informant who talked about his role in other bombings and named at least 20 other members of the Birmingham IRA or its political wing, Sinn Fein. The informer, Mullin said, talked about meeting six weeks after the bombings with an IRA man who admitted that he had placed the bomb in one of the two pubs. Mullin says he has interviewed that man, identified in the book as ``Z.'' ``What this document shows,'' Mullin wrote, ``is that as long ago as November or December 1975, the police had someone purporting to tell them the identity of one of the men who had planted the pub bombs. He was in a position to know. His information on many other matters was accurate. And yet they chose to take no action.'' The cause of the six has been taken up by Amnesty International, the Irish government and most recently by Cardinal Tomas O Fiaich, the Roman Catholic primate of Ireland. Pressure for a review intensified in October after a court set aside the convictions of four young people for IRA bombings in Guildford and Woolwich in 1974. As in the Birmingham case, there were allegations that police had ignored credible information that they had the wrong suspects, had coerced confessions and had falsified evidence. Five of the six convicts were arrested the night of the bombings as they were about to board a ferry to Belfast for the funeral of an IRA man. All six _ Johnny Walker, Patrick Hill, Hugh Callaghan, Richard McIlkenny, Gerry Hunter and Billy Power _ were sentenced to life in prison in 1975. Mullin said he has interviewed 14 people with knowledge of the bombings, including four men directly involved, and all agree that none of the six convicts was involved.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Britain-Iraq, Bjt
Bush Concerned Over Spread Of Nuclear Weapons
DOC.TEXT: President Bush expressed concern Wednesday over the spread of nuclear weapons in the Middle East after the arrest of five people in an alleged attempt to supply Iraq with American-made devices for triggering nuclear weapons. ``We again call upon nuclear suppliers to exercise special restraint in providing materials related to the development of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and intermediate-range missiles in this volatile area,'' the president said in a statement. While avoiding any direct criticism of Iraq, Bush noted that it was one of many nations that have signed the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. ``Iraqi officials are well aware of our views on nuclear proliferation which we have made clear on several occasions,'' Bush said, calling on all nations to abide by the treaty. His statement was issued after five people were arrested in Britain after an 18-month investigation by British and U.S. officials in an alleged scheme to deliver 40 devices for nuclear weapons to Iraq. Bush said the arrest ``raises once again the administration's deep concern about the issue of nuclear proliferation in the Middle East.'' He said the proliferation of nuclear weapons, along with chemical arms and intermediate-range missiles, ``continues to pose serious threats to U.S. interests as well as the interests of our friends in the region. ``These programs only serve to heighten regional tensions and exacerbate regional problems,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Criticizes U.S. Immigration Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf pvs `Nathan Kingsley...' to UPDATE with comment from refugee bureau
DOC.TEXT: The United States has routinely denied asylum to refugees from oppression in countries it considers friendly, while granting asylum to those fleeing Communist governments, Amnesty International and congressional critics charged Wednesday. The international human rights organization said that from June 1983 to September 1989 only 2 percent of Guatemalans seeking asylum were successful. It said the figure for El Salvador was 2.5 percent and for Haiti just over 2 percent. By contrast nearly 91 percent of persons seeking asylum from Romania, then under Communist rule, won their cases. ``The United States government is slamming the door to its Salvadoran, Guatemalan and Haitian neighbors,'' John G. Healey, executive director of Amnesty International USA, said at a news conference. ``Asylum case after asylum case shows that the State Department and the Immigration and Naturalization Service deny certain people equal treatment.'' Randy L. Levine, a New York attorney who was ranking associate deputy attorney general from 1986 to 1988, took issue with the Amnesty report. ``In my experience, most of the refugees from Guatemala and El Salvador would not qualify for asylum because they do not have a well founded fear of persecution,'' Levine said. ``Most of them are economic refugees.'' Nathan Kingsley, public affairs officer for the State Department's Bureau of Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, which advises the INS on asylum matters, said he had not seen the Amnesty report. ``The position of the government is that the governments in El Salvador and Guatemala are democratically elected,'' said Carl Albrecht, a spokesman for the department's refugee bureau. ``There are problems, but we view those governments in a different light than we did Romania or other places where we thought the persecution was greater.'' A Justice Department spokesman, Duke Austin, said that for five years the Intergovernmental Committee for Migration, a volunteer group based in Geneva, has monitored Salvadorans deported to their homeland from the United States and has found no cases of persecution. It said the State Department and others have monitored those returned to Haiti, with similar results. ``Can it be established that the United States is in fact returning people to their native homelands and they are subsequently being persecuted?'' Austin asked. ``If that is the case, then we are violating the intent of the law. I don't know of a single case that has ever been established in El Salvador or in Haiti. Not one.'' He said he did not know of any in Guatemala either, although he was not aware of any similar surveys being made there. Austin also said Congress had not complained that the 1980 Refugee Act, designed to assure equal treatment of asylum-seekers, was not being complied with. However, Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., in a statement read for her by an aide at the news conference, commended Amnesty International for its ``campaign to end discrimination in the application of U.S. immigration laws.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., submitted a statement saying that the promise of the 1980 law had not been fulfilled ``for many refugees even in our own hemisphere.'' Sen. Mark O. Hatfield, R-Ore., said, ``It has long been apparent to me that U.S. officials have administered the act in a manner that discriminates against asylum-seekers from `friendly' nations such as El Salvador and Guatemala. The repression in those countries is just as real as the repression in Nicaragua or Vietnam.'' According to Amnesty's figures, 27 percent of cases from Nicaragua and nearly a third of those from Vietnam were granted. The organization, which monitors human rights violations, said government bias against asylum-seekers from particular countries ``appears to be a worldwide pattern.''

DOC.HEAD: Black College Enrollment Up
DOC.TEXT: Black enrollment at colleges and universities is up after years of decline, with the lion's share of the increase at private institutions, according to federal statistics released Wednesday. The National Institute of Independent Colleges and Universities cited Education Department figures showing a 7.1 percent increase in black enrollment at their institutions between fall 1986 and fall 1988. Black students increased 0.2 percent at public institutions over the same period. The rise reverses a trend toward shrinking black enrollments. Between 1982 and 1986, black enrollment dropped 5.4 percent at independent colleges or private and 4.6 percent at public institutions, the institute said. A similar reversal occurred for Native Americans. Overall minority enrollment at private schools increased 5.3 percent from 1986 to 1988, compared to 3.3 percent during the earlier period. At public colleges there was a 4.5 percent hike, a slowdown from the 5.4 percent rise charted during the 1982-86 period. Richard Rosser, president of the independent colleges group, said member schools have used aggressive recruiting tactics and made ``a real commitment to financial aid'' to achieve the jump in minority enrollment. Rosser said that since 1980, independent institutions have doubled their financial aid commitment in real dollars, while financial aid rose only about 9 percent from 1970 to 1980. Frederick S. Humphries, president of historically black Florida A&M University, said, ``It's very gratifying to know there's an increase in minority enrollment in both public and private institutions. That needs to happen. Hopefully, all of us can grow because we need to grow. We need to serve better the minority students of America.'' Florida A&M is one of 117 historically and predominantly black colleges that belong to the National Association for Equal Opportunity in Higher Education. In a separate enrollment study released Wednesday at the start of a four-day conference, the association said fall 1989 enrollment at the 117 institutions was 294,427 students _ an increase of 9,747 or 3.4 percent over fall 1988 enrollment counts. Association President Samuel Myers said he applauded the increase in minority enrollment but warned that all higher education institutions must find effective ways to address the needs of minority students once they get them on their campuses. ``It's my hope that these institutions will not only bring those students in but that they do something to retain those students, give them the support they need to graduate,'' Myers said. Rosser responded that recent studies show independent institutions ``have a higher retention rate and persistence rate for minorities in all programs at all our schools. The figures show how hard we've been working.'' Native Americans' enrollment increased by 9.2 percent from 1986 to 1988 at private colleges and universities, compared with 3.6 percent at their public counterparts. For the 1982-86 period, the institute said, Native American enrollment decreased 4.8 percent at the independent schools and increased only 0.9 percent at public institutions. Enrollment of Hispanic students in independent higher education decreased by 4.4 percent, due primarily to enrollment declines in Puerto Rico. Enrollment of Asian students increased by 22.3 percent in independent colleges and universities and by 10.5 percent in public higher educaiton. Despite the healthier increase in minority enrollment at independent schools, minorities accounted for a greater proportion of the student body at public institutions _ 19.9 percent compared to 18.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Ban Exports of Pesticides Banned in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Bite into a banana from Ecuador _ or any developing country _ and you could be swallowing residue from a pesticide outlawed in the United States for health reasons, an Ecuadoran official said Wednesday. ``Ecuador, like many developing countries, is not in the condition to guarantee that highly toxic pesticides will be used in even a relatively safe manner,'' Mercedes Bolanos de Moreno, chief of Ecuador's plant protection program, told the Senate Agriculture Committee. She said her country has no national pesticide policy. ``Instead, policies change frequently, according to changes in government and the influence of financially interested groups,'' she told the panel, which is considering a bill to stop U.S. companies from exporting chemicals not registered for use in this country. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., called the importing of produce sprayed with these pesticides ``the circle of poison'' and said his top priority in this session of Congress is stopping the practice. ``One-fourth of the produce we eat is imported,'' said Leahy. ``That's 135 pounds of fruits and vegetables for every man, woman and child'' a year. While Agriculture Department inspectors have the power to stop foods found to contain banned chemicals from entering the United States, Leahy's bill would prohibit the export of such pesticides. In the last two years, inspectors have halted imports of beef from Honduras, pineapples from the Philippines and carrots from Latin America after determining that the foods contained pesticides banned from use in the United States. Jay Vroom, president of the National Agricultural Chemicals Association, said, however that Leahy's bill would hurt countries the United States is trying to help. ``Some pesticides produced in the United States and sold overseas are unregistered here because the specific pest controlled is not a U.S. problem, or crops concerned are generally not grown in America, like coffee, rubber, cocoa, bananas, tea,'' said Vroom. He said attempts to control how other countries use agrichemicals would amount to U.S. imperialism. But Ms. Bolanos de Moreno said she would welcome the legislation. U.S. shoppers buy large quantities of bananas from Ecuador, which also ships plantain, coffee, cocoa and sugar to the United States. Ms. Bolanos de Moreno said Ecuador does not have the money or staff to evaluate all the chemicals being offered for sale for crops there. ``In fact, we only have one person in charge of reviewing all studies submitted for registration,'' she said. ``The U.S. pesticide registration process is far more extensive and permits regulators to evaluate all the risks associated with a product's use,'' she said. She also said the current methods used by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to advise other countries on risks associated with certain chemicals aren't working. She said her country has received few notices from the EPA about changes it has made in regulations on pesticides. She said several chemicals were removed from the U.S. market, but she was never told of the actions. EPA official Linda Fisher said her agency wants the law on exporting pesticides to be strengthened but is not in favor or Leahy's bill. She said the EPA is working on strengthening its export policies in hopes of fixing problems Ms. Bolanos de Moreno described. Under questioning from Leahy, Ms. Fisher said the EPA presently has no authority to stop a U.S. company from exporting a chemical that is banned here, even if the foreign country has said it doesn't want it. Furthermore, there is no agency within the federal government that a foreign government can call if it wants to keep a U.S.-manufactured chemical out of its country, she said. Leahy said his bill would not only prevent chemicals banned here from being exported, but also would stop any food sprayed with illegal pesticides from being imported. That would protect Americans from companies that decide to manufacture the illegal chemicals elsewhere, the senator said. Virtually the same legislation also has been introduced in the House and is awaiting hearings there.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Airline to Resume Flights for Soviet Jews
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for Moscow-dated item on news advisory
DOC.TEXT: The state Hungarian carrier Malev will resume flights of Soviet Jews to Israel, suspended last week after it received terrorist threats from Palestinian extremists, authorities said Wednesday. State television did not say when the flights, suspended March 21, would be resumed. Earlier Wednesday, the minister of transportation and telecommuncations fired Malev general manager Lajos Jahoda, the state MTI news agency reported. It said Jahoda ``agreed with the decision'' to fire him, ``which was a political consequence of the tension that had emerged'' after flights carrying Soviet Jews from Budapest to Tel Aviv were suspended. Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, a radical, Lebanon-based group, threatened airlines of all nations that help fly Soviet Jews to Israel. Israeli officials expect up to 750,000 Soviet Jews to emigrate the next decade as the result of relaxed rules in the Soviet Union and tighter entry quotas in the United States. The prospect angers Arab leaders, who fear Palestinians will be displaced by the influx. MTI quoted Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens as saying Last Saturday that Israel hoped Hungary ``which has just become a democracy, will not give an example of surrendering to terrorism.'' On Sunday, Hungarian Foreign Minister Gyula Horn criticized Malev's ``rush decision'' and said it was made without consulting the government. Terrorists should not be encouraged through bowing to their threats, Horn added . In Moscow, the Soviet newspaper Literaturnaya Gazeta on Wednesday had criticized Malev for suspending the flights, accusing it of ``indecisiveness in the fight against international terrorism.'' The article was published a day after the U.S. administration expressed disappointment at the suspension and urged Hungary to reconsider. Literaturnaya Gazeta made no mention of the position taken by the Soviet national airline Aeroflot, which stopped selling tickets for Soviet Jewish emigres traveling to Hungary. A group of U.S. Jewish leaders on Tuesday met with a senior Soviet Foreign Ministry official, Yuri Reshetov, to express concern about the steps taken by Aeroflot and Malev, the mission's leader, Marvin Lander, national chairman-elect of the United Jewish Appeal, said. Jewish activists in the Soviet Union also said a family could take up to 880 pounds of luggage on Malev, and many counted on it to transport their most precious belongings. They say Aeroflot would only transport 88 pounds a person. From January 1989 through January 1990, 16,700 Soviet Jews have joined about 180,000 of their brethren who have emigrated to Israel since 1967. The expectations of mass immigration led right-wing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to suggest Israel needed to retain the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip to house the immigrants. Despite Israeli clarifications that it had no such policy, Shamir's suggestion inflamed the Arab world. Israel responded by clamping military censorship on immigration figures and routes, citing Arab threats. Several countries joined the Soviet Ukraine at the United Nations on Wednesday in criticizing the settlement of Jews in the Israeli-occupied lands and called for an end to Soviet Jewish emigration there. The comments came during the third day of Security Council discussions on the settlement of Soviet Jews in the occupied lands. The council planned to continue the discussions on Thursday. Yugoslav envoy Dragoslav Pejic, speaking for the non-aligned countries, said the issue ``constitutes a most serious additional element of tension and instability, not only in the occupied Palestinian territories but also in the broader region of the Middle East.'' Pakistan, India, Qatar, Libya, Bangladesh and Tanzania also asked an end to settlement of Soviet Jews in the occupied lands.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after pvs 3rd graf bgng ``This Saturday ...'' to add Bush's banquet remarks.
DOC.TEXT: The late Jesse Owens, whose performance at the 1936 Olympics put the lie to Hitler's boasts of racial superiority, picked up a fifth gold medal Wednesday for ``humanitarian contributions in the race of life.'' President Bush presented the Congressional Gold Medal to his widow, Ruth Owens, in a ceremony at the White House also attended by three daughters and teammates of the track legend. This Saturday marks the 10th anniversary of Owens' death at age 66. The president later hailed Owens's multiple gold medals in the Berlin games ``a victory for humanity'' in prepared remarks to a banquet sponsored by the U.S. Olympic Committee. ``The Olympics, like democracy, are a kind of dialogue _ a way that nations can converse in the language of friendly competition, not deadly conflict,'' Bush said. Bush called Owens, who was black, an ``Olympic hero and an American hero every day of his life ... born with the gift of burning speed.'' ``He was always the fastest,'' said Bush, recalling the afternoon in May 1935 when the Ohio State runner broke three world records and tied a fourth in the space of 45 minutes. ``Talk about a guy in a hurry,'' Bush laughed. ``He was the epitome of that.'' At the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin, Owens captured four gold medals _ in the broad jump, 100-meter dash, 200-meter dash and 400-meter relay. ``The Berlin Games were to be the showcase of Hitler's theories on the superiority of the master race until this 23-year-old kid'' showed up, Bush said. ``It was an unrivaled athletic triumph. But more than that, it really was a triumph for all humanity.'' Bush, borrowing a phrase from Ruth Owens, said it was not those athletic feats but ``his humanitarian contributions in the race of life'' that earned Owens the Congressional Gold Medal. Owens devoted himself to working with youth and serving as ``a special ambassador for sports,'' said Bush. He said the athlete's legacy lives on through the Jesse Owens Games, a playground Olympics; the Jesse Owens International Trophy for amateur athletes and the Jesse Owens Foundation, which awards scholarships to needy youth. ``Despite the many honors, his greatest satisfaction came from his work with youth,'' said Mrs. Owens, 74. Attending the ceremony along with Owens' family were former Olympians Mal Whitfield, Harrison Dillard and Herb Douglass; former teammates John Chavers, Samuel Devine and Chester Thomas, and two Ohio Democrats, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum and Rep. Louis Stokes, who spearheaded the drive to strike the medal. The silver-haired Mrs. Owens, standing outside the White House afterwards, called the event ``absolutely beautiful.'' She added: ``I'm sure with the sun shining straight down, Jesse's watching us, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Dingell Says Aegis May Be Vulnerable
DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: A House committee chairman on Wednesday charged that the Navy is ignoring the possibility that its sophisticated Aegis air defense system may be vulnerable to anti-radiation missiles. ``The more this issue is reviewed, the more our concern grows about the Navy's refusal to address this problem,'' Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., said in a March 27 letter to a House colleague. The staff of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations, which Dingell chairs, has been reviewing the Navy's purchase of the new $1.2 billion guided-missile destroyer. The destroyer, called the Arleigh Burke class after the World War II naval hero and former chief of naval operations, will be equipped with Aegis computers as well as Tomahawk cruise missiles and an expensive all-steel superstructure. In a letter to Rep. Charles Bennett, D-Fla., chairman of the House Armed Services subcommittee on seapower and strategic critical materials, Dingell complained that the Navy has refused to test the Aegis system against anti-radiation missiles or ARMs, missiles which home in on an adversary's radar beams. Dingell described the missiles as effective weapons that more nations, including the Soviets and Third World countries, are consistently developing. ``At your Feb. 28, 1990, hearing, you suggested they put the Aegis radar on a raft and run a test against an ARM _ then the Navy witnesses claimed it would be too expensive and they would not learn anything,'' Dingell wrote. ``Why this incredible relunctance to test?'' In an interview, Bennett wondered whether those who prepared the letter for Dingell had read the Navy's testimony correctly. ``I was surprised at some of the words he used,'' Bennett said Wednesday of the letter. ``He seemed to be saying that the Navy did not affirm that they had tests that proved to be successful for this weapon.'' Although Bennett has complained in the past about Dingell's inquiry into the guided-missile destroyer, he said Wednesday that he was not objecting to the oversight subcommittee's review of the program. However, he added that the Burke destroyer is ``the world's best ship regardless of anything he's (Dingell) said.'' Lt. Cmdr. Craig Quigley, a Navy spokesman, said: ``Questions raised in his letter to Congressman Bennett are not new and have been addressed thoroughly by the Navy in hearings, reports and briefings to the Congress. The Navy has full confidence in the (Ticonderoga cruiser and Burke destroyer classes using the Aegis) and the Aegis combat system including our abilty to counter the ARM and other missile threats.'' Navy Secretary Lawrence Garrett said earlier that anti-radiation missiles should be ``easier for Aegis to detect, engage and destroy than other types of anti-ship missiles.'' Nevertheless, Dingell said the Navy ``appears to be paralyzed by the ARM threat.'' The lawmaker suggested that Bennett's subcommittee demand that the Navy develop plans for a ``realistic test'' of the Aegis combat system before more funds are spent on the Burke destroyer.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Missionary, British Wife Slain in Liberian Conflict
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of a missionary couple were found Wednesday in an area where hundreds of civilians have been killed in battles between government troops and rebels, diplomatic sources said. The bodies of the Rev. Tom Jackson, 72, an American, and his British wife, June, were found in their home village of Bahn in eastern Nimba County, the sources said on condition of anonymity. They spoke from Monrovia, the Liberian capital, and Abidjan, capital of neighboring Ivory Coast. U.S. and British embassies in Monrovia advised their citizens in Nimba County to leave the region immediately, except those working at a well-guarded iron ore mine at Yekepa, near Saniquellie town. Fifty Americans and 20 to 30 Britons are affected, the embassies said. About 6,000 Americans, most of them missionaries, live in Liberia, which was founded in 1847 by freed U.S. slaves. In Washington, the State Department said it could not confirm the couple was dead, although it had received reports their car was found abandoned. The Jacksons belonged to the U.S.-based United Liberian Inland Church and had lived in the country for 40 years, translating the Bible into the local Gio and Mano languages. Jackson was from North Carolina, and Mrs. Jackson, in her late 50s, was from Croyden, Surrey. Reports from Monrovia said 16 people, including Bahn Mayor John Kayea, were killed in the town Saturday in a gun battle between soldiers and rebels. The reports could not be immediately confirmed. They did not mention the missionaries, but a source in Abidjan indicated the couple might have been killed when they tried to stop troops killing civilians. ``It is not yet known who was responsible for the killings,'' one diplomat said. ``Very little information is available because roads to the village have been cut off by the fighting.'' Jackson's daughter, Beth Workman of Raleigh, N.C., said she received reports from missionaries still in the region that guerrillas had shot the couple accidentally as they were driving to Monrovia. ``They just heard a car coming and opened fire, but it wasn't a vendetta,'' she said. ``It's sad any way you look at it, but at least we can feel better about it.'' ``Even the rebels respected Daddy,'' she said. ``They knew he wouldn't get involved. I don't think anyone would have had a vendetta against him.'' The fighting has spread the past two weeks, and Nimba has been cut off from neighboring provinces. Refugees who fled to Monrovia last week said troops had burned down villages and killed an unknown number of people. Western diplomats and international human rights organizations say soldiers have killed hundreds of civilians since they were deployed in Nimba to crush about 200 rebels led by former civil servant Charles Taylor. The rebels invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24 in a bid to oust President Samuel Doe, who has ruled this West African nation since a violent coup on April 12, 1980. Soldiers in Nimba have targeted people of the Gio and Mano tribes to which the rebels belong, escalating the rebellion into a tribal conflict. Rebels retaliated by killing civilians of Doe's Krahn tribe, but not on the same scale as the military. Diplomats say the military killings have outraged many people and won recruits for the rebels, who previously had little support. Doe said last month that his troops have had difficulty differentiating between rebels and civilians. In the past, Washington has been a generous and loyal supporter of Doe. But diplomatic sources say the United States is considering cutting back its large embassy in Monrovia following a decision to end new aid to the country because of continuing rights violations and misuse of aid funds.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa Frees Six More Political Prisoners
LaserPhoto CPN1
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: The government on Wednesday freed six black nationalists jailed for crimes ranging from high treason to arms possession, a move the six said was aimed at reducing foreign pressure on South Africa. ``Our release is just a window-dressing to ease pressure from the international community,'' said Muzi Nkosi, 34, who read a statement on behalf of the prisoners after they left Robben Island prison. The African National Congress has demanded freedom for all political prisoners before it will open talks on constitutional reforms with the white-minority government. Five of the prisoners were ANC members and one belonged to the Black Consciousness movement. All were due for release in November or December. Thirty-five prisoners have been released since February, when 300 prisoners staged a two-week hunger strike to demand freedom for those convicted of politically related crimes. President F.W. de Klerk has agreed to free prisoners held for non-violent political crimes, but he has said the release of violent political criminals will have to be negotiated. De Klerk legalized the ANC and other black groups in February and freed ANC leader Nelson Mandela after 27 years of imprisonment in a bid to bring blacks to the negotiating table.

DOC.HEAD: Military Helicopter Explodes, Killing Six Crew Members
DOC.TEXT: An air force helicopter exploded while en route to rescue an injured soldier, killing all six crew members, the military said Wednesday. Lt. Marcio Meira said the French-built Super Puma helicopter exploded Tuesday night over the Restinga da Marambaia military area, 43 miles west of Rio de Janeiro. The craft had been dispatched from a nearby airbase to rescue a soldier injured during training maneuvers, Meira said. The air force said the dead included the pilot, two lieutenants, two sergeants and a medical assistant. Cause of the accident in clear weather was not known, but the Air Force has begun an investigation, Meira said.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Cabinet Rank for EPA
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs. Minor editing throughout
DOC.TEXT: The House overwhelmingly approved legislation Wednesday that would create a Department of the Environment and require the federal government to comply with toxic waste management laws. The 371-55 vote on a bill to elevate the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet-level came after a lengthy dispute over whether the measure was being weighed down with too many controversial requirements that might threaten a veto. An attempt pushed by the Bush administration to substitute a ``clean'' bill that would have dealt only with creating the new department was turned back by a vote of 266-161. Republicans argued that the additional provisions were ``designed to embarrass'' President Bush and force a presidential veto. Bush has said he wants to sign a bill creating a Department of the Environment on Earth Day, April 22. A similar bill elevating the EPA to Cabinet rank has been approved by the Senate Government Affairs Committee but has yet to be taken up by the full Senate, which has been preoccupied by clean air legislation. In addition to creating a 15th Cabinet-level agency, the House bill also would: _Require the federal government be subject to the same federal environmental laws on disposal of hazardous wastes as industry, lifting an exemption that over the years has allowed some agencies, including the Defense Department, to pollute areas near federal facilities. _Require the new department to limit its use of private consultants and take additional actions to guard against conflicts of interest involving both consultants and outside advisory panels. _Call for creation of an independent Bureau of Environmental Statistics within the new department with the director named to a four-year term and not subject to dismissal except for malfeasance. _Beef up enforcement activities against polluters with the hiring of additional investigators and creation of a new training academy for investigators. The number of criminal and civil investigators would be increased by 30 percent a year over five years. The legislation would take care to insulate the department's new statistical bureau to avoid interference in the development of environmental statistics and reports. It prohibits department officials, including the secretary, as well as other administration officials from reviewing the bureau's reports. Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., one of the key sponsors of the legislation, said the bill signals ``a new era of national resolve for a clean and safe environment.'' He said the legislation will ``depoliticize'' the EPA, provide citizens with improved and reliable environmental statistics and put ``a halt to conflicts of interests'' at the agency. Conyers had cited a case last summer in which government scientists had been directed to change congressional testimony on global warming by the Office of Management and Budget. The EPA over the years has been criticized for relying too heavily on outside consultants and for cases in which consultants or advisory boards include people who have associations with industry, including polluters. Republicans argued during floor debate on the bill that the additional provisions interfered in what should be the prerogative of the executive branch. ``We're not here to fine tune or micromanage,'' said Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. Likewise, the Bush administration had warned it might veto the bill if many of the provisions in the House legislation are included in final legislation from Congress. While Bush has endorsed elevating the EPA to a Cabinet-level department, he has raised particular concerns over some of the House provisions. Administration officials told congressional leaders last week that several parts of the House bill, especially the provisions insulating the new statistical bureau, ``interfere unacceptably'' with the president's management of the executive branch. White House and EPA officials noted that the bill would prohibit other administration officials, including the secretary of the environment, from reviewing reports and works of new Bureau of Environmental Statistics and that its director could not be dismissed for anything other than malfeasance. Among other complaints were that the bill would restrict the hiring of private consultants by the new department and require a certain percentage of senior officials, including regional administrators, be hired without consideration of political affiliation. ``These are measures that are not applied to other agencies,'' said EPA Director William Reilly, noting that no such restrictions are imposed on the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which operates within the Labor Department. Neither version of the bill envisions a significant expansion of the EPA. An independent regulatory agency, the EPA has about 16,000 employees and a budget of $5.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Contra Rank-and-File Feel Betrayed, Remain Ready for Battle
DOC.TEXT: Platoon leader Ivan and his Contra loyalists relax on a hillside, but they cradle M-16 rifles in their laps and wear hand grenades on their camouflage uniforms like medals, ready for battle should Sandinista guns break the silence of the countryside. A pact between leaders of the Contras and Nicaragua's new United National Opposition government calls for the rebels to lay down their weapons. But the rank-and-file rebels have no intention of doing that. ``If they signed that pact, they made an error,'' said Ivan, whose real name is Monico Gonzalez Rivas. ``Here in the mountains you feel things in your own flesh. Here is where we're going to decide.'' Ivan and his men see the pact, signed Friday in Honduras, as a death warrant because it makes no mention of what had been a top Contra demand: that the Sandinista military also disarm to make way for the formation of a neutral army. ``I see it as something very difficult, this thing of giving up our weapons, because they would have to order our coffins at the same time,'' said platoon member Filadelfo Lopez Castro, whose nom de guerre is Filiberto. Ivan and his platoon can afford to rest at least for a while in the rolling farmland 10 miles north of Jinotega, a provincial capital and important Sandinista military post. Peasants in this region strongly favor the Contras, who they feed and protect. Andres, an area ranch hand who asked he not be further identified for fear of the Sandinistas, strongly opposes the plan to disarm the Contras. ``If they make the boys disarm, then all of us might as well take to the hills. The piricuacos (an Indian word meaning dogs) would wipe us out,'' said Andres, referring to the Sandinistas. Ivan, 25, has fought the leftist Sandinistas for eight years, seen them sign successive regional peace pacts and enjoyed the unexpected thrashing the Sandinista Front suffered in the Feb. 25 elections. ``All these treaties, it's us who have made them sit down to negotiate,'' said Ivan. ``If we're taken out and the Sandinistas keep their weapons, they can stage a coup against UNO at any time.'' Ivan's view that the Contras will help assure the democratization of Nicaragua is not reflected in the latest negotiations between UNO and the Sandinista Front. After a month of meetings, negotiators on Tuesday announced they had agreed to a protocol for tranferring power on April 25, when President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is to be inaugurated. The document calls on the Contras to respect the demobilization pact and return to civilian life. It also says the Sandinistas will turn control of the army and police over to UNO and that the forces will be non-partisan. Officers now in the army and the Interior Ministry are Sandinista Front cadres who have undergone extensive political indoctrination. ``In a democratic country you can't have an army that belongs to a party,'' Ivan protested in an interview a few hours before the protocol was announced. A few miles away, another Contra combat unit came down from the bush to a tiny shop by a dusty country road where they mingle with local people. Patrol leader Caminante, a pseudonym of Juan Antonio Garcia that means ``Walker,'' says a call by the United States for the rebels to dismantle or face a cutoff in the U.S. aid they have received since 1981 doesn't matter much. ``We've got the people behind us, and as long as we have that we won't starve,'' he said. Invisible, the nom de guerre of Caminante's second-in-command, Jose Alfredo Altamirano, says the Contras held talks with UNO representatives in the days after the elections. ``We told them what we think. But one thing is what they tell us here and another what they do over there,'' he said, referring to Tegucigalpa, Honduras. Enforcement of the accord in Tegucigalpa for disbanding the Contras depends on the will of the rebels to voluntarily give up their weapons. The Contra's top military chief, Israel Galeano Cornejo _ or Commander Franklyn _ did not sign it. Instead it was signed by his negotiator, Oscar Sovalbarro, Commander Ruben. There has been speculation that this indicated there was a split within the rebel forces. ``You tell me that Ruben signed the agreement. Fine. Did Franklyn sign it? No? Well, there you go,'' Ivan said.

DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE EPA ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Surinamese Rebels Released After One-Day Delay
DOC.TEXT: The army on Wednesday freed guerrilla leader Ronny Brunswijk and 10 of his followers, a day after being ordered to do so by the civilian government. Army chief Lt. Col. Desi Bouterse, former ruler of this isolated South American republic, announced the release of the Jungle Commando leader Brunswijk and 10 others at a news conference at the army general staff headquarters. The government of President Ramsewak Shankar had ordered the Bush Negro rebels freed Tuesday, one day after they were arrested by military police on drug charges. The rebels were in the capital Paramaribo for talks with government officials on ending their 3{-year insurgency. Charges against Brunswijk stemmed from the Jungle Commando's seizure on March 20 of 2,200 pounds of Colombian cocaine. Brunswijk said last Sunday that his men confiscated the cocaine from a plane that took off from Cali, Colombia, and landed because of bad weather near a rebel base in the bauxite town of Moengo. Brunswijk said the rebels also took four Colombians into custody and confiscated their plane. Two of Brunswijk's bodyguards were killed in a shootout with soldiers during the arrest, according to government and military authorities. The Jungle Commando, with 200 to 400 followers, claims to represent Bush Negroes, descendants of runaway slaves who make up about 10 percent of the 400,000 population. The group seeks economic development for Bush Negroes and an end to alleged discriminatory practices. Fighting between the Jungle Commando and army forces erupted in July 1986. A cease-fire currently is in effect. Bouterse told reporters he had been concerned about the possible international repercussions of freeing suspects in a drug case. The armed forces commander said he asked for a written order from the public prosecutor's office and when he received that, there was no reason to hold the rebels. Brunswijk, who also spoke at the news conference, said President Shankar had ordered his arrest, contrary to reports that the military had acted on its own. There had been speculation that Bouterse staged the arrest to scuttle the peace negotiations or divert attention from rumors of drug-trafficking by the military. Brunswijk, a former army sergeant who once served as Bouterse's bodyguard, said he would cooperate with the government's investigation of drug trafficking, but denied any involvement. Bouterse seized power in a 1980 military coup and ruled until the election of a civilian government in November 1987. He has continued to wield power behind the scenes, however, and strongly opposes a tentative peace settlement that he says would allow the insurgents to remain armed and patrol the bush regions of eastern Suriname where they have their power base. Suriname, situated on the northeastern shoulder of South America, gained independence from the Netherlands in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Bonn Takes Major Step to Reduce Influx of East Europeans
DOC.TEXT: West Germany took further action Wednesday to reduce the steady influx of ethnic Germans from Eastern Europe, saying fewer reasons existed for them to leave now that democracy has taken root there. Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said Bonn has decided newcomers will be eligible for generous social assistance here only if West German authorities screened them for exile status before they leave their homeland. Screening up to now has been done here. Schaeuble said he hopes the bill will clear Parliament and take effect June 22. Earlier this month, West Germany decided to end a special assistance program for East German resettlers. East Europeans of German heritage have been flooding into West Germany in the past two years, driven in recent months mostly by hopes of improving their financial status in this well-to-do nation. About 380,000 ethnic Germans arrived last year. This year the figure has already reached 99,200. East European exiles who can prove they have German roots are automatically granted citizenship here. When they arrive, ethnic Germans are guaranteed shelter while they seek to establish new lives and are eligible for generous social assistance. Many West Germans bitterly resent the newcomers because of increased competition for housing and jobs. They question West Germany's expending great sums of money on East Europeans when political conditions in the East bloc have dramatically improved. Schaeuble said on Wednesday that political conditions in a would-be exile's homeland will play a major role in qualifying for exile status as an ethnic German. ``The countries of origin (in Eastern Europe) are on the road to democracy. In addition to improved travel possibilities, people living there have more personal freedoms,'' he said. His proposed law is seen as an attempt not only to encourage Eastern Europeans to stay home, but to cut down on the number who come to West Germany claiming German heritage when such ties are either slim or non-existent. He said West German diplomatic personnel will do the screening in East European countries and the goal will be that ``only people can emigrate to West Germany ... who in fact fulfill the legal conditions.'' Chancellor Helmut Kohl's political opponents, the Social Democrats, also favor finding ways to cut down on the stream of East Europeans. On March 20, Kohl's Cabinet decided to scrap a 40-year-old resettlement program for new East German arrivals. More than 150,000 East Germans have arrived this year and about 340,000 last year.

DOC.HEAD: US Fines West German Firm for Nuclear Exports
With AM-Britain-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Degussa A.G., a West German firm, has agreed to pay a penalty of $800,000 for re-exporting American metals useful in making nuclear weapons to North Korea and four other countries, the Commerce Department announced Wednesday. The other countries were Czechoslovakia, India, Italy and Britain. The Commerce Department said this was one of the largest penalties ever imposed for such violations. ``We believe the company knew that re-exporting U.S.-origin nuclear-related materials required authorization from Commerce,'' said Dennis Kloske, undersecretary for Export Administration, in a statement. ``Authorization of the shipments to India and North Korea would have been denied.'' Edward E. Dysan of the law firm Baker and McKenzie, which represents Degussa in Washington, said in an interview that the shipments had been approved by the West German government. There was no attempt to conceal the deals and the firm does not either acknowledge or deny that they were illegal, Dyson added. Degussa has its headquarterers in Frankfurt, West Germany. The department said that in 1986 amd 1987 Degussa sent three shipments of zirconium to North Korea, Czechoslovakia and Italy. Zirconium is used to encase uranium rods so that they can be used in nuclear reactors. It said that in 1984 and 1987 Degussa sent three shipments of beryllium to India and Britain. Beryllium is used in designing, fabricating and testing nuclear explosives. The Commerce Department statement said that in addition to paying the penalty, Degussa has promised: _To maintain a special unit to see that it complies with U.S. rules; _To report all deals for six months in beryllium, zirconium and other metals of U.S. origin; _To permit the department to make unannounced inspections of its special metals facilities in West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: White House Withdraws Request To Withhold Defense Funds
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration on Wednesday withdrew its request to Congress to delay $2.2 billion in Pentagon expenditures this year, avoiding a potential dispute over the authority of the executive branch. ``We are pleased to inform you officially that we no longer intend to withhold the funds that have been deferred,'' White House Budget Chief Richard Darman said in a letter to Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee. Presidents routinely ask Congres to delay billions of dollars of planned spending each year. By law, these requests _ commonly known as deferrals _ are permissible because of unexpected contingencies or a chance to save money through better management. The delays are not allowed for policy reasons. But the Bush administration, in making the request to lawmakers on Feb. 6, justified the deferrals, saying, ``This proposal reflects changes in requirements in view of promising developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.'' Byrd and Sen. Mark Hatfield of Oregon, ranking Republican on the appropriations committee, later complained that some of the requests ``appear to go well beyond the permissible housekeeping deferrals.'' The deferrals also drew the ire of several lawmakers who favor the particular programs that would have been affected. Among the deferrals were $200 million for the V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor, which is manufactured in Texas and Pennsylvania; $593 million for construction and conversion of Navy ships, work that is a boon to many coastal states; and $325 million for the Coast Guard's purchase of an icebreaker. On Tuesday, the House Appropriations Committee had included language in its $2.4 billion supplemental money bill disapproving the administration's request to defer $2.2 billion in Pentagon spending. Instead the panel, in talks with the Pentagon and the Office of Management and Budget, found $1.8 billion in defense cuts that will partly offset the cost of the supplemental.

DOC.HEAD: Governing Party Urges Elderly Lawmakers to Retire
DOC.TEXT: The governing Nationalist Party Wednesday urged elderly lawmakers, many in their 80s and 90s and who have not faced re-election in four decades, to bow to popular demand and retire. The statement from top party officials added new pressure on the legislators, frozen in office since 1949 when the Nationalists lost a civil war on mainland China. Lawmakers' terms were extended indefinitely to support the Nationalists claim to be China's legitimate government. The old-guard lawmakers, members of the Nationalist Party, occupy 658 seats in the 752-member National Assembly, or electoral college, part of Taiwan's tricameral parliament. ``This party hopes the senior legislators can understand public demands and make a wise decision,'' said party spokesman James Chu. Elderly lawmakers in the assembly stirred nationwide resentment this month by proposing large increases to their power and pay. They were the target of the largest demonstration in Taiwan since martial law was lifted three years ago. The protest forced President Lee Teng-hui to promise further political reforms. Chu said party officials would decide how to retire 70 senior members from the lawmaking Legislative Yuan this year, and other elderly legislators within two years. But, Chu said, the governing party continued to respect the elderly lawmakers and the contributions they have made to the party. Also on Wednesday, younger members of the National Assembly passed a resolution to expel senior colleagues who are too frail to attend session.

DOC.HEAD: American Missionary Slain; Lebanese Groups Claim Responsibility
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with U.S. comment, SUB grafs 12-16 pvs bgng, `The headquarters' with 8 grafs; pickup 17th pvs, `Israeli Army...' EDITS thereafter to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BEI1, JRL2
DOC.TEXT: Extremist groups claimed responsibility Wednesday for the slaying of an American missionary, who was shot to death in his south Lebanon home by masked intruders who burst in as he prayed with his family. The groups accused the victim, William Robinson, of trying to establish an Israeli settlement in south Lebanon, a predominatly Shiite Moslem area. The Israeli government and Robinson's relatives in his home state of Massachusetts denied it. Robinson, 59, had since 1983 run an orphanage for handicapped children, called the Christian Children's Home. Israeli troops scoured their self-proclaimed security zone in south Lebanon for the killers, who entered Robinson's home in Rashaya Foukhar on Tuesday night. The village of 4,000 is inside the security zone, about eight miles northeast of Israel's border. Lebanese security sources reported that the Israelis and their militia allies raided houses and arrested an undisclosed number of people. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the three attackers were armed with 9mm pistols equipped with silencers. First they killed six German shepherds guarding the Robinsons' home. The sources quoted Robinson's wife, Barbara, as telling U.N. investigators the men burst into the house at about 8:30 p.m. while Robinson, his wife, four sons and 26 children from the orphanage next door were singing bedtime prayers. ``Who is Robinson?'' one gunman shouted in English. The missionary said without hesitation: ``I am Robinson.'' According to Mrs. Robinson, two gunmen ordered her to take the children into her bedroom, where one assailant tied her to a chair. Another searched the room, took $4,000 and jewelry, the sources said. They then tossed a sleeping gas canister into the bedroom, knocking everyone out. An hour later, Robinson's 7-year-old son woke up found his father's body in a pool of blood in the bathtub. He had been shot in the neck and chest, the sources reported. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the United States ``deplores this act of terrorism against an American citizen.'' Ms. Tutwiler reaffirmed the U.S. position that the situation in Lebanon is ``so dangerous for Americans'' that passports remain invalid for travel to Lebanon. She said Robinson had been warned on several occasions by U.S. government personnel to leave Lebanon. He had asked twice that his passport be revalidated but was denied both times, she said. The Lebanese Communist Party claimed responsibility for his slaying. ``His execution brought an end to schemes to plant Jewish settlers in south Lebanon,'' it said in a statement issued Wednesday. The party and its militia have carried out numerous raids on Israeli targets, including an abortive suicide truck bombing in southern Lebanon on April 21, 1985. Another claim of responsibility came from the Lebanese National Resistance Front, an alliance of 12 leftist factions that include the Communists. It did not specify which faction killed Robinson. It accused Robinson of ``seeking to establish an Israeli settlement on Lebanese territory.'' The National Resistance Front is made up largely of Shiite Moslems. Ms. Tutwiler said she had no information to corroborate the claims that Robinson was settling Jews in southern Lebanon. Israeli Army Spokesman Nachman Shai's office said the allegations of plans to settle Jews in south Lebanon, a predominantly Shiite Moslem area, were ``totally baseless ... without any factual content. Israel has no intention or plans to establish settlements of these types within sovereign Lebanese territory.'' Unlike other Israeli-occupied Arab territories, the Israelis have not established any settlements in south Lebanon. They have occupied the security zone, a 6- to 10-mile-wide strip of land, since withdrawing the bulk of their army from Lebanon in 1985, three years after invading. Lebanese sources, who asked not to be identified, said Robinson had been involved in a dispute with villagers over land on which he wanted to expand the orphanage. Earlier this month, villagers petitioned the Lebanese government to prevent Robinson from establishing what they claimed would be an Israeli settlement on Lebanese soil. The petition said Robinson moved into Rashaya Foukhar's school immediately after the Israeli army invaded Lebanon in 1982, and that he gradually brought in relatives and Israeli friends. He ``seized the pine forests near Rashaya Foukhar and recently brought in Israeli engineers to build houses for 100 families,'' mostly Jewish immigrants from the United States and Sudan, the petition alleged. Scott McDonald, an announcer with the Christian-run Voice of Hope radio station, said Robinson wanted to build a home for elderly people in south Lebanon. The victim's sister, Elnora Coppolino, said Robinson had no political motives for settling in south Lebanon. ``When he left here they had been bombing in southern Lebanon, bombing the schools and the children were getting killed and he was concerned about the children,'' said Mrs. Coppolino, speaking by telephone from her home in Athol, Mass. Mrs. Coppolino said Robinson was brought up in Athol, a small town about 50 miles from Springfield. She said her brother was a Congregationalist and moved to Lebanon in 1978. His work in Lebanon was not affiliated with any particular group, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands March in San Juan to Protest Telephone Co. Sale
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of union workers staged a one-day strike and marched to the capital Wednesday to protest the government's plan to sell Puerto Rico's telephone company for $2 billion. More than 60 unions representing private and public workers took part in the general strike and what was the biggest protest demonstration in this U.S. commonwealth in recent history. San Juan's Channel 24 TV station estimated the crowd at 160,000. Organizers had said they expected 100,000. Police had no estimate. At one point, a line of marchers 10 to 15 abreast stretched for more than two miles from Dos Hermanos Bridge at the entrance of the Condado tourist district to the domed capital in colonial Old San Juan. Demonstrators, many wearing bright yellow, blue, red and green union T-shirts, were bused into San Juan from across the Caribbean island, which has 3.3 million inhabitants. Protesters carried banners and signs, blew whistles and chanted slogans as they filed by the headquarters of Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon's Popular Democratic Party. Plywood protected the building's glass front, and police guarded the entrance. In a televised speech later, the governor called the protest ``damaging'' and ``absurd.'' He said he would not give up his plan to sell the government-owned Puerto Rico Telephone Co. ``The labor and political leaders who carried out this march want to blackmail the government and the people,'' he said. Hernandez Colon, elected to a second four-year term in 1988, proposed the sale in his state of the commonwealth message Feb. 20. Proceeds are to be used to create two perpetual funds of $1 billion each, one for education and the other for public works projects such as road and bridge repairs and water and sewer improvements. The perpetual funds are expected to generate $85 million to $95 million a year in interest revenues. Critics say the governor acted without proper consultation with opposition parties and with no assurances that jobs and employee benefits would be protected by a new owner. The government acquired the telephone company from ITT Corp. in 1974 for $165 million. It now earns $70 million a year and employs 8,000 people. Juan Velez, president of the Communications Authority Employees Union, one of two unions representing 4,800 telephone workers, told a rally at the capital that legislators supporting the sale should be turned out of office. ``The workers are not only here in defense of national patrimony (state-owned assets), but also in defense of true electional reform,'' said Velez. A brief scuffle broke out when protesters surged against police lines at the foot of the capital steps, but no injuries were reported. Otherwise, the march and rally were peaceful. The effects of the strike on the public were minimal, except for huge traffic jams in the area of the march and rally. Public buses were idle, but most schools, banks, government buildings and stores remained open. Several bomb threats including one at Fort Buchanan, a U.S. army post, were reported by police, but all proved false. The National Guard on Tuesday moved large electricity generators to the governor's mansion, La Fortaleza, and the capitol in the event of an electricity outage.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats, Republicans Cite Inexperience In S&L Nominee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with Ryan replies to charges and conclusion of hearing; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Democrats on the Senate Banking Committee sharply criticized President Bush's nominee for top savings and loan regulator Wednesday, charging inexperience and conflicts of interest. ``Every indication I have is he doesn't know anything about the financial services industry,'' said Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., at the start of a grueling 4{-hour confirmation hearing. But the nominee, T. Timothy Ryan, Jr., a former senior Labor Department official, vigorously defended himself as an experienced administrator and tough regulator. ``I think I have a reputation for moving things along,'' Ryan said. ``I make things happen ... and I have a proven track record in enforcement.'' President Bush last Thursday nominated Ryan, 44, to a five-year term as director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. The office regulates 2,600 S&Ls and its director sits on a five-member board conducting the administration's S&L bailout and insuring S&L deposits. The committee could vote on the nomination as soon as its next meeting April 3. Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, who is not a member of the committee but attended the session, charged that conflicts of interest between the nominee's public and private careers ``raise basic questions about Mr. Ryan's sense of propriety.'' Metzenbaum cited several aspects of Ryan's career after he left the Labor Department in 1983. As the department's solicitor, Ryan engineered a consent decree which installed an independent counsel to oversee the Teamsters' $4 billion Central States Pension Fund. He helped select former Attorney General William B. Saxbe for the job. Ryan then left government to practice law and later Saxbe received court permission to join Ryan's law firm, bringing thousands of dollars in fees from the pension oversight contract. In 1985, the Labor Department asked Ryan to resign as a member of its Employee Retirement Income Security Act Advisory Council after it discovered that he was also serving as counsel to a trade group, the Employee Stock Ownership Association of America. Metzenbaum also criticized Ryan for sitting on the council while a client, the Washington Business Group on Health, had an interest in issues before it. He said Ryan should not have advised the National Maritime Union of America on a union election the Labor Department began investigating shortly before Ryan left government. In his defense, Ryan said the federal judge overseeing the Teamsters' case concluded it was not improper for Saxbe to join his firm. He said he never participated in employee-owned stock matters while working for the advisory council, did not represent the business group on the pension matter that came before the advisory board and never dealt with the Labor Department directly concerning the maritime union. Ryan also was strongly defended by Sen. John Warner, R-Va., who employed him as an aide in his last three campaigns. ``The president, the secretary of the Treasury and to some extent I have been involved in this nomination and we're going to stand by this man,'' Warner said. ``The man's tough. The man's fair. The man's honest.'' However, even Republicans expressed concern about Ryan's lack of experience in the banking and savings and loan industries. After the Labor Department post, where he was responsible for managing 600 attorneys in Washington and 16 field offices, Ryan entered private law practice with the firm of Reed, Smith, Shaw & McClay. He specialized in pension and employee benefit law. ``What concerns me is ... you don't have the background or scope of knowledge to try to understand what is happening out there in the trenches,'' said Sen. Connie Mack, R-Fla. Despite their misgivings, senators are under intense pressure to confirm Ryan quickly because his appointment could remove a constitutional challenge to the administraion's savings and loan bailout. A federal judge in Washington last week ruled that the acting director of the thrift office, Salvatore Martoche, and his predecessor, M. Danny Wall, lacked the authority to close failed thrifts. Wall was never confirmed by the Senate for the job. Sen. Donald W. Riegle, D-Mich., the chairman of the panel, said he went along with the administration's request to schedule an early confirmation hearing but warned Ryan that there's no guarantee he will be confirmed. Complained Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., ``We're being sort of whipsawed into rushing your nomination.'' Some Democrats also are uneasy about Ryan's reputation as a long-time Republican activist. He served as an aide or attorney in presidential campaigns for Richard Nixon in 1972, Gerald Ford in 1976 and George Bush in 1988. He was a legal counsel to Ronald Reagan's 1980 transition team. ``This (agency) will not be a political operation,'' Ryan said. ``I would not be part of that. I think this problem is much too big to be treated in a political fashion.'' The hearing was attended by S&L financier Charles H. Keating, Jr., owner of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, based in Irvine, Calif. Its bailout is expected to cost $2.5 billion _ perhaps the costliest thrift failure in the nation. Keating, who was denied his request to speak to the committee, said he did not think Ryan's qualifications were adequate. ``I have a distinct interest here in seeing the leadership in this industry the best and most qualified for the job. We have a financial interest in what happens,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Adopted, Given to Orphanage Six Years Later
DOC.TEXT: A suburban couple separated two young brothers they adopted in 1984, putting the older boy in an orphanage on Christmas and forbidding him from seeing his brother, a public guardian who sued the couple said Wednesday. ``It's every little boy's nightmare,'' said Cook County Public Guardian Patrick T. Murphy. ``Rick's parents told him they were going to put him into an orphanage and they did it. It's like telling a kid you're going to send the bogey man after him and then doing it.'' The lawsuit filed Tuesday in Circuit Court seeks visitation rights for the brothers and seeks $50,000 in damages for alleged emotional harm to Rick, 11. Any money would be held in escrow for Rick until he is 18, Murphy said. The couple, who live in suburban Bellwood, adopted Rick _ not his real name _ and his brother, now 8, in August 1984 after the boys' natural mother abandoned them. The parents put Rick in a nearby Oak Park orphanage last Christmas, and received approval March 9 from Circuit Court Judge Walter Williams to surrender their parental rights to him. The brothers never before had been separated. The adoptive parents, identified in the lawsuit only as Joseph and Pamela Doe, said Rick did not ``bond'' to them, Murphy said. The parents said Rick ``is only out for what he can get,'' and they prevented his younger brother from seeing him, according to Murphy. Murphy, whose job as public guardian is to act on behalf of children such as Rick, said he sued instead of appealing the judge's decision because a lawsuit would be faster and might be more successful. The parents' attorney, Mary C. Martin, declined to discuss the case Tuesday. Calls to her office Wednesday were not returned. Murphy said Rick is now in a temporary foster home. Rick blames himself for the separation, the guardian said. He called Rick a ``normal kid'' who has never been in trouble with the law. ``This is not a schizophrenic kid who is climbing the walls and throwing feces at people,'' he said. ``He's a normal kid.'' Murphy played a tape he said was Rick speaking of his experience. Rick says, ``Mom and Dad were talking about something, and they said they were going to put me up for adoption. I thought they were kidding. They weren't.'' Rick then apologizes to his brother for a fight the two had. ``This is for you,'' he said. ``Remember that day that I hurt your nose when I beat you up? I'm sorry for that. I didn't mean it ... . I hope I get to see you again.'' The lawsuit describes the parents as a middle-class couple who own two small businesses. Murphy said the lawsuit is unusual, but only because parents usually don't separate adopted children. ``Now you've got bureaucrats and judges who say it's OK,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lujan To Look For Alternatives On North Dakota's Garrison Project
DOC.TEXT: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan agreed Wednesday to look for ways to continue construction of North Dakota's Garrison Diversion water project, which the Bush administration wants to kill. ``We owe it to the ... people of North Dakota to look at the alternatives,'' Lujan said after a closed-door meeting with the North Dakota congressional delegation. Garrison, possibly the most criticized water project in the nation, would divert Missouri River water for farm irrigation and municipal use. Over the years it has been attacked as being too costly and environmentally unsound. The project was scaled back under a 1986 agreement wtih environmental groups that sifted the focus of the project from irrigation to municipal water use. However, $800 million of the its $1 billion price tag is still earmarked for building irrigation facilities. The project is again in serious trouble on Capitol Hill, because of the administration's proposal to cancel it and a recent report by the Interior Department's inspector general that the project probably isn't financially feasible. The report said the farmers who would get Garrison water for irrigation will have to pay a larger share of the construction cost than they can afford.
