Lujan said he agreed to form a working group representing the congressional delegation and the administration to discuss the options for the project. ``I can't tell you now how we can resolve these issues,'' he said. Because of the inspector general's report, construction will probably have to stop at least temporarily on parts of the project that would supply water for irrigating farms, said Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D. The inspector general's report is critical to the project because the Interior Department must develop an acceptable plan for allocating the construction costs before the government can sign a repayment contract with the Garrison Diversion Conservancy District.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Charges Three in Plot to Ship Nuclear Devices to Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 24 grafs to UPDATE with three charged and identified, Bush's comment, NBC details. Picks up 20th, `Iraq accused...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON3
DOC.TEXT: Customs officials said they foiled an attempt on Wednesday to supply Iraq with 40 U.S.-made devices for triggering nuclear explosions, and that three people were charged. U.S. and British investigators worked on the case for 18 months. The Customs and Excise Department in a statement named the three as Lebanese engineer Toufic Fouad Amyuni, 37; Ali Ashour Daghir, 49, a company director with dual Iraqi and British nationality; and export executive Jeanine Celestine Speckman, 41, a Frenchwoman married to a Briton. The statement said they were charged under the Export of Prohibited Goods Control Act and will appear before Uxbridge Magistrates Court in west London at 10 a.m. Thursday. All three gave addresses in or near London, it added. Iraqi diplomats in London refused to comment on the case. An investigation initiated by U.S. customs climaxed in a freight shed at London's Heathrow Airport as an attempt was made Wednesday morning to put the devices _ which may have been dummies _ aboard an Iraqi Airways flight to Baghdad, British customs officials said. Authorities said five people were arrested in and around London, including Iraqi national Omar Latif, who was immediately served with a deportation order, and a Cypriot with a British passport who was released after questioning. In Washington, the U.S. Customs Service said sealed indictments had already been returned at a San Diego District Court. After the arrests, President Bush expressed concern over the spread of nuclear weapons in the Middle East and said in a written statement: ``We again call upon nuclear suppliers to exercise special restraint in providing materials related to the development of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and intermediate-range missiles in this volatile area.'' While avoiding direct criticism of Iraq, Bush noted it was among the nations that signed the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Customs officials in London, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the devices were capacitors, electrical components of the detonation chain of a nuclear bomb. Defense experts said it demonstrated Iraq's determination to become a nuclear power, even at the risk of being caught violating Western bans on the export of strategic high technology. Indications emerged, however, that the devices deposited at Heathrow were dummies, substituted for the real hardware as part of the U.S. customs operation. British Broadcasting Corp. TV said customs officers made the switch after the packages arrived from the United States at the beginning of the week. Channel 4 TV News carried an interview with the manufacturer of the so-called krytrons, who said his company turned over dummies to U.S. customs late last year. ``We provided about 40 devices ... to the Customs Service and they were deliberately made to be inoperative,'' said Don Kerr, president of EG & G in Wellesley, Mass. He indicated he did not know whether these were the devices that reached London, saying: ``Basically we supplied these devices to the Customs Service in the United States and the subsequent movement of them is unknown to us.'' The Home Office said Latif was to be deported because of ``attempted breaches of legislation governing the export of strategic goods from the United Kingdom.'' BBC-TV showed footage of the operation that it said was shot by an NBC crew that was in on the investigation. NBC reported Scotland Yard detectives raided the headquarters ``of what is being described as a secret Iraqi nuclear procurement network,'' and removed documents and other evidence. It quoted authorities as saying ``the man at the top of the Iraqi operations is Ali Daghir, who was sent to London from Baghdad almost two years ago.'' NBC said Daghir was arrested at his office shortly after the Iraqi flight took off. British officials made few formal statements about the incident. U.S. customs spokesman Ed Kittredge commented, ``They're sensitive about Iraq and the number of British citizens there.'' Kittredge mentioned Iraq's execution March 15 of Farzad Bazoft, an Iranian reporter who was working for a British newspaper. Iraq accused Bazoft of spying. Britain reacted by withdrawing its ambassador from Iraq and expelling some Iraqis, but it has been reluctant to let relations with Baghdad worsen further. More than 10,000 Britons work in Iraq. The Foreign Office summoned the Iraqi ambassador to inform him of the expulsion but refused to link the action to the alleged smuggling operation. Military experts said the devices are available only to a handful of major powers, and their export is strictly controlled. They recalled two previous smuggling attempts, one involving Israel and the other Pakistan, both of which have nuclear weapons ambitions. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is known to harbor ambitions of eclipsing Egypt and Syria as the premier military power of the Arab world. In 1981, Israeli warplanes bombed an Iraqi nuclear reactor, claiming it was designed to make bombs. Lately, Iraq has developed long-range missiles thought to be capable of delivering a nuclear warhead. Professor Paul Wilkinson, a Bradford University terrorism expert, said: ``If they're trying to smuggle in these highly sophisticated trigger devices, that means they're very serious about making nuclear weapons, and soon.''

DOC.HEAD: Four To Be Inducted into Women's Hall of Fame
DOC.TEXT: A photojournalist, an athlete, a scientist and a politician will be the next members of the National Women's Hall of Fame in Seneca Falls, N.Y., the head of the hall announced Wednesday. The four, chosen out of about one thousand nominees, will join the 42 women already in the feminist pantheon, according to Sally Parr, executive director. They are: _The late Margaret Bourke-White, a photojournalist who worked for Life and Fortune magazines. _Tennis star Billie Jean King, who was ranked the No. 1 women's player four times in her career. _Florence Siebert, a retired medical researcher who in the 1930s isolated and purified a protein that paved the way for an accurate test for tuberculosis; _Barbara Jordan, a Texas Democrat who served in Congress from 1972 through 1978, the first woman and the first black to give the keynote address at a national political convention. The four will be officially inducted Aug. 26, Women's Equality Day, at Seneca Falls.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Falls in Rockies
DOC.TEXT: Spring snowstorms fell in northern sections of the nation from the Rockies to Maine on Wednesday, leaving up to 9 inches of snow, and rain fell in parts of the Midwest and the South. Temperatures dipped below freezing in the mid-Atlantic Coast states. In Wyoming, 3 to 5 inches of snow fell in Lander, Pinedale and Big Piney, and up to 9 inches covered Bondurant and Cora. Two to 5 inches fell overnight between Duluth and Park Rapids, Minn. Heavier snowfall in the six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST included 2 inches at Casper, Cheyenne and Rawlins, Wyo., and Duluth, as well as an inch at Goodland, Kan., and Laramie, Wyo. Snow also fell in parts of Colorado and Kansas, northwest Wisconsin and northern Maine. Rain dampened central and northern Utah, southeast Colorado, southern Nebraska, Kansas and parts of Oklahoma, southwest Iowa, much of Missouri and Arkansas, northeast Louisiana, Mississippi and western Tennessee. Showers and thunderstorms fell along the upper Texas coast and in southwest Louisiana, and scattered rain fell over north-central Texas and southwest California. In Atlantic City, the mercury dipped to 18 degrees, tying the record low for the date set in 1966. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was zero degrees at Houlton, Maine. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 13 degrees in Limestone, Maine, to 86 in Tampa, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Underlines Need for Restraint in Talk With Gorbachev
With Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher underlined the need for restraint on all sides in the Lithuania crisis during a 50-minute telephone conversation Wednesday with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, her office said. The phone call, arranged in advance through diplomatic contacts, was timed to precede Mrs. Thatcher's meetings Thursday and Friday with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Britain and with President Bush in Bermuda on April 13. Mrs. Thatcher's office gave no details on Gorbachev's response on Lithuania but said she emphasized the need for restraint and negotiations and expressed hope the crisis could be settled in a way suitable to both sides. ``The people of Lithuania have made clear their wish to determine their own future,'' Mrs. Thatcher said to the House of Commons Tuesday. She said Britain had never recognized the 1940 Soviet annexation of Lithuania though it was recognized ``in fact'' in the 35-nation Helsinki accords in 1975. ``Undoubtedly, that is a very difficult situation, both for President Gorbachev and for the people of Lithuania,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. ``I believe that it calls for great restraint on both sides. Force is not an appropriate way to settle the position. I hope it will be settled by restraint on both sides and by their discussing it so that they come to a satisfactory conclusion. ``That view was also taken by the 12 foreign secretaries of the European Community,'' she said. Mrs. Thatcher's spokesman, who by custom was not identified, said the conversation also covered other world events, including the East German elections, prospects for German unification, and the prime minister's visit to Kiev in June.

DOC.HEAD: Outspoken Liberal to Retire
DOC.TEXT: Rep. George W. Crockett Jr., D-Mich., a fiery champion of liberal causes for nearly five decades and defense lawyer for Communist Party members in a celebrated 1949 trial, Wednesday announced his retirement. ``After 68 years of working, I'm hoping to enjoy a little time off,'' the 80-year-old chairman of the Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs said in a brief floor speech announcing that he will not seek a sixth term. Crockett had announced his candidacy for re-election, but faced at least two challengers for the Democratic nomination in his heavily Democratic Detroit district. He said in an interview the prospect of stiff opposition did not influence his change of heart. ``I've just gotten older and wiser,'' he said. Crockett recently became the first member of Congress to advocate decriminalizing drug use, the latest of many stands that have outraged conservatives and even made some fellow liberals uneasy. Born and reared in Jacksonville, Fla., he earned a law degree at the University of Michigan and was an attorney with the Justice Department and the United Auto Workers union. Judging by his courtly demeanor and mild manners, it might be hard to believe Crockett's fiery past. In 1949, Crockett gained national attention for his spirited defense of 11 communists charged with subversion in New York. His clashes with the presiding federal judge, Harold Medina, earned him and four other defense lawyers a four-month prison sentence for contempt of court. He was elected judge in the Detroit Recorder's Court, which handles criminal cases, in 1966 and served 12 years. He was elected to Congress in 1980. As chairman of the Western Hemisphere subcommittee, he opposed the Reagan administration's Central American policies, especially its support of the Nicaraguan rebels. He was jailed overnight in 1984 after demonstrating outside the South African embassy. ``He's not a person constantly seeking votes or trying to get before the media or particularly concerned with what the polls tell him is the popular position,'' said a Democratic colleague from Michigan, John Conyers said. ``He's always been his own man.'' ``He has been a gentleman and despite the fullness of his years, he's been a very active chairman of an important subcommittee,'' said Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., a member of the Western Hemisphere panel.

DOC.HEAD: North Dakota Lawmaker Retires After 52 Years
LaserPhoto MIN1
DOC.TEXT: The nation's longest serving state lawmaker, who took office when Franklin Delano Roosevelt was president and the desk of each North Dakota legislator was close to a spittoon, called it quits Wednesday. It was ``time to step aside,'' from the House seat she held for 52 years, said Brynhild Haugland, 84. Her retirement becomes effective this December, following an election in November. The Minot Republican, first elected in 1938, modestly referred to herself as ``the least of the least.'' ``I just tried to do my best,'' Miss Haugland said. ``Serving in the House has been a joy.'' But legislative colleagues said Miss Haugland's gentle demeanor and unflashy style masked political shrewdness and a steely will to prevail on issues she held dear. ``She's a political genius,'' said Republican colleague Rep. Janet Wentz. ``She was never wasteful with her power. She knew when to use it.'' Miss Haugland is the nation's longest-serving state lawmaker, said Bill Pound, director of the National Conference of State Legislatures, a Denver-based research group. Miss Haugland recalled the old days. ``Those spittoons would always rattle,'' she said. ``People would inevitably kick them.'' Rep. Rod Larson, who was vice chairman of Miss Haugland's Human Services and Veterans Affairs committee in the last two sessions, said the lawmaker had a knack for doing things in a quiet way. Miss Haugland was chairwoman of the committee for 23 of the 26 sessions she served in the Legislature, which meets in odd-numbered years and is not in session. ``She just knew what she wanted to do, and she was very up-front,'' Larson said. ``She wouldn't worry about the popularity or unpopularity of things. ``If she didn't like somebody, she didn't mince words either,'' he said. ``People knew where they stood with her.'' Gov. George Sinner declared March 18, 1987, as Brynhild Haugland Day, and the entire House paid tribute to her service, decorating her desk with balloons. The largest hearing room in the state Capitol is named for Miss Haugland, and the last two editions of the North Dakota Blue Book, a standard reference work on state government, have been dedicated to her. ``She is an inspiration to us all,'' Sinner said Wednesday in a statement. ``Her service to this state is unparalleled.'' ``She is absolutely a walking history book,'' Larson said. For four sessions, Miss Haugland was the only woman in the entire Legislature and for four others, she was the House's only woman, said Ann Rathke, a Bismarck historian who is researching North Dakota's women lawmakers. ``It didn't bother me,'' said Miss Haugland, who ran a dairy farm and now rents her 800 acres of cropland on her farm two miles northwest of Minot. ``People respect you for who you are.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted Of Planning `Snuff' Movie
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury on Wednesday convicted an Alexandria man on conspiracy charges in a plot to kidnap, torture and murder a young boy for production of a pornographic ``snuff'' movie. Though no youngster was ever actually kidnapped, the U.S. District Court jury of eight women and four men found that there was enough evidence to convict Daniel T. DePew on two charges of conspiracy. DePew, 28, faces up to life in prison and will be sentenced May 27 by Judge T.S. Ellis III. The conviction ended 2{ days of testimony and evidence in which violent acts were discussed in lurid detail and the lifestyles of sadomastochistic homosexuals was revealed in court. Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Smythers questioned defense attorney James Lowe's assertion that the defendant never intended to carry out the plan. ``Which child are we going to turn over to him to test, to see if he would do it?'' Smythers asked the jury. DePew testified at length on Tuesday and Wednesday, claiming that he was too intimidated to get out of the plot and said it was ``a fantasy.'' During cross examination by prosecutors, the defendant also admitted that he had engaged in violent homosexual activities at the age of 12. He also said that the sexual activities described throughout the trial were ``enjoyable'' to him but that he was not attracted to young boys, What appeared to be a damning piece of evidence presented on Wednesday was a video tape DePew made with his lover, Dean Lambey, in which he described a person who wanted to ``kill boys'' while a video camera panned a playground. Another video tape shown to the jury on Tuesday depicted violent sex between the lovers. Smythers said in his closing summation that the video ``would have been enough to gag a maggot.'' Prosecutors said DePew and his partner were arrested before they could carry out the plan, which police officers contend was real. DePew tesified that he talked to Lambey about the plan because he wanted him as a sexual partner. During the investigation, police established a long-distance computer relationship with the men through a computer bulletin board for pedophiles. Lambey pleaded guilty last fall and is serving a 30-year sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Albanians Stage Peaceful Protest in Kosovo
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo peacefully protested Wednesday on the first anniversary of constitutional changes that curbed the autonomy of their troubled region. Throughout the province, for two hours beginning at noon, streets in towns and villages were almost empty as ethnic Albanians stayed indoors to protest. The constitutional amendments gave Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic, near total control over Kosovo, where ethnic Albanians comprise 90 percent of the 1.9 million population. ``With this silent protest we want to mark a year of repressive and brutal policy which has to the extreme curtailed our human rights,'' said a statement by newly formed, independent ethnic Albanian groups that called the protest. March 28 was proclaimed a holiday in Serbia and was celebrated with public festivities. Kosovo's Communist Party president, Rahman Morina, told The Associated Press the ruling party will allow free elections in Kosovo and may open a dialogue with some the new groups in the province. Western human rights monitors, speaking to reporters in Belgrade, stressed, however, that violence has increased in Kosovo since January and dialogue seems distant. Karl Schwarzenberg, chief of the Vienna-based International Helsinki Federation, said after touring Kosovo that mass arrests there of ethnic Albanians constitute ``a frightening example of the power of a one-party dictatorship.'' About 60 ethnic Albanians demanding the return of autonomy have died in clashes with security forces in Kosovo since the constitutional changes were passed a year ago. Thousands have been arrested and jailed for ``separatist and terrorist activities'' that Serbian authorities say are aimed at taking Kosovo out from Yugoslavia to join neighboring Communist Albania. Serbia says the constitutional changes were needed to protect minority Serbs in Kosovo from harassment by ethnic Albanians. Heavily armed Serbian police, who last week took full control in Kosovo, patrolled towns in the region frequently checking identity cards of pedestrians, searching cars and sometimes arresting people. Veton Suroi, a leading ethnic Albanian activist and a leader of a coalition of newly formed independent groups, said, ``We think street protest cannot solve Kosovo's problems. The street protests can only provide an excuse for more repression.''

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Jams TV Marti for a Second Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 4-6: ``The Cuban,'' with Cuban comment
DOC.TEXT: TV Marti tried to resume broadcasts to Cuba on Wednesday for a second day but Cuban authorities jammed the transmission two minutes after it began, the State Department said. The Voice of America project, designed to bring news and entertainment to Cuban viewers, remained on the air from 3:45 a.m. to 6:45 a.m. and the signal was blocked for all but the first two minutes, department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. The Cuban government has called the experiment ``tele-aggression'' and lodged a protest with the Federal Communications Commission after Tuesday's premiere, which also was jammed. The Cuban news agency, Prensa Latina, likened the broadcasts to a Laurel and Hardy comedy routine. ``After a series of falls from rooftops and broken ladders, they are back at point zero,'' it said. ``What is beginning as a species of comedy of the absurd could end in tragedy,'' a reference to the Cuban government's characterization of the broadcasts as a possible prelude to armed U.S. intervention on the island. After the current testing phase of TV Marti is over, the administration will make a judgment as to whether the project is technologically and legally feasible. The transmissions are being sent during the early morning hours in order not to interfere with local programming. Wednesday's schedule included a baseball feature with former Cincinnati catcher Johnny Bench, a tennis show with Boris Becker and features on Albert Einstein and Hispanic contributions to American life. Programming is to continue on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Puzzled By Wakeup of Man in Vegetative State
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with patient's doctor saying case may not be typical, that patient had some atypical responses and patient's condition Wednesday; hospital saying it's had inquiries from around the world; picks up 19th graf, `Experts said ...'
DOC.TEXT: Medical experts said Wednesday they were puzzled by reports that tranquilizers revived a man who'd spent eight years in a vegetative state. ``This is so bizarre,'' Dr. Catherine Bontke of the Institute for Rehabilitation and Research in Houston said in a telephone interview. ``It just doesn't make sense. It doesn't fit anything I know.'' But the patient's doctor warned that the case was an isolated one that should not be automatically applied to similar cases. ``It makes me nervous that people are going to see this as a possibility'' for treating such patients, said Dr. Andres Kanner, a University of Wisconsin neurologist. ``I think we are getting excited prematurely,'' he told a news conference. ``Every patient is different. Why this happened with this patient, we don't know.'' Since the case was reported Tuesday, the university has received inquiries about it from around the world, said University Hospital and Clinics spokeswoman Priscilla Arsove. Kanner reported Tuesday that a 45-year-old man was awakened after being injected with Valium during a routine dental procedure March 12. The man has been awakened several times since, Kanner said. The patient, a former airline pilot, was injured in a car accident 10 years ago. He was in a coma for about three months, then improved, but lapsed into a vegetative state about eight years ago, Kanner said. The patient, whose identity was withheld at family request, was being cared for in a nursing home when the drug was administered, the doctor said. The patient is being observed at the hospital, and doctors are experimenting to find the dose of tranquilizers that would allow the man, who is married and has children, to leave the hospital and return home, Kanner said. When medicated, the man can remain fully conscious for up to 12 hours at a time, the neurologist said. On the day he was first revived, the man was able to walk, talk and perform complicated math calculations, Kanner said. When not treated with the medication, the man returns to the vegetative-like state, Kanner said Wednesday. The patient remained in that state Wednesday at the hospital, while doctors experimented with oral administration of the drugs, he said. But that procedure so far has not had the same effect as when they were injected and the man woke up. Doctors plan to continue experimenting for a few weeks and, if no progress is made, they will re-evaluate the situation. Continuous injections of the tranquilizing drugs ``has its risks,'' including depression of the respiratory system or the heart, Kanner said. A vegetative state is different from a coma because vegetative state patients have sleeping and waking patterns, often open their eyes and sometimes utter words, experts said. Kanner said Wednesday the man was in a ``vegetative-like state'' rather than a ``true vegetative state.'' The man had some reactions that would not be characteristic of someone in a permanent vegetative state, Kanner said. For example, the man would sometimes pull his arm away when someone tried to give him an injection, he said. Experts said the man's reaction should stimulate research and cause doctors to re-examine some of their patients, but it probably wouldn't have a significant immediate effect on medical practices. ``It must cause caregivers to be more cautious,'' said Dr. Richard Foa of Washington, a member of the American Academy of Neurology's Ethics and Humanity Subcommittee. ``But an anecdote like this wouldn't alter my practice.'' Foa said the vegetative state has been studied in recent years as specialists try to narrow its definition. Usually, a persistent vegetative state patient is given that prognosis after six months to a year. Many doctors believe the condition justifies the removal of life-support systems, Foa said. ``The immediate question that arises is, `Was this individual properly diagnosed?''' Foa said. Still, the Madison case will raise questions when doctors consider withdrawing life-support systems, Foa said. ``But it shouldn't lead to fundamental changes in the care given,'' he said. The case should be meticulously documented, Foa added. Kanner declined to comment Wednesday on his colleague's opinions, except to say that doctors at his hospital have not concluded why the drugs help the man. Kanner said Tuesday that one theory is that benzodiazepines, such as Valium and barbituates, inhibit certain nervous system functions and may have blocked the effects of the vegetative state. But Dr. Nathan Zasler, a member of the Medical College of Virginia in Richmond, said drugs such as Valium typically would have a worsening effect on vegetative state patients. ``There are no reports that I am aware of where Valium was used to wake people up,'' Zasler said. ``Typically, what we would find is that it would make them worse rather than better in terms of arousal.'' ``Lots of people are misdiagnosed,'' Zasler said. ``To me, this sounds really bizarre, but I'm not saying it can't happen.'' There were about 10,000 persistent vegetative state patients in the United States in 1988, according to the American Academy of Neurology in Minneapolis.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Providing King Holiday Passes in Idaho
DOC.TEXT: The Idaho House approved legislation Wednesday to make Idaho the 47th state with a holiday honoring slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. The House voted 53-27 for the bill previously passed by the Senate. Later, the Senate accepted a House amendment that made the holiday's complete name ``Martin Luther King Jr.-Idaho Human Rights Day.'' Final approval by the Senate was expected Thursday before the bill goes to Gov. Cecil Andrus, who proposed the holiday. The bill was the subject of tortuous arguments in the legislature last week. Opponents said their constituents didn't care about Martin Luther King. ``We're told this isn't a black holiday, but yet we're also told we can't change the name,'' said Rep. Stan Hawkins, a Republican. ``If you really have a guilt trip in mind by passing this, you're making a mistake.'' Rep. L. Ed Brown, also a Republican and one of the bill's sponsors, said the decision on the bill would ``say more about Idaho than .. about Martin Luther King.'' ``Idaho is not the state in the Union that's going to determine Martin Luther King's greatness,'' Brown said. ``Forty-six states and the federal government have already done that.'' Brown said adopting a King holiday would ``send a very special message to future generations about how Idahoans feel about minorities.'' Besides Idaho, only Arizona, Montana and New Hampshire have not adopted state holidays corresponding with the federal holiday honoring King on the third Monday in January. The Idaho Legislature created a state commemorative day in 1987, and a bill creating a state holiday died in a House committee last year despite arguments its failure would only reinforce the perception some have of Idaho as a haven for racists. Opponents said they objected to another day off for government employees. Proponents said Idaho's economy would suffer through lost tourism and convention business if it failed to establish the holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Sudan's Military Government Foils Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: The military government has arrested a number of civilians and military officers for planning to stage a coup, the official Sudan News Agency reported Wednesday. It quoted an unidentified military official as saying those arrested ``were planning a limited movement to achieve subversive objectives.'' ``The situation is contained and an investigation has begun with those involved,'' the military official said. He said Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir's government had been monitoring their activities for four months but gave no details on the number of detainees or when they were arrested. He said they included Abdul-Rahman Farrah, a retired navy officer and a former security adviser to the disbanded Umma Party. The military official indicated the others also belonged to the disbanded Umma and Communist parties. He said the two parties had joined 10 others and 31 trade unions last October in signing a secret document called the National Democratic Alliance Charter. The charter calls for the overthrow of el-Bashir, who seized power in a military coup on June 30, and outlines steps to convene a constitutional conference to end the 7-year-old civil war in the south. El-Bashir dissolved all political parties, trade unions and professional associations after the coup. Sudanese sources in the Egyptian capital, Cairo, said that in the past week members of the disbanded parties had amended some points of the charter at the request of the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army. They said the changes included a stipulation that the constitutional conference be held within six months of the overthrow of el-Bashir, and that Sudanese and rebel troops be combined into a single force once the war ends. A rebel delegation arrived in Cairo last week and met with President Hosni Mubarak on Tuesday. The rebels took up arms against the government in 1983, demanding greater autonomy and administrative and economic reforms in the south.

DOC.HEAD: Carter Center Poll Finds Wide Diversity Among Soviets on Key Issues
DOC.TEXT: A poll of nearly 2,500 Soviets found them far from united on how to reshape their society and often divided along ethnic lines in their views of religion, the Red Army and the Communist Party. The survey, released Wednesday by former President Carter's public policy center, found a sharp divergence on the role of government. The traditional Communist notion that the state is responsible for everyone's well-being was favored by 46 percent, but 45 percent said individuals should rely on themselves. ``Many of those who want rapid change to solve social problems also hold the state responsible for individual well-being,'' wrote poll analyst Ada Finifter, a Michigan State University political science professor. ``Thus it is likely that there will be shifting and unstable majorities for various reform efforts.'' George Gerbner of the University of Pennsylvania said half of the respondents believe most people cannot be trusted and the poor have only themselves to blame for their predicament. Sixty percent agreed that most people in the Soviet Union are indifferent to the fate of others. ``With millions likely to be out of jobs when the convulsion runs its full course, this will add to the volatility of the situation,'' Gerbner said. The National Center for Public Opinion Research in Moscow helped direct the poll with American researchers from the the University of Pennsylvania, Michigan State and the Carter Center, which is affiliated with Emory University. Pollsters conducted 90-minute interviews with 2,485 Soviet citizens in their homes last November and December. No margin of error was given. Carter called it ``the first-ever definitive poll conducted in the Soviet Union.'' The opinions of many respondents appeared largely influenced not by their age, education or Communist Party membership, but by the minority groups they belong to, the pollsters said. The Soviet census identifies more than 100 national groups, usually identified by their language. Future Soviet policies will have to take into account ``that on the most fundamental and deeply felt questions, the peoples of the Soviet Union inhabit vastly different worlds,'' wrote Ellen Mickiewicz, a Carter Center fellow and political science professor at Emory. However, 72 percent of those polled opposed allowing a dissemination of opinion advocating superiority of one nationality over another. Just 1 percent of residents in the Baltic republics and 6 percent of Georgians agreed that the Soviet Army always acted in the people's interests, compared with 26 percent of Central Asians and 29 percent of Russians, the poll showed. Forty-two percent of Georgians said the Communist Party never makes decisions serving the public, compared with 6 percent of Central Asians. Sixty-nine percent of respondents from Moslem-dominated Georgia agreed that religious institutions acted in the people's best interests, compared with 44 percent of Baltic residents, 39 percent of Russians and 20 percent of Central Asians, the poll showed. ``The church has played a more active role in trying to moderate during the recent civil strife in Georgia,'' Ms. Mickiewicz said. Nationally, just 26 percent of Communist Party members polled expressed full confidence in the party and 12 percent expressed no confidence, the poll showed. Fifty-four percent of Soviets defended free speech even at the cost of political disorder while 37 percent said public order should be more important. Only 11 percent of the respondents said they agreed with the ``old order'' precept of strict income equality, and 84 percent want to permit varying incomes, pollsters said.

DOC.HEAD: College Student Goes on Trial in Newborn's Drowning
DOC.TEXT: A college student accused of drowning her newborn in a dormitory toilet murdered the child because he was an inconvenience, prosecutors said Wednesday in opening arguments. Tears rolled down the cheeks of 18-year-old Claire Moritt as Assistant State Attorney Joan Richardson denied the defense's contention that Ms. Moritt had gone temporarily insane. ``This is a girl who chooses to deny or replace those things she feels are unpleasant,'' said Ms. Richardson. ``When she could not wish this baby away, could not deny it _ she killed it.'' If convicted of first-degree murder, the Hillsborough Community College student from Hollywood would automatically be sent to prison for life, with no chance of parole for 25 years. The jury also could decide Ms. Moritt is guilty of a lesser degree of homicide. In graphic detail, attorneys recounted how the early morning darkness of Oct. 23 was punctuated by the cries of a baby in Ms. Moritt's high-rise dormitory suite. When the cries continued, roommates pounded on her bathroom door and demanded to know what was wrong. Ms. Moritt replied she was not feeling well. Once inside, they found Ms. Moritt naked, on her knees and surrounded by blood. They took her to the hospital and returned to find the 6-pound, 9-ounce baby boy, swathed in a sheet, face-down in the toilet. The prosecution called two of Ms. Moritt's dormitory suite mates, who described helping their bleeding friend down three flights of stairs to take her to the hospital, and returning to find the baby. Prosecutors characterized the defendant as an upper middle-class child who was spoiled and preoccupied with what others thought of her. ``Claire is not unlike women you hear about who ... give birth to healthy babies and throw them in a trash dump to get rid of them,'' Ms. Richardson told the jury. ``But she didn't make it to the trash dump. ``There were too many people around. In a panic she had to do something, and she chose to wrap that baby in sheets and stuff it head-first in a toilet.'' Defense attorney B. Anderson Mitcham described his client as a good student who had never been in trouble before, and only realized she had given birth when told by a social worker at the hospital. Ms. Moritt never realized she was pregnant, maintained her normal weight and had regular menstrual periods, Mitcham said, adding that she still has no recollection of going into labor or giving birth. The defense attorney said 10 psychologists and psychiatrists who examined Ms. Moritt found she was temporarily insane at the time of the birth, suffering from a dissociative disorder in which she refused to acknowledge the pregnancy. ``In simple terms, she could not adhere to what's right and she could not refrain from what's wrong,'' Mitcham said. Mitcam also implied that the child found in the toilet may not have been dead when he was found. The newborn was taken to the hospital in a sealed plastic bag, but doctors spent a half-hour trying to revive the infant, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Slain Missionary's Sister Waits for News
With AM-Lebanon-Missionary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The sister of an American missionary killed by masked assassins at his home in Lebanon said Wednesday she is watching the news, waiting by the telephone and trying to get in touch with his wife. ``I would like to know that the children are all right,'' said Elnora Coppolino, elder sister of slain missionary William Robinson. ``I would like to know if she wants to go home now. I would like to see them come home.'' Two Lebanese extremist groups Wednesday claimed responsibility for Robinson's assassination, saying they were trying to prevent him from establishing an Israeli settlement in south Lebanon. Mrs. Coppolino said her brother, a Congregationalist, was only interested in running his 7-year-old orphanage, the Christian Children's Home for disabled children. ``He had a very strong faith in the Lord and he thought it was God's will that they go over there and do what they could for those people. Whatever happened would be God's will,'' Mrs. Coppolino said in a telephone interview from her home in Athol, about 50 miles north of Springfield. She said she had no inkling that her brother was not welcomed by his neighbors. ``He said they were very friendly. I have lots of reports that came back from different people. I have copies of letters that are written in Arabic and different things about the good work that he's done over there,'' she said. She said Robinson began by opening a home for orphans and later took in children who were disabled or injured. Family members worried about Robinson's safety, but he was determined to stay, she said. ``When he left here they had been bombing in southern Lebanon, bombing the schools and the children were getting killed and he was concerned about the children,'' Mrs. Coppolino said. The assassins broke into Robinson's house Tuesday night while he was singing bedtime prayers with his American wife, four sons and 26 other children from his orphanage, Lebanese security sources told U.N. investigators. The Robinsons had last written home in February, with a letter from Robinson's wife, Barbara. ``She said `Bill is good, busy every day.' She said there was a lot of fighting in the north of them. And sometimes some of the shells came down that way, but that's not unusual; they were all OK,'' Mrs. Coppolino said. Robinson, 59, was brought up in Athol and served four years in the Marines, his sister said. He studied electronics in the service and worked on television cable systems in Athol and Pittsfield before moving to California and Illinois. Because he could not get a visa, Robinson entered Lebanon from Israel in 1978, Mrs. Coppolino said. She said he worked for two years to support the orphanage he founded in 1983, but for the last five years had relied on donations from several countries, including Italy and Norway. Mrs. Coppolino said Marine Col. Richard Higgins, who later was captured and believed to be executed, had visited the orphanage and congratulated Robinson on his work.

DOC.HEAD: 6-Year-old Lung Transplant Patient Dies
DOC.TEXT: A 6-year-old boy who underwent a lung transplant eight days ago died from a bacterial infection Wednesday, a hospital spokesman said. Danny Beard died at 11:18 a.m. after his immune system rejected the lung he received in an operation March 20 at The Children's Hospital, said spokesman Phil Lotane. The boy's parents, William and Kathryn Beard, were at his bedside when he died. The boy had been in critical condition since the operation, and had been hooked to a lung machine since Feb. 25, when a mysterious virus attacked his lungs. A bacterial infection started in Danny's bloodstream and spread through his body, said Dr. James Fackler, director of the hospital's multi-disciplinary intensive care unit. ``With any organ transplant, the body recognizes the new organ as foreign,'' Fackler said in a statement. ``We had to go to extraordinary lengths to suppress Danny's reaction to his new lung.'' Anti-rejection drugs often leave transplant patients more susceptible to infection. The hospital said last week that the donor was a child from New England, but gave no other details.

DOC.HEAD: Lost Hemingway Story to be Published
DOC.TEXT: A handwritten manuscript crisscrossed by revisions has yielded a previously unpublished short story by Ernest Hemingway that probably was his last, the professor who deciphered the work said Wednesday. ``It's very exciting,'' said Donald Junkins, who teaches English at the University of Massachusetts. ``I'm positive that this is the last short story that Hemingway ever wrote.'' Junkins titled the story after the first five words of the manuscript: ``Philip Haines Was a Writer.'' Solving the riddle was a painstaking process that began two years ago when Junkins began studying two handwritten manuscripts that were among Hemingway papers given to the John F. Kennedy Library in Boston in 1980. He discovered one was the beginnings of a novel that was scrapped; the second used the same plot for a short story. Decoding the revisions scrawled all over the papers took hours, Junkins said. The professor said he picked up on clues to the story while on vacation in Bimini, the setting of Hemingway's ``Islands in the Stream,'' a book about a painter called Thomas Hudson. ``As I wrote and as I kept writing I knew that I had a story but I didn't know if I had an ending. That's the big thing. That was the exciting part of it,'' Junkins said. ``I was swimming on Thomas Hudson's beach. Here I am and I've got this story,'' he said. ``I just went very slowly.'' The story is scheduled for publication in the April issue of ``The Hemingway Review,'' published by the English department of Ohio Northern University. ``We're pleased with ourselves, but you can't blame us,'' said editor Charles Oliver, who enjoyed the new story although, unlike Junkins, he didn't think it was one of Hemingway's best. ``It's a lot of fun to be able to publish a new Hemingway short story even though we know it isn't as good as his best work.'' ``It really does tell a fascinating story about the writer. We really see his mind at work,'' Oliver said. Also in the new issue is a second unpublished work of Hemingway's, an incomplete story called ``A Lack of Passion'' that was researched by Susan Beegel, an independent scholar who lives on Nantucket island, Oliver said. Beegel said she went looking for the 1920s story about a frightened bullfighter in Pamplona, Spain, after finding a reference to the story in the non-fiction work ``Death in the Afternoon.'' Beegel said the story is remarkable because it deals with a frightened, impotent character as opposed to the macho heroes who people Hemingway's best-known works. ``It's going to help change the way people think about Hemingway,'' she said. Hemingway, who killed himself with a shotgun in Idaho in 1961, won a Nobel Prize for literature. The Haines story, is set in Paris and explores how the title character throws away a marriage for a doomed relationship. Junkins said Hemingway started to write a novel on that theme, but then stalled. ``It's a man who is in the process of divorcing his wife, and his girlfriend has gone back to America to wait out the divorce and he can't write,'' Junkins said. The 31-page short story apparently had been mistaken for an earlier version of the unfinished novel, Junkins said. The material appears to date from about 1959, toward the end of Hemingway's life, said Junkins, who matched cafe descriptions with those in the vignettes that were posthumously published as ``A Moveable Feast.'' Junkins said he believes there are several reasons why Hemingway did not finish the novel. ``For one thing, all the tension in the story comes from the fact that in the novel the girl in America will not come back to Paris. The point is if she comes back, what's going to happen. The novel cannot go anywhere the way he set it up.''

DOC.HEAD: Grenade Attack Wounds Filipino Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Assailants in a speeding car hurled a grenade that wounded three soldiers in a Manila suburb, police said Thursday. Police Cpl. Rogelio Millare said the soldiers were standing near their patrol car when attacked Wednesday night in Pasig. The unidentified attackers escaped. Their motive was unknown, but the assault occurred on the eve of the 21st anniversary of the Communist New People's Army. Police have been on alert in the capital. At least nine people, including a lieutenant colonel, died during the past week in attacks in the Manila area that were blamed on rebels. On Wednesday, the military reported that its troops destroyed a heavily fortified Communist rebel training camp in two days of fighting that left 59 insurgents and one soldier dead. Armed forces spokesman Col. Juanito Rimando said 23 soldiers were wounded as 1,200 soldiers stormed the camp Sunday in the remote mountain town of Lianga in Surigao del Sur province, about 540 miles southeast of Manila.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Killed in California, Two Injured in Texas Chopper Crash
DOC.TEXT: A Navy pilot died when his Korean War-era jet fighter went down in the Mojave Desert Wednesday, and two soldiers were seriously injured in a New Mexico helicopter crash, authorities said. The single-seat QF-86 Sabre went down about 10:30 a.m. PST between the China Lake Naval Weapons Center range and Death Valley National Monument, about 150 miles northeast of Los Angeles, said base spokeswoman Loretta King. The cause was unknown. The Navy keeps the 1950s-vintage QF-86 Sabres at China Lake for use as pilotless drones for air-to-air target practice. They also are flown for routine training, King said. The pilot's identity was withheld pending notification of relatives. Two soldiers were injured when an Army OH-58 Kiowa helicopter crashed Wednesday morning about 30 miles northeast of the Texas-New Mexico border, said Fort Bliss, Texas, spokesman Brad Rose. He had no information on what caused the crash, which occurred as the helicopter was passing over a bombing range in preparation for target practice to make sure no one had wandered onto it. Injured were 1st Lt. John Vaughn, 27, and Chief Warrant Officer 2 Gerhard Turner, 28, Rose said. They were in serious condition at Beaumont Army Medical Center,

DOC.HEAD: Report: Utah Equipment Did Not Produce Cold Fusion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-9, `Pons did ...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Pons comment; picks up 10th graf, `Others, however ...'
DOC.TEXT: Cold fusion equipment used by a University of Utah chemist who claimed to harness the power of the sun in a lab jar didn't produce any nuclear energy, said a physicist at the school who tested the apparatus. ``We did not see a peep,'' said Michael H. Salamon, who measured the nuclear output of cold fusion gear in the lab of Stanley Pons for five weeks. ``There was not an iota, not a sniff, of conventional fusion occurring. We saw no neutrons or gamma rays that could be attributed to a fusion process.'' His findings appear to be another blow to the already widely questioned announcement last March of a revolutionary new source of energy. But one backer of cold fusion said the new findings fail to prove anything because Pons' equipment was not working properly when Salamon tested it. Salamon said his measurements, published in Thursday's issue of the British journal Nature, were made at Pons' invitation. He conducted the tests last May and June, about two months after Pons and Martin Fleischman of the University of Southampton in England announced they achieved fusion at room temperature in simple laboratory equipment. Pons responded, ``It's pretty distressing, because most of the allegations in the paper are not true.'' In a telephone interview Wednesday from Salt Lake City, Pons said the physicists ignored energy cells that were producing large amounts of heat and instead set up their monitoring equipment to check ones that were making only low amounts. He said the sensors were also placed at an angle that missed evidence of nuclear activity. Pons said Salamon's team was in the laboratory ``for political reaons.'' ``They were embarrassed by this,'' he said. ``They were embarrassed that a chemist had fallen into a nuclear reaction so simply. Their outside colleagues were putting tremendous pressure on them.'' Pons also accused Nature of trying to undermine his work by publishing negative studies while ignoring supporting evidence. Others, however, viewed Salamon's paper as one more reason to be skeptical. ``It's another nail in the coffin,'' commented Ronald Parker, director of the plasma fusion center at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ``They did a very careful search for fusion effects, and they came up empty.'' Fritz G. Will, director of the state-funded National Cold Fusion Institute at the University of Utah, said small changes in experimental conditions, including humidity, can affect whether or not Pons' fusion cells produce heat. At the time Salamon checked the equipment for signs of fusion, Will said, ``experimental conditions prevailing in those experiments were not suitable to finding the phenomenon.'' Pons' equipment consisted of a palladium electrode wrapped in platinum and immersed in a flask of deuterium oxide, or heavy water. When electricity is run through the metals, proponents say, deuterium atoms fuse, giving off more heat than the energy put in. Nuclear fusion powers the stars. Traditionally scientists have believed that fusion could occur only at extremely high temperatures. Cool, small-scale fusion would provide a convenient, limitless source of power and be one of the greatest scientific discoveries of all time. Pons' and Fleischman's seeming breakthrough was questioned when researchers in other labs had trouble duplicating their results. While many scientists say they doubt cold fusion exists, experiments continue at labs around the world. Cold fusion, if it occurs, is likely to produce heat, extra tritium and specific patterns of neutron and gamma ray releases known as nuclear signatures. ``Nintey-five percent of those researchers who have tried to find anomalous effects, whether excess heat or nuclear signatures, have come up empty-handed,'' Will said. ``The mere fact that a large percentage of scientists have failed to confirm does not mean that the phenomenon that has been confirmed by 5 percent is incorrect. The burden is on those who haven't found it to change their experimental conditions so they find it also,'' he said. Will said 20 labs experimenting with cold fusion have produced excess heat, about a dozen have found large tritium counts and ``at least a handful'' have seen signs of neutron release. Salamon set up sensors for gamma rays that would be discharged when neutrons produced by the nuclear process hit the water bath that surrounded the fusion cells. Salamon said he had planned to study Pons' records of heat produced by his fusion cells to see how they matched up with the detection of gamma rays. However, he said Pons later refused to turn over the records. During the five weeks of study, Salamon's equipment was out of service for a two-hour period because a lightning strike knocked out the power. Salamon said Pons later told him that the fusion cells produced excess heat during this time. However, Salamon said he could find no residual signs of a neutron burst that would have lingered for several days.

DOC.HEAD: Kentucky Senate Passes Bill to Overhaul School System
DOC.TEXT: The state Senate on Wednesday approved an overhaul of the school system, funded with a $1.26 billion tax increase, that is designed to boost Kentucky's ailing schools into the nation's front ranks. The bill is ``a do or die effort for elementary and secondary education in this state,'' said Majority Floor Leader Joe Wright, a driving force behind its passage. The 946-page bill, which would repeal and rewrite all Kentucky laws dictating how public schools are run, passed by a 30-8 vote. It goes back to the House, where it originated, for action on Senate amendments. Gov. Wallace Wilkinson, elected in 1987 on an education platform, said the 1990 General Assembly would leave a ``legacy of education reform.'' ``For once we'll be able to point to something other than a basketball team and say we're No. 1,'' said Sen. Nelson Allen, chairman of the Senate Education Committee. Most of the programs foreseen in the bill can be found in various school districts around the country. But passage of the bill would provide the only statewide school system that draws together an array of motivational programs that provide special help for problem children and reward schools' performances, said David Hornbeck, a Washington, D.C., consultant who was one of the bill's main architects. Kentucky currently ranks near the bottom in most educational categories. The legislation was produced under pressure of a state Supreme Court ruling last year that Kentucky's school system was unconstitutional because children in poor counties were denied a quality education. The bill would pump millions into the state's poorest districts, increase teacher pay and provide cash rewards for improving schools while punishing those with declining standards. Schools would be judged by the success of their students and given regulatory freedom to reach their goals. Control of the system would shift from an elected state superintendent to an appointed education commissioner. The new system would emphasize early childhood education, eliminate graded classrooms until the fourth grade and target potential dropouts for extra help. If the General Assembly gives the new system time to work, refraining from changes for six to eight years, ``I earnestly believe we can make a total reform of the school system,'' said David Karem, a Democratic sponsor of the bill. The bill would be financed out of a penny increase in the sales tax rate, elimination of several individual income-tax deductions and a 1 percent hike in corporate income taxes. The Senate amended the bill to eliminate the state deduction for federal tax payments. The House version would have phased it out, granting a $2,000 deduction for 1990 and $1,000 for 1991. No one likes taxes, ``but we all like education,'' said Sen. Pat McCuiston, a leading Democrat. ``We all realize the necessity of it and, therefore, we have to pass the financing that goes along with this school package.'' Republican Floor Leader John Rogers voted against the bill and predicted retribution at the polls. ``The taxpaying voter will never forget what you did to him here,'' said Rogers, a Republican.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Threats, Bombs Keep Bus Drivers Home in Peru; Traffic Snarled
DOC.TEXT: The government said Wednesday's ``armed strike'' called by Maoist rebels was a flop, but transportation snarls cropped up throughout the capital when bus drivers stayed home in fear of guerrilla reprisals. At least 20 bombings rocked Lima overnight, including three car bombings, as the Shining Path movement stepped up its violence in an attempt to frighten Peruvians into boycotting national elections scheduled for April 8. Government, labor and business representatives contacted by The Associated Press said most workers showed up for work, but no figures were available. ``The armed strike was a complete failure,'' Labor Minister Wilfredo Chau said. Private bus drivers bowed to rebel threats and stayed off the streets, however, causing serious public transportation backups. Thousands of workers trying to reach their jobs lined up to catch the few public buses operating. An armed strike is a general strike called by the rebels that carries the threat of violence against those who ignore it. The last armed strike took place Nov. 3, nine days before nationwide municipal elections. It did not receive much support although bus drivers stayed off the streets in the early hours of the strike. Bomb explosions hit police stations, banks, campaign offices and other targets around the capital during Tuesday night. Police reported one person injured and extensive damage. Officers said two other car bombs were deactivated Tuesday night, including one set to go off at Lima's international airport. David Quintana, president of a private bus drivers union, said Tuesday night that many drivers received written death threats at their homes from the guerrillas. He said drivers were ready to stay off the streets on election day if the government did not provide protection. The government issued a decree Wednesday giving a two-hour grace period to workers who arrived late due to the bus shortage. Last week, the government put Peru's 80,000 police on alert and declared a state of emergency in the capital due to guerrilla violence. The decree came after rebels killed four congressional candidates in five days. More than half of Peru's 22 million people live in areas affected by states of emergency, including Lima's 7 million residents. Shining Path began fighting Peru's elected governments in 1980. The government says more than 18,000 people have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Harris Appeal; Case to go to 9th Circuit
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday refused to block the scheduled execution next week of a man who murdered two teen-agers, bringing him one step closer to becoming the first person executed in California in 23 years. Barring a last-minute stay, Robert Alton Harris, 37, would go to the gas chamber Tuesday. ``Not only do I decline to intervene, but I, myself, have concluded that this defendant has had his day in court like no other defendant,'' U.S. District Judge William B. Enright said after hearing arguments by Harris' attorneys and state prosecutors. ``Citizens of this state are entitled to due process, also. They deserve no more than that, but they deserve not one bit less,'' Enright said. ``Capital punishment is the law of this state. It has been repeatedly ... validated by the citizens of this state. ``If the courts are to have any validity at all, they must be capable of instituting final judgment,'' he said. Defense attorneys Charles Sevilla and Michael McCabe said they would renew their appeal by filing a petition in the U.S. 9th Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco on Thursday morning. Should that petition fail, the final avenue remaining would be the U.S. Supreme Court, which has denied Harris' appeals four times. Enright said he had reviewed papers filed in the case, as well as the transcript of Harris' 1979 trial, penalty phase and appeals. He said he found nothing to uphold defense attorneys' claims that Harris received inadequate defense counsel or that psychiatric experts examining Harris gave incompetent evaluations. ``At every critical point, the defendant was given the benefit,'' Enright said. ``Facts are facts. Facts are the bedrock of any trial and the facts in this case are egregious.'' The judge, while praising McCabe and Sevilla for their determined litigation efforts, said he was disturbed they had resorted to attacking the professionalism and competency of Harris' trial attorney, as well as some psychiatric experts. Enright said his review of the record showed just the opposite and cited Harris' own statements agreeing that he had received excellent representation from his trial attorney, Thomas Ryan. In arguments preceding the judge's decision, Sevilla claimed the defense had been denied state funds to hire psychiatric experts to pursue their theory that brain damage contributed to the violent behavior that culminated in the July 1978 shootings of John Mayeski and Michael Baker, both 16. Harris had abducted the boys at gunpoint from a drive-in restaurant as they sat in their parked cars. He forced them to drive to a remote area where he shot them so he could use their car in a bank robbery. Sevilla also claimed that Harris' abusive childhood and his mother's heavy drinking during her pregnancy with him exacerbated Harris' mental disorders. Sevilla challenged the evaluation of a state mental health expert who characterized Harris as a sociopath incapable of remorse or rehabilitation. Deputy Attorney General Louis Hanoian said there was nothing new in the petition and that all the issues raised in it had been fully litigated. ``They've just slapped a new label on it,'' he said.

The Sandinistas have agreed to cede control of the army and police in a preliminary agreement with advisers to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro on transferring power. The agreement, reached late Tuesday, stresses that the demobilization of the Contra rebels is crucial if a civilian government led by Mrs. Chamorro is to take over from the Sandinistas on April 25 as scheduled. Dismantling of the rebel force that once had strong U.S. backing ``constitutes an essential element for creating the climate of peace, stability and tranquility in which the transfer of government should take place,'' the agreement says. The heads of the transition teams signed the preliminary agreement after a month of negotiations. Mrs. Chamorro defeated President Daniel Ortega in free elections on Feb. 25.

Federal aviation authorities will no longer fine airlines for safety violations if the carriers find the problem themselves, quickly correct it and report it to the government. Federal Aviation Administration chief James B. Busey announced the new policy Tuesday at a luncheon with airline officials. An industry spokesman applauded the policy change, but a pilots' group cautioned against a falldown in FAA enforcement. Busey acknowledged that his agency, which monitors safety at airports used by U.S. carriers throughout the world, doesn't have enough manpower to catch every violation. He said airlines have the responsibility to audit their own safety. ``We cannot police every aspect of the industry, cannot crawl through the belly of every aircraft, look over the shoulder of every pilot, or personally screen every passenger and every piece of luggage that flies in the system,'' the FAA administrator said.

Cuba is expected to take additional measures against the United States in retaliation for U.S.-sponsored television programming to the island, producing further setbacks to the already strained relationship. After Cuban authorities jammed the initial broadcasts of TV Marti on Tuesday, the State Department expressed regret but said transmissions will continue. The emphasis was on entertainment as testing began, but a primary goal of the station is to provide objective news to a country that the administration says has received none in 31 years. The station is a pet project of conservative elements of the Cuban exile community in Florida, and Cuban officials have told U.S. diplomats that exiles may be a target of Cuban retaliation.

Prosecutors intend to use a pair of gasoline-soaked sneakers and a hunk of dance floor to help make their case against a man charged with setting the fire that killed 87 people in a social club. A grand jury Tuesday began hearing evidence against 36-year-old Julio Gonzalez, charged with 87 murders in the blaze at the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx. Police said he set the fire early Sunday after being snubbed by an ex-girlfriend who worked there. ``We'll have a made case even if he backs out of the confession,'' said Edward McCarthy, spokesman for the Bronx prosecutor's office. The club had been ordered closed for fire and safety code violations and the landlord was trying to evict the owner for non-payment of rent.

Eight years after an auto accident left him in a vegetative state, a man given a tranquilizer in a dentist's office fell asleep, woke up and started to speak. Soon he could say his name, walk and feed himself, a doctor says. Dr. Andres Kanner, a neurologist with the University of Wisconsin Hospital, said Tuesday it's a mystery why tranquilizers awakened the man. ``I don't know what it is,'' Kanner said. ``It was just luck he had to have some dental work and it was just luck they administered the drugs.'' The patient, identified only as a Wisconsin man in his mid-40s, had been in a vegetative state, not a coma: His eyes were open and he occasionally uttered words, but he could do nothing else, the doctor said in an interview Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: `America's Funniest Home Videos' Looks To The Mailbags
LaserPhoto LA2 of March 24
DOC.TEXT: Mailbags stuffed with fainting brides, singing dogs, polka-dancing chickens and raids into the privacy of the shower arrive daily at the busy shop that produces ABC's surprise hit, ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' Programmers _ and analysts of what the television audience wants to see _ are agog at the reaction to the half-hour Sunday show, which has host Bob Saget introducing and narrating clips from home videos sent in by viewers. Network television, which has lost viewers steadily over the past decade due in part to the advent of videocassettes, has found a way to bite back. The midseason replacement series reached No. 1 in the A.C. Nielsen ratings for the second week of March, and a one-hour rerun special knocked venerable ``60 Minutes'' out of the Top 10 slot. It also has mugged ``Murder, She Wrote.'' In the cramped warren of rooms at ABC where ``American's Funniest Home Videos'' is made, executive producer Vic Di Bona oversees a hustling young staff of 70. They have learned, this weary-eyed crew, some amazing trivia about America: _ There are still plenty of outhouses in this country, just waiting for someone with a Camcorder to kick open the door and astound the occupant. And spouses like to surprise each other in the shower with a video camera. _ There also are more folks than you realize who can make their bunched-up bellybuttons whistle out a tune. _Nearly every kid in the nation sticks their face and hands into their first birthday cake. The mailbags, bringing up to 1,800 tapes a day, are ``America's Funniest Home Videos''' lifeline. ``This is a show that is truly hand to mouth,'' said Di Bona. ``If the country ain't funny, I ain't funny.'' Di Bona said his weekly show costs around $400,000. His material is free, but he claims his staff and equipment costs are considerably higher than other half-hour shows. He estimates, for example, that the video machines purchased a few months ago are about to wear out. And because the tapes are of private events, clearances have to be obtained from featured characters before it can run. But the cost still is about half the estimated $800,000 a week needed to produce a Top 10 series like ``The Cosby Show'' or ``Cheers,'' even with the $10,000 awarded to the funniest home video each week. ABC's censors have so far squelched just two of the clips Di Bona submitted. A youngster applying the nozzle of a running vacuum cleaner to his face was nixed, as was one of a baby crawling with a clear plastic mixing bowl over his head _ too close to the eyes and nose, censors said. Efforts to stage events are so poorly done that they have always been spotted, staff members say. A clip gets on the show after being viewed by a screener, who grades it on a scale from one to 10, with those with a five or below eliminated. The others are viewed by an assistant producer and move up the line before being selected. Most segments zoom along with pratfalls, snaky garden hoses, upchucking babies and brides tossing wedding bouquets into the twilight zone, but the producers are trying to pace the show with some longer pieces. A 90-second clip, for example, showed a couple married for 43 years arguing over singing a favorite song. The wife comes from behind the camera and joins her husband to warble the tune as a duet. Di Bona bought the rights to the format from a show in Japan, but said its appeal is ``a little bit of Warner Bros. cartoons, a lot of Three Stooges, a little bit of Keystone Kops.'' The low cost, high ratings and easy-to-copy formula assure competition. Plans were announced last week for a syndicated show called ``The $1 Million Video Challenge.'' Di Bona, a television veteran of 22 years whose previous credits include ``Entertainment Tonight,'' is building his fortress now. ``We're at the vanguard,'' he says. ``We have really set the stage for all of this, and we realize that there are people who are trying to copy and will copy us. We are making very sure that they are going to have a tough time doing it.'' He said that he has sown up deals for shows with ``America's Funniest Home Video's'' format in England, Australia, Scandinavia and Germany and smaller markets like Thailand and Saudi Arabia. Negotiations are under way for a show in France. The deals include exchanges of video clips with the foreign shows, one method to keep the series fresh. Another, suggested by ABC entertainment chief Robert Iger, is ``Assignment America,'' with Saget asking the audience to send in such items as magic tricks and first haircuts.

Elsewhere in television ... BACK ON THE AIR: MTM Television Distribution Group will produce 90 new episodes of ``WKRP in Cincinnati.'' No word from MTM on who will star in the new version. The original ``WKRP,'' which ran from 1978 through 1982, still can be seen in syndication, and MTM hopes to combine the old and new episodes as a syndication package for the 1991-1992 season.

DOC.HEAD: African-American' Gaining Currency as Replacement for Black
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lenda cq in 1st graf.
DOC.TEXT: It was last June, when she began work at the Museum of African-American History in Detroit, that Lenda Jackson unconsciously began to change the way she defined herself. Instead of black, she started saying African-American. ``I consider myself a black woman, but African-American just sounds better to me,'' says Ms. Jackson, the museum's public relations director. ``African-American is just more descriptive of what we are. No one is really black, like the color black.'' Many black Americans have come to that conclusion in recent years, especially since the Rev. Jesse Jackson proposed a change in terms of reference. African-American appears to be gaining currency as the term of choice for many blacks and shows signs of seeping into the culture at large. In addition to Jackson, it is used by New York Mayor David Dinkins, Atlanta Mayor Maynard Jackson, Rep. William Gray of Pennsylvania, tennis star and author Arthur Ashe and novelist Ishmael Reed. Oprah Winfrey has referred to herself as ``a colored girl who became a Negro, then black, then African-American.'' President Bush, in mourning the death in December of black choreographer Alvin Ailey, called him ``a man committed to weaving his African-American heritage into our nation's cultural tapestry.'' It has become the preferred term at some radio stations and black newspapers, including the New York Amsterdam News and The Atlanta Voice, and on college campuses and in scholarly publications. ``It's fashionable now to be known as African-American,'' Ms. Jackson said, ``just as in the '70s it was fashionable to be called Afro-American or black _ which was preferable to Negro, just as Negro was preferable to colored.'' In one sentence, that more or less sums up a century of linguistic history _ one rife with politics, bigotry and deep emotion. Just as one can date a tree from its rings, one can roughly judge the age of a black organization from its title: the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (1909), the United Negro College Fund (1944), the Congressional Black Caucus (1971). Now add to the list the African American Summit (1989). It was at this conclave of black leaders in New Orleans last April that Jackson made a speech in which he called for a change from black to African-American. The change was first proposed the previous December at a meeting in Chicago to lay the groundwork for the summit. Ramona H. Edelin, president of the National Urban Coalition, suggested that blacks needed a greater sense of their history. One way to start, she said, would be to call themselves African-Americans. The term was already gaining use, especially in academic circles. Ms. Edelin's idea was enthusiastically adopted. ``To be called African-American has cultural integrity,'' Jackson explained at the Chicago meeting. ``It puts us in our proper historical context. Every ethnic group in this country has a reference to some land base, some historical culture base. African-Americans have hit that level of cultural maturity.'' Surveys conducted since then have shown that the term has been accepted by at least a sizeable minority of blacks. In polls last March and April by Time magazine and the Chicago Tribune, 26 percent of the black respondents said they preferred African-American. Sixty-one percent in the Time poll said they preferred black; in the Tribune poll, only 40 percent said they preferred black, and 31 percent said either term was fine. In May, the San Diego school district surveyed black pupils, parents and civic leaders to determine which term they preferred. Forty-one percent of the students, 49 percent of their parents and 70 percent of local leaders said they preferred African-American. As a result of the survey, San Diego schools now use African-American instead of black in their lessons and official paperwork. ``I frankly am astonished at how quickly it's been received,'' Ms. Edelin said. ``Some people never liked black, because you may have noticed that African-Americans come in every shade in the universe. Black was always confusing for some children. ... This obviates all that confusion, and also hopefully will get us past some internecine wars over shades of color.'' In contrast to the change from Negro to black two decades ago, little rancor surrounds the emergence of African-American. It is not associated with a radical political movement, as black was, and has never been used as a putdown, as black once was. A variation, Afro-American, has a long history as a respectable term for blacks. At NAACP headquarters in Baltimore, spokesman James Williams said many officials use the terms African-American and black interchangeably. The organization's official position is that usage is up to the individual. African-American, said John Baugh, a professor of linguistics at the University of Texas at Austin, ``is a term that will gain broad acceptance, especially in literate circles, and it will be a term that conveys respect. But it will not become offensive to call an African-American black.'' If African-American is to become the standard term, nearly everyone agrees the next step must be for it to be accepted in mainstream culture. That may be starting. The Merriam-Webster Co. will consider placing the word in the next Webster's dictionary, editorial director Frederick Mish said. New words must be used frequently in different settings over a period of years before they make it into the dictionary. ``It's well on its way to meeting the kinds of tests we require for new entries,'' Mish said. The U.S. Census Bureau is using the terms ``black or Negro'' on its 1990 census forms. It used ``Negro'' in 1960, ``Negro or black'' in 1970 and ``black or Negro'' in 1980. Census spokesman Miguel Rivera said African-American would be used in the 2000 census if there is sufficient demand. Most general interest newspapers have rules of style that require their writers to use black unless they are quoting someone. That, too, could change. At the Los Angeles Times, spokeswoman Laura Morgan said some black journalists have expressed a preference for African-American, and the newspaper is considering changing its rules. At The Boston Globe, ``the term black is preferable, but there is no proscription against the use of African-American,'' spokesman Richard Gulla said. The Associated Press Stylebook used by many newspapers calls for the use of black. ``However, if usage dictates, eventually we'll change,'' Stylebook Editor Norm Goldstein said. Not everyone likes the new term. Some people have suggested that it doesn't apply to all Americans of color: blacks who came from the West Indies, for instance, or those black Americans whose ancestors did not come from Africa _ dark-skinned people from Australia or Asia, for instance. Phillip T. Gay, an associate professor of sociology at San Diego State University, wrote the Los Angeles Times last April to make the case for black instead of African-American. ``The culturally significant links to Africa were broken during the years of slavery,'' he wrote. ``A name change might obscure that fact, but it won't change it.'' But Ms. Edelin and other proponents of African-American say their whole point is to reclaim that lost heritage, to ``revive the best that is in our ancient culture.''
