DOC.TEXT: U.S. religious broadcasters are turning their eyes toward a new market _ the Soviet Union. At the recent meeting of National Religious Broadcasters, both Robert Schuller and Pat Robertson announced new Soviet ventures. Robertson said he has received permission to open a ministry center in Moscow and that his program, ``Superbook,'' a cartoon series based on the Old Testament, ``is the first Western religious program to air regularly in the Soviet Union.''

The 110-year-old Bowery Mission, widely known for its care of needy men, has opened a new shelter for homeless women and children. ``A growing number of homeless women and children have been coming to the mission for help, but until now we've had no place to put them,'' said the Rev. John Willock, head of the mission on lower Manhattan's Bowery Street. A pilot project in six newly leased apartments has been started on East 94th Street to house about 70 homeless women and their children, and negotiations are going on for a downtown site to house another 70.

Charles Colson, head of Prison Fellowship, says the American prison system ``does not rehabilitate'' prisoners, ``fails to restore the victim'' and fails the government's purpose of deterring crime. At a convention of the National Association of Evangelicals, he said evangelicals err in not recognizing the church's role in society at large. They should exert influence in all areas, he said, but are losing ground. He said the country is becoming ``less Christian in its value structure.''

Religious leaders should stand up for social causes in the world even when issues are muddled, the president of Yeshiva University said at ordination exercises for 100 rabbis. Rabbi Norman Lamm said they should speak out on problems even when ``the horizon is murky instead of bright ... positions gray instead of black and white, when alternatives are flawed instead of perfect, when you can't `look it up' but have nothing but your judgment to consult.''

U.S. Roman Catholic bishops have been assured that the Immigration and Naturalization Service won't seek information on undocumented aliens turned up in the 1990 census. This will allay fears about participation among undocumented people and help insure that all minorities will be counted, said Msgr. Nicolas DiMarzio, head of the church's migration-refugee services.

The Fellowship of Merry Christians suggests that believers be ``fools for Christ's sake,'' as advocated by the apostle Paul, on April Fools' Day April l and throughout April as ``Holy Humor Month.'' The interdenominational fellowship seeks to restore April Fools' Day _ once called All Fools' Day _ as an observance on the Christian calendar.

A World Convocation on Justice, Peace and the Integrity of Creation has called for greater ecumenical commitment ``in word and action'' to a set of principles, including: ``That all exercise of power is accountable to God; God's option for the poor; the equal value of races and peoples; that male and female are created in the image of God, that truth is the foundation of a community of free people.'' Also, ``the peace of Jesus Christ, the creation as beloved of God; that the land belongs to God ... that human rights are given by God.'' The convocation March 5-12, bringing together church leaders from around the globe, was sponsored by the World Council of Churches.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Fri PMs April 30.

For release Fri PMs March 30, or thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Church-Goers Found Better Workers And Charity Volunteers
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Americans who regularly attend their local church or synagogue are more productive in the workplace, have a more stable family life and volunteer more time to charitable causes. These are among survey findings compiled in a new report, ``Religion and the Public Interest,'' by a national interfaith organization that encourages religious participation. Religion in American Life (RIAL) issued the report shortly before the mid-April launching of its annual advertising campaign to stimulate worship attendance, with this slogan, ``Bring A Friend.'' The report, incorporating recent findings of five research organizations, says that a lot more Americans are regular worshippers than is the common impression. More than l00 million people attend church or synagogue regularly, but a survey in the nation's four largest cities found that a majority thinks the number is less than half that. ``People simply have no idea about how many go to church each week,'' said Nicholas B. van Dyck, president of of RIAL, with headquarters in Princeton, N.J. ``The reality is double what people think it is.'' While many worship frequently without making it every week, the latest Gallup poll finds that in an average week, 43 percent of Americans _ 107 million of them _ attended church or synagogue. The report says 96 percent of the population or 242 million Americans believe in God, and 69 percent of them or 172 million claim affiliation with a religious denomination. The findings were compiled from studies by the Gallup Organization, the Lilly Endowment, the Independent Sector, ``Giving USA'' of the American Association of Fund Raising Counsel and Proprietary Research. Other items cited in the report: _ Regular worshippers are 50 percent more likely to reject illicit drugs than non-worshippers. _ Churches and synagogues contribute more to America's social services and in improving the lot of the needy than any other non-governmental institution, including corporations. _ Beyond their own expenses, religious organizations contribute $19 billion annually to child and elder care, education, health, food for the hungry, housing for the homeless and other non-religious work in the public interest. _ The dollar value of volunteer time given by church-goers to community services that are not church-related amounts to more than $6 billion annually. _ Churches and synaoggues lead the list of the top 24 organizations regarded as improving urban life and are found to be among the most cost-effective charitable institutions in society. _ Church and synagogue members are more likely than non-worshippers to agree that ``duty comes before pleasure'' and that ``facing daily tasks is a source of pleasure and satisfaction.'' ``People from congregations account for most of the volunteer hours for health care, education and the arts in this country,'' van Dyck said. He added that they also ``demonstrate better-than-average productivity in the work place'' and ``commitment to family life.'' About 50 religious bodies _ Protestant, Roman Catholic, Mormon, Jewish and Eastern Orthodox _ are represented in RIAL, which was founded in 1949, and has greatly increased in scope since. Its annual campaigns, developed by the Advertising Council, include billboards, posters in public transportation, broadcast spots and public service ads in magazines and newspapers. A preparatory brochure, ``Get Ready, Get Set, Invite a Friend,'' has been distributed to congregations of participating denominations. Ads are to include a toll-free telephone number directing callers to evangelism departments of the church of their choice. Concerning the year's slogan, van Dyck, a Presbyterian, said 86 percent of regular church-goers initially were invited by a friend, which makes application of the slogan promising for boosting church rolls still more.

DOC.HEAD: Government Seeks `Believable' Count of Homeless Americans
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: For most interest groups pushing their wares in Washington, certified U.S. government numbers are among the roots of all influence. They use the statistics as evidence of strength and of the magnitude of problems they insist should get federal attention. That has made the numbers game an integral part of the process in which rival blocs lobby for influence and, above all, federal dollars. But activists who claim to represent the interests of the homeless in America are not playing at numbers now. Some of them tried to sabotage the government's first attempt to count the homeless, preferring to stick with old estimates on the theory that census takers couldn't come close to counting all the people involved. They argue that any census count will be so low that it shouldn't be compiled at all. ``It's going to be used to try and drive down appropriations,'' said Mitch Snyder, the Washington activist for the homeless who has made himself the most visible figure in the movement. He has a vested interest in the current, undocumented estimate that more than 3 million Americans are homeless, because he was involved in producing the number. But others who work to help the homeless disagree with those who resist the census, contending that an attempt at a real count will help dramatize the problem and could promote programs to deal with it. That's the way government counts have worked in other campaigns. Lyndon B. Johnson's war on poverty gained impetus when the government, which he was running at the time, put numbers on the problem by setting a poverty income line and estimating how many Americans lived on less money. The Census Bureau never has claimed that it could produce an accurate count of all the homeless people in the country, only that it would send its people out on March 20 to find as many as possible, and would report those findings in 1991 as part of the overall census. It won't describe the findings as a count of the homeless but, rather, as a report on how many people its enumerators found in shelters, on the streets and in hotel rooms that cost $12 a night or less. Barbara Bryant, director of the census, said that should cover the vast majority of homeless people. ``There are no believable numbers of homeless in America,'' she said. ``This is going to get an order of the magnitude of the problem.'' While there may not be any believable numbers, there are estimates of the number of homeless that range from 250,000 to more than 3 million. The latter number is Snyder's; it first appeared in a paper published by his Community for Creative Non-Violence in 1982. In congressional testimony in 1984, Snyder said the number was meaningless. ``We have tried to satisfy your gnawing curiosity for a number because we are Americans with Western little minds that have to quantify everything in sight whether we can or not,'' he said. At about the same time, the Department of Housing and Urban Development conducted its own survey and came up with an estimate of 250,000 to 350,000 homeless. In 1988, the Urban Institute issued an estimate of about 600,000. Snyder countered that ``just about everybody in America who is involved thinks the figure is 2 to 3 million.'' Carl F. Horowitz, a Washington urban planner, recounted the story of the numbers in an analysis written for the conservative Heritage Foundation last year. He said Mary Ellen Hombs was the principal author of the report that came up with the 3 million figure. She later became coordinator of the National Coalition for the Homeless. Horowitz quoted her as saying that numbers don't make any difference, that the government should spend its money housing the homeless instead of trying to count them. The count is done now, at a cost estimated at more than $2.7 million. The result will be announced late in 1991. And the argument will start all over again.

DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Broke? Need a rich uncle? When it comes to war reparations, win or lose you can't beat Uncle Sam for generosity, even though he's never been in the black since the day he was born. And, with one ironic exception, that ain't whistling Dixie.

President Bush has asked Congress for $500 million for aid to Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua, which reminds us once again that in war or peace, aggressor or aggressee, Uncle Sam picks up most of the tab. The money now sought is intended to help one country recover from an American invasion and the other from a war the United States supported for 10 years. Tiny Granada was broke until Uncle Sam invaded in 1983 and sent $110 million in appreciation. The whole business recalls an old Israeli joke. Prime Minister Ben Gurion was worried about keeping his new nation solvent. A colleague playfully suggested Israel go to war against the United States and, after certain defeat, could expect a flood of dollars from Washington. Ben Gurion thought that over carefully. Then, with Talmudic caution, he asked, ``But suppose we win?'' After two of its three biggest wars, the United States supplied its defeated enemy with billions in aid. The exception and ultimate in ironies followed Appomattox. After World War II, we helped Japan and West Germany rebuild their economies and they rebuilt so well we are now begging for mercy. But after our own Civil War, the government in Washington sent no aid to the Americans who lost. Nothing went south except the carpetbaggers and other vultures of Reconstruction. In this century, Uncle Sam became the biggest giver and lender in history. Until the early 1950s, he was supplying 90 percent of all foreign aid from all nations (Library of Congress). It was still 60 percent in 1965, 25 percent in 1977, less than 15 percent since. A mighty oak from one sickly acorn. The United States began in 1789 in debt _ $55 million borrowed at home and abroad to pay for the Revolution. It became the richest nation on Earth but never got into the black. The closest was 1834 when the national debt was only $38,000. Been up since. There was always something. We wanted to buy California and New Mexico but Mexico wasn't selling. So we provoked a war and took them. We called it ``Manifest Destiny'' and paid Mexico $15 million in conscience money for the land that stretched to the sea and made us a continental nation. Wars grew bigger. Came the end of World War I, the European Allies owed Uncle Sam $9.2 billion and Germany owed the Allies $33 billion in reparations. There then occurred a wondrous sequence in which Europe borrowed from Sam to pay Sam. Germany borrowed $2.5 billion from American investors, paid the Allies $4.5 billion in reparations, the Allies paid the U.S. $2.6 billion and then everything else was defaulted by the Depression. In World War II, we didn't call it debts; we called it lend-lease. Under that name, we sent more than $52 billion worth of military and civilian supplies to Great Britain, the Soviet Union and 38 other countries. In theory the recipients were to return what usable equipment they had left after the war! In theory, they also were to supply the United States with reciprocal goods and services as best they could after the war! Never was theory more sorely tried. Lend-lease turned out to be almost entirely gift. Since World War II, and largely for reasons of the Cold War, the United States has supplied more than 100 countries with $372 billion worth of economic and military aid. Thousands of foreign military officers were brought here for special training at American expense. Abroad, the United States maintained a network of bases around the world for which it paid handsome rent. Fair-minded readers will want to remember that in the War of 1812 the British charged us nothing for burning Washington.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, April 1

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Jewish Autonomous Region is Anything But
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf `Kaufman, a' to INSERT dropped word `ago'
DOC.TEXT: A log cabin is the only place of Jewish worship in this frozen region once called a promised land for Soviet Jews. The makeshift rabbi, Boris Kaufman, conducts some services with the New Testament. He says he believes in Jesus Christ. That makes Kaufman a Christian, not a Jew, but few would notice in the Jewish Autonomous Region of the Soviet Union. Little is Jewish but the name in this remote corner of the Soviet Far East set aside in 1934. Kaufman, a 40-year-old preacher with a red beard who settled on Judaism after trying the Baptist and Pentecostal faiths, said he got his job by default after the region's only rabbi died a few years ago at age 86. ``Everything fell apart'' after the rabbi's death, Kaufman recalled. He acknowledged having little knowledge of Hebrew, the language of the Old Testament, and said he interprets Jewish religious doctrine loosely. During Hanukkah, the Feast of Lights, when Jews around the world lit ceremonial candles and recited holiday prayers, there were no candles in the Jewish Autonomous Region and no worshipers in the cabin. Snow-covered street banners bore only secular greetings, for the New Year. The region has no real rabbi or other Jewish clergy, no religious education or kosher food. No one can remember the last true Jewish wedding or bar mitzvah, the ritual that marks a boy's 13th birthday. As a Western writer put it, decades-old hopes for the Jewish Autonomous Region were ``blown away by the cold Siberian wind.'' After the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution, the new leaders broke with the czarist policy of confining Jews to a section of the southern and southwestern Russian Empire known as the Pale. They gave Jews their own territory, a sparsely populated tract between the Bira and Bidzhan rivers, a region the size of Belgium rich in forests, tin deposits and such wildlife as the Siberian Ussuri tiger and wild boar. Most of the Jewish Autononomous Region is farmland. Wooden huts dot the landscape outside the regional capital, Birobidzhan, a town of old brick apartment buildings and newer pre-fabricated concrete dwellings. It was an artificial entity prompted by the new government's nationalities policy and by military strategy. It forms a buffer on the border with Manchuria. Creating the region also served to counter Zionism, the movement advocating Jewish settlement in Palestine. The government hoped large numbers of Jewish farmers and tradesmen would make the 5,000-mile trek from Moscow and other Russian cities. In 1935, President Mikhail Kalinin boldly predicted: ``In 10 years' time, Birobidzhan will become the most important guardian of the Jewish national culture.'' Kalinin's hopes were not realized. Comparatively few Jews made the trip, and of those who did come to escape persecution and famine, many soon left. The climate was harsh _ temperatures reached -13 Fahrenheit this winter _ the land was undeveloped and the nation's Jewish centers were a world away. Bolshevik leader Leon Trotsky, a Jew who was born Lev Bronstein, eventually described the experiment as ``a bureaucratic farce.'' The late Soviet leader Nikita S. Khrushchev declared it a failure. Jews never became more than a small minority in the region, despite Lenin's stipulation of uniform nationality in such areas. The Jewish Autonomous Region has 8,887 Jews, 4 percent of the region's population and fewer than one-half percent of the Soviet Union's 1.4 million Jews. Official propaganda still portrays the region almost as a Jewish paradise, a showplace of assimilation and a refutation of claims that Soviet Jews are persecuted. In a dispatch in October 1988 about the Russian-born Jewish writer Sholon Aleichem, the official news agency Tass said ``Birobidzhan's example clearly shows that the writer's dream of seeing his people free and happy has come true.'' Most Jews in the region appear to have assimilated, and to have succumbed to official atheism. Some did not survive Josef Stalin's purge of 1937 and his campaign against ``Jewish cosmopolitanism'' in 1948. Exhibits in a section of the Birobidzhan museum say many Jews, including Americans who came to help work the land, were killed or sent to labor camps. Yiddish schools, a publishing house and a theater were closed. Birobidzhan has some appearance of Jewish life, along with factories that make combines, shoes and electrical transformers. Signs on stores and public buildings are in Yiddish as well as Russian. The main street is not named after Lenin, as in most Soviet cities, but for Sholom Aleichem. In keeping with government policy of treating Jews as a nationality, not a religious group, there are some signs of Jewish culture _ a theater, radio programs in Yiddish, a cultural club and schools where Yiddish is taught after a 42-year ban. A hotel restaurant serves pseudo-Jewish cuisine. There is virtually nothing religious, although President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has proclaimed official tolerance of religion and permitted a revival of religious life nationwide. Kaufman said few young people are interested in the religion and he has difficulty assembling the required 10-man quorum for services. He would like to see a religious revival, he said, and hopes a young man studying in Moscow will become the rabbi in Birobidzhan. The student has been offered the job, but some Jews in Birobidzhan said he wasn't interested. Local officials, many of them Jews, seem uninterested in improving religious life. Mayor Mark Kaufman, no relation to Boris, acknowledged the log-cabin synagogue was in bad shape and pledged to improve conditions for worship. He also called the synagogue a ``part of Jewish history'' and suggested converting it to a cultural center. Arkady Kuperman, ``religion'' correspondent of the Yiddish-language newspaper, Birobidzhaner Stern, said he saw nothing wrong with the lack of interest in religion. ``We are atheists,'' he said. ``We spent our whole lives without God, and this doesn't bother me.'' At Birobidzhan's teacher-training college, opened in October as part of Gorbachev's liberalization program, there is a Jewish language and literature department with classes in Yiddish. Hebrew classes are planned, but not religious instruction. ``There are no real believers among us, except for old people,'' said Larisa Tsilman, one of the institute's two young Yiddish teachers. Officials see the region as an alternative destination for Soviet Jews considering emigration. A few families have applied to move here because of what they consider an increase of anti-Semitism elsewhere in the Soviet Union. Most Soviet Jews wanting to leave, however, continue to choose Israel or the United States. Talk of emigration also increases among Jewish residents of Birobidzhan. Four families went to live abroad last year. Vladimir Okun, 66, who runs the Birobidzhan chess club and keeps up with the gossip, predicts all the Jews in the Jewish Autonomous Region will be gone in five years.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, April 1

DOC.HEAD: Rising Prices Bring New Crowd, New Mood to Aspen
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Sheriff Bob Braudis, his star on the wall behind his desk and his skis in the corner, admits to living a childhood dream as a ``marshal in the Wild West.'' But the former New York City business analyst, like others who chased dreams to Aspen in the 1960s and 1970s, now sees the town's ``wild'' side being squeezed out. Aspen's population is changing, and its long struggle to figure out just how much growth it can handle is intensifying. ``Back then, coming to Aspen was analagous to dropping out,'' says Braudis. ``I came to Aspen to get away from traffic jams, negative newspapers, crowding, pollution _ and all those things have caught up with me.'' Braudis doesn't get many calls to round up horse thieves or even, as a sheriff here might have a decade ago, drug dealers. Now, he's asked if his deputies can provide security at fancy parties. ``The core of Aspen has become really manicured and buffed. Old Victorian buildings have been torn down and rehabbed,'' says the sheriff and former ski bum. ``Ski bums can't afford to live here anymore. The death of the ski bum is somewhat symbolic of what's happened to Aspen.'' Discussing what's happened to Aspen has become something of an obsession here following back-to-back elections. On Feb. 13, voters rejected a proposed ban on fur sales and approved the building of a large hotel downtown, the widening and straightening of overburdened Highway 82, and measures aimed at creating affordable housing. The Ritz-Carlton Hotel vote was particularly divisive, many residents say, and reflected a new, more welcoming attitude toward growth. On March 13, voters recalled anti-growth city councilman Steve Crockett, who was accused of being rude to constituents, but kept in office Mayor Bill Stirling, who led the anti-fur campaign, and two other targeted councilmen. The recall movement began in response to their reluctance to approve the large-scale hotel. The transformation from funky, rustic retreat to glitzy resort isn't unique to Aspen; it's happened in other upscale tourist towns. But few places have responded with as much acrimony, hand-wringing and national attention. This was, after all, one of the first communities in the nation to embrace daylight-savings time, nuclear-free zones and public-smoking bans, and to close its doors to neon, billboards and fast-food restaurants. Unlike its development-hungry neighbors on Colorado's Western Slope, Aspen's problem is how to work with the developers knocking at the door and still keep the qualities that attracted dreamers in the first place: a clean environment, a social conscience, a sense of community. Aspen's population, estimated at about 5,000 during the summer and four times that in the winter, is one of the most educated per capita in the nation. The town has attracted a variety of arts groups, think tanks and environmental research institutes. One local newspaper refers to the area outside the Roaring Fork Valley as ``The Real World.'' But Aspen is less and less of an escape for anybody but the ultra-rich. Hemmed in by mountains, it has limited building space. In the late 1970s, the Pitkin County commissioners set an annual limit on infrastructure growth of 3.5 percent to control mushrooming subdivisions. Some say those limits only drove up the price of existing properties, particularly in the late 1980s when the Aspen Skiing Co. began a marketing push following a mini-recession early in the decade. By 1989, the average price of an Aspen home reached $1 million. Michael Kinsley, a county commissioner from 1975 to 1985 and now an economic-development expert for the Rocky Mountain Institute, says real estate prices would have risen without growth restrictions. ``Supply and demand doesn't (explain) circumstances here,'' he says. ``What it ignores is the nature of the demand. People want million-dollar houses.'' Many locals have been pushed out of rental units or sold their properties for a fortune and moved ``down valley'' to towns like Basalt, Carbondale and Glenwood Springs. Many who remain, from doctors to dishwashers, live in employee housing or pay rent kept artificially low by city mandate. They often leave town to go shopping, getting groceries in Glenwood Springs and clothes as far away as Denver, about 200 miles away. Now, an estimated 20,000 cars a day travel Highway 82, nearly three times the traffic it was made for, says Braudis. It's estimated half Aspen's workers live down valley and commute. That emigration leaves a disquieting feeling among those remaining that their community may be unraveling. Braudis predicts that within a year or two, Pitkin County will be forced to form a paid or partially paid fire department because Aspen is losing the people who volunteered for year-round services like the fire department and the mountain rescue team. ``Walking to work sometimes it's kind of like a movie set,'' says Steve Wicks, 36, who moved to Aspen when he was 15 and now owns Aspen Drug. ``Everything's maintained, but nobody's home. There's nobody out washing the car or riding their bike.'' All but one of his 15 employees lives down valley, Wicks says. Cliff Camron, manager of the Aspen Athletic Club, has the same problem. ``This was our most difficult year to find staff because of the difficulty of finding housing,'' says Camron, who lives in price-controlled housing, paying $750 for a one-bedroom apartment. Offsetting the migration down valley is an influx of the super-wealthy, who often live in Aspen only part of the year, and the poor, mostly Hispanics who take the service jobs ski bums used to hold, says Braudis. Aspen still has its resident stars from earlier, more off-beat times, like singer John Denver and writer Hunter S. Thompson, but they are eclipsed during the resort's busiest weeks by a galaxy of glamorous part-time residents, from Don Johnson to Donald Trump. Despite the recent anti-fur campaign, fur coats are nearly as numerous as parkas on the downtown mall and in restaurants. ``The newer immigrants have distinguished themselves in several areas with an elitist and socially stratified attitude,'' Braudis says. ``In the old days, the millionaire got off the plane and went to his home and changed into jeans and a turtleneck. He emulated the ski bums, and invited them to parties. Now, there's a little Berlin wall between them and the locals. That's probably typical of most high-dollar resorts, but it's never been true of Aspen.'' The newer residents and tourists ``have expectations of a much higher level of service than a rural Colorado government can afford,'' which is taxing his department, Braudis says. Calls to the sheriff's office have increased 56 percent in the last three years ``without a commensurate increase in the population,'' he says. ``People are asking government to intervene inappropriately. I have to contrast that with the rugged individualism of the '60s and '70s,'' he says.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. sweetened its buyout of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. as analysts projected a record $700 million first-quarter charge against earnings for the struggling Wall Street firm. The pretax charge estimated by a top credit rating agency would be the largest in securities industry history, exceeding a $470 million charge by Merrill Lynch & Co. in the 1989 fourth quarter. American Express also said Tuesday that as a result of its improved buyout offer for the Shearson shares it doesn't already own, attorneys had agreed to drop about 20 class-action lawsuits filed by shareholders challenging the merger.

Eastern Airlines sharply scaled back its business prospects, forecasting a bigger loss for this year and delaying this summer's planned emergence from bankruptcy reorganization. The carrier said Tuesday that difficulties in rebuilding its strike-battered business also meant it would be unable to fulfill a tentative agreement to pay unsecured creditors 50 cents on the dollar. Eastern said it also may seek to cut $33 million in retiree health benefit payments to help bolster its finances.

Sales expectations for the second quarter are at a seven-year low but still point away from a recession, according to a survey of business executives released by Dun & Bradstreet Corp. In its quarterly survey of business expectations, Dun & Bradstreet said Tuesday that expectations for higher prices among all types of companies were unchanged from those for the first quarter, while expectations for gains in second-quarter sales dipped slightly.

The Supreme Court upheld strict limits on political campaign spending by corporations, ruling their free-speech rights are outweighed by the need to subdue big-money influence over elections. In a 6-3 ruling Tuesday, the court upheld a Michigan law challenged by that state's Chamber of Commerce. Twenty other states and the federal government have similar statutes. The decision was hailed by the Federal Election Commission and Common Cause as a major victory for honest government. But the American Civil Liberties Union said it unfairly discriminates against corporations. __ LOS ANGELES (AP) _ A big institutional holder of Lockheed Corp. stock has decided to support Texas investor Harold Simmons in Simmons' bid to oust the board of directors of the aerospace giant. The decision was announced Tuesday by the California Public Employees' Retirement System, a $56 billion fund that holds 500,000 Lockheed shares, less than 1 percent of Lockheed's stock.

Engine and transmission component maker J.P. Industries Inc. says it has agreed in principle to be sold to Turner & Newall PLC, a British maker of industrial materials and equipment, for $375 million. Turner & Newall agreed to pay $17.30 a share for J.P. Industries' stock, or about $190 million, under a tender offer and assume some $185 million in J.P. Industries' debt, Miran Sarkissian, vice president for corporate affairs and development for J.P. Industries, said Tuesday.

The media and entertainment giant Time Warner Inc. agreed to buy Lane Publishing Co., a regional publisher whose Sunset magazine is distributed in 13 Western states, for $225 million in cash and stock. The proposed purchase disclosed Tuesday would be the first sizeable acquisition for Time Warner since Time Inc. completed its $14 billion acquisition of Warner Communications Inc. in January.

AT&T announced an office computer system the company says offers unique features to allow employees to work together on group projects more effectively. American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s new Rhapsody system unveiled Tuesday links personal computers in a network, an increasingly popular computer configuration for offices because it allows workers to share information.

United Technologies Corp. and West Germany's Daimler-Benz AG announced preliminary agreement to operate their jet engine divisions as a single company for certain ventures. Under the memorandum of understanding disclosed Tuesday, Daimler-Benz will invest in Pratt & Whitney, United Technologies' jet engine division, and United Technologies will invest in Daimler's Motoren-und Turbinen Union, or MTU, Daimler's aerospace and defense division.

The stock market rallied Tuesday as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 29.28 points to finish at 2,736.94. The dollar finished higher against most key currencies except the British pound. Bond prices were slightly lower. Gold prices staged a weak recovery; silver and platinum prices continued lower; copper futures fell; most grain and soybean futures dipped; energy futures were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Hey, Boss. Why Don't You Do It This Way?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation. IdeAAs is cq in 5th graf
DOC.TEXT: Plywood suggestion boxes collecting dust in the corners of workshops are history. Employers want to hear the ideas more than ever before, but today those boxes are replaced with computer-punched applications. Worker-involvement programs use surveys, interviews and even health plans to cut costs and increase production. ``Suggestion systems pick the brain of the employee,'' said Jim Canada, president of the National Association of Suggestion Systems. ``The culture of today is that managers must realize their employees have excellent ideas and solutions, and they must look at these ideas openly.'' NASS, a Chicago-based group, represents 1,200 of the world's largest companies. It tracks the successes and failures of suggestion programs and helps members forge their own plans. The results are suggestive. American Airlines saved $40.7 million in 1989 by adopting workers' ideas, said Canada, who manages the carrier's IdeAAs in Action program in Tulsa. In 1988, NASS member organizations saved $2.25 billion in labor and material costs. The idea is that workers know their jobs better than anyone and know how to streamline them. Worker incentives to make suggestions range from cash to merchandise to letters of recommendation. At American's maintenance and engineering facility in Tulsa, employee Carol Hamer suggested using an adhesive rather than hot glue to assemble airline seats. The change saves time and cut costs by nearly $230,000. Ms. Hamer was given $36,000 for the idea. ``These people are living and breathing their jobs eight hours a day,'' Canada said. ``They're going to know far more about a function than management.'' The NASS program covers more than soliciting ideas for improvement, Canada said. Teams interview employees about their positions and hand out surveys. Under a ``Wellness Program,'' companies encourage employees to stay healthy. ``You work to improve the health of the worker,'' he said. ``It's my belief that employee will be more productive.'' The first corporate suggestion program started at Eastman Kodak Co. in 1898. William M. Connor told his bosses in Rochester, N.Y., the windows should be washed regularly in the black-paper slitting room. Decades later, prior to World War II, the programs grew dramatically. The government asked companies providing war materials to cut costs, and NASS was formed in 1942. About the same time, corporate America was undergoing massive changes. Fewer executives climbed the ladder to their postings and lateral career moves were status quo. ``The old style of workers moving up the ladder after they've been machinists would be one where they retain some of the insights of the work situation,'' said Kenneth Benson, a nationally recognized industrial sociologist at the University of Missouri. ``The problem even with that is that technology changes pretty rapidly. One's direct knowledge of the work situation may be pretty quickly outdated.'' So, turn to the line worker. Benson said suggestion programs are vital to overcome resentment some workers feel toward employers. They become involved in the company's decisions by sharing their ideas and common ground is struck. ``There is a fundamental conflict of interest between workers and managers that centers around the struggle over wages and profits,'' Benson said. ``It's a structural problem. ``Once managers enter into managerial positions, they're structurally removed from workers. They're in different worlds. They have different goals. Workers very quickly begin to distrust them and see them as representatives of the other side.'' Canada said the NASS programs will become vital as competition increases among companies and employers discover a neglected resource. ``In the '90s, companies will be forced to become more competitive,'' Canada said. ``Their greatest resources will be their employees. They'll be seen less for their physical stature and more for their minds and creativity. ``It's extremely important to involve the employees.''

DOC.HEAD: Airline's Emergence From Bankruptcy Now Expected Later
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines says difficulties in rebuilding its strike-battered business are causing it to lose much more money than expected and will delay its emergence from bankruptcy reorganization. The beleagured carrier also said Tuesday that its dampened business prospects have left it unable to pay unsecured creditors 50 cents on the dollar, as it had tentatively agreed to do. The airline, which has been trying to reorganize under federal bankruptcy court supervision, said it now expects to lose $330 million this year, or $185 million more than it estimated in January. Eastern also said it no longer projects a profit for next year because restoring its revenue structure, battered by a strike by its machinists, flight attendants and pilots unions, has taken longer than anticipated. The gloomier outlook means the carrier will not emerge from bankrupcty court proceedings early this summer, as it had hoped. Phil Bakes, president and chief executive of the Miami-based carrier, presented the revised business plan to the creditors group meeting in New York. In an interview after the meeting, Bakes expressed disappointment about having to revise the projections but he said: ``We have no reason to believe Eastern will not emerge successfully from Chapter 11.'' The delay will probably last for 30 to 60 days beyond the previous goal of late June or by July 1, he said. A spokesman for the Machinists' union, Charles Bryan, reacted bitterly to Eastern's announcements. ``They never produce what they say they're going to produce. We've known for many years from doing business with these people _ everything they do is so elusive, it's like trying to take hold of smoke,'' Bryan said. Calls to some of the unsecured creditors, largely equipment supplies such as aircraft and engine makers, weren't returned. The creditors are owed $980 million by Eastern. They stood to receive about $490 million in cash and notes from Eastern and sister carrier Continental Airlines under a tentative agreement announced in late February. But Bakes said the airline has had trouble generating increased revenue from business travelers. He blamed ``the negative and disruptive public perception surrounding Eastern's reorganization process.'' Bakes estimated that Eastern lost two to three business passengers per flight in January and February, which would amount to more than $100 million in lost revenue over a fully year. The carrier's results during the first two months of the year also suffered from high fuel prices and the lack of cost-saving agreements with its pilots and flight attendants, he said. He said the carrier's flight activity as of July 1 will be 12 percent less than estimated in January and Eastern will cut its fleet to 148 from 160 by selling aircraft. Eastern also plans to seek annual savings of $33 million by cutting the cost of health benefits to early retirees and those under age 65. The bankruptcy court must approve the move. The carrier also may try to save $80 million in annual labor costs by seeking a bankruptcy court-supervised resolution of its long-running contract dispute with the Air Line Pilots Association and Transport Workers Union. Eastern and the union have tentatively agreed to an interim contract that includes a 25 percent wage cut for pilots still being paid at pre-strike wage rates, but that would expire July 1. Eastern said it will file for the resolution this week unless the National Mediation Board succeeds or appears likely to succeed in reaching a resolution in contract negotiations. Under section 1113 of the bankruptcy code, Eastern could obtain a contract resolution within 52 days. Eastern, a division of Houston-based Texas Air Corp., began operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from its creditors on March 9, 1989, five days after three unions struck the carrier. Since that time, the pilots and flight attendants unions have withdrawn from the strike. Bakes told the committee that Eastern will boost its marketing effort, including a substantial expansion in advertising and promotional spending on its business flyer program, to counter negative accounts of Eastern's situation. Bakes also said Eastern and Texas Air plan to continue to move ahead on an agreement with court-appointed bankruptcy examiner David Shapiro under which Texas Air and its Continental Airlines subsidiary would assist Eastern in completing its reorganization.

DOC.HEAD: American Express Sweetens Stock Buyback; $700 Million Charge Predicted
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. will charge a record $700 million against quarterly earnings to pay for layoffs, office closings and reserves against bad real estate loans, according to a top credit rating agency. The pretax charge estimated by Standard & Poor's Corp. would be the largest in securities industry history, exceeding a $470 million charge by Merrill Lynch & Co. in the 1989 fourth quarter. Meanwhile Tuesday, Shearson parent American Express Co. sweetened its buyout of all publicly held shares of Shearson it doesn't already own. In response, attorneys agreed to drop about 20 class-action lawsuits filed by shareholders challenging the merger. American Express also said a previously announced $750 million capital infusion had been made available to Shearson. American Express will have pumped about $1.35 billion into Shearson in recent months once the recapitalization plan is completed. Detailing the charge, S&P said Shearson will need up to $300 million to cover potential losses from its Balcor Co. real estate subsidiary, up to $100 million for severance payments to 2,000 employees laid off this month and up to $100 million to pull back from certain business lines. But ``if March performance is awful then all bets are off and conceivably the number could be higher,'' S&P vice president Jeffrey Bowman said. Shearson has said it expects a ``significant'' first-quarter charge. A Shearson spokesman declined further comment on the charge, which Wall Street analysts had estimated at as much as $500 million. Separately, The New York Times reported in Wednesday's editions that Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. was planning to dismiss 300 to 500 employees as part of a reorganization. ``We are engaged in the process of shrinking certain businesses while expanding in others,'' a spokesman for the securities firm told the newspaper. Under the stock buyback, American Express will exchange about 13.4 million shares of its common stock for the 28 million remaining publicly held Shearson shares. The Shearson stock would be converted into 0.48 of a share of American Express stock. That would be a 12.7 percent increase from the 0.426 a share announced March 4. Based on Tuesday's closing price of $25.62{ a share for American Express and $12.50 for Shearson, the deal values the minority stake at about $343 million. The deal marks a reversal for American Express, which had intended to reduce its majority stake in the Wall Street firm that has been strained by overexpansion in the 1980s and a recession in the securities industry. If completed, American Express would own about 92 percent of Shearson, with the rest held by Nippon Life Insurance Co. of Japan. Bowman said that while the recapitalization is positive for Shearson, American Express' credit rating could come under pressure if it is forced to continue injecting large amounts of capital into the brokerage. After an initial recapitalization plan to breathe life into Shearson fell through early this year, American Express decided to take control of its securities unit in an attempt to avoid a credit rating reduction. The big credit card and financial services firm installed one of its executives to run Shearson and announced a major cost-cutting that included the layoffs and 50 branch office closings. Shearson hopes the moves will save $400 million a year. Shearson, with about 33,500 employees, is the second largest Wall Street firm behind Merrill Lynch. Shearson is hampered by overcapacity from its 1988 acquisition of E.F. Hutton & Co., diminished stock trading business since the 1987 market crash and problems with its $1.1 billion real estate loan portfolio. The revised stock purchase by American Express was approved late Monday by Shearson's board following the recommendation of a special committee of three outside Shearson directors and the American Express board. Shearson and American Express also said shareholders had agreed to drop class-action lawsuits challenging the merger, pending court approval. The lawsuits claimed American Express was offering too little for the Shearson stock, which it had sold at $34 a share in an initial public offering in 1987. Spokesmen for Shearson and American Express declined to comment on whether the buyback was sweetened to resolve the litigation. But shareholder attorneys said the price was raised in response. ``I don't think there's any question that the litigation was a factor in the increased price,'' said R. Bruce McNew, an attorney with the Philadelphia law firm of Greenfield & Chimicles, which filed a class-action lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Agrees to Buy Lane Publishing for $225 Million
DOC.TEXT: The family-owned California company that publishes Sunset magazine and Sunset Books has agreed to be acquired for $225 million in cash and stock by Time Warner Inc. The deal, which is expected to be completed within a month or so, would be the first sizeable acquisition for Time Warner since Time Inc. completed its $14 billion acquisition of Warner Communications Inc. in January. Time Warner executives said the purchase would not add to the company's $10.7 billion debt. Nearly two-thirds of the price is in preferred stock and the cash portion will come the company's cash flow, they said. Time Warner said Tuesday it had agreed in principle to pay $80 million in cash and $145 million in preferred stock for Lane Publishing Co., based in Menlo Park, Calif. Lane had revenue of nearly $100 million last year, according to an executive familiar with the deal who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``This transaction underscores our optimism about the prospects for the magazine and book businesses,'' Time Warner's co-chairman and co-chief executives, Steven J. Ross and J. Richard Munro, said in a statement. It also gives Time Warner a second regional publishing operation. The company has owned Southern Progress Corp., which publishes Southern Living, Cooking Light and other magazines from Birmingham, Ala., for five years. Sunset, The Magazine of Western Living, is a general interest magazine with a monthly circulation of 1.3 million and readership of nearly 5 million. It publishes four zone editions each month in 13 Western states. The magazine, founded in 1898 by the Southern Pacific Railroad Co., initially was intended to influence travel to the West. But it now focuses on five major editorial areas _ travel and recreation, home design and use, food and entertaining, gardening and landscaping, and the environment. The magazine was sold to its employees in 1914, and L.W. Lane bought it and founded Lane Publishing in 1928. Lane formed a personal friendship with Time founder Henry Luce in the 1930s, and their companies established several business relationships. Sunset and the West Coast edition of Time, for instance, have shared printing presses since 1944. Lane's sons, L.W. ``Bill'' Lane Jr., 70, and Melvin B. Lane, 67, are the co-chairmen of Lane Publishing. They and their families decided late last fall to put the company up for sale and had discussions with several well-known national publishers before selecting Time Warner, according to Lane spokesman Gene Elsbree. ``Our highest priorities have always been to maintain Sunset's editorial excellence, to continue its growth and to ensure that the future of Sunset is in the right hands,'' the Lane brothers said in a statement. ``We're confident that these will now be achieved.'' Sunset Books publishes contemporary lifestyle books on topics such as gardening, landscaping and entertainment. The books are distributed through nurseries, home improvement, hardware, building supplies and stationery stores as well as through book and department stores worldwide. Lane also owns Sunset Films, based in San Francisco. It makes mainly industrial films and handles the audio-visual presentations that Sunset magazine uses for its sales presentations. The deal also includes the company's headquarters located near the Stanford University campus about 30 miles south of San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Chairman Gives Ground Under Simmons Assault
DOC.TEXT: No matter how his proxy battle to unseat Lockheed Corp.'s board turns out, Texas billionaire Harold Simmons can brag he forced the aerospace company's management to pay more attention to shareholders. Simmons got a boost Tuesday from California's $5.6 billion Public Employees' Retirement System. Calpers, the nation's largest private pension fund which owns 500,000 Lockheed shares or less than 1 percent, said it would vote for Simmon's slate of directors at Lockheed's annual meeting Thursday. The chief reason was Simmons' support for a shareholders' committee to advise Lockheed management, said Calpers assistant general counsel Kayla Gillan. Calpers advocates such panels as a way institutional investors can influence companies. Ms. Gillan said other big institutional shareholders share Calpers' concerns _ good news for Simmons and his chief lieutenant, J. Landis Martin. ``We're feeling very good about our position,'' Martin said. Lockheed Chairman Daniel Tellep quickly responded by promising institutional shareholders a seat on the board after the annual meeting. It was an attempt to woo the big institutions who own 60 percent of Lockheed's stock. ``We will work with our institutional shareholders to develop a list of potential directors from within or outside their ranks who could provide additional perspective to our directors,'' Tellep said in a statement. ``We believe that selection of at least one director from that list could provide important input to the future of the company.'' Simmons so far shows a paper loss of about $100 million on his $530 million investment in Lockheed. In waging his proxy battle, he has said that if he gets control, he will refocus Lockheed on profits rather than sales. He claims that will increase the price of Lockheed's stock, which has plunged nearly $20 in recent months. Lockheed closed $1.12{ higher at $37 a share Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange. Tellep acknowledged the company had concentrated on growth in new areas but said it already has refocused toward profits under a restructuring announced last year. He said that after a decision to take nearly $500 million in writeoffs last year, sending profits tumbling to $2 million from $624 million in 1988, Lockheed is now ready for a big turnaround. ``The fact of the matter is that I've been stressing improved profits and return on assets, and our five-year forecast reflects that,'' Tellep said in an interview this week. ``It's incorrect to say that we're more interested in sales.'' Simmons controls about 19 percent of Lockheed's stock and can acquire no more than 20 percent before Lockheed's anti-takeover provisions kick in, making further stock purchases prohibitively expensive. He has indicated he is likely to sell big chunks of Lockheed's operations outside of its space, missiles and aeronautics divisions. But Tellep said such a divestment program is already underway. Beginning in 1989, Lockheed began selling off seven units with combined sales of $200 million, he said. He also attacked Simmons' claim that companies purchased by Simmons have shown a consistent pattern of improved earnings and share values. ``Our share price decline is exactly within the pattern of the whole defense industry,'' Tellep said. ``Simmon's NL Industries' stock declined 34 percent in the last six months, so he's not exactly perfect.'' He reiterated his contention that Simmons knows nothing about running a defense contractor the size and complexity of Lockheed, which had revenues of $9.9 billion last year. ``He says a lot of things, but the question is, what is his plan,'' Tellep said. ``His fundamental problem is a lack of understanding of our basic business makeup.'' He said he intended to meet with Simmons after the shareholders' meeting Thursday to give him more insight into the company. And in a video prepared for Lockheed workers, who also own about 19 percent of the company through an employee stock ownership plan, Tellep promised better communication with them. Tellep also told Calpers that after talking to shareholders around the country, he realized he should support confidential voting, Ms. Gillan said. That is one of several proposals advocated by Simmons and Calpers, along with dropping the company's tough anti-takeover provisions. Simmons' promises are wider-ranging than Lockheed's and he signed his, Ms. Gillan said, explaining the fund's decision to back Simmons. ``We haven't seen anything in writing from Mr. Tellep,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: BankAmerica Joins Warranty Trend; Citibank, Chase To Follow
DOC.TEXT: The extended warranties and loss-protection now provided by many credit cards may soon be available for goods bought with checks issued by many banks. Bank of America said Tuesday almost any purchase made by its customers using a personal check will be protected for free against loss, theft, damage or fire for 90 days after purchase. The protection also automatically doubles the manufacturer's U.S. warranty, up to one additional year on items such as home appliances, video equipment, computers, toys and sports equipment. The coverage will be effective almost immediately for the bank's more than 3 million checking customers. The move is part of a budding trend by banks to woo depositors by offering the added services on checking accounts. Citibank and Chase Manhattan Bank in New York plan to start similar programs next week, following the lead of First Chicago last week and several smaller banks, Valley National Bank in Phoenix, Ariz., Napa Valley Bank in California and CrossLand Savings Bank in New York. ``I think as time goes by, more and more banks will offer this protection to their checking customers to remain competitive,'' said Chase's marketing vice president, Chester Myszkowski. Banks aren't the only ones providing this new service. Coast Savings, a California thrift, last week announced a similar plan. American Express Co. and many bank card companies have been offering purchase insurance to premium card holders for more than two years. In addition to providing the protection for check users, Bank of America also will extend coverage as of April 1 to purchasers using its regular credit cards. The bank has been offering the service to its premium card holders for 2{ years. Bank of America has 5{ million credit card customers. ``With this service, our customers can save hundreds of dollars in costly repair or replacement bills,'' said Thomas E. Peterson, vice chairman. The coverage is being underwritten by National Union Fire Insurance Co. of Pittsburgh, and Bank of America has no liabilities for losses, said bank spokeswoman Shirley Rigby Norton. She declined to disclose the cost of the insurance to the bank, citing proprietary reasons, but said it would not have a significant impact on the bank's expenses. ``It's not expensive in what it costs the banks per account, probably less than $1 a year,'' said Robert V. Conte, a broker with CBSI, an insurance marketing company in Harrison, N.Y., that set up the Chase and First Chicago plans. The underwriter for those plans also is National Union Fire Insurance Co. ``There's no comparable policy that consumers can buy individually,'' he said. ``The extended warranties offered by dealers on things like stereos are expensive and have huge profit margins built in. Adding it to checking accounts is all the rage all of a sudden.'' The banks' extended warranties may cut into the profits of retailers who offer their own extended warranties. But a spokesman for Chicago-based Sears, Roebuck & Co., which offers a variety of ``maintenance agreements,'' said he ``would not anticipate'' that the bank programs will affect sales of Sears' product coverage. ``Our coverage does more than extend the manufacturers' warranties, and it can last up to 10 years,'' said Sears spokesman Gordon Jones. As of April 2, Citibank, a unit of Citicorp, will expand its purchase protection service now offered only to credit card customers to the bank's 1 million customers who have a combined checking and savings account known as Citi-One. Chase customers with similar ``Better Banking'' accounts will get the coverage as of April 1. The Chase Manhattan Corp. unit has been offering the coverage only to customers using unsecured credit lines and credit cards. The loss protection plan for all the major banks gives buyers as much as $50,000 coverage, limited to the amount of the purchase paid by check or credit card. The plans have a $2,500 limit for claims involving jewelry, watches, furs and fine art. Customers do not have to register to join the programs or register their purchses. Eligible purchases will be covered only in excess of other collectible insurance, such as homeowner's or tenant's insurance, and can pick up the deductible from the customer's other insurance. Customers must provide a sales receipt, a copy of their canceled check or charge card slip, and damaged merchandise as proof of purchase.

DOC.HEAD: Bentsen Skeptical of Revenue-Raising Prospects of Savings Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is counting on its proposed Family Savings Plan to generate more revenue than it would cost, but the Senate's chief tax-writer is skeptical. ``That carries me back to 1981'' when the Reagan administration predicted that huge tax cuts would pay for themselves, Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said Tuesday. ``Now we have these enormous deficits that in part were brought about by that `magic.''' The Family Savings Plan is part of a package proposed by President Bush as incentives to increased saving and investment. Under the plan, a person with income under $60,000 or a couple earning less than $120,000 could annually deposit up to $2,500 and $5,000, respectively, and pay no tax on the interest if the account was maintained for at least seven years. Sidney L. Jones, assistant secretary of the treasury for economic policy, told the Finance Committee that the proposal would generate $40 billion in new individual savings over the next five years. He said the White House Council of Economic Advisers estimates that the plan would so boost saving and economic growth that it would lead ``to an increase in government revenues as well as personal saving in the longer run.'' The administration makes the same argument on behalf of the biggest part of the president's savings and investment package: a proposal to cut the tax on capital gains, the profits from sales of investments. Some economists quarrel with the administration's basic argument that a tax incentive will increase savings. They cite Individual Retirement Accounts as an example, saying that most of the money going into IRAs is simply a transfer from taxable savings accounts. The Finance Committee received conflicting advice on that point from two analysts associated with the private National Bureau of Economic Research: _Jonathan Skinner of the University of Virginia said an IRA _ which provides a tax incentive at the time a deposit is made _ can boost savings by locking up an account until retirement. He predicted that Bush's plan, which could be cashed in after seven years, would lead to shuffling money from taxable to non-taxable accounts. _Lawrence J. Kotlikoff of Boston University said ``it is clear that saving policies of the last decade, such as expansion of IRAs, failed to promote national saving.'' He suggested taxing consumption _ such as with a national sales tax _ to encourage saving. The one point on which the economists, administration witnesses and committee members agreed is that Americans save too little of their income, far less than Japanese and West Germans. The U.S. saving rate last year was 3.6 percent of net national income, compared with an average of 8.9 percent during the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s. ``Increased savings would lower the cost of capital for our nation's business, enhance the ability of American companies to compete in a global market and lower the cost of most goods and services we consume,'' said Kenneth W. Gideon, assistant secretary of the treasury for tax policy. The National Association of Counties complained that the savings plan would force up the cost of borrowing for highways, schools and other state and local building projects. Mary O. Boyle, a Cuyahoga County, Ohio, commissioner speaking for the association, said the accounts would compete for the same savings dollars as the tax-exempt bonds on which states, cities and counties rely. ``Local governments would be forced to pay higher borrowing costs just to compete _ an ultimate cost shift to all taxpayers,'' Ms. Boyle said. That would endanger the nation's system of highways, bridges and sewers, she said. But Gideon said the new accounts ``will have at most a small impact on the tax-exempt bond market.''

DOC.HEAD: Airlines Spared of Fines if They Catch Own Safety Violations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Federal aviation authorities will no longer fine airlines for safety violations if the carriers find the problem themselves, quickly correct it and report it to the government. Federal Aviation Administration chief James B. Busey announced the new policy Tuesday at a luncheon with airline officials. An industry spokesman applauded the policy change, but a pilots' group cautioned against a falldown in FAA enforcement. Busey acknowledged that his agency, which monitors safety at airports used by U.S. carriers throughout the world, doesn't have enough manpower to catch every violation. He said airlines have the responsibility to audit their own safety. ``We cannot police every aspect of the industry, cannot crawl through the belly of every aircraft, look over the shoulder of every pilot, or personally screen every passenger and every piece of luggage that flies in the system,'' the FAA administrator said. The program could require airlines to designate safety auditors or set up separate safety departments, Busey said. ``I'm offering an incentive to encourage executives of airline companies to monitor personally the safety of their operations as closely as they monitor the bottom line,'' he said. A backlog of several thousand fine cases has plagued the FAA for several years. Most are for security screening violations at airports, and Busey said he has not yet decided how to handle them. In the past, the FAA has assessed fines of up to $10,000 per incident for security and maintenance violations even when an airline reports that it has found the problem itself. Busey said the new plan would cover large and small airlines and apply to any kind of violation. ``Make no mistake,'' he warned. ``Our inspectors will continue to conduct regular inspections and surveillance, and they will expect and demand 100 percent compliance with rules and regulations.'' Robert Aaronson, president of the Air Transport Association, which represents major carriers, said safety often depends on the prompt sharing of information about problems among airlines. He said the new program will encourage that. Aaronson said the policy would help ease a longstanding adversarial relationship in which the FAA acts as ``accuser, jury, judge and hangman'' in safety violation cases. The agency continues to have that power, he said, but Busey's approach is an improvement. Aaronson said some airlines have been fined after discovering that an airport screening device was inoperative for an hour, correcting the problem and then reporting it to the FAA. Henry A. Duffy, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, said penalties should be increased with the voluntary approach. ``The voluntary aspect of it is fine,'' he said, ``but there are always some airlines that require tough enforcement. You've always got to have that guy with the club.''

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Violence No Excuse Not to Resume Talks, Union Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The union representing striking Greyhound bus drivers is urging the company to couple its offer of rewards for information about strike-related violence with a return to negotiations. ``Anything that brings criminals to justice is great, but it's no excuse to stay away from the bargaining table,'' union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson said Tuesday after Greyhound Lines Inc. said it would pay $100,000 for information leading to convictions for shootings at buses or terminals. Since the strike started March 2, there have been shooting attacks on 21 Greyhound buses and two attacks on terminals, Greyhound vice president P. Anthony Lannie said in announcing the rewards. ``The terrorism must stop,'' Lannie said. ``It's inevitable that somebody is going to get hurt.'' No one has been seriously injured in any of the shootings. On the second day of the walkout, a striking driver in Redding, Calif., was crushed to death by a bus driven by a replacement driver. No one was charged. ``Certainly, we condemn the violence, but we don't have a hand in it,'' Nelson said. Meanwhile Tuesday in West Hartford, Conn., the case against a striking driver accused of shooting at a bus two weeks ago was moved to Hartford Superior Court so officials there can determine whether more serious charges are warranted. Roger Cawthra, 44, is accused of firing the shot that hit the luggage compartment of a Greyhound bus carrying 19 passengers. No one was injured. Cawthra, the only person who has been arrested in any of the shootings, was charged with first-degree criminal mischief, a felony, and three misdemeanors _ first-degree reckless endangerment, unlawful discharge of a firearm and unlawful discharge of a firearm on a public highway. The union said it is willing to resume negotiations at any time. Lannie said the company would not resume talks, which broke down 10 days ago in Tucson, Ariz., until management had ``hard assurances'' from the union that the violence would stop. Federal mediators are trying to meet separately with both sides, but no immediate sessions were scheduled, officials said. ``We have no reason for optimism,'' Greyhound's Lannie said, adding that the union also would have to soften its wage demands before negotiations could resume. Wages, work rules and job security are the key issues in the strike, which involves 6,300 drivers and 3,000 other Greyhound workers.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened in calm, early European trading today, fueled by weakness in the West German mark and Japanese yen, currency dealers said. Gold prices rebounded. Traders said investors were changing their minds about the dollar as initial euphoria over German unification fades and uncertainty about the economic costs for the mark emerge. Tensions in Lithuania and concern over how Soviet Leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev will handle them were also driving investors away from the West German currency. ``It's more emotional than technical, but people are getting used to the notion of a stronger dollar again,'' said an analyst in Milan, Italy. Another said: ``People are turning to the dollar from a lack of choice.'' In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose for the ninth straight day, closing 1.67 yen higher at 158.63 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 158.65 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.7162 West German marks, up from 1.7108; 1.5212 Swiss francs, up from 1.5175; 5.7685 French francs, up from 5.7535; 1.9295 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9247; 1,260.00 Italian lire, up@down from 1,261.75; and 1.1773 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1761. The dollar also rose against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6221, compared with $1.6255 late Tuesday. Gold prices rose in nervous trading. The metal opened in London at a bid price of $374.50 a troy ounce, up from $369.26 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $373. In Zurich, the bid price was $373, up from $369.65 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.15 to close at a bid $374.62. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.01 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $4.98.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Climbs For Ninth Day Against Yen
DOC.TEXT: The dollar climbed today against the yen for a ninth straight day despite the reported selling of $1 billion by Japan's central bank and closed at its highest level in more than three years. The rise sent prices plunging on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar closed at 158.63 yen in active trading, up 1.67 yen from Tuesday's close of 156.96 yen. It opened at 158.30 yen and ranged between 158.15 yen and 158.85 yen. The currency now has gained 6.43 yen in Tokyo in nine trading days. The dollar's close was its highest since it finished the day at 158.05 yen on Jan. 12, 1987. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 562.39 points, or 1.77 percent, closing at 31,263.57. The index fell 14.53 points Tuesday, following a 1,468.33-point surge on Monday. An analyst with Nomura Securities Co., who spoke on condition of anonymity, said stock investors were reluctant to make purchases because of uncertainies in the market caused by the yen's rapid decline against the dollar. Volume on the first section of the exchange was estimated at 600 million shares, down from 700 million shares on Tuesday. A Bank of Tokyo official said the central bank intervened in the market by selling about $1 billion to prop up the yen. The Bank of Japan usually does not comment on its market interventions. ``Unless the political or economic situation changes, we can expect this thing to continue,'' Chemical Bank dealer Richard Cameron said of the dollar's rise. ``The dollar has been so strong, and its rising pace is very fast,'' said Shinichi Kato of Mitsui Bank. Kato said large demand for the dollar was pushing the U.S. currency higher. Importers, many of whom are afraid that the dollar will rise further, are jumping at the dollar whenever it moves downward, he said. Kato also blamed the lack of coordinated market intervention among central banks for the dollar's swift ascent. ``The Bank of Japan alone can no longer control the situation,'' he said. ``The dollar's upward momentum has become too strong now.'' At a regular news conference Wednesday, Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno said it is hard to understand why the yen continues to fall when Japan continues to run large trade surpluses. High exports would be expected to boost demand for the yen. But Mieno suggested that tensions in the Soviet Union and developments in Europe, together with factors connected with the end of Japan's fiscal year, were boosting the dollar in foreign exchange markets. The major monetary nations will continue cooperative intervention aimed at strengthening the yen and chances were good for stability returning to the market, he said. Overall, Mieno said he sees no immediate threats to Japan's current economic expansion, which has continued for 40 consecutive months. Because the U.S. Federal Reserve Board took no measures in the market on Tuesday, Japanese market players began to speculate that the United States approves of the current dollar-yen rate, said Kato. ``The dollar will soon hit the 160-yen level. It's just a matter of time,'' he added. The price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds closed at 86.14 points, up from Tuesday's close of 86.03. Their yield declined to 7.320 percent from 7.345 percent.

DOC.HEAD: GNP Increases 3 Percent in 1989, Government Reports
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 3rd graf, While the ..., saying report is further evidence of no recession and rewords 4th graf, picking up 3rd graf pvs, The 3 percent...
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy posted a 1.1 percent gain from October through December, the slimmest quarterly advance in three years, helping slow the increase of goods and services to just 3 percent in 1989, the government said today. The Commerce Department's final revision of its fourth-quarter gross national product was up slightly from the 0.9 percent gain in its estimate last month. The department's initial estimate in January was 0.5 percent. While the improvement was modest, it was further evidence the economy can avoid an immediate recession and continue the longest peace-time expansion in U.S. history. The growth in the final three months of 1989 followed increases of 3.7 percent in the first quarter, 2.5 percent in the second and 3 percent in the third. The 3 percent gain for all of 1989 was the smallest since a 2.7 percent advance in 1986 and followed increases of 4.4 percent in 1988 and 3.7 percent in 1987. A consensus of economists had indicated in advance of the latest report that fourth-quarter growth would remain at 0.9 percent. Many analysts, however, believe that while the pace of economic growth rose further during the current quarter, partly because of weather-related factors, it will not bounce back in 1990 to the levels experienced during much of the 1980s. In fact, the latest consensus of top economists projects a 1.7 percent growth forecast for this year. That would be the poorest performance since economic activity declined 2.5 percent in 1982 during the last recession. The fourth quarter's 1.1 percent gain was the lowest since a 0.8 percent advance in the third quarter of 1986. An inflation index tied to the GNP rose at an annual rate of 4.5 percent last year, the Commerce Department said, the same as its estimate last month. The various changes left the GNP expanding in the fourth quarter at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.17 trillion. The department attributed the final revision to an increase in final sales, which offset a decrease in the amount of inventories. The biggest drag on the economy in the fourth quarter was durable goods, which declined 14 percent. Other areas of weakness included capital spending and housing construction. Exports, on the other hand, jumped 9.4 percent in the fourth quarter, while imports rose just 2.2 percent. In a companion report, the department said after-tax profits of U.S. corporations rose 2.8 percent in the fourth quarter. Corporate profits fell during each of the other quarters of 1989 _ 1.1 percent in the first, 7.2 percent in the second and 5.4 percent in the third. Profits rose 1.4 percent in the final quarter of 1988. The economy grew more than 3 percent during each of the years since the 1981-1982 recession except when it slowed to a 2.7 percent gain in 1986. But even moderate growth relieves recessionary fears that some felt late in 1989 as the economy slowed as a result of high interest-rate policies of the Federal Reserve as it sought to stem inflation. David Wyss, chief financial economist for DRI@McGraw-Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting organization, said he is looking for 1.5 percent growth during the current January-March period, ``which still is pretty weak by normal standards, but it doesn't look like we're headed for a recession.'' A recession usually is defined as two consecutive quarterly declines in the GNP. The last decline was a one-quarter, 1.8 percent drop in the second quarter of 1986, after which the economy resumed growth. Kathleen Cooper, senior financial economist for Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles, said she expects first-quarter growth of about 2 percent. ``This quarter turned out to be a good deal stronger than we anticipated,'' she said. ``But it may well be that the first quarter will be the strongest of the year,'' she added, saying 1990 growth would register between 1.5 percent and 2 percent. On the other hand, Michael K. Evans, head of Evans Economics Inc. here, is forecasting a ``surprisingly robust'' second-quarter growth of between 3 percent and 4 percent. Both Ms. Cooper and Evans said the relatively stronger numbers means it is unlikely the Federal Reserve will ease its tight-credit policies. The Bush administration and many economists have urged the Fed to permit interest rates to fall to stimulate the economy. The Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank's monetary-policy setting arm, met behind closed doors on Tuesday to decide on its policies for the next six weeks. As usual, it will not announce its decision until next month.
