DOC.HEAD: Colt Workers Get Back To Work After Four-Year Strike
DOC.TEXT: Union workers triumphantly marched into a Colt Manufacturing Co. plant today, ending a strike that lasted more than four years and that resulted in employees becoming part owners of the firm. About 80 members of United Auto Workers Local 376, carrying banners proclaiming ``We Beat 'Em And We Bought 'Em,'' proudly walked into Colt's gritty brick factory building for the start of the 7 a.m. shift. More than 300 co-workers who will return to work over the next two months lined the streets outside, cheering as the workers took their first step inside since walking off the job on Jan. 24, 1986. ``It's really kinda spooky,'' said Raynold Guerrett, 47, as he listened to instructions on how to operate some of the new computerized machinery that has since been installed at the nation's oldest handgun manufacturer. The strike officially ended last Thursday when a buyout agreement was announced which makes the striking workers co-owners of the plant along with Colt managers, the state of Connecticut and private investors. About 60 have retired, nearly 40 have died and a few have chosen to remain at other jobs they found during the strike. But company officials said 90 percent of the strikers contacted so far said they planned to return. Some 1,050 UAW Local 376 members walked off the job after working 10 months without a contract. ``It's amazing that so many of them are coming back and left whatever job they were working at to come back,'' said Ronald E. Stilwell, executive vice president and chief operating officer of the new Colt company. ``The enthusiasm is incredible.'' Thursday's buyout agreement with New York-based Colt Industries, parent of the gun maker, meant all 600 replacement workers hired to keep Colt plants in Hartford and West Hartford running during the strike lost their jobs. However, a handful of the replacement workers can expect to be offered jobs, Stilwell said. The new company, formerly known as Colt Industries Firearms Division, is treating the returning veteran workers as if they were just hired. Each employee will fill out an application, undergo a physical, attend an orientation and go through training. The new buyout agreement gives the workers a total of $13 million in back pay, settling an unfair labor practices suit against the company. Workers also got a 13 percent wage increase and a stock ownership plan which will allow the UAW members to own 11.5 percent of the company.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of New Homes Remain Slack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs blaming slow sales on mortgage rates, picking up 2nd graf pvs, The Commerce...
DOC.TEXT: Sales of new homes last month rebounded 3.1 percent from steep declines in December and January, the government reported today, but analysts said sales remained depressed because of high mortgage interest rates. ``It's not a terribly optimistic outlook for the housing industry,'' said economist Richard Peach of the Mortgage Bankers Association. ``I don't see much of a decline in rates in the months ahead and there's substantial risk that they will go higher in the second half of the year.'' The Commerce Department said new single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 607,000 units in February after plummeting a 6.8 percent in January and a revised 8.0 percent in December. Sales in both January and February were the lowest since 556,000 homes were sold on an annual basis last March. Sales totaled 589,000 in January. Sales in December _ the fourth coldest on record _ had dropped to 632,000, which was revised down from the 634,000 units originally reported. But January was the warmest on record and analysts were surprised at its failure to lure buyers. February also was unusually warm but failed to bring sales back to the level of 649,000 units sold in 1989. The National Association of Realtors reported on Monday that sales of existing homes fell 2.3 percent in February to their slowest pace in seven months. It blamed the decline on rising mortgage interest rates. Interest on fixed-rate mortgages rose from 10.17 percent at the beginning of February to 10.31 percent before falling to 10.23 percent at month's end, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. Realtors chief economist John A. Tuccillo said Monday that rates should begin to drop in the months ahead and renew buyer interest. The Commerce Department said the median price of a new home continued to climb in February, rising 4.0 percent to $130,000. That compared with the Realtors' median price of $95,400 for an existing home. The median means half of the homes cost more and half less. Sales jumped 21.3 percent to 256,000 units at an annual rate in the South but fell elsewhere in the nation. They were down 18 percent to 82,000 units in the Northeast, 6.4 percent to 88,000 units in the Midwest and 1.6 percent to 181,000 units in the West.

DOC.HEAD: Top Stock Manager Announces Retirement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 7 grafs background, quotes; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Peter Lynch, regarded as one of the top stock managers in the country, announced today he would retire as the overseer of Fidelity Investments' $13 billion Magellan mutual fund. In a statement from the company, Lynch said: ``When I was 10 years old my father died. He was 46. Now I'm 46, and this is very much on my mind.'' ``I have been blessed in my 21-year career with Fidelity and I very much want to give something back to the community,'' he said. ``In addition, I strongly wish to increase my commitment to my family.'' Lynch's retirement date will be May 31. The new portfolio manager of the Magellan fund will be Morris Smith, 33, currently manager of Fidelity OTC Portfolios. Under Lynch, who took over in May 1977, the Magellan fund has grown sharply. The assets in 1981 were approximately $100 million, compared with its current $13 billion. According to company estimates, $10,000 invested in the fund on May 31, 1977, would have grown to $270,007 on Dec. 31, 1989. During the last five years, when it was the largest common stock fund in the country, Magellan has outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500 by an average of 6 percent a year, the company said. Despite this success, Lynch indicated recently it was becoming more difficult to find underperforming stocks that can yield high returns, since stock prices overall have continued their annual growth. Lynch was elected earlier this month to the Fidelity Group's board of trustees, and he will join the board in April. ``I wouldn't leave Fidelity to manage investments anywhere else,'' he said. ``I'm not looking for a different situation.'' Fidelity Chairman and Chief Executive Edward C. Johnson 3rd said in a statement: ``Even if he never invests another dollar, Peter Lynch has won a place of honor in the history of money management.''
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 437.05 down 2.45 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Plan Quick Vote on Bill Despite GOP Objections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout with House leaders comment.
DOC.TEXT: House Democratic leaders today predicted early passage of their version of a major child-care bill, saying a competing version backed by the White House lacks an important feature for middle-class familes. ``Everybody likes it,'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt said after a closed-door caucus with House Democrats to explain the leadership's package. ``The Democratic bill is going to win.'' The Democratic bill is aimed at providing tax credits and other federal subsidies to help working families find and afford child care. Also to be voted on is a competing alternative backed by some conservative Democrats, Republicans and the White House. Democrats made their package public Tuesday evening before the Rules Committee, which sets procedures for handling legislation. The leaders planned to send it to the floor Thursday, despite protests by the Republican minority that it was moving too fast and they had not been given an advance look at the bill. ``We're not trying to redesign at the federal level the child-care system that's out there,'' said Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., a sponsor of the leadership's bill. ``We're trying to modestly upgrade it.'' A major difference between the two versions is that the Democrats would provide federal funds for school systems to set up programs of before- and after-school care based in the public schools. Miller, who had been in a series of negotiations with the White House in a futile effort to reach a bipartisan compromise, attacked the GOP version today as an ``assault on the public school system'' because it lacks that program. Another sponsor, Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., said that program _ providing care for so-called ``latchkey'' children who otherwise might go unattended _ would assist middle-class families. The Senate has approved its version of a child-care bill. The House approved conflicting versions last year, and its latest debate is an effort to forge a new position. In both bills, the centerpiece is an earned income tax credit for low-income families with at least one parent working. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, estimated the cost of the leadership's package at $27 billion over its five-year phase-in. But Rep. Clay Shaw, R-Fla., and other Republicans said their analysis of the Democrats' bill put the cost at $31.3 billion. The conservative alternative sponsored by Shaw and Rep. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas, was estimated to cost just under $20 billion. ``Thirty-one billion, I think, is pretty hard to justify in times of scarcity,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn. ``I believe you're going too far, too fast, too big with this.'' Reps. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., and Louise Slaughter, D-N.Y., both questioned whether the package of vouchers, tax credits and other features would actually produce any more child care. ``I don't think there's many women's fingerprints on this bill,'' Slaughter said. Both of the competing versions would permit federal subsidies for care provided by religious-based day care centers _ even those that provide religious instruction and base hiring decisions on church membership. Other features of the Democratic leadership's bill would expand the Head Start program, at a cost of $600 million a year, and spend $2.9 billion on the Social Services Block Grant program to allow states to subsidize care, including the use of vouchers. The Democratic bill also includes $3.3 billion to finance a new school-based program for before- and after- school care. The Stenholm-Shaw bill has no such program. Both measures would finance the package in part by reducing or eliminating the existing dependent care tax credit for upper-income families, beginning with those earning $70,000 a year. The Democrats would finance part of the package, $13 billion over five years, by extending the excise tax on telephone service. Sponsors acknowledged that the revenue sources they had identified would not cover the full cost.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Extend Losses
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending the modest losses posted in the previous session amid slack export demand and a sharp drop in soybean oil. Corn and wheat futures were pressured by slack export demand and forecasts for rain in the western Corn Belt, promising improved soil moisture as the spring planting season nears. Mark Weidner, a soybean market analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc., said trading activity was growing increasingly cautious ahead of Friday's Agriculture Department reports on quarterly grain stocks and spring planting intentions. DOC.HEAD: Court Hears Arguments on Affirmative Action Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: A government policy giving women and minority groups preferences in the award of broadcast licenses discriminates unlawfully against white males and is a failure, the Supreme Court was told today. But lawyers for the Federal Communications Commission and a Hispanic-owned company defended the congressionally sanctioned policy as a legitimate means of promoting diversity over the airwaves. The justices heard arguments in cases from Florida and Connecticut that could have major impact on a broad range of affirmative action programs. The court is expected to rule by July. Gregory H. Guillot, representing a broadcasting company denied a license that was awarded to a Hispanic-owned rival, said the FCC ``policy is a complete, total failure. It's bad, ineffective and unconstitutional.'' He also said the policy has increased minority ownership of television and radio stations by only one percent in 18 years. ``I'm no mathematician. But that means there will be 600 years left'' for the policy to achieve equal racial representation in the broadcast industry, he said. Margaret Polivy, a lawyer for the Hispanic-owned company, said Congress has identified women and minorities as ``missing voices'' in the mass media and has taken legitimate steps to remedy the problem. Achieving equality is ``a concept that underlies our democracy,'' she said. Justice Antonin Scalia said promoting a colorblind society is equally important. He said the idea that government benefits should not be awarded because of ``the color of our skin ... also underlies our democracy.'' Daniel M. Armstrong, representing the FCC, said it is vital for minorities and women to be given a greater voice in the media. ``Broadcasting has the power to shape opinion that few industries can match,'' he said. ``Some race-conscious steps are necessary.'' The FCC's defense of affirmative action has prompted a split with the Justice Department, which has raised the specter of unconstitutional reverse discrimination and has said the FCC programs lack justification. The high court dealt a major setback to affirmative action last year when it struck down a Richmond, Va., program that set aside a chunk of local public works contracts for minority-owned businesses. The 6-3 ruling cast doubt on the constitutionality of numerous affirmative action plans of states and cities but had no direct bearing on federal programs. A less conservative high court in 1980 upheld a federal public works program that set aside 10 percent of the funds for minority contracts. That decision said Congress has special constitutional authority to approve such preferences. The FCC policies have been the focus of a lengthy dispute between Congress and federal officials. The commission adopted the policies when President Carter was in office but disavowed them during the Reagan administration and started making plans to dismantle the affirmative action programs. Congress in 1987 barred the FCC from spending money to restudy or repeal the policies, and that prohibition remains in effect. At issue in the case from Florida is the FCC policy of giving minorities and women extra credit when evaluating their applications for new television and radio station licenses. A three-judge panel of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Washington upheld preferential treatment in the award of a TV license in Orlando to the Hispanic-owned Rainbow Broadcasting Co. A rival, Metro Broadcasting Inc., said it should have received the license. In the Connecticut case, a different panel of the same appeals court struck down the FCC's so-called distress-sale policy. That policy allows a broadcaster faced with loss of its license to sell it to a minority-owned business at 75 percent of market value. The appeals court overturned the award of a license in Hartford to Hispanic-led Astroline Communications Co. and gave it instead to Alan Shurberg, a non-Hispanic. The Justice Department, in a legal brief filed with the high court, said the FCC's preferential policies lack ``coherence.'' ``The commission's use of racial preferences remains today as much as ever a policy in search of a purpose and an adequate supporting record,'' department lawyers said. ``Racial classifications, when imposed by the government, must at a minimum reflect the deliberate judgment of a competent authority that such measures are necessary for specific purposes.'' The cases are Metro Broadcasting vs. FCC, 89-453, and Astroline Communications vs. Shurger Broadcasting, 89-700.

DOC.HEAD: Four European Airlines Join Forces To Cut Costs
DOC.TEXT: Four European airlines have joined forces in an effort to cut costs, planning to buy 239 new planes together and inviting two aircraft manufacturers to submit bids. The four airlines are seeking bids from McDonnell Douglas Corp. of the United States for its not-yet-completed MD-90 aircraft and from Airbus Industrie, a European consortium, for its A320 and A321 jets, according to a newspaper report. It is believed to be the most ambitious attempt by airlines to collaborate in an effort to reduce the cost of their jet purchases by placing a group order. Don Hanson, a spokesman for McDonnell Douglas' aircraft subsidiary, was quoted by the International Herald Tribune as saying the order would be one of the largest in airline industry history. Industry experts say that on the basis of Airbus' prices, a group order for 239 planes would be worth around $10 billion. Airbus confirmed Wednesday that it received a preliminary request for bids from the four airlines: Swissair, Scandinavian Airlines System, Austrian Airlines and Finnair. Airbus is a consortium grouping Aerospatiale of France, Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm GMBH of West Germany, British Aerospace PLC and Construcciones Aeronauticas SA of Spain. SAS is estimated to have a long-term requirement for 126 new aircraft, while Swissair will need 52, Austrian Airlines 26 and Finnair 35.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 4.28 to 2,741.22 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. DOC.HEAD: Senate Debates Effects of Proposed Air Pollution Law
DOC.NOTE: EDs: DELETES extraneous 2-word 10th graf, ``The pressure...; picks up 11th graf, also bgng, ``The pressure...
DOC.TEXT: The Senate battle to enact tougher air pollution controls moved closer to a conclusion today as senators debated the effect the bill will have on Midwest utilities and coal miners. Senate leaders reiterated that they planned to bring the clean air bill to a final vote next week after receiving approval from fellow senators Tuesday night to limit debate on the complex and controversial legislation. Several hours of debate today focused on the concerns of Midwest senators over the cost of proposed acid rain pollution controls on utiltities in that part of the country and the effect on high-sulfur coal miners. But by a vote of 72 to 25, the Senate rejected a proposal that would have provided those utilities a 20 percent tax credit if they used ``scrubber'' technology for pollution control, instead of switching to other fuels. The measure was aimed at helping coal miners who stand to lose up to 5,000 jobs because of the new air pollution controls if Midwest utilities switch to other fuels. Sen. Arlen Spector, R-Pa., sponsor of the bill, said the credit was needed for Midwest utilities to comply with new pollution control requirements and avoid severe electric rate increases. But critics said taxpayers nationwide should not have to help pay for cleaning up the Midwest's dirty power plants. Meanwhile, about 500 coal miners and their families rallied outside the Capitol in a protest against the acid rain provisions in the bill, saying the requirements would force them out of jobs. The Senate agreed Tuesday night to limit debate on the clean air bill and bring the measure to a vote next week. The agreement represented a major step toward passing the first clean air legislation by the Senate in 13 years. ``We're clearly now going to finish this bill by a specific time,'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said after he received his colleagues' approval to schedule a final vote for April 3. ``The pressure now is going to be for the senators to bring their (remaining) amendments to the floor. The reality now is that time is going to run out,'' said Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader. Meanwhile in the House, the Energy and Commerce Committee continues today to consider what is expected to be a string of amendments to its clean air legislation. Rep. John Dingell, R-Mich., the panel's chairman, hopes to send a bill to the floor before the Easter recess. The committee was expected today to consider an amendment that would require a phase-in of alternative fuel vehicles in urban areas with the worst smog. A similar requirement failed to win Senate approval. The announcement by Mitchell of a time limit for debating the clean air bill came late Tuesday after the Senate grappled most of the day with a proposal to ease permit requirements for businesses. The Senate rejected the measure by a vote of 50-47, although industry complained the new requirements would create a ``bureaucratic nightmare.'' ``We've been here a long time now and the end is in sight,'' declared Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., one of the bill's floor managers. The Senate began considering the clean air bill in late January, worked out a compromise with the White House during three weeks of closed-door negotiations and has been debating the compromise since March 5. Both the Senate and House bills would require a wide range of pollution controls on industry, automobiles and electric power plants in hopes of dramatically reducing acid rain and bringing air quality within federal standards in most urban areas by the turn of the century. More than a week ago, Mitchell was thwarted from getting agreement on a time limit for consideration of the bill. But Tuesday night, Mitchell tried again and this time obtained unanimous consent to schedule a final vote for 8 p.m. next Tuesday. Meanwhile, behind-the-scenes discussions continued in an attempt to work out an agreement with Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., over his proposal to provide financial assistance to coal miners who lose their jobs because of new restrictions under the legislation. Mitchell said if no compromise was reached he planned a vote on the Byrd proposal for Thursday. Byrd earlier had been widely believed to have enough votes to pass his amendment, but Mitchell refused to bring it to a vote. The White House has called the $500 million measure too expensive and Mitchell has expressed concern that its passage might threaten the overall clean air bill. Democratic and Republican sources in the Senate suggested Tuesday that it was unlikely that Bush would want to endanger enactment of a clean air bill solely because of the coal miner assistance provision.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Minister Hints at Concession in U.S. Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: Japan is considering revising a law that limits the opening of of large foreign stores, a key issue in trade negotiations with the United States, government officials indicated Wednesday. Kabun Muto, minister of International Trade and Industry, told business leaders that anything short of a change in the Large-Scale Retail Store Law is unlikely to satisfy U.S. negotiators in next week's trade meetings in Washington. ``The U.S. is quite adamant on the issue,'' Kyodo News Service quoted Muto as saying. ``I am quite worried that our proposal for only improving enforcement of the law may not get us off the hook.'' At Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's request, the government has created a series of proposals aimed at satisfying U.S. requests in the so-called Structural Impediments Initiative talks. The talks are aimed at eliminating factors in each country's economy that hinder reductions in their $49 billion trade imbalance. U.S. and Japanese negotiators are to exchange interim reports on their progress during the fourth round of the talks, set for next Monday and Tuesday in Washington. The United States reportedly has made more than 200 proposals for eliminating what it contends are barriers to foreign involvement in Japan's economic and business structure. Government officials have declined to disclose the contents of the proposals, but have acknowledged that scrapping the Large-Scale Store Law is one of three major U.S. demands. The law requires large stores to obtain a consensus from small, local shop keepers before opening a new outlet in a given area. Otherwise, the large stores must wait as long as eight or 10 years. In contrast, many Japanese retailers such as Mitsukoshi and Tokyu department stores and Yaohan supermakets already have opened stores in the United States. In a test of the barriers, the government has agreed to consider a request by U.S. toy retailer Toys R Us Inc. to open a 53,800-square-foot discount store in Niigata, 160 miles northwest of Tokyo. U.S. officials say such large-scale stores are more likely to carry more foreign products, leading to an increase in Japan's imports. Japanese business leaders have expressed strong opposition to Muto's idea of relaxing the law because it would hurt small shop owners. ``Before we review the law itself, we should monitor the enforcement of the law first,'' said Rokuro Ishikawa, president of the Japan Chamber of Commerce and Industry, one of Japan's most powerful business organizations. Opposition also has been expressed within the governing Liberal Democartic Party against the administration's plan to revise the law. A senior party official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said legislators opposing the change were concerned about losing political support from small shop owners, who are among the party's traditional backers. ``I think most of us understand logically that the U.S. demands make sense and are good for Japan, but many politicians are reluctant to pay the political cost for the benefit of others,'' he said. ``Also as a party, we have to worry about whether we are able to win the opposition camp's approval to pass a revision of the law in Parliament,'' he added. The governing Liberal Democratic Party has the power to decide the content of trade proposals Japanese negotiators will present to their American counterparts in next week's talks, but any legal changes must clear the opposition-dominated upper house. On Wednesday, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told that Kaifu a rapid, sharp increase in Japan's public works spending _ another U.S. proposal _ was not possible. The United States has proposed Japan increase public works spending to 10 percent of gross national product. The finance minister said he rejected the U.S. demand for the increase when he met with U.S. leaders last week in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Tumble On Heavy Speculative Selling
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell sharply Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid heavy speculative selling that partly reflected profit-taking and greater supply prospects. Grain futures closed moderately lower. Analysts said the soybean sell-off began at the opening bell when at least two large commodity brokerage houses aggressively sold soybean oil contracts, triggering a plunge to two-week lows in the oil market. The selling quickly spread to the adjacent soybean and soybean meal pits, spurred on by reports of ideal harvesting weather for the South American soybean crop and forecasts for beneficial rain in the Midwest and northern Great Plains, the main regions for U.S. soybean, corn and spring wheat production. ``Oil took a big hit on the opening and we never really recovered,'' said Victor Lespinasse, a trader in Chicago for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Further selling was tied to positioning ahead of Friday's Agriculture Department reports on quarterly grain stocks and spring planting intentions, analysts said. At the close, wheat futures were 2\ cents to 4 cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.51 a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 3 cents lower with May at $2.59\ a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 2{ cents lower with May at $1.45} a bushel; soybeans were 6 cents to 10\ cents lower with May at $5.90\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Cocoa-Trading Nations Agree To Finance Cocoa Pact Extension
DOC.TEXT: Cocoa-trading nations agreed Wednesday to finance a two-year extension of the cocoa pact that will delay the sale of stockpiled beans into the current glutted market. ``The finance is guaranteed,'' said West Germany's Peter Baron, who is chairing talks at the 41-nation International Cocoa Organization on the future of the current cocoa pact. Unless the producer-consumer treaty is extended for two years from October 1, the organization's 250,000-ton stockpile must be sold off within five years. This would have serious consequences for prices, which are already close to their lowest for 14 years, following five seasons of world overproduction. The two sides agreed earlier this week to back an extension of the agreement, but consuming nations said they wanted financing settled before giving their formal approval. Following a full meeting of producers and consumers Wednesday, Baron said that ``an overwhelming majority'' agreed that financing should be assured through either payment by producers of some of their debts, or limited sales from the stockpile during the two-year extension period. Unless producers pay some of their accumulated debts of more than $140 million, the cocoa organization expects to find itself $15 million short of the funds needed to finance a two-year extension. The bulk of the cash will be needed to finance the storage of the stockpile until Sept. 30, 1992. It was agreed Wednesday that if the organization came close to its financial limits it should be ``empowered to sell cocoa to bridge any gap,'' Baron said. There had been doubts about the producers' readiness to accept this, delegates said. The organization also agreed in principle that the levy of $30 a ton on internationally traded cocoa should cease April 15, Baron said. The failure of producers to pay the cocoa organization this levy charged on their exports is the cause of their debts. Consuming nations, which have been paying the levy on imports from non-cocoa-organization members, have long pressed for its cessation. Delegates said Wednesday they foresee no problems in a formal decision to extend the pact on Friday, the last scheduled day of the talks.

DOC.HEAD: Milken, Other Executives Take to the Classroom for a Day
DOC.TEXT: Former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond wizard Michael Milken taught math for a day at the 102nd Street Elementary School, then handed out calculators to grateful pupils. Arco Corp. President Robert E. Wycoff sat in the principal's office at Manual Arts High School to get a crash course on its students. A GTE Telephone Operations president settled in at Bethune Junior High School while a Toyota Motors USA's senior vice president went to North High School in Torrance. More than 40 executives in all participated Tuesday in a ``principal for a day'' program, designed in part to help corporate America determine what it can do to improve the nation's schools. The Los Angeles Educational Partnership, the program's sponsor, has raised $10 million since 1984 to fund projects by innovative teachers, a program to prevent students from dropping out and the introduction of new curriculums. ``There is a growing sense of frustration that the reform efforts haven't worked and that more radical steps are needed,'' said Virgil Roberts, the partnership's chairman. The group hopes to draw attention to the schools through its ``Educational Partnership Week'' activities. Nationwide, businesses have established more than 140,000 partnerships with public schools, according to the U.S. Department of Education. Milken, who set up his own investment management firm based in Los Angeles last year after leaving Drexel, has been involved in numerous charitable efforts, many involving education. Milken left Drexel last year after he was indicted on 98 counts of securities fraud and racketeering. He has pleaded innocent and is expected to go to trial in New York on new charges. Drexel is going out of business after its parent filed for bankruptcy protection. Arco's Wycoff said he was impressed by what he saw Tuesday at the inner-city Manual Arts High School _ especially by English teacher Jo Zarro's composition class. ``I like her, I like her enthusiasm. Is there any way you can reward her?'' Wycoff asked principal Marvin Starr. ``Only with praise,'' Starr said. Some educators said there are drawbacks to a corporate presence in the classroom. ``Self-interest is the primary motivation of most of those involved in school reform, and at times interests of a particular constituency are at odds with what is good for schoolchildren,'' said Lewis C. Solmon, dean of the Graduate School of Education at the University of California, Los Angeles. He said some firms are more interested in selling computers, textbooks and other material than in improving school performance. But Michael W. Kirst, an education professor at Stanford University, said businesses are in schools ``because they saw the work force quality was dropping.'' ``If they were happy with the quality of the public schools they would pull back from education and go on to such issues as housing, transportation or taxes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Import Dealers Say Iacocca Blames Problems on Consumers
DOC.TEXT: Import car dealers counterattacked Wednesday as Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca continued his road show to tout his company's cars as being just as good as Japan's. As Iacocca visited New York on his six-city tour in search of image and market share, the Washington-based American International Automobile Dealers Association accused him of blaming consumers for poor sales of U.S. cars. ``Lee Iacocca became famous for ending his commercials by saying `If you can find a better-built car, buy it.' Now he is complaining because the American consumers have taken his advice,'' said the group's president, Walter E. Huizenga. ``I was not aware they were outselling us, so that's a little off base,'' responded Chrysler spokesman Tom Jakobowski. Chrysler's 1989 domestic sales totaled 917,506 cars. Among the imports, Honda was closest at 389,472. Cars with Japanese nameplates made up 25.8 percent of the U.S. car market, up from 21.1 percent in 1982. The share held by the Big Three of Chrysler, General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. slipped from 69.8 percent to 67.5 percent during that period. In 1989, for the first time, the best-selling car had an import nameplate _ Honda Accord _ although 60 percent of Honda Accords are built in the United States. Chrysler has launched national television advertisements featuring Iacocca contending that Chrysler's quality was as good as Japan's. ``Nobody knows it, and that's going to change,'' he says in the commercials. Iacocca launched the current six-city tour earlier this month, traveling with an array of 1990 Chrysler models and executives to talk about the cars. In addition to touting Chrysler, Iacocca has been criticizing trade barriers that keep U.S. companies from competing in Japanese markets. ``What we sell in one year in Japan they sell in 46 hours here. This crap has got to stop,'' Iacocca said at Wednesday's New York news conference. The import association represents 9,700 dealers selling Japanese and other imported cars. Among other things, it lobbies for an end to the voluntary import restraints on Japanese automakers, spokesman Paul Donnellan said. ``The free market is an excellent barometer of relative automobile quality and the American consumer is an excellent judge of that quality. They know the quality of imported cars is better _ and they are better. No amount of complaining is going to change that,'' Huizenga said. The group said Japanese vehicles sold under Chrysler nameplates, such as the Dodge Colt and Ram 50 pickup truck, accounted for 7 percent of Chrysler's 1989 sales. It also said more than half the 400,000 Plymouth and Dodge minivans sold last year had Mitsubishi engines. Jakobowski said Chrysler wasn't bashing imports or telling Americans not to buy them. ``What we are saying is Chrysler builds as good a product or better,'' he said. ``What we are doing is speaking out to dispel the myth that U.S. cars are inferior.''

DOC.HEAD: Survey Indicates Biggest Cities Not In Recession
DOC.TEXT: Economic activity reached five-year highs during the fourth quarter in 18 of the nation's 24 biggest cities, according to a survey released Wednesday by the consulting firm Grant Thornton. The quarterly survey indicated that, based on an index measuring a number of indicators, San Diego led in economic activity during the final three months of 1989, followed by Minneapolis-St. Paul, Cincinnati, Atlanta and Milwaukee. Minneapolis-St. Paul, Milwaukee and Cincinnati had the greatest gains in economic activity over the final quarter of 1988, while Milwaukee, Los Angeles and Phoenix showed the greatest improvement from 1989's third quarter. Over the past five years, the oil-belt cities of Houston, Denver and Dallas showed the least improvement based on the index. However, all three cities were in the top 10 for improvement over fourth quarter 1988, while Denver and Houston still were at their peaks from the January 1985 base for the index. Boston, Phoenix and Cleveland showed overall declines in the economic indicators during 1989. On a third- to fourth-quarter basis, only Seattle showed a decline. The index compiled by Grant Thornton, an international accounting and management consulting firm, evaluates factory hours, employment, construction permits, retail sales, business starts and failures and money supply in 24 cities around the country. Of the 24 cities tracked by Grant Thornton, the six that did not reach a five-year peak in economic activity at the end of 1989 were Seattle, Cleveland, Phoenix, Boston, New York and Dallas. The survey found that a common thread among the fastest-growing metropolitan areas was job growth. Over the five-year period, San Diego added more than 165,000 jobs, a gain of 20 percent. The Minneapolis-St. Paul work force increased by more than 155,000, or 13 percent, and job growth in Cincinnati was more than 110,000, or 17 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Wang Names President as Chairman; Predicts Larger Loss
DOC.TEXT: Richard Miller, president of Wang Laboratories Inc., was named the company's new chairman and chief executive officer Wednesday, succeeding the computer maker's founder, An Wang, who died of cancer last weekend. The board of directors' action was expected by analysts, who noted that Miller already assumed much of the leadership last year when he was named president. ``(Miller) basically has the future of the company on his shoulders,'' said George Elling, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co. ``Now we have to see whether his strategy ... to re-establish the company can succeed. I think the jury is still out.'' Miller already has begun reorganizing the company to reverse recent losses, though he noted Wednesday that the current quarter's loss probably will be larger than originally expected. Also, while Miller last fall predicted the company could return to profitability by the end of its fiscal year on June 30, he said Wednesday that the company expects ``losses for the balance of the fiscal year.'' ``Industry conditions remain extremely difficult,'' Miller said in a statement, ``but we believe we have in place the programs necessary to complete the turnaround.'' Wang's class B shares closed at $5.37{ Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange, down 50 cents. Miller's appointment and comments about losses were made shortly before the market closed. Miller, a former General Electric Co. executive, became president last August after Wang's son, Frederick Wang, was forced from the job. Wang posted a $424.3 million loss for the year that ended last June 30. Wang became a leading computer company largely by making word processors. But analysts say the Lowell-based company stumbled when it failed to react quickly to the emergence of personal computers in the 1980s, which replaced much of the need for word processors. Wang then shifted its strategy to mid-size minicomputers, but that market has been slumping as the smaller desktop computers grow more powerful and are being connected in networks. ``The company has been floundering the past few years to find a strategy,'' Elling said. The projected deepening losses this quarter are not unexpected, he said, adding, ``The real issue is whether they can turn it around, if ever.'' The Wang family expressed support for Miller's strategies. ``We have complete confidence in Rick Miller and the long-term plan now being carried out to return Wang Laboratories to profitability,'' Frederick Wang said in a statement, speaking on behalf of his family. The family effectively has control over the company, with the power to elect three-quarters of the board of directors. Part of Miller's strategy has been to trim the company's costs and reduce its debt through layoffs and selling assets. At the same time, he has declared that the company will be more responsive to the needs of customers _ one of its shortfalls, according to analysts. ``Although additional restructuring will occur, we have already made significant progress,'' Miller said. Miller said the company is on target to reduce its bank debt to less than $93 million, down from $575 million. The company also has reduced operational expenses by over $300 million annually. Wang now employs about 22,500 people, compared with 28,000 at the end of the last fiscal year. Miller will continue serving as the company's president. The board also elected Lorraine C. Wang, wife of the late chairman, to the newly created position of honorary chairperson. Mrs. Wang was a founding director of the company.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower Except Against Yen; Gold Up Slightly
Precedes LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose sharply Wednesday against the Japanese yen despite reports of intervention by the Federal Reserve, but it fell against all other major currencies in light, trendless trading. Gold prices were slightly higher following a mixed performance overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $369 a troy ounce, up 30 cents from late Tuesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $369.35 an ounce, up 50 cents. Currency dealers attributed the dollar's decline against the European currencies, in part, to traders trying to cash in on the dollar's recent gains. But they said the market lacked a clear direction. ``There has been no fundamental forces to really drive it,'' said James T. McGroarty, a senior vice president at Greenwich Capital Markets Inc. in Greenwich, Conn. The end of Japan's fiscal year, however, has been raising the demand for dollars among Japanese corporate dealers to shore up accounts, he said. Japan's new fiscal year begins April 1. The Fed reportedly sold modest amounts of dollars for yen at around 159.10 yen, which helped dampen the dollar's advance, dealers said. But they said they expected the dollar to hold above 158 yen in the near term, barring further concerted intervention from central banks. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose for the ninth straight day, closing 1.67 yen higher at 158.63 yen. It also traded at 158.63 yen in London, and at 158.595 yen in New York, up from 157.635 yen Tuesday. The dollar was weaker against the British pound. Sterling rose to $1.6285 from $1.6255 in London, and to $1.6270 from $1.6260 in New York.
