Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.15 to close at $374.62 an ounce. Silver prices lost ground. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.917 a troy ounce, down from $4.954 late Tuesday. Silver fell in London to $4.95 an ounce from $4.98.

DOC.HEAD: Pension Funds, Other Big Investors Hold Balance in Lockheed Proxy War
DOC.TEXT: Daniel Tellep scolds Harold Simmons in full-page newspaper ads. Simmons chides Tellep in double-page ads. Their faceoff over who should control Lockheed Corp. will dominate the company's annual meeting Thursday. But there's plenty in common between Tellep, Lockheed's chairman, and Simmons, who paid $524 million for 19 percent of Lockheed's stock and who now wants Tellep and other board members voted out. Each has a big stake in the future of the aerospace giant. Each professes to find promise in that future, although their visions differ, with Simmons wanting to carve away far more of the company's non-core businesses. And each has been wooing the big pension funds and other institutions that hold 60 percent of the stock in Lockheed and could provide the margin of victory. Lockheed's stock, which traded as high as $54.75 during the third quarter of 1989, closed at $36.87{ a share on Wednesday. Simmons has shown a paper loss of $100 million on his investment. ``Obviously, I wouldn't have bought the shares we did at $48 or $49 if I'd known it was going to fall. I would have waited,'' said J. Landis Martin, Simmons' chief strategist. ``But we're very enthusiastic about the prospects for Lockheed and for its share price, particularly if we win.'' Martin predicted Lockheed employees, who own about 19 percent of the company's stock, would back Tellep by as much as 95 percent. That could effectively cancel Simmons' vote for his 19 percent stake, leaving the decision to the big investors, several of whom recently decided to back Simmons. The results of the battle to elect Simmons' slate of directors won't be known until at least next week, after proxy votes are totaled by a company in Delaware. The same goes for results of votes on shareholders rights proposals Simmons backs, such as elimination of Lockheed's takeover defenses. Simmons, Lockheed's largest shareholder, began his proxy battle after his request for six seats on the 15-person board of directors was rejected. Other big shareholders persuaded Simmons about 10 days ago to accept a compromise to give him three seats, but Tellep rejected that plan when the other shareholders brought it to him, Martin said Wednesday. In an interview Monday, Tellep described meeting with Simmons on Jan. 31. He said Simmons first demanded six seats and that Lockheed do away with its ``poison pill'' anti-takeover provision that makes it prohibitively expensive for a hostile buyer to acquire more than 20 percent of the company's stock. The failure of the compromise set the stage for a showdown at Thursday's annual meeting. Simmons is expected to attend the meeting, to be held in a hangar not far from the ``skunk works'' where Lockheed's SR-71 ``Blackbird'' spy plane and stealth fighter were born. The company began a major restructuring last year, promising to become leaner and more competitive in the face of shrinking defense budgets. It began selling about $200 million in non-core businesses. Lockheed also took nearly $500 million in charges related to cost overruns on fixed-price development programs, including one for a submarine-hunting plane. That helped depress earnings to $2 million, or 3 cents a share, from $624 million, or $10.37 a share, the previous year. Now, Tellep says Lockheed's ready for a turnaround. ``We did have a tough year last year, but I believe the plan that we put in place will begin to show results this year,'' he said. Simmons also talks about refocusing Lockheed on its core businesses of space, missiles and aeronautics. He has strongly suggested he will sell $1 billion in less lucrative operations from Lockheed's technology services and electronic systems divisions _ divestitures Tellep says are ill-advised at this time. Tellep and Simmons have battled in a series of newspaper ads aimed at Lockheed investors and workers. Simmons has said he will spend about $6 million in the proxy fight, Lockheed $8 million. Lockheed's ads portrayed Simmons as an opportunistic corporate raider seeking to control Lockheed primarily for his own gain. Simmons has countered by pressing his arguments that he could run Lockheed better. In one particularly caustic ad, Simmons provided his ``translation'' of statements from Lockheed's annual report. A sample: Lockheed: We characterize 1989 as a transitional year which prepared us for strong financial performance in 1990 and beyond. Simmons: 1989 was a bad year. L: Lockheed's sales increased slightly when adjusted for the completion of the C-5B program. S: Sales are down $541 million. But they're up if you count business we don't have anymore. L: Early this year, we agreed with the customer that work on future phases of this (C-17) program will be performed by another supplier. S: We got fired.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Finish Mixed
DOC.TEXT: An excess supply of crude oil in the nation's storage tanks dragged crude futures prices lower Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, while a decline in product inventories strengthened gasoline and heating oil prices. Trading in the energy markets was driven mainly by new statistics from the American Petroleum Institute showing a higher-than-expected increase in crude stocks and sharply lower supplies of refined products, including gasoline. ``The markets seemed to act just as the APIs would dictate,'' said Stefanie Rzasa, an energy broker for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The May contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main U.S. grade of crude oil, tumbled 40 cents to $20.08 a barrel after a 2-cent rise on Tuesday. Contracts for delivery through the summer months also fell, while later contracts posted small advances. Regular unleaded gasoline for April delivery rose 0.22 cent to 57.45 cents a gallon and May gained 0.44 cent to 64.56 cents. Contracts for delivery after June were mixed. No. 2 heating oil for delivery in April advanced 0.40 cents to finish at 55.73 cents a gallon, while later contracts posted losses. The latest statistics from API, the trade association representing major oil companies, showed gasoline stocks fell 5.8 million barrels in the week ended March 23 to 235.4 million barrels. Distillate fuel supplies dropped 2.2 million barrels to 103.6 million while crude oil inventories rose 7.5 million barrels to 358.6 million. Jim Steel, energy analyst for Refco Inc., said seasonal factors and the slowdown in refinery operations for annual maintenance in recent weeks were largely responsible for the buildup in crude supplies and the drop in refined products. During yearly maintenance, demand for crude oil by big oil companies declines while at the same time refineries make less gasoline, oil and other products.

DOC.HEAD: Sony Making Laser Discs in U.S., Giving Market a Boost
DOC.TEXT: The sluggish laser video disc market got a shot in the arm Wednesday with the announcement that a Sony Corp. division has begun making the movie discs in the United States. The new source of discs could ease a bottleneck that has slowed the growth of the technology, which provides higher-quality pictures and sound than videotaped movies. The discs are based on the same distortion-free digital technique as music compact discs. Digital Audio Disc Corp., an Indiana-based subsidiary of the Japanese electronics giant, said it had begun making the discs at a plant in Terre Haute. The major maker in the United States of video discs is Pioneer Electronic Corp. of Japan. Other makers include 3M Co. and a joint venture of NV Philips and DuPont Co. Laser discs require a separate player that is hooked up to a television. Several companies sell combination compact disc-laser disc players. But market growth for laser discs and their players has been constrained by lack of adequate disc supply, said Martin Greenwald, president of Image Entertainment Inc. of Chatsworth, Calif., a laser disc distributor. Image Entertainment, which licenses the laser disc rights to movies from major studios, has signed a multiyear contract to have Digital Audio Disc Corp. make its discs, Greenwald said. Terms were not disclosed. Image Entertainment also buys discs from other manufacturers, including Pioneer, Greenwald said. But these companies cannot keep up demand, and Image currently has a backlog of about 1 million discs on order. Greenwald said his company and the Pioneer disc division share about 90 percent of the market for distributing laser discs in the United States. Greenwald said the move by the Sony division into laser disc manufacturing ``is major stepping stone in the growth of laser.'' Most laser discs are bought by individuals for home use. The disc rental market is small _ about 10 percent of total discs sold _ and is not expected to grow substantially for several years until the number of laser disc players in homes increases greatly, said Greenwald and James M. Frische, president of Digital Audio Disc Corp. Currently, there are about 500,000 laser disc players in U.S. homes, Greenwald said. Industry projections show laser disc players should be in 5 percent to 10 percent of U.S. households by 1995, compared with a VCR penetration rate of about 85 percent by then, Greenwald said. But even at this smaller number, the market for the discs themselves should hit $1 billion a year by then, he said. With an increase in disc manufacturing, the cost of the discs should drop, Greenwald said. Currently, they retail for $25 to $40. Digital Audio Disc is the largest maker of compact discs in this country. Despite the immense growth and popularlity of CDs, Frische said he doesn't project the same boom for laser discs anytime soon. That's partly because they lack the ability to record TV programs and so are not a direct replacement for VCRs.

DOC.HEAD: Cocoa Futures Soar On Ivory Coast Unrest, Brazilian Logjam
DOC.TEXT: Cocoa futures prices rocketed to seven-month highs Wednesday amid fears that political and economic crises could disrupt exports from the Ivory Coast and Brazil, the world's two largest cocoa producers. Uncertainty about Brazil's changing economic policies also underpinned gains in futures prices of sugar and coffee. On other commodity markets Wednesday, soybean futures tumbled; copper futures surged; precious metals were mixed; petroleum futures were mixed; and livestock and meat futures advanced. Cocoa futures settled $39 to $47 higher on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange with the contract for delivery in May at $1,164 per ton, the highest settlement price of a near-month cocoa contract since Aug. 18. ``It was an explosive move, one of the biggest moves I've seen in a long, long time,'' said analyst Arthur Stevenson of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Civil unrest in the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer, has kept the market on edge for the past six weeks following the implementation of austerity measures aimed at saving the once-prosperous West African nation from bankruptcy. Many of the Ivory Coast's problems stem from last year's collapse of cocoa and coffee prices to their lowest levels in more than a decade. Fears of supply disruptions flared again Tuesday on reports of clashes between police and protesters whose illegal demonstrations paralyzed the capital city of Abidjan. The market was further supported by rumors that the Brazilian government had suspended all commodity exports while it untangles the snarls of red tape created by economic reforms announced nearly two weeks ago. After the markets closed, the Brazilian government announced that coffee and sugar exports were in effect suspended temporarily due to the abolition of two government agencies that had been responsible for authorizing coffee and sugar shipments. The government said cocoa exports were not affected by the cost-cutting measures but that cocoa shipments had been moving unusually slowly because of seasonal factors. In addition to the Brazilian situation, sugar futures were supported by expectations that the United States will replace its sugar import quota system with a tariff system that could result in higher U.S. imports of the sweetener, analysts said. Sugar futures settled .20 cent to .26 cent higher with May at 15.59 cents a pound; coffee futures rose .49 cent to .83 cent with May settling at 90.80 cents a pound. Soybean futures fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade amid heavy selling fueled by reports of ideal harvesting weather for the South American soybean crop and forecasts for beneficial rain in the Midwest and northern Great Plains, the main regions for U.S. soybean, corn and spring wheat production. Wheat futures settled 3 cents to 5 cents lower with May at $3.50 a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 3{ cents lower with May at $2.59\ a bushel; oats were 2\ cents to 3 cents lower with May at $1.45\ a bushel; soybeans were 9 cents to 11} cents lower with May at $5.88} a bushel. Copper futures prices soared on New York's Commodity Exchange, partly reflecting a resumption of Japanese buying in the physical market. Copper settled 1.9 cents to 4.25 cents higher with April at $1.205 a pound. The March contract expired quietly at $1.225. Gold futures finished nearly unchanged on the Comex amid continuing nervousness after Monday's price collapse. Prices of other precious metals continued to slide. Gold ended 10 cents lower to 60 cents higher with April at $369.10 a troy ounce; silver was 3.7 cents to 4.7 cents lower with March at $4.917 a troy ounce; platinum settled $3 to $3.70 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with April at $474.80 a troy ounce. In petroleum trading on the New York Merc, West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 40 cents lower to 12 cents higher with May at $20.08 a barrel; heating oil was .50 cent lower to .40 cent higher with April at 55.73 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .14 cent lower to .44 cent higher with April at 57.45 cents a gallon. Strong cash markets and bullish chart signals helped boost livestock and meat futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle settled .17 cent to .70 cent higher with April at 77.72 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .35 cent higher with March at 82.75 cents a pound; live hogs were .07 cent lower to .25 cent higher with April at 52.95 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .35 cent to 1.40 cent higher with May at 53.95 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Galvin Pleads Guilty in ``Ill Wind'' Case
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 2nd graf to give count of convictions, SUBS 5th graf to recast; INSERTS one graf after 13th pvs, `Mazlat deposited ...,' with background on Israelis. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A major figure in the Pentagon procurement scandal of the 1980s pleaded guilty Wednesday to bribing a former assistant Navy secretary to help an Israeli company obtain a contract. The guilty plea by defense consultant William M. Galvin, 59, to charges he bribed then-assistant Navy secretary Melvyn R. Paisley was a significant development in the ``Operation Ill Wind'' procurement fraud investigation that has netted 35 convictions. In addition, Galvin admitted participating in a scheme to bribe deputy assistant Air Force secretary Victor D. Cohen to help another defense firm obtain a radar-detection contract. Paisley, who left the Pentagon in April 1987 to go into business with Galvin, has not been charged. But Galvin's guilty plea signals that prosecutors are moving closer to charging Paisley, who has already been implicated in a separate bribery scheme. ``It's a major development in the case and we are rapidly moving against a number of the people named in the papers,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Joseph Aronica. Galvin, who pleaded guilty to conspiracy, bribery and tax evasion, could be sentenced up to 40 years in prison and fined up to $1 million. U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton scheduled sentencing for Aug. 3. Galvin agreed to repay $648,548 in back taxes and interest owed on money he did not report to the Internal Revenue Service. A year before Paisley resigned as assistant Navy secretary for research, engineering and systems, he agreed to help an Israeli company get a contract to sell ground equipment to operate remote-controlled aircraft, court papers said. Israel is a major manufacturer of the pilotless intelligence planes that carry cameras and other equipment to monitor enemy troop movements. The president of Mazlat, Ltd., the Israeli company, deposited $50,000 in a Swiss bank account set up by Galvin six days after Paisley signed a 1986 directive ordering the Navy to buy the ground-control equipment from Mazlat instead of another company. Galvin, Paisley, Mazlat president Zvi Schiller and Israeli defense consultant Uri Simhoni agreed to share equally the $2 million that Mazlat was to place in the Swiss account. The figure represented 2 percent of the value of the contact, court papers said. Mazlat deposited $268,000, according to the documents. Schiller is a retired Israeli army general and once served in his country's military mission to Washington. Simhoni, a retired Army major general, was once Israeli military attache in Washington, said Ruth Yaron, spokeswoman for the Israeli Embassy. Former Unisys Corp. executive Charles F. Gardner was sentenced last year to 32 months in prison for bribery for arranging the purchase of Paisley's resort condominium in Idaho for an inflated price. Paisley's attorney, E. Lawrence Barcella, said his client ``still maintains his innocence.'' Galvin also pleaded guilty to participating in a scheme with Loral Electronics Corp. executive Louis Oberndorf to bribe Cohen to help the Yonkers, N.Y.-based company obtain a contract to sell the Pentagon radar-warning devices. He admitted paying $123,100 in monthly payments between 1983 and 1987 to a friend of Cohen's, Kyle H. Woodbury, for consulting work. But Galvin understood some of the money would be used for Cohen's benefit, the court papers said. Galvin helped Cohen open a Swiss bank account in 1986, which Cohen concealed from the Internal Revenue Service and the Air Force, the court filings said. Neither Cohen, Woodbury nor Oberndorf has been charged. Loral pleaded guilty in December to charges that a subsidiary tried to influence Cohen improperly, paying $5.77 million in fines and civil penalties. Cohen's lawyer, Julian Greenspun, said prosecutors had no evidence that his client had participated in a bribery scheme with Galvin. ``I don't think the government can show that Kyle Woodbury ever improperly gave Vic Cohen a dime,'' said Greenspun. Greenspun said the only money Woodbury paid Cohen was to rent a house from his friend.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Confidence Improves Significantly For First Time In Five Months
DOC.TEXT: Consumers feel more optimistic about future business prospects than they did last month, but less positive about current business conditions, according to a survey released Wednesday. The Conference Board's monthly survey showed the most significant improvement in consumer confidence in five months. The business research group said its consumer confidence index for March is 110.2, a gain of 3.5 points from February. The monthly survey conducted by National Family Opinion Inc. covers 5,000 households in the United States. About 20 percent of respondents feel that current business conditions are ``bad,'' the survey found. That's an increase of 2 percent from last month. However, looking ahead six months, people were significantly more optimistic about job prospects and business conditions than they were in the first two months of the year. ``The substantial increase in the number of new jobs in recent months has contributed to the increasing sense of job security,'' said Fabian Linden, executive director of the board's Consumer Research Center. ``This development has also apparently made consumers feel more comfortable with the general business outlook.'' More people said they intend to buy a car, although fewer reported they planned to buy a home. ``This is most likely a reflection of the recent rise in mortgage rates,'' the survey concluded. Interest in buying major appliances also declined. The Conference Board is a New York-based business group.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Details Plans To Streamline Network; 6,000 To Lose Jobs
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. will eliminate scores of customer-support centers nationwide as part of a previously announced streamlining that will cut 6,000 jobs, company officials said Wednesday. The Communication Workers of America, which had been working with AT&T to eliminate jobs through early retirement rather than layoffs, criticized the plan and said employees were being treated unfairly. AT&T officials, however, said they had delayed announcing details of the streamlining as long as they could while negotiations continued. When talks with the union broke off Tuesday, the company decided to announce the changes, said AT&T spokeswoman Daisy Ottmann. ``These are jobs that are being eliminated because the work is no longer there,'' Ms. Ottmann said from the company's operations headquarters here. Under the plan, the number of centers will be reduced from about 160 in 60 metropolitan areas nationwide to about 100 centers in 30 areas, beginning as early as May, the company said. AT&T will reduce the number of centers providing direct support for business services from 57 to 28. Employees at the new customer service centers will provide specialized support according to customer and type of service rather than geographic area. In other changes, management of the AT&T long-distance network now handled regionally by 38 centers will be consolidated into six centers at two national locations in Denver and Conyers, Ga., a suburb of Atlanta. The changes are part of an $18 billion program begun in 1984 to modernize AT&T's network. The company said the changes are designed to improve customer service while reducing network operating costs. It was announced last fall that the streamlining effort would reduce about 6,000 jobs, but details of the plan were announced for the first time Tuesday. As AT&T increases the installation of new digital technology, there is less need for all its employees, said AT&T spokesman Burke Stinson. Until Tuesday, AT&T and the union were negotiating the number of employees that would have their pensions sweetened to entice them to retire early. CWA spokesman Steve Rosenthal said that the front-line employees were not being offered as attractive a package as managers were last year, when a special retirement plan prompted 12,500 to depart. Stinson said the company plans to reduce its work force by up to 12,000 employees this year. He said he did not know how many would be laid off because efforts to entice people to retire early were continuing, although no new talks with the union were scheduled.

DOC.HEAD: Blue Arrow Shareholders Approve Changing Name to Manpower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and 8th graf, `In the ...' to CORRECT that vote changed name to Manpower PLC sted Inc., shift to Inc. will occur later when company is reincorporated in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Blue Arrow PLC shareholders on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved changing the company's name to Manpower PLC, initiating a plan that will reincorporate the temporary employment giant in the United States. Blue Arrow Chief Executive Mitchell Fromstein said in a statement that 99 percent of the votes cast by shareholders were in favor of changing the name. ``There was a strong demonstration of support for the directions of the company,'' Fromstein said. The name change is part of the final chapter of an unsual takeover battle that began in 1987 when the British congolmerate bought the much larger Manpower, based in Milwaukee, in a $1.3 billion hostile takeover. Fromstein was president of Manpower and was retained in that position after the takeover. He sat on Blue Arrow's board of directors for about a year until he was fired because of what he termed ``a conflict in management philosophies'' with Antony Berry, then Blue Arrow's chief executive. But Blue Arrow's directors reviewed the dispute between Fromstein and Berry, fired Berry and named Fromstein as chief executive a month later. During the takeover, most U.S. investors in Manpower sold out to Blue Arrow. But since Fromstein took over Blue Arrow, U.S. investments in the British parent have risen to 75 percent of outstanding shares. In the next stage of Fromstein's plan, Blue Arrow is expected to reincorporate in the United States as Manpower Inc., divest itself of most of its remaining outside holdings and focus on Manpower's services, which comprise 80 percent of the British conglomerate's current operations. ``Ultimately it's anticipated that we will sell all of the non-Manpower operations so that effectively, it winds up being back what it was, back where it was, run by who it was _ two years later,'' Fromstein said last week. Manpower, which provides trained temporary employees to companies, employs about 1 million people a year. It operates 1,450 offices and has 300,000 customers worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Posts $257 Million Loss for 1989
DOC.TEXT: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable television system operator, reported Wednesday it lost $257 million last year, citing expenses linked to the financing of acquisitions. The net loss for the year that ended Dec. 31 was equal to 73 cents per share, compared with net earnings of $56 million, or 15 cents per share, in 1988, the company said in a news release. ``The decrease of $313 million was primarily due to decreased gain on sales of assets, increased interest expense incurred to finance certain acquisitions, the increase in depreciation and amortization resulting from those acquisitions, and TCI's increased pro rata share of losses of affiliates,'' TCI said in a news release. For the year, TCI said its revenue rose to $3 billion from $2.2 billion in 1988. Operating income was $569 million in 1989, up from $491 million in 1988. The increases were the result of a broadening of the subscriber base and theatre operations as well as the consolidation of United Cable Television Corp., which began last May, the company said. The TCI report also incorporated the full 12-month results of WestMarc Communications Inc., which it acquired a majority interest in last May. TCI and consolidated subsidiaries served about 7.8 million basic subscribers and 5.8 million pay television subscribers at year-end 1989. It also operated 2,659 theatre screens through United Artists Entertainment.

DOC.HEAD: Four Indicted in LA Penny Stock Scam
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury in Los Angeles has indicted four men on numerous fraud charges in an alleged penny stock manipulation scheme involving the securities of Magna Technologies Inc., officials said Wednesday. The 42-count indictment, handed up March 7 and unsealed Wednesday, charged Jacob Rubenstein, Dr. Robert Gutstein, Robert Victor and Herbert Stone with numerous counts of securities, wire and bank fraud as well as a single conspiracy count. In addition, Rubenstein, a promoter of Magna stock, was charged with failure to file a tax return and Victor, a Los Angeles-area businessman, faces a single tax fraud count. The indictment, announced jointly by the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington and Robert L. Brosio, U.S. attorney for the Central District of California, accused the four of a scheme plotting to manipulate the stock price of Magna, ``which was, in essence, a shell corporation'' located in Thousand Oaks, Calif. Gutstein was described in court papers as Magna's chairman and a large shareholder. Stone was a securities trader with Norbay Securities Inc. in New York, the primary market maker in Magna stock. Low-cost, high-risk penny stocks, which trade for less than $5 a share, are usually not listed on stock exchanges or the National Association of Securities Dealers' automated stock price-quote system. Investors often must rely on the few traders who handle the company's stock to quote the latest buy or sell price _ making the stocks prone to fraud and manipulation. The indictment stems from an earlier civil action brought by the SEC against Rubenstein, Gutstein, Stone and four others, most of whom settled with the SEC. SEC documents in Washington provided no other details. In another matter, the SEC announced Wednesday that a federal judge in Chicago ordered William A. Rooney Sr. to pay $28 million in alleged illegal profits from a pyramid, or Ponzi, scheme. In a Ponzi scheme, named for a notorious scam artist in the early part of this century, new investors are constantly recruited so that their money can be used to pay off earlier clients, in a pyramiding scheme that usually collapses as the money owed investors grows beyond the company's abilities to recruit new funds. Rooney was accused in an SEC complaint Jan. 2 of diverting the profits over a 17-year period from the sale of nine-month promissory notes for three companies he controlled. Last Thursday, U.S. District Judge John A. Nordberg granted an SEC request for default judgement against Rooney, including disgorgement of $12 million in alleged illegal profits and $16 million in interest. SEC documents in Washington provided no other details.

DOC.HEAD: Posts $78.6 Million Loss for 1989
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollars are U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Theatre giant Cineplex Odeon Corp. said Wednesday it posted a $78.6 million loss for 1989 amid a restructuring that began before the departure of chairman Garth Drabinsky in December. The theatre chain also said it has agreed to sell major interests in two related businesses for a total of $55 million, and reached agreements in principle with major bank creditors that will restrict its ability to make new investments. The company said it expects 1990 ``will be a difficult year from the point of view of profitability. This is consistent with the restructuring necessary to return the corporation to profitability and positive cash flows.'' Cineplex Odeon said its loss came on revenue of $644 million. In 1988, the company earned $40.9 million on nearly identical revenues. The 1989 loss came despite a sale of assets that resulted in a one-time gain of about $70 million. Last year, Cineplex sold its Live Theatre division to Drabinsky and his associate, Myron Gottlieb, after a lengthy battle for control of the parent company. It also sold a 50 percent interest in Universal Studios Florida. Cineplex said it has agreed to sell to British-based Rank Organization its remaining 51 per cent interest in Film House for $40 million and its residual interest in Universal Studios Florida for $15 million. Cineplex is one of the largest theatre chains in North America, with about 1,920 screens in 500 locations.

DOC.HEAD: Failed Thrift Sets 1989 Loss at $1 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Lincoln Savings & Loan Association, whose failure is expected to be the costliest in thrift history, said it lost $127.5 million in the fourth quarter, bringing its loss for 1989 to $1 billion. The S&L was seized last April by federal regulators. They have estimated it will cost taxpayers $2.5 billion to bail out the institution. Lincoln said its assets at year-end were $2.9 billion, down from $5.3 billion in 1988. Before it was seized, Lincoln was owned by American Continental Corp. of Phoenix, a firm controlled by land developer Charles Keating Jr. Keating has sued the government to get the thrift back, claiming the takeover was arbitrary and capricious. A hearing on the suit is continuing in U.S. District Court in Washington, D.C. Regulators have contented that Lincoln used complicated real estate, stock and junk bond transactions to book phony profits to bolster Keating's faltering real estate empire, which included heavy investments in Arizona.

DOC.HEAD: Partnership Says It Won't Bid for National Intergroup
DOC.TEXT: Centaur Partners said Wednesday it won't make a bid for National Intergroup Inc. and is only trying to protect its investment in the company by seeking seats on the board. ``The real issue here is corporate governance: majority rules,'' said Centaur, the largest shareholder in Pittsburgh-based National Intergroup with a 16.5 percent stake. New York-based Centaur wrote to National Intergroup Chairman Howard Love to respond to the company's letter to shareholders on Tuesday, which challenged Centaur to ``stop talking and make a firm cash offer.'' Love and NII President James Pasman also told shareholders the company would sell off its metals investments, including a 50 percent share in National Steel Corp., and concentrate on wholesale distribution, primarily of pharmaceuticals. In its letter, Centaur said National Intergroup's restructuring program is ``vague'' and does not say how it will deliver value to shareholders. Centaur is seeking to gain seats on National Intergroup's board, restructure the company and sell off assets. It has claimed it could receive $29.34 a share by breaking up National Intergroup. Love called that figure ``pure fantasy'' in his letter and advised shareholders to keep the existing board. Centaur said its figure of $29.34 a share is based on an independent analysis conducted by Paine-Webber Inc. and is $3 less than National Intergroup's book value. ``If you believe that our valuation range is overstated, then you have either overpaid for businesses (as many have asserted), or have run them down without reflecting this deterioration,'' Centaur's letter said. National Intergroup stock closed at $16.87{ Tuesday, down 37{ cents on the New York Stock Exchange. Centaur also criticized National Intergroup management and said the company has lost $450 million in six years. ``We believe it would be irresponsibe to continue to trust your leadership and your promises,'' the partnership said.

DOC.HEAD: US Sees World Bank Loans to China Limited
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 3 grafs after pvs 4th graf bgng ``We've made...'' to add comments from Export-Import bank chairman. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank which has been lending as much as $2 billion annually to China plans to restrict the aid to basic human needs assistance, a high Treasury official told Congress on Wednesday. ``We do not see at this stage a major resumption of non-BHN (basic human needs) lending in the immediate plans of the bank management,'' said Charles H. Dallara, assistant secretary of the Treasury for international affairs. Dallara said the Treasury had resisted pressure during the bank's recent closed-door meetings to increase lending. ``We've made very clear that in our sense a lending program should be one that is modest, moderately paced and limited in the foreseeable future strictly to basic human needs,'' he added, in testimony before the House Banking subcommittee on international development. Meanwhile, another U.S. economic expert argued that continued commercial ties with China can help stimulate reforms. ``The administration has searched for a balance between an adequate expression of moral disapproval and actions that reflect long-term U.S. interests,'' said John Macomber, chairman of the U.S. Export-Import Bank. Macomber said that his bank had financed three projects in China this year worth $72.8 million. In recent weeks the World Bank's 152 member governments have approved three loans worth $140 million to China for earthquake relief, aid to poor farmers and vocational education. The World Bank is the biggest source of aid to Third World countries and the United States makes the largest contribution, but does not have a veto over loans. Barber B. Conable, the bank's president, suspended consideration of $780 million worth of loans when Chinese tanks went into Tienanmen Square last June. However, he did not stop disbursement of loans already granted. Conable has said he wants $1 billion worth of new loans to China to go forward by June. But Dallara said that would cause concern among U.S. officials because the only way so large an amount could be loaned would be by going beyond basic human needs. Delegate Walter E. Fauntroy, D-DC, chairman of the subcommittee, warned that a proposed U.S. contribution of $3.18 billion might be in trouble with Congress if the bank resumed large scale lending to China. The contribution would go to the bank's International Development Association, which makes 40-year loans at a less than 1 percent annual interest rate to countries where the average citizen's income is no more $580 a year. China is one of them. For the three years beginning July 1 IDA is seeking about $15 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Pathe Profits Off 12 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Pathe Communications Corp., which has agreed to buy MGM-UA Communications Co. for $1.29 billion, said its profits fell 12 percent in the fourth quarter and reported a $32 million loss for the full year. Pathe, which produces and distributes entertainment worldwide and operates movie theaters in Europe, also said Wednesday its $20-a-share tender offer for MGM-UA is expected to be completed in April. The company already has made a $50 million deposit and has signed a distribution deal worth $75 million to MGM-UA, but has yet to announce how it intends to finance the buyout. ``Combining these two companies into a truly global organization will produce both substantial entertainment and meaningful financial results in the future,'' said Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian financier who is Pathe's president and chief executive. ``The future looks extremely promising.'' For the October-December quarter, Pathe earned $22 million, or 37 cents a share, compared with $25 million, or $2.12 a share, in the same period in 1988. Revenue fell 29 percent to $79 million from $111 million. Earnings per share declined more sharply than overall net because Pathe had an average of about 60 million shares outstanding in the fourth quarter, compared with 11 million a year earlier. For the year, Pathe's $32 million loss, the equivalent of $1.13 a share, compared with a profit of $21 million, or $1.57 a share, in 1988. Revenues fell 6 percent to $350 million from $371 million. Revenues from cinema operation rose 10 percent to $167 million, but movie distributing income fell 17 percent to $185 million, Pathe said. Yearly profits were depressed by $47 million in charges taken because of a lowered estimate of future revenues from the company's old film library and $14 million for films over 5 years old that were fully amortized in 1989, it said.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Doubles Aid Request for Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS Hamilton's state from N.Y. to Ind. in 10th graf: ``Rep. Lee; CORRECTS day from Thursday to Wednesday in last graf. Also on general wires.
DOC.TEXT: A House committee moved Wednesday to more than double President Bush's request for aid to emerging democracies in Eastern Europe to soften the shocks of changing from communism to a market economy. ``It would be a very serious mistake for us to conclude the survival of democracy in Eastern Europe is a done deal,'' said Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., who offered an amendment in the Foreign Affairs Committee boosting potential aid to the region to $719 million in the year that begins Oct. 1. The adopted the aid boost on a voice vote, adding it to an omnibus foreign affairs bill. At the same time, the House speeded progress of legislation Bush has sought to aid new democracies in Central America. The chamber was to consider a $2.4 billion money bill, which includes $420 million for Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua, on Thursday. The administration has agreed to pay for the Panama and Nicaragua aid by cutting a list of Pentagon projects and accounts totaling $1.8 billion. The new amount for Eastern Europe compares with $300 million the White House has sought for next year. The administration argues that the smaller amount would be as much as countries like Poland and Hungary, which have progressed far enough in their reforms to be eligible for U.S. help, can absorb immediately. Solarz, however, said his package of environmental cleanup aid, housing grants and loan guarantees, and private sector development assistance is needed to soften the ``cold turkey'' switch from centrally planned economies to market systems. East European countries will suffer severe shocks as they close down inefficient government-owned enterprises, throwing people out of work, and switch to private employment, he said. ``It could create a socially and politically explosive situation,'' he told the committee. ``We need to do more than we've done so far.'' Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., agreed. ``We have a unique opportunity to achieve goals we've sought for 40 or 50 years,'' he said. ``The stakes are enormous. The risk is that we won't be bold enough in meeting the challenge.'' Hamilton acknowledged there is a shortage of money for new programs, particularly in the area of foreign aid. But he added: ``The American people have been fired by the changes in Eastern Europe, and want to see freedom triumph ... We've simply got to find the resources to play the role of a world leader.'' Solarz's amendment was added to a catch-all foreign aid bill that includes implementing provisions needed to permit emergency short-term aid to new democratic governments in Panama and Nicaragua, as well as authorization for an additional $200 million to Nicaragua next year. The sums mentioned are spending ceilings. Congress must still appropriate the money, and may appropriate any amount up to the ceiling. It was approved on a voice vote after Republicans sarcastically feigned an effort to double Solarz's aid figure. ``We must act boldly and with great fanfare,'' intoned Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., before withdrawing his amendment. Republicans believe Democrats are using Eastern Europe as a political weapon, portraying Bush as weak by continually increasing aid beyond amounts the White House asks. A similar scenario last year led to a quadrupling of Bush's request. The fate of the bill remained unclear. The House committee planned to hold it over until next week pending the outcome of planned talks between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and lawmakers concerned about human rights issues in El Salvador. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, meanwhile, adopted a pared-down version Wednesday that largely tracked the administration's Panama-Nicaragua request and added no provisions on unrelated matters such as Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Drops, Stocks Gain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, dollar, comments
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply against the yen Thursday morning, triggering a modest rebound in share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange and a decline in bond yields. The dollar closed the morning session at 157.45 yen, down 1.18 yen from Wednesday's close. The dollar opened at 158.30 yen and ranged widely between 156.95 yen and 158.30 yen during the morning. Following the yen's rebound, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average regained 105.53 points, or 0.34 percent, ending the morning session at 31,369.10. The index shed 562.39 points Wednesday. The price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond rose to 86.48 points late in the morning from Wednesday's close at 86.14. The dropped the yield to 7.25 percent from 7.32 percent. The Nikkei index fell in early trading because of large-scale, index-linked selling, but it soon bounced back in reaction to the yen's rise against the dollar, said Tomoyuki Morimoto, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co. ``Recovery in bond prices also encouraged market players and prompted their buying,'' he said. ``But the market's purchasing power is still limited because of a lingering pessimism among participants.'' The dollar's decline was a continuation of a weaker trend that began in New York overnight. There, the dollar temporarily rose above 159 yen but turned downward and ended at 158.59 yen following intervention by the U.S. Federal Reserve. Fuji Bank dealer Kenzo Shinomiya said the dollar's weakness reflected selling by market players who sought to take profits after buying the dollar during its strong rise in recent weeks. ``But the dollar's recent uptrend is not over yet. Today's fall is only a temporary break in a continuing trend,'' he said. Traders said intervention by the Bank of Japan helped push the dollar down. The central bank was seen selling several million dollars Thursday in an attempt to support the yen. Meanwhile, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said he hopes exchange rates will come to reflect real economic conditions, Kyodo News Service reported. Kyodo also quoted Hashimoto as saying he intends to urge cooperation among the Group of Seven nations on currency stability at their meeting scheduled for April 7 in Paris.
